column2: DURHAM, N. C., March 27 -- The president of Duke University announced today that he would resign June 30 "to protect my family from severe and sometimes savage demands of such a career."
RALEIGH, N.C., March 27 -- Columbia University began its drive to retain its National Collegiate fencing championship today by advancing all three of its fencers into tomorrow's semi-final round.
Tony Roche lost his goodluck tennis shorts yesterday afternoon but won his quarter-final round match against Richard (Pancho) Gonzalez last night at Madison Square Garden.
ELMONT, L. I., March 27 (UPI) -- A 16-year-old student at Elmont Memorial High School was arrested today on a charge of making a false report of a bomb to the police.

THE Southwestern New England Championships, a sectional tournament, begin today at Holy Trinity Hall, 225 Scofield Avenue, Bridgeport, Conn. The schedule is: today, Men's Pairs and Women's Pairs, 2 P.M., Mixed Pairs, 8:15 P.M.; tomorrow, Open Pairs 2 P.M. and 8:15 P.M., Sunday.

A special City Council committee investigating poverty programs said yesterday that a Bronx beauty culture school had received $200,000 in city antipoverty funds, but had given no evidence that it trained anyone.

PIERRE BOULEZ conducted Haydn's Symphony No. 91 last night in Philharmonic Hall. Mr. Boulez is midway through his guest appearance with the New York Philharmonic, and he interrupted his survey of 20th-century masterpieces to take a look at Haydn.

In January, 1968, the New York-New Jersey Red Cross Blood Program joined with the Community Blood Council of Greater New York to form the Greater New York Blood Program creating a single voluntary blood program for the whole New York area.

CAIRO, March 27 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser said today in a speech that "the day will come" when Egyptian troops would bomb and shell Israeli civilians in retaliation for Israeli bombardment of civilian centers along the Suez Canal.

The local school board of District 2 has obtained a court order directing Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, Superintendent of Schools, to explain why he should not be prevented from transferring its district superintendent.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -The Nixon Administration is testing the temper of the nation's cities to try to determine the chances for renewed racial violence this year.

Richard C. Pistell, chairman of the General Host Corporation, said yesterday that the Greyhound Corporation had agreed to negotiate later this year the possible sale of Greyhound's holdings of stock of Armour Co. to General Host.

STEAMBOAT SPRINGS, Colo., March 27 (AP) -- The University of Denver ski team, seeking to regain the National Collegiate title it lost last year to Wyoming, gained the lead today in the slalom, opening event of the championships at the Mount Werner area.

Members of the Jewish community of German origin, including survivors of Hitler Germany, turned out yesterday to give a cordial welcome to West Germany's new Ambassador to the United States, Dr. Rolf Pauls.

Among the many inconsistencies provided by the Defense Department over the ABM is their insistence that this missile system is purely defensive and therefore not a threat to anyone. Almost in the same breath they point to the Soviet ABM system (now obsolete) and stress its threat to us.

ORANGE, N. J., March 27 (UPI) -- About 700 students walked out of two Orange schools today, apparently breaking agreements made with school officials Tuesday to return pending a hearing next week on their grievances.
The world's dean of professional photographers, who celebrated his 90th birthday yesterday, is preaching revolution at an age when most men practice prudence and conservatism.

LOS ANGELES, March 27 -- The defense in the trial of Sirhan B. Sirhan rested its case today and the prosecution prepared to call several psychologists and psychiatrists who are expected to have differing views of the defendant's mental condition.

CLEVELAND, March 27 (AP) -- Four Cleveland men were arrested today in a raid by Secret Service agents in which $500,000 in counterfeit $10 and $20 bills was confiscated. The men were charged with possession of counterfeit money.
PASADENA, Calif., March 27 (UPI) -- Saidallah Sirhan, 36 years old, brother of Sirhan B. Sirhan, was rushed to a hospital in serious condition tonight after he was struck by a car.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 27 -- On the stage, there were pants and above-the-knee skirts, chain belts and any number of current fashion fads. Beyond the stage, it was obvious that this was no ordinary fashion show.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 -- Private funeral services were held here today for Mrs. Prentis Cobb Hale, a prominent West Coast society leader, who according to the police, shot herself to death Tuesday night in the family mansion in the exclusive Pacific Heights district.

The European Concorde has so far created noise levels indicating it could not operate within noise limits already in force at major American airports. Doubts from within government on its viability for use here are distinct and growing.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Car theft is now a business operated by multimillion-dollar theft rings backed by organized crime, according to Michael J. Murphy, president of the National Automobile Theft Bureau and former police commissioner of New York.

The newest horticulturists at the New York Botanical Garden are 20 enthusiastic students who are tending the wooded grounds, tilling the rich garden plots and cultivating their own green thumbs under a state-sponsored program to help potential high school dropouts.
Columbia University yesterday named Wesley J. Hennessy dean of the School of Engineering and Applied Science.

Answering a recent call by James J. Bliss, executive vice president of the National Retail Merchants Association, for greater newspaper-retailer dialogue, the Florida Publishing Company of Jacksonville yesterday announced here just such a move by its two papers.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower was reported to be holding his own today against the heart condition that threatens his life.

ALBANY, March 27 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission, which is investigating reportedly poor performance in the passenger-train operations of the Penn Central railroad, said today that the railroad would be permitted to raise its fares by 10 per cent beginning April 1.

If Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea of Montauk would only give the word, New York's eight million people could be assured of better police protection. The lack of his imperial nod is the only obstacle to passage by the State Assembly of the bill granting this city greater flexibility in assigning policemen to the street during the night hours when muggers, rapists and other criminals are on the prowl.
LAGOS, Nigeria, March 27 -- Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, the Nigerian chief of state, told Prime Minister Wilson of Britain today that Nigeria would brook no interference in her affairs.
The Federal Reserve System maintained its restrictive credit policy during the last two weeks, monetary data published yesterday showed.
Peace -- it's wonderful."
WILMINGTON, Calif., March 17 (UPI) -- Explosions and a fire in an oil refinery killed one man and injured at least 41 other persons tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A Senate report issued today warns that the money problem of America's older people is worsening each year and that Social Security and other forms of retirement income are not keeping pace with the times.

CAIRO, Ill., March 27 (AP) -- Spokesmen said today that a clergymen's group had been assured by the state's attorney that action would be taken to protect the safety of a controversial Roman Catholic priest working with Cairo Negroes.
Prices on the London stock market closed narrowly irregular yesterday after profit taking had reduced earlier gains. Advances outnumbered losses at the close, however.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers declared today that the United States was prepared to withdraw its forces from South Vietnam "over a very short period of time" if North Vietnam would agree to simultaneous withdrawal.

TRENTON, March 27 -- State Attorney General Arthur J. Sills withdrew tonight as a potential candidate for the Democratic nomination for New Jersey Governor after he reportedly failed to win the support of the powerful Hudson County Democratic organization.

MONTREAL, March 27 -- The Quebec Government has asked federal authorities for troops and Royal Canadian Mounted Police constables on the eve of a demonstration in support of a demand that McGill University be converted into a French-language institution.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen, accusing Federal officials of harassing businessmen over job discrimination, threatened today to "go to the highest authority in this Government and get somebody fired."
LONDON, March 27 (AP) -Two Beatles disagree on whether they will perform in public again. Ringo Starr says no, John Lennon says yes.

Hugh M. Smythe, a former Brooklyn College professor who is now Ambassador to Malta, has been officially recommended as the first president of the City University's experimental Bedford-Stuyvesant College.

PITTSBURGH, March 27 -- I. W. Abel, president of the United Steelworkers, said today the 1.2-million-member union was opposed to conglomerate mergers, and that some steel concerns already had been hurt by take-overs.

AT 8:40 P.M. as Patrolmen Christopher Dowdell and Richard Younger were cruising their 15-square-block sector of the 24th precinct -- an area spreading out from 107th Street and Amsterdam Avenue -- a call came in on their radio: "Disorderly man with a knife at 308 West 94th Street, any available car."
David S. Kahl, vice president for engineering, and Richard E. Muller, vice president, works manager, Sperry Rand Corporation's Sperry Gyroscope division.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 -- On scattered fronts today, Manager Gil Hodges of the New York Mets applied a tacit little spur to Ed Kranepool, Ron Swoboda and Tommy Agee by beginning his Cleon Jones-at-first base experiment -- all on account of Rodney Earl Gaspar.

Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, announced yesterday that a privately established, privately financed Board of Mediation for Community Disputes would begin operations here next Jan. 1 to help resolve controversies outside the labor management field.
PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- The Penn Central Company's plan to add a nonstop train to its experimental New York-to-Washington Metroliner service drew a bitter reaction in Philadelphia today.
A selected list of the nation's leading chain and catalogue retailers chalked up sales of $3,745,841,000 in February, a gain of 12.5 per cent over sales in the corresponding 1968 month.

Parents of the Harlem community and staff members of the Museum of Modern Art calmly appraised yesterday the new Children's Art Carnival at the Harlem School of Arts, but 13 five-year-olds passed judgment on it with whoops and squeals.

Federal Judge Dudley B. Bonsal refused yesterday to issue an order that would have reopened "Che," an Off Broadway play, pending an attack on the constitutionality of the state's obscenity laws. Argument was set for Tuesday in Federal Court.

ALBANY, March 27 -- The state is preparing to build a $42-million municipal hospital in the Bronx at a time when the city says it does not have enough money to run the 20 municipal hospitals it already has.

LOS ANGELES, March 28 -- A prominent psychiatrist, appearing for the prosecution in the trial of Sirhan B. Sirhan, said today the killing of Senator Robert F. Kennedy had been "motivated by political reasons" and was not the action of a psychotic.

LAGOS, Nigeria, March 28 -- Prime Minister Wilson of Britain met for two and a half hours this morning with Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, the Nigerian chief of state. He then flew to Enugu in Eastern Nigeria for a brief visit.
Four national Jewish organizations and the New York Board of Rabbis urged Governor Rockefeller and legislative leaders yesterday to meet the budgetary needs of the City University.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Administration has made a drastic cutback that will eliminate, starting in July, more than half of the controversial Job Corps' youth training programs, a major Congressional supporter of the corps charged today.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- The Pentagon's former research chief called on Congress today to halt the growth of the United States military machine before it becomes "a Frankenstein monster that could destroy us."

The artificial kidney machine has been saving people with kidney disease since 1958. Two or three treatments a week and a victim could live a normal life.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright charged today that the Nixon Administration had made "no serious scientific review" of the antiballistic missile program and that its Safeguard system was "purely a political gimmick." "The Defense Department doesn't take this committee of the Congress seriously," the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee protested.
Iron Ruler of the October House Farm is the 2-1 favorite in the Westchester, the mile race that will serve as the feature attraction at Aqueduct today.

Peter Rehak of The Associated Press was named the winner yesterday of the 1969 George Polk Memorial Award of the Overseas Press Club of America as well as the club's award for "best daily newspaper or wire service reporting from abroad" during 1968.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -The infrared microscope, which enables scientists to study such things as the heat-seeking characteristics of night-flying moths, has now been equipped to take pictures.
The Conservative Party endorsed State Senator John J. Marchi as its candidate for Mayor at a long and acrimonious meeting ending early this morning.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 28 -- American records were smashed in five of the six finals tonight in the 46th annual National Collegiate swimming championships. But the race without a record -- the 100-yard backstroke -- proved the most exciting as Fred Haywood of Stanford beat Charles Hickcox of Indiana by two-hundredths of a second.

The Vietnam peace-hope rally boomed along yesterday for its third straight gain as trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 12.43 million shares -- the highest turnover in nearly five weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Following is the text of the announcement of the death of former President Eisenhower read at Walter Reed General Hospital by Brig. Gen. Frederic J. Hughes Jr., commanding general of the hospital:

MILITARY leadership of the victorious Allied forces in Western Europe during World War II invested Dwight David Eisenhower with an immense popularity, almost amounting to devotion, that twice elected him President of the United States.

Elmer W. Engstrom, a former president of the Radio Corporation of America, will bid farewell as an active executive of the company at the annual meeting, to be held in Felt Forum at Madison Square Garden on May 6.

The Aluminum Company of America, the Reynolds Metals Company and the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said yesterday that they would make selective price increases on fabricated aluminum products.

YONKERS -- For nearly a month now, Mrs. Sydney B. Klein has been keeping busy cleaning her rambling, three-story frame house from attic to cellar. She has a deadline -- next Wednesday at sundown, when the eight-day Jewish holiday of Passover begins.

DWIGHT D. EISENHOWER was born in an age when personal generalship at high command was a thing of the past. He could not command from horseback, as Napoleon did, nor could he plan in a tent, like Ulysses S. Grant and Robert E. Lee.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 28 (Reuters) -- An earthquake struck western Turkey about 4 A.M. today, killing at least 53 persons near Alasehir and injuring 350. Two thousand houses were reported to have collapsed.

As an undergraduate and graduate student I had the unique opportunity to attend college against the background of the Vietnam war. Like many students, most of the material I read and many of the professors I spoke with criticized United States involvement in Southeast Asia.

Haven Industries, Inc., which recently won control of the National Sugar Refining Company, announced yesterday that it had acquired about 6 per cent of the stock of the Warner Company, a producer and distributor of building materials.

MIAMI, March 28 (AP) -- Florida Memorial College ordered an indefinite suspension of classes today, saying that unrest brought on by housing shortages on a new campus was endangering its academic program.
The interests of the four American Cardinals-designate reflect the pastoral, ecumenical and social priorities of the Roman Catholic Church as a whole in the wake of the 1962-65 Ecumenical Council.

BRUSSELS, March 28 -- President Nixon's decision to proceed with a limited Safeguard antiballistic missile program and Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird's estimates of the future vulnerability of some American weapons have quickened interest in greater independence for Europe in the manufacture of its own conventional and perhaps, eventually, nuclear weapons.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A three-day state funeral will be held for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in the nation's capital.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 28 -The Chinese Nationalist regime here views with considerable satisfaction the disarray that marks Communist ranks around the world.

LONDON, March 28 (UPI) -- The United States Federal Maritime Commission and its "regulatory antics" in trying to extend its jurisdiction to foreign shipping came under fire today from the top spokesman of the British shipping industry.
The once simple International Code of Signals of the old "Able, Baker, Charlie" days has been revised for the second time since World War II.

MIAMI, March 28 -- Bob Murphy, golf's 1968 rookie of the year, jogged around the course last Tuesday preparing for the $200,000 National Airlines open tournament. This afternoon the 26-year-old red-haired professional ran in eight birdie putts for a 66 and took the 36-hole lead by one stroke at 135.

NOW that it's chic to be Greek, it's no surprise that the beauty houses are catching on to the idea. Helena Rubinstein has chosen the island of Mykonos rather than the suddenly famous Skorpios as inspiration for its new make-up, but the idea is the same.
The rising demand for more and better health care in the United States will soon draw large numbers of women into the medical work force, a Federal labor statistician said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) -- The family of Dwight D. Eisenhower has asked that persons wishing to remember the former President make charitable contributions rather than send flowers.
BOSTON, March 28 -- Sam Jones was ejected early in the first quarter tonight and Bill Russell had one of his poorest playoff games, yet the Celtics crushed the Philadelphia 76ers anyway, 134-103.

The City Center for Drama and Music, which got its start late in 1943 with the help of the mercurial Mayor La Guardia, has celebrated its first quarter-century with due ceremonial and has now plunged into its second quarter-century as if it believed passionately in Robert Browning 's advice, "Grow old along with me, the best is yet to be."

DWIGHT D. EISENHOWER was born in Denison, Tex., on Oct. 14, 1890. He was of German descent. His ancestors belonged to evangelical groups from which evolved the Mennonite sect. Subjected to religious persecution, some of the family had emigrated from Bavaria to Switzerland in the 17th century.

A graceful, 84-year-old Southern magnolia tree, believed by horticulturists to be the largest and oldest north of Baltimore, is in danger of ending its existence in a Bedford-Stuyvesant front yard. A new housing project is rising in the area, and wreckers are just three doors away.
SYRACUSE, March 28 -- Dr. John E. Corbally Jr. was elected chancellor and president of Syracuse University today to succeed Dr. William P. Tolley, who has served in the post for 27 years, on Sept. 1.

GARY, Ind., March 28 (UPI) Mayor Richard G. Hatcher, one of the first Negroes to become mayor of a major American city, sought today face-to-face meetings with residents of a predominantly white neighborhood who want to pull out of Gary.

TEL AVIV, March 28 -- Israeli defense and security authorities believe that air strikes across the cease-fire line are proving highly effective. They indicate that the raids will continue while being modified.

ALBANY, March 28 -- The Assembly passed a bill today increasing the penalty for persons convicted of selling pornography to minors. The bill raises th.e penalty from the current one year maximum in jail to four years and increases the fine.

President Nixon's statement at his March 4 news report that he had under consideration the appointment of an envoy to the Vatican reinforces my view that he will not unite the American people. For while we held our hands out to him on Inauguration Day, he disclosed by his use of men of the cloth that he was looking forward to re-election even before he took his oath of office.
All stocks and commodities exchanges will be closed Monday, a national day of mourning for former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, who died yesterday.

HAVANA -- At the Hotel Habana Libre, canned prerevolutionary music washes over eccentric English tourists , foreign delegates and advisers, harassed reporters, forever leaving the airport for a glimpse of a hijacking, and uniformed girls of the militia, wearing large curlers.
Sadness was in the faces yesterday of the generations that knew him as the general and the President, but there was no anguish, no deep shock.

A Federal judge, in Brooklyn District Court disclosed yesterday that $29-million had been paid to the next of kin of 127 passengers and crew members killed Dec. 16, 1960, in a collision over Staten Island between a United States DC-8 jet airliner and a Trans World Airlines propeller plane.

Since 1875, when John McCloskey became the first American Cardinal, the Archbishop of New York has traditionally received the red hat which symbolizes the Roman Catholic Church's highest honor. Archbishop Terence Cooke's elevation yesterday by Pope Paul VI reflected that tradition -- a fact the new Cardinal acknowledged when he said, "I am aware that this appointment belongs to the people of New York more than to me personally."

TORONTO, March 28 -- A Canadian specialist on foreign affairs advised his country today to withdraw and progressively disband its North Atlantic Treaty Organization military units but remain in the alliance, give more economic aid to poor countries and make a special effort to bring Communist China and the rest of the world closer together.
ROME, March 29 -- Pope Paul VI nominated 33 Cardinals today, including four from the United States, to bring the membership of the College of Cardinals to 134, the largest ever.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28 -- With one week left in Florida, the New York Mets are rapidly approaching the final shakedown for their eighth National League campaign. Today, they lost to the Houston Astros, 5-4, in the unfamiliar warmth of actual sunshine.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was a much honored man. He held more than 50 military decorations that had been awarded by nations around the world, more than 20 honorary degrees from universities here and abroad and a wide assortment of civic and municipal honors.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Following is the text of a proclamation by President Nixon announcing the death of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower:

FORMER President Dwight D. Eisenhower had a zest for recreations that could take his mind off serious military and political matters. His passion for golf was well known, but he was equally enthusiastic about bridge.

MOSCOW, March 28 (Reuters) -- The Communist party paper, Pravda, said today that Chinese troops were building up military fortifications on their side of the border at the Ussuri River, the scene of recent Chinese-Soviet clashes.

The restraint in the growth of money and credit that developed in the last three months may have gone on long enough, a leading central banker cautioned yesterday. This warning flag was raised by W. Braddock Hickman, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland and a critic of the "inappropriately easy" monetary policy during the second half of 1968.
MOSCOW, March 28 -- A Rumanian delegation refused today to sign Soviet-backed resolutions that attacked West Germany, Israel and the United States.

MRS. TRUMAN HANDY, who smiles easily, and often has a bit of mischief in her eyes, sat recently in her place of business at 146 East 55th Street in a room whose pine walls came from London and whose Versailles parquet floor started out in France, and looked back with pride and amusement upon 50 years of interior decorating.

Television and radio were prepared for yesterday's announcement of the death of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower and immediately put into effect plans for extensive coverage of the funeral services and events leading to his interment Wednesday in Abilene, Kan.
JERUSALEM, March 28 -Hundreds of Arab mourners fought with Israeli security forces today in a brief but violent clash at the historic Damascus Gate of Jerusalem's walled Old City.

ANGUILLA, March 28 -- Lord Caradon, British delegate at the United Nations, arrived here today to try to arrange at least a temporary peace between Britain and this small Caribbean island of 6,000 people.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 28 -- Britain and France said in the Security Council today that the "highly dangerous" and "deteriorating" situation in the Middle East required a prompt peace initiative by the major powers.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., March 28 -- About half the student body of Port Chester High School -- both black and white -- boycotted classes today to protest a Board of Education decision to limit a three-day student tribute to the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to one day.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) -- Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin proposed today legislation to regulate the credit life and disability insurance industry, which he said overcharges the public by $220-million a year.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Former Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today that the Nixon Administration's plans to cool off the economy would put thousands of Americans out of work and doom equal employment chances for Negroes.
Two commodities, one international and one domestic, had a busy day on the downside yesterday, namely world sugar and live beef cattle.
MADRID, March 28 -- Marking the 30th anniversary of the end of the civil war, the Spanish Government tonight canceled all criminal responsibility for any acts committed during the war.

Playing in the friendly confines of Madison Square Garden, where they won 30 of 37 regular-season games, the New York Knickerbockers expect partisan vocal support from a capacity a crowd of 19500 fans this afternoon as they resume their National Basketball Association semi-final round series with the Eastern Division's leading team, the Baltimore Bullets.

The Times in a March 10 editorial "Professionalism vs. Blight" said that a variance issued by the Board of Standards and Appeals for the development of our building opposite Lincoln Center could undermine the Lincoln Square special zoning district now under study.
PORTLAND, Ore., March 28 (AP) -- Fifteen plywood mills were shut down at the end of work today as prices skidded from recent records.
RALEIGH, N. C., March 28 -- The University of Pennsylvania combined strength in all three weapons today and virtually clinched its second National Collegiate fencing championship.

NEWARK, March 28 -- The two public utilities that own Sunfish Pond and Kittatinny Ridge overlooking the Delaware River offered today to return the little glacial lake to the state without cost.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) -- President Nixon has set down a policy for invoking the doctrine of "Executive privilege" -- withholding information from Congress -- that at least equals his two predecessors in its restrictiveness.

VINELAND, N. J., March 28 -- Some 1,500 Puerto Ricans from this city, supported by Puerto Ricans from at least nine other New Jersey municipalities and New York City, participated in a peaceful demonstration march here today to protest slum housing and discrimination in jobs, and to demand representation on various city boards.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- "To mold, to balance and to integrate" the forces contending, designedly or inherently, to undermine "the principles of our democratic system" -- this was the lifetime mission of Dwight D. Eisenhower as he saw and practiced it.
ATHENS, March 28 -- The Greek poet George Seferis, holder of the 1963 Nobel prize for literature, called today for an early end to Greece's "dictatorship."

BOSTON, March 28 (UPI) -- Archbishop Iakovos, primate of the Greek Archdiocese of North and South America, said today Mrs. Aristotle S. Onassis, "may decide" to leave her Roman Catholic religion and join the Greek Orthodox Church.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Mamie Doud Eisenhower was at her husband's bedside as he sank into a peaceful death shortly after noon on this fair day. It was the end of her vigil through 10 anxious months.
AINTREE, England, March 28 -- There is a race course in this town, a grim suburb of blackened Liverpool, and it is a very famous race course.

BONN, March 28 -- The West German Government has cut off the nation's largest general student organization, the German National Union of Students, from all federal funds. In another action, state government executives have agreed to expel campus activist for as mcuh as three years.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Justice Department threw its weight today behind the efforts of a group of Chicago Negroes seeking to make "blockbusting" real estate speculators pay back high profits they have made from Negro home purchasers.

PASADENA, Calif., March 28 (UPI) -- The Mariner 7 spacecraft performed smoothly today on its lengthy journey toward the planet Mars, but scientists were still puzzled by three irregularities that turned up shortly after the launching.

The New York City Opera debut of Karen Armstrong of the Metropolitan Opera has been scheduled for the week of performances beginning April 6. The soprano will appear as Queen of Shemakha in Rimsky-Korsakov's "Le Coq d'Or" on April 9.
The New York Telephone Company yesterday reported a decline in net income for 1968 despite an increase of 6 per cent in operating revenues.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 28 -- Tonight's the night when Billy Haughton, harness racing's top-winning reinsman, and Nardin's Byrd, one of the leading horses in one of the nation's top stables, make their first starts of the year in this area.
POINTED toes are coming back (or have they ever been away), but the shoe industry is reacting like an ostrich with its head in the sand that has just been jolted from the rear.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) -- A Pulitizer Prize-winning reporter told Senate investigators today of a reform school where "bully boys" beat younger offenders and forced them into acts of sodomy.

The National Basketball Association has reportedly landed Lew Alcindor. The Milwaukee Bucks won the battle for the University of California, Los Angeles, giant and were believed to have offered him a five-year pact that could reach $1.4-million in salary, bonus and other benefits.
The eighth annual Botticelli Ball will be held April 18 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom. The guests will pay $45 each, and the proceeds will assist Orphans of Italy.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird ordered today a high-level Pentagon review of Army plans to eliminate references to God and religious philosophy in character guidance courses that are given to soldiers.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- It appears that at least three of the five Southern school districts that won extra time from the Nixon Administration to meet Federal desegregation requirements will let their time run out and forfeit Federal funds.

LINDEN, N. J., March 28 -- Melvin Morgulis of New York City, a photographer for the American Civil Liberties Union, was sentenced last night to 30 days in Union County Jail on charges of disturbing an assembly and using profane language in a public place.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -South Vietnam has, in the words of one Asian diplomat, "put out the bait" for the National Liberation Front in the Vietnam negotiations.

Wearing red mod ties and equipped with ballet dancers and a piano soloist, the American Symphony Orchestra presented its third in a series of eight Teen-age Concerts yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

THE American sculptor David Smith, who died in 1965 at the age of 59, was one of the great artists of this century. The African Jazz-Art Society and Studios will present tonight a cultural program entitled "Africa on Our Minds" at Rockland Palace, Eighth Avenue and 155th Street.

FT. LEWIS, Wash., March 28 (UPI) -An Army court-martial board today handed down sentences of from nine months to six years for four soldiers convicted of mutiny in connection with a sit-down strike last October at the Presidio stockade in San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Federal Communications Commission said today that it had no authority to judge or act on the broadcast in December and January of anti-Semitic material on radio station WBAT-FM in New York The controversial statements on the "Julius Lester Program," it said, are protected by the guarantee of free speech in the First Amendment of the Constitution.
Representative John M. Murphy, campaigning for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, yesterday toured what he called "pornography alley" on West 42d Street.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 28 (UPI) -- Gen. Aga Mohammad Yahya Khan, the leader of Pakistan's new military Government, has authorized local military commanders to make their own laws when dealing with disturbances or other problems, the Pakistan Radio announced today.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 28 -- Edward St. John, a backbencher in the Federal Parliament, resigned tonight as an endorsed Liberal party candidate because of his opposition to Prime Minister John Gorton and announced that he would sit as an independent.

William F. Lucas has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, Louisville, Ky. W. L. Lyons Brown Sr. has been elected chairman of the board, a post he had relinquished in 1966.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The White House indicated today that President Nixon would replace Clifford L. Alexander Jr. as chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

PARIS, March 28 -- Analysis by allied experts of the proceedings at yesterday's plenary session of the Vietnam talks here has confirmed their impression that the stand of the North Vietnamese and Vietcong on the subject of secret negotiations was less rigid than it might have been.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 28 -- United States armor and aircraft beat back a North Vietnamese ambush of a United States Army convoy today 45 miles northwest of Saigon. It was the second ambush of a convoy in the area in four days.

Passenger liners of United States registry operating out of East Coast and Gulf ports will keep on sailing even if next week's labor negotiations break down. The four seagoing unions and employer groups are scheduled to start joint talks Wednesday. The present contracts expire June 15.

PROVO, Utah, March 28 (AP) -- Iowa State whipped through the semi-final round of the National Collegiate Wrestling championships tonight, carrying four men into the championships along with a seemingly insurmountable lead.

UPON leaving the White House, Dwight D. Eisenhower went to live on his farm at Gettysburg, Pa., the first real home he had had since entering the Army in 1915. He had bought the farm in 1950 for $23,000. He liked the quiet, rolling Pennsylvania countryside and the opportunities that his new leisure afforded him to golf at the nearby Gettysburg Country Club and to paint in oils.

THE veteran master Alex Kevitz is making a gallant run for first place in the current Manhattan Chess Club championship. A title for Kevitz at the end of this year's event will keep unblemished a remarkable feat -- a record of having won the Manhattan title at least once in every decade, starting in 1926.

PASADENA, Calif., March 30 (UPI) -- The "perfectly operating'' Mariner 7 spacecraft will be left to guide itself on its journey to Mars until April 7 when engineers will slightly alter its course, a Jet Propulsion Laboratory spokesman said today.

DETROIT, March 30 -- A Detroit policeman was shot dead last night during a gun battle that started on a street and ended in a church in the heart of the black ghetto devastated by rioting in 1967. There were no signs of renewed trouble today.

Chevrolet will offer a new model tentatively called the Monte Carlo. This two-door hardtop is related to the 1969 Pontiac Grand Prix. But where Pontiac emphasized an extremely long hood and pointed nose, Chevrolet uses its traditional grid-pattern grille for its new car, and single, unconcealed headlights. This will hold down the cost and the price.
The New York Greek-Americans routed Hellenic, 3-0, at Eintracht Oval in Queens yesterday and will represent New York in the United States Challenge Cup soccer matches.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., March 31 (UPI) -- Bail of $250,000 -- reported to be the largest amount ever set by a Nassau County judge -- was posted today by the father of Jay Pobliner, who is accused of killing his wife last Dec. 27.

TOKYO, March 31 -- American military bases on Okinawa should be placed under the same restrictions as American bases in Japan, once the Ryukyu Islands revert to Japanese administration, in the view of former Foreign Minister Takeo Miki.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 31 Reuters) -- Asian holders of British passports clamored for entry permits to Britain here today with only hours to go before a Government deadline under which many Asian businesses must close.
PITTSBURGH, March 31 (UPI) -- George (Red) Sullivan was dismissed today as coach of the Pittsburgh Penguins of the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The funeral service for former President Dwight D. Eisenhower today forged elements from the Episcopal and Presbyterian traditions into a broadly ecumenical liturgy that focused on the fundamental Chritian theme of hope in the midst of sorrow and struggle.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 31 -- A master plan for the development of land owned by Nassau County at Mitchel Field was made public today.

The city's capital budget for the fiscal year beginning next July 1 stood at $1,130,273,512 yesterday as Mayor Lindsay, for the first time in his three years in office, did not veto any changes made by the Board of Estimate and City Council.

DETROIT, March 31 -- At 5:30 Sunday morning the judge marched into police headquarters in downtown Detroit and asked for a list of the 147 Negroes arrested hours earlier after a gun battle with black separatists in which one patrolman was killed.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Dwight David Eisenhower, 34th President of the United States, started on his last journey to his boyhood home today. The funeral train bearing his flag-draped coffin was sent off with a 21-gun Presidential salute.
CLARION, Pa., March 31 (AP) -- One end of an old highway bridge spanning the Clarion River collapsed today, taking with it the trailer of a big truck loaded with steel.

The changes in the Medicaid program voted by the Legislature will remove up to 85,000 people from the program who may end up on relief, Mitchell I. Ginsberg, the city's Human Resources Administrator, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Nixon conferred privately today with President de Gaulle, and later with three key advisers on Vietnam, including his principal peace negotiator, Henry Cabot Lodge. Having canceled all official appointments for the Eisenhower funeral, the President found himself with plenty of free time.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 31 -- Al Downing and nine other players were cut by the Yankees today, leaving the squad only one over the 25-man limit.
Etas Kompass, an expanding Italian publishing company, and Harper Row, Publishers, Inc., have agreed to establish a jointly owned subsidiary in New York.

The Collins Radio Company announced yesterday that its directors had voted unanimously to "oppose vigorously" a proposed exchange offer for Collins stock from the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, a much smaller concern.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 31 -- Heavy fighting broke out again northwest of Saigon during the last 24 hours, but elsewhere throughout South Vietnam the pace of the war slowed.

A special meeting of the railroads that own the Railway Express Agency has been called for Wednesday to review the terms of a purchase offer made for the business by Salomon Brothers Hutzler and Michael Lawrence. The offer expires April 15.
The American Stock Exchange broke a tradition yesterday and began a major reorganization of its clearing operations by naming Joseph J. Gulick as president of the Exchange Clearing Corporation.

PRAGUE, March 31 -- The Czechoslovak Government reported today that widespread anti-Soviet violence, reaching "hysteria," had extended to several cities after the victory of the Czechoslovak ice hockey team.
LOS ANGELES -- Can the arts help troubled and alienated youngsters in slum neighborhoods find a connection to the mainstream of society?

CALDER WILLINGHAM, who in his younger days made his fame with a lean and astringent novel, "End as a Man," has now in middle age and six novels later written a fat and flabby one. It is a long novel but not a big one, a Walter Mitty tale that is supposed to happen on an abandoned island, but is really an erotic day dream of a city dweller.
The sports world paused yesterday to pay tribute to the late President, Dwight D. Eisenhower, on a national day of mourning declared by President Richard Nixon.
The London stock market settled into the pre-Easter doldrums yesterday, after a moderate amount of morning activity. Prices were little changed at the close.
There is a woman in Exeter, N.H., who questions hunters' masculinity with alarming regularity.

Brutality and other maltreatment are so ingrained in the Marine Corps that the corps "may serve as a laboratory" for the study of institutionalized violence, a psychologist charged in a paper delivered here yesterday.

DETROIT, March 31 -- Amid growing complaints that the police used excessive force in responding to the murder of a fellow policeman Saturday night, Police Commissioner Johannes F. Spreen said today his men had handled the incident "in the only manner open to police officers."

With a charge that the Roman Catholic Church has "repeatedly failed to respond to the major problems of racism, war, poverty and technology," a group of priests yesterday announced plans to form local associations that would press for church reform.

Consumer purchases of houses, cars and household durable goods will be down by one per cent in the first half of 1969, compared with the last half of 1968, according to a quarterly projection released yesterday by the Commercial Credit Company of Baltimore.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Lyndon B. Johnson came back to the capital today for the first time since he surrendered the Presidency, and his visit was short and guardedly proper.

Twelve peace groups have planned demonstrations against the Vietnam War in 42 cities from this Thursday through Easter Sunday, Stewart Meachem, peace secretary of the American Friends Service Committee, announced yesterday.

And so April begins, foolishly enough. No other month has the courage to begin in jest, with a day dedicated to fools.

TEL AVIV, March 31 (AP) -- Defense Minister Moshe Dayan warned today that Israel faced new tests from her Arab neighbors and declared: "We can't waste a day preparing ourselves for the possible battle that might come."

Anything, you might say, but liturgical music.

THE funeral service of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower received sensitive and perceptive live coverage from the television networks late yesterday afternoon. The reverence of the service in Washington National Cathedral was movingly reported in pictorial terms, while simultaneously the television medium caught the interest inherent in the assemblage of world dignitaries.

A sit-in by more than 200 Queens College students and a handful of faculty members continued into its fifth day yesterday as the college president, Dr. Joseph P. McMurray, suspended all military and industrial recruitment on campus.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- David Packard, Deputy Secretary of Defense, has been contradicted by a second scientist on the details of Mr. Packard's testimony before the Senate Disarmament Subcommittee in support of the Safeguard missile defense system.

William Bradford Huie, the Alabama author who bought publication rights to the life story of James Earl Ray, said yesterday he believed that Ray had killed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to gain "status" with other convicts.
C. P. Snow, the British author and physicist, said yesterday that he was prepared to believe that Jews are genetically superior to other people.
LONDON, March 31 -- Britain's representation at the funeral of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower was criticized in newspaper editorials and public comment today as inadequate.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, April 1 -- A new leadership for Syria's ruling, extreme left-wing Baath party was elected last night at the closing session of the party congress in Damascus, the Syrian Government radio reported.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Dwight D. Eisenhower is going home to Kansas, and nothing could be more appropriate to the special place he holds in American hearts and history. He was a soldier, but the military ranks of stone across the slopes of Arlington are better surroundings for the Kennedy brothers -- killed in action before their days were full, like so many who lay beside them.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 31 (Reuters) -- President Suharto today launched a new five-year economic plan seen by economists as a modest attempt to put the country's development on a firm basis by 1974.

The University of Maryland, noted more for its football than basketball teams, went to newspaper advertising yesterday to persuade high school court stars to enroll there.

The decision of the Nixon Administration against building a dam in the Red River Gorge of eastern Kentucky is a notable triumph for citizen conservationists. A beautiful and scientifically interesting wilderness valley has been saved from drowning, and an important principle established.

RABAT, Morocco, March 31 -- Morocco today became the fourth country, after Greece, Turkey and Tunisia, to sign an accord of association with the European Economic Community, or Common Market. The ceremony, at the Foreign Ministry here, marked the end of nearly six years of negotiations.

WALTON-ON-THAMES, England, March 31 (AP) -- George Harrison, the Beatle, and his wife, Pattie, stood hand in hand in court today and pleaded guilty to the possession of marijuana. They were fined u250 ($600) each.

Passover, the festival that celebrates the exodus of the Israelites from Egypt into the Promised Land more than 2,000 years ago, begins at sundown today with the Sealer -- the ceremonial meal.
