WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Republicans and Democrats on the Congressional Joint Economic Committee agreed today that the surplus in the Government's budget should be made larger than the $3.4-billion projected by President Johnson as part of the battle against inflation.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 1 -- A lot of ballplayers have to take a cut in salary because they keep taking too big a cut at the plate.

TWO men took 53 pieces of luggage to Italy -- and still had to buy another suitcase in Rome. Earle K. Angstadt Jr., president of Abercrombie Fitch, had to get a bag to replace the one he had left behind, along with 51 other pieces, to be copied by Whip di Roma.

OTTAWA, April 1 -- The decision of the Government of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau to build a $400-million international airport for Montreal at a site opposed by the provincial government of Quebec has set off a new controversy between Ottawa and Quebec.
PRAGUE, April 1 -- The Communist party leadership met today in extraordinary session as it was announced that Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, the Soviet Defense Minister, flew to Czechoslovakia yesterday.

THE rich get richer, as in the case of the Can-Am. The million-dollar series of road races for Group 7 sports racing cars has acquired financial support for the first two races of the 1969 schedule, both of them in Canada.
DETROIT, April 1 -- Mayor Jerome P. Cavanagh said today that action taken by the police last Saturday night might have averted a full-scale riot.

The recent three-week West Virginia coal strike cut the coal loadings of the Chesapeake Ohio -- Baltimore Ohio Railroad system to less than half of normal and resulted in the consolidated system reporting a $900,000 drop in earnings in the first three months this year.
A report on British retail trade, showing a sharp drop in consumer spending, depressed prices on the London stock market yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- The House, told that some officers had served 18 years of almost continual sea duty, voted today to pay $15,000 bonuses to nuclear submarine officers who elect to serve four more years.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company disclosed plans yesterday to permit its giant stockholder family to re-invest more conveniently their dividends in additional A.T. shares. The offer, one of the first ever made by a major company, was contained in a separate mailing accompanying the concern's quarterly report.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1 -- Highly placed Arab informants said today that the period of political turbulence in Syria appeared to have come to an end with the election last night of the new leadership of that country's ruling Baath party.

IN a small park on Fort Washington Avenue, where on a late November afternoon in 1776 nearly 3,000 American soldiers finally fell to a massive attack by British and Hessian troops, old women now sit on green slatted benches.

HANOI, North Vietnam, April (Agence France-Presse) -- The Vietcong drew up a balance sheet of their five-week-old offensive today adn concluded that it had "shattered" a strategic plan conceived by Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, commander of United States forces in South Vietnam.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, which two years ago helped to create an international furor by suggesting that the United States might modify its gold policy, yesterday called for careful study of a basic reform in the international monetary system.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Representative Silvio O. Conte, Massachusetts Republican, said today he would introduce a bill to end the Government's mandatory controls on oil imports.
GENEVA, April 1 -- Sweden submitted to the disarmament conference today a preliminary version of a treaty prohibiting underground nuclear tests.

Weeb Ewbank, the general manager and coach of the world champion New York Jets, reported yesterday "favorable" contractual negotiations with Verlon Biggs, the defensive end who exercised the option clause in the 1967 contract rather than sign a 1968 contract.

PHUBAI, South Vietnam -- The current Communist offensive differs from its predecessors neither in weapons nor tactics. It simply seeks to retain the capability, after five weeks of stiff casualties, to endure another 60 to 90 days in which to produce unexpected reflections on the Paris peace talks.
MOSCOW, April 1 -- Tass, the Soviet press agency, announced tonight the conclusion of maneuvers held in Bulgaria last week by Bulgarian, Rumanian and Soviet forces.
As the New York City hospital crisis drags towards total disintegration, we learn the tactics of the mayor, the State Legislature and others.
Motion-picture exhibitors, labor unions allied with firm distribution and some private citizens and public officials, started a nationwide assault yesterday on pay television.
The Osipov Balalaika Orchestra from the Soviet Union will play three concerts at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 4 and 5 in an American tour of 48 cities.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A band of black militants was poised to begin guerrrilla warfare in New York City when its members were arrested in June, 1967, on charges of criminal anarchy, the Supreme Court was told today.
The City University unveiled yesterday a new "talk-back" closed-circuit television system that allows students to watch and listen to broadcasts and ask questions of the instructors.
SOME old and some new names shared the program, last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, of the Evenings for New Music. The old were two giants of a previous generation, Bela Bartok and Charles Ives.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Justice Hugo L. Black asserted today that the Supreme Court had declared criminal evidence to be inadmissible on so many constitutional grounds that prosecutors were being denied their right of trial by jury.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Senator Albert Gore, a major opponent of the Safeguard missile defense plan, suggested today that the Administration might "move to get itself off this hook" by shifting its position.

A decision in Boston yesterday by Chief Federal District Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. brings back into focus a bitterly disputed section of the 1967 draft law concerning conscientious objectors. The law confers exemption from military duty on a man "who by reason of religious training and belief, is conscientiously opposed to participation in war in any form."
It is hard to believe after the reverent public response to the Eisenhower funeral services that America is quite as indifferent to religion as the modern prophets and publicists say.
BREWSTER, N. Y., April 1 -- Worms raised in a Brooklyn garden proved effective on the East Branch of the Croton River this morning as the trout season opened.

I believe it quite appropriate, as I said in Chicago on March 20, for university professors voluntarily to advise the Government on its problems of defense technology. A most wholesome influence on the military establishment can be and is being exerted by independent advisory bodies.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 1 -- The Security Council condemned Israel tonight for an air attack on Jordan in a vote that split the major powers.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Administration is now so convinced that Senator Edward M. Kennedy is the most likely Democratic opponent of President Nixon in 1972 that it has taken the first steps to counter any drive by him.

The Endicott Johnson Corporation, the footwear manufacturer and retailer whose chairman accused the former management last week of "an extravagant waste of money," reported a loss yesterday for the first two months of its fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- The Food and Drug Administration served notice today that it intended to act to stop the marketing of 78 drug products containing antibiotics on the ground that they exposed patients to "an unnecessary risk."

MOSCOW, April 1 -- The Soviet Union's leading China experts appear to believe that Mao Tse-tung has called the ninth party congress to make formal his break with the Soviet model of Communism and the substitution of "Maoism" as China's ideology.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1 -- The seesaw pattern of the enemy's offensive continued in the last 24 hours.

Bird books are getting more ambitious, more informative, more elegant, more expensive. This one, by Dean Amadon of the American Museum of Natural History and Leslie Brown, a Kenyan zoologist, covers all 290 or so species of diurnal birds of prey -- vultures, condors, kites, eagles, hawks and falcons, some with such fascinating names as Madagascar Cuckoo-Falcon and Carunculated Caracara.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- The Defense Department made public today the following names of servicemen killed in Vietnam:
Vandals broke into Midwood High School in Brooklyn early yesterday and set fire to the disicplinary records, detroying the files on students who have been in trouble.
MINEOLA, L. I., April 1 -- The District Attorney was asked today to investigate an alleged fraud against the county by a Hicksville bus company "that could go as high as $100,000."

The former attorney for James Earl Ray said in New York yesterday that Ray went to Memphis last April 3 to try to sell rifles to Cuban exiles and that he never knew in advance that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was to be murdered.
A tall blond visitor from California stopped in a New York store yesterday to buy a compact.

BOSTON, April 1 -- A Federal District Judge declared unconstitutional today the section of the draft law under which a man can be exempted as a conscientious objector only if his objection to war is religious.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The United States foresees "no imminent compromise" with South Africa over sales of newly mined gold and sees "no particular urgency" about the matter, it became known today.
The body of Dwight David Eisenhower was borne yesterday in a black-draped railroad car across the rainswept heartland of America where farmers and veterans and housewives paid silent homage.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The present inflation has been caused mainly by past actions of the Federal Reserve System in trying to make it easier for the Treasury to borrow needed money, Leif H. Olsen, senior vice president and economist of the First National City Bank, said today.

The city proposed an enlarged summer program for the Neighborhood Youth Corps yesterday and requested Federal planning funds to avoid the last-minute rush of past years that left the program susceptible to fraud.
The stock market sustained a slight reversal yesterday after two weeks of generally higher prices resulting from hopes for a peace breakthrough in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird announced today that B-52 bomber raids in South Vietnam would be decreased by more than 10 per cent as a result of further cuts in the next defense budget.

The Assembly's Democratic minority leader called yesterday for the removal from their ranking committee posts of the two legislators who bolted the party to vote for the Republican-sponsored sales tax increase.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A hostile subcommittee of Congress questioned today A. Ross Eckler, the Director of the Census Bureau, about whether the 1970 census would intrude unduly into private lives.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Job Corps program, now threatened with a drastic cutback in funds, received Congressional praise today as a much-needed arm in the war on poverty.

LOS ANGELES, April 1 -- Sirhan B. Sirhan exploded in rage once again today in court and was quickly warned that another outburst would result in his being placed in restraint for the rest of the trial.

WAUSAU, Wis., Wednesday, April 2 -- David R. Obey, Democratic State Assemblyman, held a narrow lead early today over State Senator Walter J. Chilsen, Republican, in a special election to fill the seat in Congress that Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird held for the last 16 years.
" Man of La Mancha" gives its 1,400th performance tonight at the Martin Beck Theater, becoming the eighth Broadway musical to reach that mark.
Jose Greco gave an unusual stylistic distribution to his Spanish dance company's program last night at Philharmonic Hall.

COLUMBIA, S. C., April 1 -- Militantly antiwar soldiers on the sprawling infantry training base at Fort Jackson here sued the Army today in an attempt to obtain the same rights to protest that civilians have under the First Amendment to the Constitution.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Navy, which has started to convert its Polaris submarines with multiwarhead Poseidon missile's, told Congress today of plans to develop a new multibillion-dollar, longer-range submarine missile system in the late 1970's.
The City Council asked the Legislature yesterday for more time to formulate its 1969-1970 expense budget because fiscal officials were still uncertain about how much state aid the city would get.

Amid wide protests that the new state budget would force cutbacks in state and local services, an analysis indicated yesterday that its scheduled 16 per cent rise in spending compared closely with the rises in the previous four years.
The City Council asked the Legislature yesterday to pass bills that would enlarge the Council from 37 seats at 48.

ABILENE, Kan., April 1 -- "The most beautiful region under God's blue sky," Dwight D. Eisenhower once said of the rolling plains stretching out to the horizon in every direction from his boyhood hometown.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The A.F.L.-C.I.O. told Congress today that it should take steps to increase the taxes of "the loophole set" before extending the 10 per cent tax surcharge for a year, as President Nixon has asked.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, deploring the reductions in Medicaid and welfare aid made by the Republican-controlled New Yor State Legislature, said today that he did not believe the cutbacks would halt Federal aid to the state or New York City.

Dr. Buell G. Gallagher has submitted his resignation as the president of City College in a letter charging that city and state budgetary cuts would force drastic curtailment of the operations of the City University.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) Two of the nation's major oil companies told the Federal Trade Commission today that games of chance "put a little fun" into gasoline buying, and most motorists like them.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- Dr. Charles Brown, the Ford Foundation's program officer, called today for a basic overhaul of American public education, starting with dismissal of bad teachers on the advice of fellow teachers and the pupils themselves.

WESTPORT, Conn., April 1 -- Residents of this suburban community have reclaimed Cockenoe Island, a 27-acre retreat in Long Island Sound that had been bought by a utility company for a site of a nuclear power station.
RALEIGH, N. C., April 1 (AP) -- A plan was announced today to split among three cities the home games of an American Basketball Association team being brought to North Carolina next season.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ordered a hearing today for a Yugoslav student who the Government said "fell into an electronic surveillance."

NEW ORLEANS, April 1 -- A Canadian scientist reported today that his research team was on the verge of developing a simple blood test to detect cancer of the colon and rectum in man in its earliest stages.

If you will admit the name of John Knowles Paine, who died in 1906, it was an entire program of works by 20th-century composers that James Yannatos and the Harvard-Radcliffe Orchestra played last night at Carnegie Hall.

The Soviet Union and France undercut their own initiative for Middle East peace yesterday when they voted for a United Nations Security Council resolution which condemns Israel for its attack on Jordan last week but virtually ignores the guerrilla actions that provoke Israeli retaliation.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Nixon Administration is hopeful that the political program that emerges from the Communist party congress that opened today in Peking will establish enough stability to permit the start of a substantive dialogue with the United States.
THE next best thing to a shopping spree in Europe could be an escalator ride to Lord Taylor's third floor.

Strong demand for actual cocoa in Europe apparently triggered the maximum daily rise of a cent a pound in futures trading here yesterday. For example, the active September delivery closed at 38.09 cents a pound, up from 37.09 on Friday. Commodity markets had been closed Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Supreme Court today dismissed an appeal by the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association of New York City and its president, John J. DeLury, that contended that key provisions of New York State's Taylor Law were unconstitutional.
More than 500 policemen moved onto the Queens College campus before dawn yesterday at the request of the administration and ended a sit-in demonstration by making 39 arrests.

ALTHOUGH the circus has returned to town, it is of little interest to Pete Rozelle, the overlord of professional football. However, he has been watching with fearful fascination the juggling act being performed by the 26 owners of the two leagues as they struggle to smooth their repertory into an acceptable pattern.
Stocks drifted down yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in moderate trading.
While all other city public schools were closed yesterday because of the spring recess, Public School 175 in Harlem was open and operating as usual.
Trailways bus service between New York and Washington was suspended yesterday morning when drivers went on strike.

LONDON, April 1 -- Arnold J. Toynbee, the British historian and philosopher, who will be 80 years old the week after next, believes that the United States has profoundly changed because of what he terms the disappointment of American expectations.
MONTREAL, April 1 (UPI) -- A 25-year-old self-styled terrorist was sentenced to 124 concurrent life prison terms and five five-year terms today for his role in a series of bombings.

Five gunmen in stocking masks invaded a Bronx railroad-freight terminal in the Highbridge section of the Bronx early yesterday and made off with an estimated total of $250, 000 worth of liquor and kosher meat.
Frederick M. Alger 3d, who at 34 years of age earns more than $1-million a year managing other people's money, seems an unlikely source of stock-market pessimism.
A GREAT town lies in the age, as well as in the eye, of the beholder. Youth enjoys a vagabond fling where age as ringing for room service.

HONG KONG, April 1 -- The long-delayed ninth congress of the Chinese Communist party opened in Peking today with the goal of rebuilding and reorganizing the party's structure after three years of purge and tumult.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court upheld today the right of unions to punish workers who go over production quotas set by their union.

Motorola, Inc., announced yesterday in Chicago that William J. Weisz had been named executive vice president and assistant chief operating officer. He formerly was vice president and general manager of the communications division.

James McCracken and Bonaldo Giaiotti, who entered the cast of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Verdi's "Il Trovatore" last week, appeared again in their roles last night. Singing with Leontyne Price, Grace Bumbry and Sherrill Milnes, they fit very well in a cast distinguished for voices and vocal skill.
BOSTON, April 1 -- They'll have to do it three more times but the Philadelphia 76ers escaped from the brink of destruction tonight, beating the Boston Celtics, 119-116.
THERE was something in he air last night at Madison Square Garden -- namely, dozens of bodies that hurtled, hovered and hung in the loftiest traditions of the circus.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Following is an approximate schedule of funeral arrangements tomorrow for former President Dwight D. Eisenhower. All times given are Eastern Standard.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- Farm prices rose 2 per cent during the month ended March 15, the Agriculture Department reported today. Rising prices for cattle and lettuce were chiefly responsible for the advance but were partly offset by declines for tomatoes and milk.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- three economics professors urged the Congress today to put new restrictions on business spending to control inflation without having to keep interest rates at present record levels.
Interest rates continued to push their way downward yesterday in the race of the heaviest volume of new financing since February.

The Paul A. McGhee Washington Square Chamber Music Concerts sponsored by New York University will return next season to their former location, the 400-seat Tishman Auditorium of the Law School's Vanderbilt Hall. For the last two years the concerts have been given in the Eisner and Lubin Auditorium of the Loeb Student Center.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Federal Highway Administration, in the first such action, moved today to impose civil penalties on two tire manufacturers and a foreign car builder for violating Federal safety standards.
A Federal judge reserved decision yesterday on a request to bar the police from re-arresting the cast of "Che!" if the show is re-opened.

" James Brown's latest song says it all for me," said the young black in the rainbow-colored Afro shirt. "You heard 'Open the Door' yet? It says: 'I don't want you to give me nothing. Just open the door and I'll get it for myself'."
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported this afternoon.
Frederick L. Ehrman, a senior partner in the investment-banking firm of Lehman Brothers, was elected chairman of the board of New York University's Medical Center yesterday.
With Madison Square Garden's main arena occupied by the circus through May 11, the Garden's boxing programs will shift to the 5,000-seat Felt Forum, beginning with a show a week from Friday.
JERUSALEM, April 1 -- The Israeli police and security officials said today that they had broken another Arab sabotage ring in Jerusalem with the arrest of 10 suspects.

Braulio Baeza, the 29-year-old Panamanian, came walking into the jockeys' room following his third straight victory at Aqueduct yesterday with the same stoic expression that has gained him the nickname of "The Iceman."

THE success of the Negro Ensemble Company, which last night presented at its St. Marks Playhouse "An Evening of One Acts," the final offering of the season, is so assured, that the company must already stand the victim of its standards.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- A group of publishers of childrens' books facing price-fixing charges across the country failed in the Supreme Court today to block their accusers' access to Government files.

By resigning from the presidency of City College in protest against budget cuts that will drastically curtail its operations, Dr. Buell G. Gallagher is making an extreme personal sacrifice to awaken city and state officials to the cuts' lethal effects on the educational aspirations of able youths from needy families.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., April 2 (AP) -- Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, attempting to ease tension on the nation's college campuses, said today that students should have a greater voice in university affairs.
DETROIT, April 2 -- Car sales dropped well below last year's level in the final third of March, pulling the month's total sales down from March, 1968, the automobile companies reported today.

WILLIAM DOLLBAUM of Brooklyn, one of a coterie of Washington Square Park players, died last month of a heart attack at the age of 42. He played primarily for fun, disdaining theory, planning the combinational stroke that must justify his offbeat style.

In perhaps the best test yet of whether high-speed trains can lure passengers away from the airlines, the Penn Central's Metroliner began two-and-a-half-hour nonstop runs between New York and Washington yesterday.
Prices of London stocks turned firmly upward yesterday, while, in Tokyo, the market surged to an all-time peak on fi'esh indications of a sus-; tained economic boom.

LIMA, Peru, April 2 -- Peru's current dispute with the United States is placing a severe strain on the ruling military junta here and there is widespread speculation that President Juan Velasco Alvarado may soon be deposed by fellow officers.
New York City's big department stores scored impressive volume advances last month in their flagship units downtown and in their suburban branches.

HONG KONG, April 2 -- The list of dignitaries at the opening of the ninth congress of the Chinese Communist party yesterday indicates that, in the next few years, China will be ruled by a coalition of "leftists" and "moderates," with the army exercising considerable influence.
At first glance, it seemed like a chichi art exhibit. At second glance, however, it turned out to be a wondrous array of new print ads for Schenley products -- 18 new campaigns for 17 brands.
Mayor Lindsay called the new state budget "anti-urban and arbitrary" yesterday and said it would exact "an equal toll" from all citizen not just those on welfare and Medicaid.

MRS. PAT CONNOR of Melbourne is a leading figure in the dog show world in Australia. Although only 32 years old, she has bred or owned more than 50 Australian terrier champions. Her Aussies have won at 36 royal shows, a record Down Under for any breed.

TRENTON, April 2 -- The State Suprmeme Court ruled unamimously today that New Jersey communities had the right to adopt their own ordinances to prevent blockbusting, a tactic sometimes used by real estates interests to generate panic-selling in white neighborhoods where Negroes are buying homes.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -President Nixon is aiming for a Federal budget of $193-billion to $194-billion for the new fiscal year.
A Federal judge yesterday set Sept. 22 as the trial date for Roy M. Cohn on charges of bribery, extortion and blackmail in connection with the city take-over of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc.
VARIATIONS on a theme are as common in cooking as they are in music. Untraditional versions of two traditional American favorites -- poundcake and brownies -are given here.

LONDON, April 2 -- Prime Minister Wilson said today that he had received assurances from Lieut. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, head of the federal government of Nigeria, of his willingness to sit down unconditionally with Lieut. Col. Odumegwu Ojukwu, the Biafran leader, or any of his representatives, to discuss a settlement of the civil war.
Spring inspires art collectors to open their doors to tours aiding various educational, medical and social agencies.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Violence on television, it is widely believed, helps produce violence in human beings, particularly young children. But if this is true, is the remedy merely to excise violence from the home screen?

PEKING, April 2 -- More than 100,000 people continued marching through Peking's streets today, carrying red flags and beating drums and gongs to celebrate the opening of the ninth party congress yesterday. The delegates today began to study proposed revisions in the party constitution and the political report made yesterday by Defense Minister Lin Piao.

The earnings of the nation's largest banks moved into new high ground in the first quarter, but the extent of the gain has been held back by sharp increases in the cost of money. This was the implication yesterday as reports started to come in from the money-market giants.
Heartland of the King Ranch scored her first victory of the local thoroughbred season yesterday.

" ARSENIC AND OLD LACE," the sturdy comedy of the 1941 Broadway season, was awkwardly revived last night in a version, altered for television, that missed much of the humor so delicately elicited by Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse from Joseph Kesselring's original script.

MONTREAL, April 2 -- Once again the Montreal Canadiens pounced on a chance opportunity in the Stanley Cup playoffs, and tonight it lifted them to a 3-1 victory over the New York Rangers in the opener of their four-of-seven quarter-final series.
PAL MSPRINGS, Calif. (AP) -- Police gunfire into the air broke up a new outbreak among youthful Easter vacationers tonight after a rock music concert in this desert community.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2 -- There was good news and bad news for the New York Mets today, and the good news apparently outweighed the bad.
ARCADIA, Calif., April 2 (UPI) -- Laffit Pincay Jr. suffered a slight fracture of his right ankle today at Santa Anita when his mount fell during the running of the sixth race.
Rimsky-Korsakov's opera "Le Coq d'Or" may be regarded as a fantasy, a political satire or a somewhat silly fairytale. The New York City Opera seems to regard it as the last-named.

THERE'S an awful lot of cotton in Brazil, and some of it showed up here this week in pulos (short jumpsuits), casacos (coat shifts) and other assorted fashions for casual wear. The designs, some styled in Brazil and others created here by Ned Goldsmith, were introduced at a show held in the offices of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the new College Point Industrial Park in Queens, although still only in the planning stage, had its first major prospective tenant.

PRAGUE, April 2 -- The ruling Presidium of the Czechoslovak Communist party today imposed new curbs on the press, threatened discipline of party members and rebuked one of the Presidium's progressive members, Josef Smrkovsky.
ROME, April 2 -- Pope Paul VI appealed today for solidarity in a church suffering from "the defection and scandal" of clergy and laymen who "crucify" her.

Blue, red, green, gold or silver brighten their covers. Some come alive with colored pictures of men and machinery; others rely on stark black and white. Whatever the appearance, they -- namely annual reports -- are being received by millions of stockholders.
A Swiss banker, who neither looks nor sounds like a gnome of Zurich, declared yesterday that the dollar seems as good as gold.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 2 -- A new nationwide survey shows that 67 per cent of the American people, a new high, say they would vote for a Negro for President, the Gallup Poll reported today.

Bond yields continued to move downward yesterday as Virginia, which had not sold a bond since 1936, marketed $81million of bonds that were priced to yield 20-100ths of a point less than top-grade taxexempt securities offered two weeks ago.

THE fortunes of "Wozzeck" took a turn for the better last night at the Metropolitan Opera. Alban Berg's famous opera, returning to the Metropolitan's repertory after four seasons, had a new conductor, several new singers in key roles, and what amounted to a new interpretation.

Twenty-one members of the Black Panther party were indicted here yesterday on charges of plotting to kill policemen and to dynamite city department stores, a police station and a commuter railroad's right-of-way.
ACCRA, Ghana, April 2 -Lieut. Gen. Joseph A. Ankrah resigned as head of state today after having admitted that he had received money for political purposes from a private company.
DOVER, Del., April 2 (AP) -Government Cut, an 18-1 shot ridden by Clinton Fromal, raced to victory tonight in the Jack and Jill Purse at Dover Downs, winning by 1 1/4 lengths from Pizza Galla.

Investors in the musical, "1776," which opened less than three weeks ago, will receive a return of $100,000 on their capital investment this week. According to Stuart Ostrow, the producer, the production, capitalized at $500,000, was brought to Broadway for slightly less than $400,000.
Two suburban counties are taking important steps toward making their governments more representative.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- In the cuts it has made so far in the defense budget, the Nixon Administration is taking a calculated risk that the Vietnam war will taper off substantially during the next year or so. But the risk, although real, is largely financial and political rather than military.
A Manhattan grand jury returned an indictment yesterday against George Poplis, charging him with first-degree manslaughter in the slaying of his 3-year-old stepdaughter.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (Reuters) -- The State Department said today that it opposed revoking permission for South African Airways to fly to the United States. It is important, a department official asserted, to keep the lines of communication open with those who question South Africa's apartheid policy.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2 -- The Detroit Tigers, baseball's world champions, have made a poor showing in Florida and the inevitable gratuitous interpretation is being voiced in various quarters: complacency.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) -- Pollution of the Potomac River is a "national disgrace," Interior Secretary Walter J. Hickel said today.
PARIS, April 2 -- Foreign Minister Michel Debre told the French Cabinet today that progress was being made in the search for peace in Vietnam and in the Middle East.
The presence of the Soviet Defense Minister, Marshal Grechko, in Prague makes evident enough the kind of brutal pressure Moscow employed to extort yesterday's surrender from the Dubcek leadership.
PITTSBURGH, April 2 -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation is "confident" that operations this year will reach a sixth consecutive record level.
LONDON, April 2 -- Britain announced today a 7-million ($16.8-million) increase in gold and convertible currency reserves in March, after making loan repayments of 60-million ($144-million).

LOS ANGELES, April 2 -- The defense in the murder trial of Sirhan B. Sirhan began an intensive effort today to undermine the testimony of a psychiatrist who contends the defendant was not legally mentally ill when he killed Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y. April 2 -- Ralph S. Mosher, a lanky, white-haired engineer who for nearly 15 years has been devising sets of mechanical - hydraulic "muscles" that would make supermen of ordinary workers, demonstrated today a device that is a principal result of his labors.
The first anniversary of Martin Luther King's assassination is upon us. The perpetrator of the crime is sentenced to a long prison term. Justice has been done. Or has it? [Editorial March 11.]

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 2 -- When three of his players got too close to the back of a practice-field batting cage today, Ted Williams warned them to stay clear.

THE University of Maryland and its new basketball coach, Lefty Driesell, seemed to have overstepped the bounds of propriety in recruiting star athletes. The Terrapins placed a $594 advertisement in the Washington Post Monday aimed at convincing four basketball playing high school seniors to go to Maryland.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -The Securities and Exchange Commission, by a 3-1 vote with Chairman Hamer H. Budge dissenting, approved the application of the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company to acquire a company that will build and operate low-income housing projects in Detroit.
The Nixon Administration has taken a welcome and overdue first step toward de-escalating the war in Vietnam with its announcement of a 10 per cent reduction in B-52 bomber raids in South Vietnam.
FORT HOOD, Tex., April 2 (AP) -- The Army denied today allegations by an antiwar group that the editor of an underground G.I. newspaper had been court-martialed because of his views.

LOS ANGELES, April 2 -Lewis Alcindor, the three-time All-America basketball center from University of California Los Angeles, signed a multiyear professional contract today with the Milwaukee Bucks of the National Basketball Association.
Stock prices drifted lower yesterday in the absence of any compelling news on either the domestic or foreign fronts.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- A mean man on a mean horse rode meanly into town. He was no stranger.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines said today that the Nixon Administration had assured him that there would be no "precipitate withdrawal" by the United States from the Pacific region after a Vietnam settlement.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 31 -- "This is the real revolution!" rejoiced The Pakistan Times after President Mohammad Ayub Khan agreed at a constitutional conference this month to opposition demands for adult franchise and a parliamentary form of government.
Formal negotiations for new labor agreements were opened yesterday by four maritime unions and two shipowner groups. Current agreements expire on June 15.

A study of more than 31,000 nuns in the United States has revealed that they are more likely than the average American woman to develop cancer of the large intestine, as well as cancer of the breast, uterus and ovaries.
MOSCOW, April 2 -- The Soviet Union, in its first authoritative reaction to the convocation of the ninth national congress of the Chinese Communist party, tonight called it "a Maoist farce."
The last holdout areas in the nation's longest and costliest maritime strike settled yesterday as longshoremen ratified a new labor contract in Galveston and Houston.
The United Corporation reported yesterday that its net assets on March 31 had increased to $196,783,348, or $15.81 a share, from $154,551,215, or $12.05 a share, a year earlier.
OTTAWA, April 2 -- A sharp division in his Cabinet kept Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau from making a planned announcement today on Canada's future relations to the Atlantic Alliance.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) -- Americans increased their installment buying levels by $798-million during February, the Government reported today. The advance was the largest in four months.

HAROLD CONNOLLY is looking for a job. The 37year-old hammer-thrower, a veteran of four Olympic Games, has made it known to friends that he is ready to give up competition for a college coaching job. This week, while on spring vacation from teaching and coaching at Santa Monica (Calif.) High School, he plans to take his wife, Olga, north for her first visit to San Francisco. Ostensibly, they will be celebrating their 12th wedding anniversary.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Capitol Hill sources said today that they had the assurance of the Pentagon that a much-disputed order barring Army chaplains from referring to God in mandatory troop guidance lectures would be rescinded.

Thomas Schippers, the 39year-old Metropolitan Opera conductor, yesterday was named musical director of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra. Mr. Schippers will succeed Max Rudolf -- who also went to the Ohio orchestra from the Metropolitan -in the fall of 1970 under a three-season contract.

The Marcona Corporation, a jointly owned affiliate of the Cyprus Mines Corporation and the Utah Construction and Mining Company, confirmed yesterday that its Marcona Mining Company subsidiary planned to invest $25-million in exploration of new iron-ore deposits in Peru.

Paul R. Screvane accused the Lindsay administration yesterday of "ineptness inexperience and lack of good judgment" and cited his own 29 years of service to the city as proof that he could do a better job than Mayor Lindsay.
ALL pre-emptive bidders have to balance the possible advantage of crowding the opponents' bidding against the danger of suffering a heavy penalty.
DETROIT, April 2 -- At Detroit police headquarters today, a trunk-sized, nine-track tape recorder was switched on and the sounds of a police battle came roaring out.
LAGOS, NIGERIA, April 2 -- After a six-month lull, federal troops have resumed their advance into the heart of secessionist Biafra.

The State Insurance Department announced yesterday its first punitive action against insurance companies for what it termed racial discrimination in the cancellation of fire-insurance policies in slum areas.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- A fight is shaping up in Congress over whether the Administration's plan for the much-criticized Job Corps may not lead to its virtual abandonment.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 2 -Carmine Abbatiello, far ahead of all North American harness racing reinsmen in dashes won and money earned this season, clicked for four more victories tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Abbatiello now has accounted for 100 triumphs and a whopping $278,071 in purse-money

ABILENE, Kan., April 2 -Dwight David Eisenhower, the Supreme Commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force, General of the Army and 34th President of the United States, was buried today across the street from the White cottage where he grew to manhood.

Good sense seems finally to have broken through the political storm clouds over Anguilla. Lord Caradon has been able to convince the Anguillans that Britain will not try to force the island back into a federation dominated by St. Kitts.
Two hundred times and more a day -- in fact about every seven minutes -- someone steals a car here.
MOSCOW, April 2 -- Jacob D. Beam, the new United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, has arrived with no new proposals, messages or initiatives in his briefcase.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 2 -Art official source here today described Iran's decision to break off diplomatic relations with Lebanon as "regrettable."
Platinum was down and silver was up in futures trading yesterday, but the reasons were vague.
The Selective Service director, Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, offered yesterday to intercede personally in behalf of any young man wrongfully reclassified by a draft board because of lega protest.

The Xerox Corporation has withdrawn 3,000 reprints of an 1895 English edition of "Mother Goose's Nursery Rhymes and Fairy Tales," following a complaint that it contained antiJewish and anti-Negro material.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) -- The Navy asked Congress today for $2.7-billion to begin modernizing the fleet.

JERUSALEM, April 2 -Moshe Dayan, Israeli Defense Minister, told the people of Nablus today that they could choose between restoring normal life in their town or watching it deteriorate into chaos and destruction.
ACCRA, April 2 (Agence France-Presse) -- Brig. Akwasi Amankwa Afrifa, who today became one of Africa's youngest heads of state, is regarded as a brilliant soldier and a man of democratic views.
TAMPA, Fla., April 2 (AP) -Donn Clendenon, who announced his retirement from baseball last month, changed his mind today and signed with Montreal, the Expos announced.
MIAMI, April 2 -- President Nixon flew directly to his vacation home on nearby Key Biscayne today after having attended the final funeral rites for former president Dwight D. Eisenhower.

THE very phrase "a oneman show" is almost, but not quite, a contradiction in terms, like, say, "an honest lawyer" or "a bashful peacock." It is difficult for any one man to make a show that stands up as an evening in the theater, as distinct from a distended cabaret act that would be pleasant enough for the first 20 minutes, endurable for the next 10 and darkest purgatory for everything that follows.
WARSAW, April 3 (AP) -A Soviet-built Polish Airlines passenger plane crashed today south of Cracow, killing 51 persons, the Polish press agency P.A.P. reported.
HONG KONG, April 2 (UPI) -- Chien Hsueh-shen, a former colonel in the United States Air Force, was elected yesterday to the presidium of the ninth congress of the Communist party in Peking.

SAN DIEGO, April 2 (AP) -John Hadl ended his holdout siege with the San Diego Chargers today by signing a 1969 contract at undisclosed terms.

THE incredible thing about the newly published "A Parisian's Guide to Paris" is that nothing quite like it has appeared before. LOS ANGELES, April 2 -Mayor Samuel W. Yorty, who was knocked to the canvas yesterday in the first round of the Los Angeles mayoral election, scrambled to his feet today with his fists flying.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce opposed today a proposal to levy a minimum tax on wealthy persons who escape all income taxes by taking advantage of certain legal deductions.

A new study indicates that at least 12 per cent of the children in Manhattan are suffering from serious mental illnesses, with an additional 34 per cent "moderately" impaired and perhaps in need of immediate help. Only 12 per cent were found to be mentally healthy or merely minimally impaired.

Eisenhower's burial ceremony yesterday at the Eisenhower Library, Abilene, Kan., as recorded by The New York Times.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 2 -- Fighting broke out yesterday near Saigon when a United States Army unit discovered an enemy force two miles south of Phucuong, about 12 miles northwest of the capital. Fifteen of the enemy were killed in the brief fight, according to the official report, and three Americans were wounded.

BEIRA, Mozanbique, April 3 (AP) -- Lazaro Kavandame, who for four years had led a guerrilla revolt against Portuguese rule in this southeast African territory, has surrendered and is urging his followers to do the same, the Government announced today.
An upstate woman who served 20 days as a Federal grand juror has been sent $728 -- the highest pay ever given to a juror in the Southern District of New York.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Vaccine against rubella, commonly known as German measles, will probably be licensed and made available for prescription use in the United States within two months.
Plans to bring Nicol Williamson's highly praised "Hamlet" to Broadway next month were canceled yesterday because of insurmountable casting difficulties, its sponsors announced.

The Soviet Union and the United States moved closer to agreement on a treaty to limit military uses of the sea bed yesterday when the Russians elaborated on proposals they introduced two weeks ago. Encouraging as any sign of flexibility in Big Power negotiations may be. the other members of the seventeen-nation disarmament conference are not likely to react with wild applause.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Bureau of the Budget has turned down Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel's request for $600-million to help clean up the country's water supplies.

BOSTON, April 3 (UPI) -- Gerry Cheevers, the goalie, gained his second straight shutout and John Bucyk scored a pair of goals tonight as the Boston Bruins took a 2-0 playoff advantage with a 7-0 rout of the Toronto Maple Leafs.
Two hundred boisterous sympathizers, preponderantly white interrupted the Supreme Court arraignment yesterday of a suspect in an alleged Black Panther plot to terrorize the city with bombings.
MEMPHIS, April 3 (AP) -- Criminal Court Judge Arthur C. Faquin Jr. was named today to succeed the late Judge W. Preston Battle Jr. as the presiding judge in the James Earl Ray case.

The Justice Department has held a series of talks with law-enforcement officials here on the establishment of a special "strike force" of lawyers and crime specialists to combat organized crime in Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester County.

The late Dr. Martin Luther King's brother said last night that he supported the Black Panther party's goals but not all its methods.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

Just how great a squeeze New York City faces under the new state budget has now been translated into figures by City Budget Director Frederick O'R. Hayes. He finds that the city will have to get along with $156 million less in state funds than it would have received if original formulas had been left unchanged.

" Corporations must act if the arts are to be saved," Bates Lowry, director of the Museum of Modern Art, told a gathering of executives yesterday at a Columbia School of Business luncheon at the Pierre Hotel.

The struggle between the Piper Aircraft Corporation and Chris-Craft Industries, Inc., which has been trying to win control of Piper, took a new turn yesterday as the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted to suspend trading in the common stock of Piper.

Heather Thomson, a Canadian soprano, made her City Opera debut last night at the New York State Theater as Marguerite in Gounod's "Faust." Michele Molese had the title role, and Roy Samuelson was Mephistopheles.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -The State Department declined immediate comment today on Prime Minister Trudeau's decision to reduce Canada's troop commitment to the alliance.
Borough President Herman Badillo of the Bronx announced yesterday that he was running as "the only liberal candidate" for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Federal Reserve Board, in what it called a "further move against inflation," raised today both its discount rate and the reserves required of the nation's banks.

Martin Starger, national programing director of the American Broadcasting Company television network, yesterday was named vice president in charge of programing, to succeed Leonard Goldberg. Mr. Goldberg is leaving to join Screen Gems, television subsidiary of Columbia Pictures.

DETROIT, April 3 -- Judge George W. Crockett said today that police action last week in a shoot-out with black spearatists and subsequent criticism of him were connected to racism.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3 -- As the New York Mets played their final game in Florida for another year -- against the St. Louis Cardinals at Al Lang Field tonight -- they looked back upon a spring training season that generated considerable optimism that rested on the shifting sands of unanswered questions.
The A. DePinna Company, an 84-year-old name in New York retailing, will go out of business in three weeks and its site at Fifth Avenue and 52d Street will eventually be covered by a skyscraper.

Mr. Boulez, using part of the string section of the New York Philharmonic (reduced strings and no basses), opened the program with five Purcell Fantazias, which in days past we knew as fantasias, especially in the old International String Quartet recording.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 3 -- A ceremony in the middle of San Francisco Bay wrote an important chapter today in the troubled history of the $1.3-billion Bay Area Rapid Transit project.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie mobilized 7,000 Illinois National Guard troops today to put down shooting, stoning, looting and street fighting that broke out in Negro neighborhoods of Chicago on the eve of the first anniversary of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

A major segment of the nation's merchant marine will begin talks with seagoing labor unions this week on four-year contracts ending June 15.
" I FEEL," said Bill Russell, "like a 35-year-old man."

A consumer survey conducted by the National Industrial Conference Board and released yesterday disclosed that American families continue to appraise the present state of the economy with optimism but feel less confident about the next six months.

NEW ORLEANS, Monday, April 7 -- A Nationalist Chinese freighter and a string of oilloaded barges collided in a fiery explosion last night on the Mississippi River. The Coast Guard said 26 or 27 persons "are not accounted for."
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 6 -- At least 11 persons, six of them children, died today when fire swept an aging wooden tenement on the East Side of this industrial city.

FORT WORTH, April 6 -- A move in the major cities of Texas by amusement vending machine companies to take over neighborhood beer taverns, the so-called poor man's club, has sparked a statewide investigation.
Beatrice Rippy, a soprano who has appeared in New York previously both as recitalist and as soloist with the Symphony of the New World, gave a recital at Town Hall late Saturday afternoon.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., April 6 -- Still erect as a stanchion on a schooner's fo'c'sle, Rear Adm. Donald B. MacMillan, retired, "paced the deck" as usual today and reflected on the expedition that discovered the North Pole on this date 60 years ago.
OAKWOOD BAYOU, Ark., April 6 (UPI) -- Ten persons, all but one of whom were related, were killed last night in an explosion and fire that destroyed a rambling, 14-room house during an Easter reunion.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) -- A reduction in the number of people on the nation's welfare rolls has been set as "a top priority" by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, an official said today.

Does this more restrictive credit stance make certain some cooling of the economy and eventually some fallback in interest rates? Will the Nixon Administration's secret Vietnam peace program succeed, lowering the Federal Government's demands for funds?

WATERLOO, Iowa, April 4 -- "All aboard. All aboard the Cannon Ball Special . . . don't forget your packages, umbrellas and babies . . . first call for breakfast. Wildcat served on toast. Corn liquor in a fruit jar. Lower berth $10, upper berth $9.

RICHARD and Shirley Hewitt, and Mel and Ann Lobell, all of Scarsdale, N. Y., won the Westchester Contract Bridge Association's Double Knockout Team Championship a week ago. The competition began last October with 27 teams.
A 20-building apartment complex in Bayside, Queens, has been bought by the realty partnership of Lawrence A. Wien and Harry B. Helmsley.
TONOPAH, Nev., March 31 -- The old silver mines perch quietly on the barren hills above the town, like old men warming themselves in the first bright days of spring sun.
BERKELEY, Calif., April 6 (UPI) -- Chancellor Roger Heyns said today that a department of ethnic studies would be in operation at the University of California at Berkeley by next fall.

POSITIONAL play, pure and simple, earned the victory for Dr. Neil McKelvie, a professor of chemistry at City College, as White in a King's Indian Defense against Edgar McCormick during the current Manhattan Chess Club championship.

A soprano could not ask for a more grateful debut assignment than the title role in Douglas Moore's "The Ballad of Baby Doe." Perhaps the most adorable home-wrecker in operatic annals, Baby Doe also has five melodious arias, a whole wardrobe of gorgeous gowns and an instantly winning musical personality.
The baseball season will open today in Washington, Cincinnati and Atlanta with the first three of 1,944 scheduled games in the major leagues.

LONDON, April 6 (Reuters) -- Airlines of British Overseas Airways Corporation B.O.A.C took to the air today after a six-day strike by its 1,200 pilots. The airline estimated its loss of revenue as $7.2-million.

In the summer of 1936, Adolf Hitler ordered plans for the reconstruction of Berlin into a grandiose capital for his Germanic Empire. The government complex, modeled after the ornate public buildings of the Second Napoleonic Empire, the Parthenon and St. Peter's Cathedral in Rome, was to have been completed in 1950.
SUMMIT, N.J., April 6 -Residents and private businesses here have teamed up in an unusual campaign to eliminate a small Negro slum in the heart of this affluent suburban community.
LONDON, April 6 -- Sir Peter Allen heads Europe's biggest producer of chemicals, with anual sales of $2.7-billion. His gross salary is equivalent to $117,000.
A man who killed three persons on the Pennsylvania Turnpike Saturday and wounded 15 others before killing himself had been judged suicidal, according to his uncle.
NAHA, Okinawa, April 5 -"If we move out of here, that's the beginning of World War III," the general said explosively. "Okinawa is our keystone. Where else can we go?"

Both Richard Nixon and Hubert Humphrey presented themselves as men with "no ties to the past," each promising an objective, detached review and re-evaluation of America's role in the world.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -Western diplomats are carefully watching for signs that the Communist party congress now in session in Peking will revive machinery for the conduct of foreign affairs.
SALINE, Mich., April 6 -- The 14-member youth choir crowded into the small lobby off the sanctuary and spilled down the basement steps of the United Methodist Church at 9:30 A.M. today.

STANFORD, Calif. -- "Man may be skeptical about following the flight of the dodo into extinction, but the evidence points increasingly to just such a pursuit," said Prof. Richard A. Falk of Princeton University, who is directing research on a project devoted to world order in the 1990's.
MIAMI, April 6 -- President Nixon, winding up his holiday on nearby Key Biscayne, attended Easter worship services with his family today and met with his troubleshooter on a dispute with Peru.

Television played havoc yesterday with the New York Knickerbocker-Boston Celtics National Basketball Association playoff game at Madison Square Garden. It left empty seats even though all tickets reportedly had been sold.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- A panel of businessmen and economists, after touring Europe, has concluded that more flexible exchange rates among currencies are not the solution to international financial problems.

In his recent message to the Geneva arms control conference, President Nixon listed control of chemical and biological weapons as one of six possible objectives for international agreement. The President's brief mention is one of the rare departures from the official policy of deep silence which the United States Government has maintained for many years with regard to these weapons.

BERLIN, April 6 -- Worship services in which Roman Catholic and Protestant congregations joined this spring in the Eichsfeld area in East Germany have promoted greater understanding in an area known for religious feuds dating back to the middle ages.

While the puck danced around the Montreal net and 17,250 fans again embraced the Rangers with loving screams, New York's finalperiod outburst fell short last night and the Rangers bowed out of the Stanley Cup quarterfinals by dropping a 4-3 decision.
An old friend quoted former Mayor Robert F. Wagner yesterday as saying that it was "60-40 that I'll be running again for Mayor."

The New York Yankees will open the American League season today in Washington, with Tom Tresh suddenly a doubtful starter at shortstop, but with their clubhouse prophet, Pete Sheehy, predicting a pennant in the new six-team Eastern Division.
ROME, April 6 -- Pope Paul VI urged modern man today to seek happiness in what he called the hard, old and severe, but true and joyful, Christian message of resurrection and redemption.
The Citizens Budget Commission called on the city's fiscal directors yesterday to establish a list of priorities immediately as the basis of budget planning for years ahead.

Most child prodigies burn out their talents long before reaching artistic maturity. Three who didn't were presented Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall by the English Chamber Orchestra: Daniel Barenboim, the conductor; Pinchas Zukerman, the solo violinist, and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, who wrote the concerto and the two symphonies on the program.

PESHAWAR, Pakistan, April 6 -- On the hot, arid valley floor below the Khyber Pass, a tip of Pakistan close to the corners of China and the Soviet Union, an American eavesdropping installation is being dismantled, a wasted relic of an age of shifting strategic alignments in this part of the world.

The long-sought goal of high-speed rail service through the crowded Northeast Corridor is at last nearing realization, after countless delays and disappointments. Metroliners began nonstop service last week on a two-and-a-half-hour schedule between New York and Washington; this week turbotrains will start carrying revenue passengers between New York and Boston.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States expected to begin talks with the Soviet Union on limitation of strategic missiles in "late spring or early summer."

IF the show still happens to be the thing in television, the Columbia Broadcasting System's cancellation of Sunday night's "Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour" was a silly and suspect move. The program chanced to be one of the best that the Smothers Brothers have offered all season, imaginatively topical and genuinely amusing, and the "sermonette" challenged by the network was not worth all the managerial jitters.
The American Smelting and Refining Company announced yesterday that it was raising its price for lead by one-half cent, to 14 1/2 cents a pound.

Three staff members of The New York Times were among 11 award winners named for journalistic achievement yesterday by the Society of the Silurians, a 45-year-old organization of past and present newspapermen.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -The constitutionality of "plea bargaining" by defendants who plead guilty to escape the threat of death sentences will be reviewed by the Supreme Court next fall.

John Doar, president of the Board of Education, has urged the local governing board of the I.S. 201 demonstration school district in Harlem to reassign seven union teachers to regular classroom duty following the Easter vacation.
A committee of Freedom House warned yesterday that the debate over the Safeguard antiballistic missile system might become as divisive as that over the war in Vietnam.
A new acting principal, appointed by the local governing board, took office at P.S. 2 on the Lower East Side yesterday despite the fact the Board of Education had previously filled the post.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -Notes from a sentimental journey:

A 42-member special committee established by Governor Rockefeller recommended yesterday a broad program of recruitment and training to bring more Negroes and Puerto Ricans into the newspaper and broadcasting industries.
FOR the second time in two years, New York State hunters will have a chance to go after bearded (male) wild turkeys in the spring.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 7 (UPI) -- A couple of unseeded players, Bob Hewitt and Kerry Harris, provided the big upsets today at the South African open tennis championships.

CINCINNATI, April 7 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers survived successive home runs by Pete Rose and Bobby Tolan to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 3-2, today behind the pitching of Don Drysdale and Bill Singer in the 1969 National League opener.

While countless thousands of office shut-ins in the financial district dreamt of enpoying the spring weather yesterday, 3,670 free souls chose to wait in line for a chance to watch an estimated 2,600 persons on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange for 10 minutes.

Stanley B. Thomas Jr., a former antipoverty aide in the Lindsay administration, has been appointed a deputy, assistant secretary for youth activities in the Federal Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., April 5 -- In the 19th century the revolutionary was Karl Marx, but now it's Groucho. Two years ago Irving Berlin, the songwriter, wired Groucho Marx that the world would be in better shape if he -- instead of the other Marx--had inspired the revolution.
As the Federal income tax deadline next Tuesday draws near rebellion against it is assuming large porportions, according to Louis Harris in a survey reported in The New York Post yesterday.

The New York City Mission Society will receive the proceeds of a dinner April 17 in the Pierre Hotel's Coronet Room and a luncheon April 21 in the Plaza's Baroque Room. Both events will further the society's camping fund.
A single center to offer a variety of city services will be built in the Hunts Point area of the Bronx with the help of a $1.3-million Federal grant, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

TRENTON, April 7 -- Seven New Jersey Assemblymen were barred tonight from running for re-election in November as a result of a court-ordered reapportionment plan drawn by computers, instead of politicians.

HOUSTON, April 7 -- An Illinois man, kept alive for 63 hours by the first man-made heart ever used in a human being, today received the healthy heart of a widow who had been flown here from Massachusetts.
The Government denied yesterday that two indictments against Roy M. Cohn stemmed from a personal "vendetta" against him by United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau.

C.P. Snow has publicly speculated on the superiority of the so-called Jewish gene pool, as evidenced in part by the disproportionate number of Jewish Nobel Prize winners. With undue whimsey, one might speculate on the superiority of the black gene pool, as evidenced by the disproportionate number of black musicians, on the theory that a sense of rhythm has brought a greater quantum of happiness into the world than intellectual attainment.

The Rameau Trio is composed of three pleasantly antique-looking people -- a boy and two girls -- who last night at Carnegie Recital Hall dipped into some fairly unfamiliar old music and came up with a number of winners.

The May Department Stores Company achieved record sales in the fiscal year ended Feb. 1, but earnings declined largely because of the 22 cents a share surcharge tax, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

A three-alarm fire that was termed suspicious in origin by the Fire Department heavily damaged the top three floors of a five-story classroom building on the campus of Pratt Institute in downtown Brooklyn yesterday.

A bus speed-up plan, tried out experimentally for four weeks along Fifth Avenue in midtown, has proved so successful that it will be made permanent and possibly also tried out along other bus routes in the city.

THRUXTON, England, April 7 (AP) -- Jochen Rindt of Austria, driving a Lotus Ford, won the International Formula Two race today. He slipped through the field to take the lead at the halfway point before an Easter Monday crowd of 45,000 to repeat his victory of last year.
NANUET, N.Y., April 7 -Eleven meet records were broken as Oceanside (L.I.) High School won the second annual Nanuet Relays today in a 20-school field.

Whatever be the dispute between Prof. Khushwant Singh [letter March 10] and Ranjan Borra [letter March 31] over India's Mideast policy, Mr. Borra's argument justifying India's attack on Pakistan in 1965 is justifying a wrong deed which had no moral basis.
A number of management promotions at the General Motors Corporation were announced yesterday.

UNTIL last Friday, Dr. Denton Arthur Cooley was known as the most productive heart surgeon in the world and one of the specialty's fastest and most skillful technicians. He had performed more than 5,000 cardiac operations, 17 of them heart transplants.
The convictions of two chiropractors and their office manager for mail fraud in a scheme to defraud the underprivileged were upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals in open court.

JOHN GUARE, whose new double bill of "Cop-Out" and "Home Fires" was seen for the first time at the Cort Theater last night, is a master of calculated irrelevancy. His is a world of misunderstandings and half-truths, a world of the most astonishingly logical illogicality.

AMHERST, Mass., April 7 -- Amherst College will discontinue free tuition for sons of residents of this town who can qualify for admission. The cutoff will begin with students who enter Amherst in September, 1970.

Three gunmen gained entrance to the apartment of the president of a printing concern by posing as moving men yesterday morning. They robbed him of $48,000 worth of jewels, furs and ivory miniatures, the police said.

DeSoto, Inc,, a producer of paints controlled by Sears, Roebuck Co., Inc., andI MPI Industries, Inc., a cabinetI manufacturer, announced yesterday that they had agreed to l merge through an exchange of stock valued at about $66.8million.

FORT ORD, Calif., April 7 (AP) -- A defense move for a change of venue was taken under consideration today as 14 more Army privates went on trial on mutiny charges. The defense asked that the trial be returned to the San Francisco Presidio.

CLEVELAND, April 7 (UPI) -- The Republic Steel Corporation's management will seek stockholder approval to revise its corporate charter in a manner that would give it more flexibility to take advantage of business opportunities as they arise, the company disclosed today in a proxy statement for the annual meeting on May 14.
SALT, Jordan, April 4 -- Spring has come to Jordan, and with it hope.
Lawyers for the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association worked all day yesterday preparing a suit seeking to prevent the Police Department from establishing a fourth platoon.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 -A three-week boycott during which containerized cargo piled up on West Coast docks was ended today by the independent International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.

The Smothers Brothers, who contend that the Columbia Broadcasting System violated their contract when C.B.S. canceled their weekly television series for next season, said yesterday that they did not plan to sue the network.

FASHION will be flying from the Fifth Avenue flag poles for the next two weeks. It's all for a good cause. The green, white and black print flags, designed by Vera, are the opening wedge in a campaign to benefit the Mayor's Committees on Playlots and Scholarships.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plans record capital expenditures of $275,million this year, the highest for the industry and more than $40-million higher than 1968 expenditures, Russell DeYoung, chairman and chief executive officer, told several hundred shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Akron.
BALTIMORE, April 7 -- A Federal court was asked today to stop Federal authorization of a major expressway destined to run through Fells Point, a neighborhood that traces its origins to 1732.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 8 -- Enemy troops attacked an American infantry unit early yesterday and inflicted heavy losses, the United States command reported.

A high Republican reapportionment expert predicted that his party would "pick up six to eight House seats" as a result of yesterday's ruling by the United States Supreme Court requiring the reapportionment of Congressional districts in the state.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Developnent, proposed today that the Nixon Administration make basic alterations in the Model Cities program, the Johnson Administration's plan for improving urban slums.
Canada will make its debut in big league baseball today when the Montreal Expos open the season at Shea Stadium against the New York Mets.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- A cutoff of Federal funds for three school districts and three hospitals in the South because of racial discrimination was announced today by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 7 -- Consumer attitudes improved in the first quarter, a University of Michigan survey reported today.

Atlantic Container Line, Ltd., the consortium of six major European steamship lines, has named three vice presidents, each of whom will head one branch of its operations in this country under O.I.M. Porton, president of ACL, U.S.A.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower was working on a book of reflections until a few weeks before he died at Walter Reed General Hospital in Bethesda, Md., on March 28.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -Companies with names that would mislead an investor about the nature of their businesses may be forced to change such names before they can register and sell their stock, under a set of guidelines made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
CHICAGO, April 7 -- The 44th Ward, just north of downtown Chicago, is a study in contrasts, ranging from tall, luxury apartment buildings along Lake Michigan to modest homes of laborers to the west.

MONTREAL, April 7 -- French Canada was given a new taste of American culture today with a triumphant parade of the Montreal Expos on the eve of baseball's 100th anniversary.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 (AP) -- Twice a week eight Temple University coeds shoulder an M1 rifle and march slickly in military drill.

Twenty per cent of the color television sets in Suffolk County are believed to be emitting X-rays at a harmful level, and all color television sets are giving off the rays to some extent, according to a two-year survey by the county's Public Health Service.

OTTAWA, April 7 -- Foreign Minister Willy Brandt of West Germany said here today that the Atlantic alliance "needs Canada," adding that it was "good" that Canada would continue to cooperate in the safeguarding of peace.

VAIL, Colo., April 7 -Along the Eagle River high in the Rockies the cattle and sheep are grazing in the mud, feeding on the brown spring grass.

CHICAGO, April 8 (UPI) -- Willie Smith, a pinch-hitter, belted Barry Lersch's Second pitch into the right-field stand with Randy Hundley on base and one out in the 11th inning today to give the Chicago Cubs a 7-6 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies.

Cazzie Russell will be in uniform tonight for the first time since Jan. 21 when the New York Knicks oppose the Celtics at Boston in the second game of their four-of-seven National Basketball Association Eastern Division championship series.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy announced his support today for continuation of the 10 per cent income tax surcharge, but said that it must be coupled with "at least a first step toward basic tax reform."

MIAMI, April 8 -- Some of the best known names in the nation's underworld are scheduled to appear before a Federal grand jury in Miami tomorrow to answer questions about gambling and narcotics.

The International Paper Company reported yesterday an increase of about 30 per cent in earnings in the first quarter this year on a sales gain of 12 per cent over the period a year ago. The results were the highest for any initial quarter in the company's history.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A member of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers said today the Administration was standing by its policy of "gradualism" in checking the inflationary boom in the economy and that last week's credit-tightening move by the Federal Reserve Board was consistent with that policy.
So much gloom has been expressed about the stock market lately that Leslie M. Pollack, research partner of Reynolds Co., is wondering if pessimism hasn't built a floor under equity prices.

GARY, Ind., April 8 -- The biggest steel company unveiled here today in the world's biggest steelworks the biggest steel forming machine of it type.

WASHINGTON -- There is an art museum in this city where, every day, children turn into stripes, tin cans, dying Indians and Abraham Lincoln. They look at what appears to be a plain black square of paint and within seconds they feel cold, quiet or sad.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Trading in common stock of the Dyna Ray Corporation will be permitted to resume April 15, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

TRENTON, April 8 -- A Hudson County Democratic Assemblyman said tonight that he would attempt to get the Federal and state courts to strike down a new reapportionment plan for the Assembly that knocked eight incumbents out of the running this year.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- A Senate hearing on Otto F. Otepka's nomination to be a member of the Subversive Activities Control Board has been set for April 15 before members of a committee that once defended him.

WASHINGTON April 8 (AP) -- The Justice Department released more money for the fight against crime today and urged all 50 states to give priority to cities with high crime rates.
The publishing industry yesterday sought out a little-known Negro photographer who has quietly been taking pictures of Harlem scenes and people for the last 50 years.

New York Hospital announced that the 40-year-old woman who received a new heart in a transplant operation April 2 died yesterday at 3:45 P.M.

The experimental Turboliner, the aircraft industry's contribution to railroading, began regular Boston-New York service yesterday, but with something less than the dash that airmen are used to.

The Society of Black Composers, Inc., presented a concert at Columbia University's McMillin Theater last night that featured performances by as unusual an ensemble as this listener has encountered in a long time.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Nixon's cabinet task force on oil import policy an-announced today a six-month agenda and named Prof. Phillip Areeda, an antitrust specialist at Harvard Law School, as its executive director.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) -- The Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen announced today that its 13,000 members would strike at 6 A.M. local time next Monday in a demand for higher wages from the nation's railroads. The president of the West Side Tennis Club, the shrine of grass-court competition in the United States, predicted yesterday the substitution of synthetic-surface courts at the layout in Forest Hills, Queens.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -One of the first errors of the 1969 baseball season was committed yesterday by the display company that hung a misspelled Presidential seal on Richard M. Nixon's box at the Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

The Union Carbide Corporation has taken a $7-million, long-term lease on 140,000 square feet of floor space in a new industrial and office building being erected on former Long Island Rail Road property in Long Island City, Queens.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 8 -- Archie Niles Jr. divides most of his time between Roosevelt Raceway, where he trains and drives standardbreds, and his nearby Old Country Road restaurant, where he serves lasagna, manicotti, spaghetti and other Italian foods.

NEW ORLEANS, April 8 (AP) -A Federal appeals court reversed itself today and said that the American Tobacco Company was not liable for the death of a smoker from lung cancer.

Corporate merger activity continued at a record pace in the first quarter of 1969, according to two private surveys released yesterday.

The rank and file organization of the city's 30,000-man police force filed suit yesterday to void a 10-day-old state law granting the Police Department the right to change the basic deployment of the force from a three-platoon to a four-platoon system.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Dr. David H. Goldstein, president of the Industrial Medical Association, said today that narcotics addiction was a much greater problem than employers realized because addicted employes were so clever at concealing it.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 9 -- The enemy fired four giant rockets into the outskirts of Saigon last night. It was the seventh such attack on the capital and its suburbs since the enemy offensive was launched Feb. 22.
