SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 -- A Palo Alto mother's contention that she had the parental authority to prevent her son from registering in the draft was rejected when a Federal court jury convicted her son today.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 8 (UPI) -- Rick Barry of the Oakland Oaks, who missed more than half the season, has won the scoring and free-throw percentage titles in the American Basketball Association, according to the final statistics issued today.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., April 8 (AP) -- The will of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, leaving most of the estate to his widow, was filed for probate today with the Adams County register of wills here.
Hard by the entrance to the Man in Africa exhibit on the second floor of the American Museum of Natural History a temporary barrier of wallboard has been erected to keep the public out.
The first international baseball game in the major leagues was played yesterday before 44,541 persons at Shea Stadium and, in any language, the New York Mets and Montreal Expos made history.
When the gate opened in the feature at Aqueduct yesterday, a 4-year-old colt named Straight Ahead went to his knees.

NEW HAVEN, April 8 -- Forty years ago in Victoria, Australia, an adolescent boy used to accompany his father, a Methodist circuit rider, on his visits to the quiet churches in the sheep country. In the Depression years that followed, in the hard-hit city of Melbourne, the boy noticed that his father's dramatic preaching style took on the tones of a social gospel.
A scheduled hearing of seven teachers before the governing board of the experimental school complex at Intermediate School 201 in Harlem was postponed yesterday until tomorrow.

A Moscow newspaper charged yesterday that Soviet diplomats and journalists living in New York City were victims of an organized crime campaign. The charges were quickly denied by Mayor Lindsay, the Police Department and the United States Mission to the United Nations.

R. H. Macy Co., Inc., which operates the Macy's and Bamberger's department stores, reported yesterday that sales and net income set records in the fiscal first half, ended Feb. 1.

Jet service between New York and Martha's Vineyard will begin this summer, perhaps as early as the July 4, under an airport-improvement plan announced yesterday by Crocker Snow, chairman of the Massachusetts Aeronautics Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Despite Congressional criticism and citizens' complaints about invasion of privacy, the Federal Government has gone ahead with plans for next year's population count on the assumption that all answers will be mandatory.
GALE Industries thudded to a new low of 5 1/4 yesterday and finished at 6, down 1 1/2 on the day, on a 77,000-share turnover.

THE New York Mets were subjected to an infinite variety of embarrassments in their seven previous seasons. But their patient fans accepted with understanding their mistreatment by the big boys on the established clubs. Yesterday, though, a crowning indignity was heaped upon them. They were beaten in a grossly untidy opening-day game at Shea Stadium by those upstart Johnny-come-latelies, the Montreal Expos.

Michael Butler, the Middle West industrialist, who made his Broadway producing debut with the hit "Hair," will present another rock musical next season, based on Mary Shelley's horror classic, "Frankenstein."
Former Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday that he was giving "strong consideration" to seeking the Democratic nomination for his former post.

Mayor Lindsay, in his first direct criticism of the Nixon Administration, said yesterday that he was troubled by the high priority that the White House had given defense spending -- especially the antiballistic missile system -- at the possible expense of the cities.
HOUSTON, April 8 -- Haskell Karp, the first person ever to rest his slim chance for life on a manmade heart, died today of complications resulting from that pioneer surgery.

The Penn Central Company in its annual report, mailed to stockholders yesterday, predicted "smoother and more efficient railroad operations" because of the experience gained in its first year since merging.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 -"I don't think my game is a question mark any more," suggested Billy Casper after his 66 led the opening round of the Masters golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -Henry S. Ruth, a professor of law at the University of Pennsylvania and a member of the Pennsylvania Crime Commission, has been named acting director of the new National Institute of Law Enforcement and Criminal Justice.
FAIRFAX, Va., April 10 (UPI) -- Deputy Assistant Defense Secretary George E. Fouch was found guilty today of taking $6.13 worth of hardware from a department store without paying for it.
Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that he had not yet taken a public position on the controversial subject of public ownership of brokerage houses.
A raison d'etre for physical education is character development through leadership (defined as a technique to secure imitation).

MONTREAL, April 10 -- The Montreal Canadiens, on their own wave length with their historic, somewhat mystical, past, stampeded back from a two-goal deficit and defeated the Boston Bruins, 3-2, in overtime tonight in the first game of their Stanley Cup East Division final series.

The Pro Arte Symphony of Hofstra University, with a chorus of more than 200, four brass bands and Arturo Sergi, tenor, will perform Berlioz's Requiem on April 18 and 19 at the Nassau Community College Fieldhouse. Eleazar de Carvalho will conduct.

EDISON, N. J., April 10 -- Reports that the Nixon Administration is preparing to close down the Kilmer Job Corps Center here caused shock and dismay today among most of the 1,700 youths currently enrolled in the program.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Nixon today named Carl J. Gilbert, chairman of the executive committee of the Gillette Company and a long-time advocate of liberal trade policies, to head the Office of Special Representative for Trade Negotiations.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- J. L. Robertson, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that it was "not fair" to permit one-bank holding companies that have long since acquired nonbanking affiliates to retain control of them when other bank-holding companies were prohibited from having such affiliates.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Before leaving the trip, Mr. Murphy and Mr. Bellmon telephoned statements to their Washington offices for release to the press.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation was accused yesterday of eavesdropping on a conference in the United States Courthouse in Chicago between lawyers and eight defendants under indictment for conspiracy to incite a riot at the Democratic National Convention in August.

High-ranking members of the Harvard administration and faculty said yesterday that the uprising by a group of radical students that was suppressed there yesterday had been planned and threatened for more than three weeks.
A 90-day jail sentence against Representative Adam Clayton Powell for criminal contempt of court was revoked yesterday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.
The National Association of Manufacturers took a hard look yesterday at the spreading tide of "consumerism" and suffered something of a black eye in the process.
Prices on the Tokyo stock market soared yesterday to peak levels for the second time this week.

Welfare rights groups filed suit in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday in a move to block state welfare officials from implementing the new schedule of sharply altered relief payments set by the Legislature last month.

DALLAS, April 10 (AP) -- The president of the American Stock Exchange expressed concern today over the competitive pressures on institutional portfolio managers for "performance" -- quick profits in stock transactions.

James Radice, president of Traffic Squad Benevolent Association, charged yesterday that the "Hierarchy" of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association had lost touch with the rank and file of policemen. He announced he would run for president of the P.B.A. in an attempt to displace the incumbent, John Cassese.
A champagne party on the New York State Theater's promenade will follow the opening of the New York City Ballet on April 22. The evening will benefit the East Harlem Protestant Parish.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 10 (UPI) -- Bill Flett's 14-foot rebound shot late in the second period tonight gave Los Angeles Kings a 4-3 victory over the Oakland Seals and evened the National Hockey League's West playoffs at three games each.

DETROIT, April 10 -- For the first time in its 66-year history the National Catholic Educational Association will give a policy-making voice to teachers and to non-Catholic educators who will become part of the restructured organization.

LILLY PULITZER, Ulla Erikson, Ken Scott and Emilio Pucci, whose designs are normally found in the fashion departments at Lord Taylor, are now also turning up on the home furnishings floors. The store has built a series of model rooms around their decorator prints, which may be bought by the yard or in various accessories.
An auction of jewels brought $1,287,310 yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries. A rare light blue diamond in a ring went for $160,000, the costliest bauble in the sale.

A report carried in yesterday's New York Times that the Metropolitan Museum had attributed to Leonardo da Vinci its $225 plaster bust of a young woman called "Lady With the Primroses" is in error, according to the museum's director, Thomas P. F. Hoving.

Wade Van Dore, a 69-year-old keeper of a small motel in Clearwater Beach, Fla., who worked as a farm hand for Robert Frost, received a $3,500 award last night from the Poetry Society of America to aid a work in progress, a memoir centering on the famous poet.
A new form of contraceptive, which involves treatment only once a month, has shown promise in initial tests on a small group of women, a California obstetrician reported yesterday.

In the 1970's, men expect to be spending 30, 50, perhaps 100 days at a stretch in space. Next month a macaque, or pigtail monkey -- now in training at Cape Kennedy, Fla. -- will prepare the way with a 30-day test run in orbit.
Two former Lever Bros. boys are bringing the Benrus Corporation into the package goods business. They haven't stopped making watches, they're just selling them like soap.

Loyal Ruler won her second race in a row in taking the main event at Aqueduct yesterday. George D. Widener's home-bred filly responded to the expert guidance of Bill Boland to register a two-length triumph over Winsome Lea in the mile event for fillies and mares.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, April 10 -- Pakistan's new military ruler, Gen. Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, said today that army would not move precipitately to hand over power to the people or to their elected representatives.

Impending budget cuts at the city's 20 municipal hospitals are running about $23-million below original projections, but it may still be necessary to close "one or more" hospitals to make the cuts, Hospital Commissioner Joseph V. Terenzio said yesterday.

The resignation of Granger Costikyan as president and chief executive officer of First Bank System, Inc., Minneapolis, to become a general partner of Brown Brothers Harriman Co., the nation's largest private bank, was announced yesterday.

BALTIMORE, April 10 -- Dr. Denton A. Cooley defended today his use of an artificial heart in an attempt to save a patient's life. He said he would try the same method again when the circumstances are right.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

The United States Freight Company and the Tropical Gas Company announced yesterday that they had agreed in principle on plans to merge Tropical Gas into United States Freight, the nation's largest freight-forwarding concern.

ROME, April 10 -- Pope Paul VI announced measures today to shorten and decentralize the road to beatification and sainthood for "men and women noteworthy for heroic virtue."

The Allied Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that preliminary figures for the first quarter indicated earnings would be about 53 cents a share compared with 51 cents a share on an adjusted basis in the 1968 quarter. The George Foster Peabody Awards Committee has decided not to present an award this year to any network television entertainment program. This is only the second time that the category has been omitted since the broadcasting awards were extended to television in 1949.

The St. Louis Cardinals came to town yesterday in rare straits for a defending champion -- three defeats in a row, no victories this season and an unassailable claim on last place in the National League.

PARIS, April 11 -- European central bankers are intensifying pressures against the United States in an attempt to shield their financial markets from the effects of rising American interest rates.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -President Nixon has chosen Donald Rumsfeld, a young Republican Representative from Chicago's North Shore, to be the new head of the Office of Economic Opportunity, White House sources said tonight.

Platinum futures resumed their downtrend yesterday, and the soon-to-expire April contract bore the brunt of the selling. It closed at $213 6/10 an ounce, down almost $6 from Thursday's close of $219 1/2.

FOR only the third time in its long and distinguished history, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has mounted a one-man show by a living artist. President Nixon's appointment of Carl J. Gilbert as his Special Representative for Trade Negotiations met with enthusiastic approval among members of the foreign-trade community yesterday.

BATTIPAGLIA, Italy, April 11 -- With nervous solemnity, citizens of this little town today buried the two persons killed during street rioting over economic conditions Wednesday. Six others were hospitalized with gunshot wounds among more than 200 policemen and civilians injured.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) -- The Air Force announced today that its Reserve Officer Training Corps program would be discontinued at eight colleges and universities because the required annual officer quota had not been met.

The New York Stock Exchange fined yesterday White Co., Inc., a St. Louis brokerage firm, and its two principal officers a total of $110,000 for violating exchange and regu latory agency rules. WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) -- President Nixon will propose tomorrow his own budget for next year. The Senate Democratic leadership made clear that the biggest item -- defense spending -- would be their battleground.

ANGUILLA, April 11 (AP) -A crowd of angry Anguillans surrounded the residence of the British Commissioner, Anthony Lee, today and tried to storm it.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -President Nixon sharply curtailed today the trans-Pacific route awards that were initially made by President Johnson but were overturned pending a review after Mr. Nixon took office.

Sirhan? I don't understand."

MONTREAL, April 13 -- "You and me, we're going to get ourselves a drink after the game, eh?" said beaming Charles Bronfman to one of the supervisors working overtime this weekend at Jarry Park, where the Expos will usher in major league baseball in Canada tomorrow.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, April 13 -- Like the 49 other states, Alaska has a generation gap, but with a difference.
FAYETTE, Miss. -- While pink azaleas, purple wisteria and black power politics blossom together, the white people in this quiet little Delta town are learning what it means to be a minority group.

It was a lovely spring weekend, especially for Compton Advertising, which picked up the United States Steel Corporation account. It's got to be worth about $4-million in billings. And prestige? My dear, you have no idea.
Are you going to cheat tonight?

A growing number of bond dealers are becoming convinced that late March, 1969, likely will turn out to have been a major turning point for interest rates, equal in importance to October, 1965, when yields ended years of stability and began to climb to levels not seen in a century.

ADEN, Southern Yemen, April 13 -- Premier Faisal Abdul Latif al-Shaabi charged at a news conference here today that Saudi Arabia was continuing to carry out armed incursions into this country by using enemies of Southern Yemen's ruling National Liberations Front who had taken refuge in Saudi Arabia.

CHICAGO, April 13 (UPI) -A youthful sailor, making the most of a weekend pass, danced playfully across the stage of a tawdry Chicago movie house early today with a spotlight marking his path. The path led to death.

Three long-haired teen-age boys dressed in the latest Edwardian fashions gave a remarkable concert in Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon under the auspices of the American Society of Ancient Instruments.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13 -Just as Bruce Devlin reached the fifth green today the attendant on the big scoreboard nearby was removing the Australian's nameplate from the list of leaders. In its way Devlin's ignominy epitomized the brutal fact of tournament golf: one man wins and all the others lose, each in his own way.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 13 -- At a session marked by boos and shouting matches, a statewide Democratic party reform conference approved today a series of demands envisioning equality for black, brown and youth minorities in the California party structure.

For many thousands of New Yorkers, the blue skies and sunshine of spring were blotted out over the weekend by columns of figures and legalistic verbiage in the pressure cookers of accountants' offices.

BALTIMORE, April 13 (AP) -Jim Palmer pitched a five-hit shutout and Tom Phoebus followed with a two-hit blanking today as the Baltimore Orioles swept a double-header from the Washington Senators, 2-0 and 9-0.

PRAGUE, April 13 -- The Defense Ministry announced today that Czechoslovakia would join new Warsaw Pact maneuvers with the Soviet Union, Hungary, Poland and "other countries," presumably Bulgaria and East Germany.
WEST HAVEN, Conn. -- The bagel business isn't what it used to be. It's better.

The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor will begin this week to distribute applications from would-be longshoremen in an effort to reopen the port's longshore register, or list of certificated workers.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13 -- Cowboy George Archer, a personable, articulate giant of 6 feet 6 inches and 185 pounds, is no more a cowboy than Elizabeth Taylor, after whom he names one of his two daughters, but Cowboy is a nickname that has been glued to him, and he may be stuck with it till the cows come home.

BOSTON, April 13 -- Many of the Boston Celtics used the word "lucky" in describing aspects of their victory over the New York Knickerbockers today. But their dressing room comments were perhaps charitable, for the Celtics used brawn, speed, accuracy and brainwork to edge the Knicks, 97-96, before 13,506 fans at Boston Garden.

CRANSTON, R. I., April 13 -Mr. and Mrs. Howard Sherline's Old English Sheepdog Ch. Prince Andrew of Sherline was named best in show today over an entry of 1,213 at the Rhode Island Kennel Club's 64th annual event held at Rhodes-onthe-Pawtuxet ballroom.

THESE collections of stories are the first by two American writers with impressive credentials. Leonard Michaels and Jonathan Strong have both been published in such prestigious literary magazines as Partisan Review, The Paris Review and TriQuarterly. Both have appeared in anthologies like "Prize Stories: The O. Henry Awards" and "The American Literary Anthology," the annual collection sponsored by the National Endowment for the Arts.

MIAMI, April 13 (AP) -- A Pan American Airways jetliner with 91 persons aboard on a flight from San Juan, Puerto Rico, to Miami was diverted to Cuba today by four men reported to have been armed with pistols and knives.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -The scope and nature of Soviet strategic weapons deployment has puzzled senior Government analysts to the point where it may play an important role in the Administration's fight for an antiballistic missile system.

An ominous toughening of Moscow's attitude toward political heresy in Eastern Europe has made this year's early spring a time of tension rather than exhilaration in that area. First the Kremlin used antiSoviet demonstrations in Czechoslovakia as a lever to force tight press censorship in Prague. Then it unleashed a bitter newspaper campaign against Yugoslavia.

First the Kremlin used antiSoviet demonstrations in Czechoslovakia as a lever to force tight press censorship in Prague. Then it unleashed a bitter newspaper campaign against Yugoslavia.
The New York City school teachers will begin a drive this week in the Legislature to push through a bill liberalizing pension benefits for city school teachers.

A five-week tour of the Middle East, focusing on Israel and neighboring Arab states, underscored for this observer the urgency of Big Power action, through the United Nations, to promote and guarantee a settlement.

CAMBRIDGE Mass., April 13 -- Shortly after he became president of Harvard in 1953, Nathan Marsh Pusey faced down, at long range, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, the late right-wing chairman of the Permanent Senate Subcommittee on Investigations, who, in an apparent effort to settle an old political score, accused the university of being soft on Communism.

A confrontation between the Board of Education and the governing board of a Harlem demonstration district is expected today as no progress has been reported toward settlement of a dispute involving seven teachers.
A major container pool is preparing for the day when it will offer 20-foot containers rugged enough to be "completely interchangeable" between air and surface modes of transportation.

Almost two years after the minuscule Caribbean island of Anguilla seceded from the Associated State of St. KittsNevis-Anguilla, Prime Minister Robert L. Bradshaw of the central government maintains his adamant opposition to what he calls "the rebellion" and breakup of the state.

YOU'D never know it from the frequency with which his name crops up when people are talking fashion, but Rudi Gernreich has kept his promise of last October to take a year's sabbatical from designing.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 13 -- Five of the finest contributors to college and professional basketball were inducted into the Hall of Fame today.

MOSCOW, April 13 -- From Yelokhovskaya Cathedral early this morning, the murmur of liturgical chant drifted to the sidewalk on Spartakovskaya Street. The church was crowded to bursting, as it always is for midnight mass on the Russian Easter.
WHEN the first chair you introduce looks like a wedge of watermelon served on a footed silver dish, what do you do for encores?

In an April 4 news story in The Times, the Rev. James Gunther of the Interfaith Citywide Coordinating Committee Against Poverty is quoted as supporting ". . . the positive use of violence" in order to rectify the recent New York State Legislature's decision to reduce the state welfare budget.

The Board of Regents' plan for decentralizing the city public school system was favored yesterday in a joint statement by the secretaries for education of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and the Diocese of Brooklyn.

YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories -- Canada's three largest unsubsidized gold mines, including two whose shares are traded in New York, have fattened their profits appreciably in the year since the major powers stopped holding down the commercial price of gold.
The cause of freer world trade was at once advanced and set back by President Nixon's appointments last week to the Office of the Special Trade Representative.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -The nation's railroads and the 10,000-member signalmen's union settled today a wage dispute that had threatened to bring trains to a halt around the country tomorrow morning.

MONTREAL, April 13 -Mickey Redmond, who didn't realize he had scored until he heard most of the 17,897 hysterical fans screaming, deflected a shot today and gave the Montreal Canadiens another overtime victory against the Boston Bruins in their Stanley Cup East Divisional final series.
BEEHIVE COVE, St. John, V. I., April 13 -- The Project Tektite aquanauts spent their 58th day beneath the Caribbean today making scientific observations and conducting experiments.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -The invitations to the White House reception read "black tie." But the great big butterfly bow tie worn tonight by W. Clement Stone of Chicago was pale blue, to contrast with his bright blue shirt and his big, big Cuban cigar.

The American Jewish Congress has asserted that there is "greater compliance" with the Supreme Court's decisions of 1963 forbidding devotional practices in public schools than with the Court's 1954 decision outlawing racial segregation in schools.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 13 -- Henry T. (Hank) Hornidge Jr. of the Larchmont Yacht Club won the annual spring regatta for the third successive year today.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio -Three connecting, two-story brick buildings stand serene atop a small mound on the main road through Antioch College's 100-acre campus here, looking much like a suburban garden apartment complex.

DETROIT, April 13 -- Car sales at the General Motors Corporation warmed up in early April with 130,732 auto deliveries reported, up 6 per cent from 122,854 a year before. G.M. sales during April 1-10 were second only to 133,405 in the comparable 1965 period.
BONN, April 13 -- West Germany's new Communist party made it clear this weekend that it would follow the Moscow line.

A FAMILIAR parrot-cry in social bridge games is "eight ever, nine never." This refers to the advisability of finessing for a queen when the declaring side has eight or nine cards in a suit and, as with most such cries, the parrots are right up to a point.
ZINDER, Niger, April 9 -- The paved road comes to an end in this isolated, dust-colored market town on the southern shore of the sand sea known as the Sahara.

CLAYTON LAKE, Me., April 7 -- When we stepped from our plane, a Cessna 185, onto snow-covered Clayton Lake, we sank to our thighs and had to don snowshoes before setting out for the International Paper Company logging headquarters a few hundred yards away at the edge of a spruce forest.
LONDON, April 14 -- Wildcat strikers shut an engineering plant in the Midlands today in a dispute over the length of an apprentice welder's hair. The workers went back tonight after a compromise.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- In what amounted to an informal State of the Union Message, President Nixon hinted for the first time today at the details and dimensions of his forthcoming domestic program.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 14 -- An African testified in court here today that he had twice been burned with an electric Shock machine in jail.

Abbott H. (Abbie) Hoffman; the 32-year-old militant Yippie leader who says he has been arrested 37 times, said yesterday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation "is trying to infiltrate us."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 14 -- Informed sources said today that top generals of the Yugoslav Army had been quietly purged on orders of President Tito, and Yugoslavia's defense strategy had been altered as a result of the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia last August.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Army took today its first formal disciplinary action against a soldier-editor of one of the antiwar antimilitary underground G.I. newspapers that have been appearing at a growing number of military bases in recent months.

Earnings of the Kaiser Aluminum Chemical Corporation in the first quarter fell to $11,219,000, or 60 cents a share, from the record $15,584,000, or 85 cents a share earned in the 1968 period. Sales, however, rose to $221,524,000 from $209,481,000.

Crowell Collier, which has been out of the magazine business since it folded Collier's, American Magazine and Woman's Home Companion in 1956, has quietly returned to that field, but in a far different way.

LONDON, April 14 (AP) -- Britain gave a last salute to its wartime commander, Dwight D. Eisenhower, in solemn rites at St. Paul's today.
Trading remained moderately active yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, but prices edged down in the final hour.

LOS ANGELES, April 14 -- Two best actresses -- Barbra Streisand and Katharine Hepburn -- were named tonight for the first time in the 41-year history of awards presentations by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

MONTREAL, April 14 -- It used to be a quiet, sleepy place, especially on Monday morning, in the section known as Little Italy. But suddenly today there was a traffic jam, a massive one, and inside refurbished Jarry Park some of the most enthusiastic fans baseball has seen for some time greeted major league baseball in Canada. Montreal may never be the same.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- "Head Start never was intended as a one-shot inoculation that would save the child for the rest of his life."

In Italy, the average wage-earner can rely on what a tax lawyer there called "the inefficiency of the bureaucracy" to avoid paying most of his taxes.

LOS ANGELES, April 14 -- The murder trial of Sirhan B. Sirhan, the self-admitted killer of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, went to the jury this afternoon after 60 days of courtroom proceedings.
TOKYO, April 14 -- "We have a strong card on the Okinawa problem that we will never play," a Japanese diplomat said recently.
DETROIT, April 14 -- The Chrysler Corporation reported today a 25 per cent drop in first-quarter earnings, compared with those of a year earlier, despite record sales in the latest three months.
Last week's stock market rally faded a bit yesterday as trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange slipped to its lowest level in three weeks.
The American Stock Exchange is considering raising the fees it charges to member firms and listed companies as a means of paying for its automation program, Ralph S. Saul, president, said yesterday,

ON Thursday, May 8, 1902, Mt. Pelee, a volcanic mountain dominating the city of St. Pierre on the French island of Martinique, blew one of its sides in the form of an enormous fireball that passed over the city like a devil's hand, incinerating and asphyxiating every living thing in its path and burning even the ships at sea.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A Securities and Exchange Commission staff study recommended today that extensive changes be made in both the substance and the form of corporate disclosure of information to the public.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 14 -- Nearly 6,000 Harvard students voted narrowly at a rally today to continue a student strike three more days. The strike was begun last week to protest use of the police against radical students who had seized a building.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 14 -- South Vietnam has quietly shifted its emphasis in land reform away from a proposed $100-million program. Land reform officials will concentrate instead on selling nearly 400,000 acres of Government-owned ricelands to tenant farmers at as little as one-tenth of the open-market price.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Congress returned today from a pulse-taking Easter recess back home that apparently found the voters discontented over Vietnam and disgruntled about taxes and inflation but still tolerant toward the Nixon Administration.
The management of the state-owned Long Island Rail Road yesterday found itself embroiied in a labor problem involving 12 "mini-uniformed" clerk-advisers.
PRAGUE, April 14 -- Alexander Dubcek, the Communist party chief, was reported today to be going to Moscow for talks on changes expected this week in the Czechoslovak leadership.
CARTAGENA, Colombia, April 14 (AP) -- A young man held a knife to the pilot's throat and forced him to fly a Colombian airliner with 29 persons aboard to Cuba today, the authorities here said.
Coach Red Holzman and his Knicks just were not ready for the long hot summer the Boston Celtics planned for them last night at Madison Square Garden.

The Chase Manhattan Bank took a look through the nineteen-seventies yesterday and came up with a forecast of the economy in the next decade. Its conclusion: A prosperous future, with king-sized problems.

Certain operatic roles have a kind of built-in success: They require such specialized talents that if a singer can do one of them at all, he or she is practically fail-proof.
WASHINGTON, April--Total business inventories resumed their strong growth in February, the Commerce Department reported today.

MILAN, Italy, Tuesday, April 15 (Reuters) -- More than 1,000 policemen using tear-gas grenades charged into San Vittore Jail here early today to try to regain control of the prison from about 1,500 rioting convicts.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 14 -- The chief delegates of the four major powers met individually with King Hussein of Jordan today and then held their third joint discussion on a Middle East peace settlement.

ALBANY, April 14 -- The Republican-ruled Legislature starting a push for adjournment by the end of the month, reconvenes tomorrow after a two-week spring holiday facing some major unresolved ussues including abortion-law reform and the decentralization of the New York City school system.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 14 -- The chairman of Resorts International, Inc., told stockholders at a special meeting here today that the company had decided to cut back its planned purchase of Pan American World Airways stock to 4.8 pet cent from nearly 10 per cent because "it seems to be an amount that makes everybody a little happier."

The Right Rev. James A. Pike, the former Episcopal Bishop of California, has announced plans to leave the Episcopal Church and set up a "Church alumni foundation" for people on the fringes of organized religion.

DETROIT, April 14 -- All four car manufacturers have reported sales gains for the first third of April. The Ford Motor Company, the Chrysler Corporation and the American Motors Corporation said today that sales exceeded those of the comparable 1968 period. The General Motors Corporation had announced its increase yesterday.

Harper Row believes it has a best seller on its winter list with a novel by the Colombian author Gabriel Garcia Marquez, "One Hundred Years of Solitude." It has already caused a literary furor in Latin America and Europe.

VIENNA, April 14 -- Premier Todor Zhivkov of Bulgaria arrived here today on an official five-day visit, apparently to sound out the Austrian Government on the recent Warsaw Pact appeal for a European security conference.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 14 (AP) -- Fence Post Farm's Red Spice II, claimed out of scored his fourth straight victory previous start for $30,000, tory today when he won the ninth race at Golfstream Park.

A silver jet whistled to a landing at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn one recent afternoon and Marine Pfc. Kenny Ledgerwood of Canandaigua, N. Y., was carried down the ramp, some blood seeping through a thick gauze bandage on his right leg.

EQUITABLE LIFE won the Metropolitan Commercial Bridge League team championship last month, maintaining the monopoly of the insurance teams in the face of a challenge from a strong International Business Machines Corporation team.

Sharp questions by City Councilmen at a public hearing yesterday indicated doubts that they could support Mayor Lindsay's proposal for reorganization of the city's health services under a public benefit corporation.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Nixon promised today that the problems of the Western Hemisphere would have the "highest priority" in his Administration.
LONDON, April 14 -- In the face of the most serious party revolt in years, the Labor Government was reported tonight to have decided to press for early legislation against wildcat strikes.

Three young singers from England who call themselves the Young Tradition offered a program of traditional, unaccompanied harmony singing in a slightly untraditional fashion last night at the Washington Square Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

THERE was good news yesterday for the beleaguered shareholders of the Dumont Corporation. The Securities and Exchange Commission announced in Washington that Dumont securities could be traded again starting next Monday.
JERUSALEM, April 14 -- Israeli and Egyptian jet aircraft fought over the Suez Canal this morning and artillery, tank and small-arms fire blazed throughout the day across the waterway.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 14 -- Serious misgivings about the plans for very large underground nuclear explosions in Nevada and the Aleutians were expressed here today by Dr. Kenneth S. Pitzer, president of Stanford University.
SANTA BARBARA, April 14 (AP) -- The oil slick that blackened 800 square miles of Santa Barbara Channel two months ago has shrunk until it is hardly visible from shore.

Alex Rose, chief tactician of the Liberal party, said yesterday that an "indicated trend" in favor of the renomination of Mayor Lindsay had "crystallized" within the party.
CHICAGO, April 14 (UPI) -- Ken Holtzman recovered after a shaky start to pitch a seven-hitter and the Chicago Cubs collected 11 hits to defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates today, 4-0.

LIMA, Peru, April 14 (Reuters) -- President Juan Velasco Alvarado of Peru today demanded Latin-American solidarity with Peru, which is engaged in a dispute with the United States over the expropriation of the International Petroleum Company.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) -- A 72-year-old spinster said today she was not going to pay anymore income taxes until the Government refunds the $73,000 excess she says she has paid over the last 20 years just because she is unmarried.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., April 14 -- A group of high-school students who believe that democratic processes should be exhausted before relying on drastic means to achieve their demands have selected their own candidate to run for the school board here.

THE refurbished, re-electrified, refitted Electric Circus swung into action last night. A lot of money has gone into the effort, including an architectural revision in which the place looks different depending on the location of the viewer.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -The Defense Department said today that Secretary Melvin R. Laird had ruled against a proposal that would have permitted defense contractors to charge the Governmeent for a percentage of charitable contributions.

State Supreme Court Justice Sidney A. Fine reserved decision yesterday on a technical but crucial question in a suit in which two city agencies are at loggerheads over a proposed apartment house across from Lincoln Center.

TORONTO, April 14 -- One of Canada's biggest base-metals mines will come into production in 1972, and its entire output, chiefly copper, will be purchased by Japanese companies, it was announced today by the Lornex Mining Corporation, Ltd., in Vancouver.

A Polish journalist, formerly consul in Detroit and vice consul in Chicago, yesterday made known his decision to seek asylum in the United States after years of "doubts about the basic validity of Communism."

Hard blows are being inflicted upon Czechoslovak journalists these days. The reimposition of pre-censorship and the suspension of some key weeklies have been followed by the summoning of newspapermen to appear before a Communist party inquisition. The result threatens to be the expulsion from Czechoslovakia's newspaper world of some of that country's bravest and ablest reporters and editors.

A "strike force council" for New York's Southern District, for which United States Attorney General John N. Mitchell has drawn up the blueprint, would remove United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau from top leadership in the drive against organized crime in this area.

The computer's growing ability to generate profits was demonstrated yesterday as the International Business Machines Corporation and Honeywell, Inc., both announced sharply higher earnings for the quarter ended March 31.

Representative James H. Scheuer's attacks on former Mayor Robert F. Wagner have caused the resignation of the honorary co-chairman of his mayoral campaign committee and have led to a dispute with his running-mate for Controller, Vincent L. Broderick.

As black students marched into Columbia University's Hamilton Hall yesterday to occupy the admissions office, an administrator who lived through last year's student revolt put his head in his hands and said, "Oh, God, the same thing is starting all over again."
The General Foods Corporation yesterday offered nearly $117-million for Britain's second-largest candy maker, Rowntree Co., Ltd. The largest is Cadbury Brothers, Ltd.

To the Editor: Barry H. Gerard [letter April 5] has written about the sad state of the cemetery surrounding Saint Mark's in the Bowery -- and of course he is right. It has been dreadful for a long time, and has been a source of much pain to us all.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) -- Bipartisan opponents of an antiballistic missile system urged the Senate today to divorce the issue from politics. Although the ABM's political implications have been smoldering in private offices for weeks, it was the first time the subject reached the Senate floor.
The Irving Trust Company named Gordon T. Wallis yesterday as vice chairman of its board of directors.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 14 -- Rum Customer, last year's triple crown champion with a perfect 1969 record in two appearances, returns to Roosevelt Raceway next Saturday for the $25,000 free-for-all Bye Bye Byrd Invitation.

Although they are now selling their "new look" of youth and speed, the New York Yankees moved yesterday to avoid the extreme of opening their home season without a left-handed home-run threat to use as a pinch hitter in Yankee Stadium.

CHICAGO, April 15 UPI -Frank Kulak, surrounded by policemen, his face devoid of emotion, was charged today with the murder of two policemen in a six-hour battle during which the disabled exmarine used guns, grenades and homemade bombs.

Supporters of the Little Orchestra Society will have an opportunity on Sunday afternoon to take an advance look at more than 30 watercolors by Dong Kingman at a benefit preview at the Hammer Galleries, 51 East 57th Street.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -Western diplomats believe that Prince Sihanouk of Cambodia may be preparing for an eventual Cambodian role in an enlarged Vietnam peace conference, presumably to get outside Communist forces to leave his country as part of an overall settlement.

MONTE CARLO, April 15 (AP) -- Arthur Ashe and Pancho Gonzalez won third-round matches, but Dennis Ralston, the United States professional, was upset by Francois Jauffret in the third round of the Monte Carlo open tennis tournament today.

Your editorial "Again, Too Much, Too Late" (April 4) contains criticism of the Federal Reserve Board for increasing member bank reserve requirements, criticism which is indeed too much, too late. The Federal Reserve deserved strong criticism for its policies following the 1966 money crunch.

HOUSTON, April 15 -- The nation's Roman Catholic bishops took steps today to win more recruits to the priesthood, after learning that the number of seminarians in theological schools has dropped 12 per cent in the last three years.

ISTVAN KERTESZ had some fun with the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Philharmonic Hall. He programed Haydn's "Farewell" Symphony and went through it with all the trimmings. Then he conducted Schubert's big C major Symphony with terrific exuberance, as though he were having the best time in the world.
NIAMEY, Niger, April 12 -Hamani Diori's favorite word, in any of the five languages he speaks, is "dialogue."
Walter W. Heller, the father of the idea, acknowledges that business was stoutly opposed to the 7 per cent investment tax credit when it was proposed at the outset of the Kennedy Administration.
The New York City Opera folds up shop this week and, on the basis of last night's performance of Puccini's "La Boheme," it sounds -- and looks -as if the company can use the rest.

Pan American's plan to pick up and check in passengers and their luggage at a half dozen airline bus subterminals around New York could become one of the most constructive programs to relieve congestion -- both at the airports and on the jammed highways. More than smiling hostesses and sliding snacks, this is a step that could really help to make the going great.
WHEN Mrs. Ezra K. Zilkha was a 16-year-old bride in Cairo, she asked the cook to make something "extraordinary" for her first large dinner party. He did.

The National Orchestral Association offered a Brahms program last night for its fourth and last Carnegie Hall concert of the season. Two works were played -- the Symphony No. 2 in D and the Piano Concerto No. 2 in B-flat major.

A group of dissident students at Queens College voted yesterday to "escalate" their sit-in by taking over today the top three floors of the 13-story Academic II building, which houses the offices of two deans and the president.

A long time ago, when I was rummaging through old issues of The New York Times, I came across an article, written more than 60 years ago, about a young reporter's marathon visit with Feddor Chaliapin, the protean Russian basso. The writer was Carl Van Vechten and he described in vivid detail the immense amount of eating, drinking and talking that went on in an unbroken 12-hour session.

ALBANY, April 15 -- The United Federation of Teachers abruptly withdrew late tonight from a secret meeting with a group of Democratic legislators who had been seeking a compromise school decentralization plan for New York City.
Two independent educators here declared yesterday that Head Start programs for poor preschool children had improved the youngsters' behavior and their social confidence.

VIENNA, April 15 -- Dr. Sigvard Eklund, Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency, warned the nonnuclear countries today against premature optimism about nuclear explosions for peaceful purposes.
More than 2,000 women are expected at the Americana Hotel next Tuesday when the women's division of the Jewish Guild for the Blind holds its annual spring benefit luncheon.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -Following are the details of the budget changes proposed today by President Nixon:
ROME, April 15 (AP) -Rioting broke out at a prison in Bari today after the police had quelled uprisings of 2,000 prisoners in two other prisons and herded the prisoners to other jails.
TRENTON, April 15 -- At least 60 airplanes were destroyed today in a pre-dawn fire that wrecked the main hangar and terminal of the Mercer County Airport, five miles northwest of here.

The Republic Steel Corporation raised yesterday its prices for hot and cold finished carbon anti alloy-bar steel by about $6.60 a ton. The new prices are effective April 28, and are the first major increase in these items since August, 1967.

A copy of the first printing of the Constitution of the United States, one of eight copies known to have survived, was auctioned yesterday for $155,000, a record price. It was the copy of Pierce Butler, a delegate from South Carolina to the Federal Convention of 1787, which finally worked out the foundation of Government.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- A welfare other suggested to the Senate hunger committee today that if the Federal Government can subsidize a United States Senator and others not to produce crops, "Why can't the poor be subsidized not to produce hunger?"

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 16 -- Not in recent memory -- certainly not since the days after the slaying of President Ngo Dinh Diem in 1963 -- has the Saigon political scene been so aboil with impending change.
It is sometimes wrong for a journalist to write without sufficient information -- especially when the author is James Reston and the subject is Harvard.

Three young men, including a soldier wounded in Vietnam, walked out of State Supreme Court yesterday, cleared of armed-robbery charges, after Brooklyn District Attorney Eugene Gold told Justice Guy J. Mangano they had been falsely accused.

The real estate industry charged yesterday that City Council leaders had "double-crossed" the industry in drawing up a bill that stiffens Mayor Lindsay's proposals for rent guidelines in most apartments not under control.
Leading industrial shares closed sharply lower on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The appointment of Franklin A. Long as the new director of the National Science Foundation is reported to have been blocked by the White House, largely because of his opposition to the antiballistic missile system.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The American Society of Newspaper Editors was told that "some dents have been made in news barriers at the Federal Government level" and that President Nixon's information chief "is trying to close the credibility gap in Washington."

TOKYO, Thursday, April 17 (Reuters) -- Defense Minister Choi Hyun of North Korea was quoted today as having said war might break out again in Korea "owing to the aggressive maneuvers of the U.S. imperialists."

CAIRO, April 16 -- Egyptian and Israeli artillery battled along the Suez Canal today for the ninth straight day. The fighting this month followed a declaration in Cairo that the clashes would continue until they reached an extent threatening an "explosion of the whole situation.
LANSING, Mich., April 16 -- Michigan moved today to outlaw the sale of DDT. It is the first of the 50 states to take such action.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- A strike deadline for 15,000 workers at Pan American World Airways was postponed late tonight for 24 hours by the Transport Workers Union.

CHICAGO, April 16 (UPI) -- The national chairman of the Remember the Pueblo Committee said today that his group had learned from "a reliable Government source" that the two North Korean aircraft that downed a United States reconnaissance plane had flown from a Soviet base and had first tried to force the American plane to land in North Korea.

The City Planning Commission made a zoning change yesterday designed to perserve Tudor City as a residential community and to protect three large apartment houses there from possible demolition for office construction.

The New York and the American Stock Exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports on changes in ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The reports include the following:

PARIS, April 16 -- High financial sources in Europe said today a South African drawing of $66.2-million from the International Monetary Fund may hasten agreement between Washington and Johannesburg on disposal of newly mined gold.

In a financing made possible by the decline in interest rates this month, the Florida State Board of Education, which had tried twice before, successfully sold yesterday $39-million of bonds at a cost below a 5 1/2 per cent interest rate ceiling.
MONTE CARLO, April 16 (Reuters) -- A tired Pancho Gonzalez was ousted, while Arthur Ashe and Andres Gimeno scraped through to the quarter-finals of the Monte Carlo open tennis tournament today.

Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Exchange, indicated yesterday that the exchange might oppose the Federal Trade Commission's recent suggestion that corporations should give it advance notice on mergers or take-overs.
In the wake of a Government report showing record supplies of frozen french fries in storage throughout the country, potato futures prices dropped sharply yesterday.

IF SOME of Martha Graham's dances have sometimes seemed obscure, much of their richness of texture comes from the revelations derived upon repeated viewing. Overlays of meaning not initially apparent are suddenly illuminated.

HOUSTON, April 16 -- The The American Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church acted today to simplify and speed up the procedures by which diocesan marriage tribunals determine whether divorced Catholics are free to remarry.
LISBON, April 16 -- Gen. Georgi Zakharov, veteran of the Spanish civil war and a Hero of the Soviet Union, stepped on Portuguese soil today.

It is indeed one of the tragedies of our times that the Governor, with his own personal interest in culture, with his family's gratifying contributions to the cultural activities of our nation, loses his perspective in relating state and city financial problems.

The Georgia-Pacific Corporation realized a 60.7 per cent rise in first-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 27.8 per cent, the international forest, gypsum and chemical operator reported yesterday from its Portland, Ore., headquarters.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Diplomatic action rather than military retaliation will be the Nixon Administration's essential response to North Korea's shooting down of a United States reconnaissance plane, officials indicated today.

ALBANY, April 16 -- The maneuvering and confusion surrounding the controversial New York City school decentralization issue intensified today as officials of the United Federation of Teachers resumed hastily canceled talks with a group of Democratic legislators.
It is jarring to find The Times [Editorial April 11] impressed with the empty words of King Hussein. "Significant concessions" indeed.
PRINCETON N.J., April 16 -- The Gallup Poll indicates that $102 is the median amount that the nonfarm public thinks is the minimum that a family of four now needs to get along each week.

BONN, April 16 -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans ran into stiff West German opposition today on his appeal for Western import restrictions against low-priced, synthetic textiles from the Far East and Italy. He said the imports were undermining the American textile industry.
JOE Pepitone just can't seem to break into the starting line-up these days. There are too many good players holding down outfield jobs and Pepitone is not able to push them aside.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 16 -With studies under way in five states and field work slated to start in five more, an ugly picture of "hidden hunger" in America is beginning to come into focus, an official of the Department of Health, Education, Education and Welfare reported today.

The Value Line Special Situations Fund, a leading performer in the mutual fund industry for a decade, has suspended the sale of its shares because of paperwork problems in the back office of its transfer agent.

WASHINGTON, April 16 - The Army, Navy and Air Force have increased the readiness of their fast-reaction forces even though the United States is not expected to retaliate militarily for the downing of a reconnaissance plane by North Korea.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 16 (AP) -- Mayor John Reading won a new four-year term yesterday, turning back the bid of Lawrence Joyner, the first Negro ever to wage a major campaign for mayor of this city of 400,000.
TRENTON, April 16 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes recommended today that the state regulate New Jersey's scandal-ridden garbage industry to end what he called "price gouging and collusive practices."

The Assembly today has its first opportunity to liberalize the cruel and archaic statute that allows legal abortions in New York State only to save the life of the mother. We share unreservedly Governor Rockefeller's conviction that the time has come to ease the unnecessary suffering caused by this 1883 law.

A computerized guidance and control system that should make rendezvous and docking between two vehicles as precise underwater as in outer space was shown yesterday by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

PITTSBURGH, April 16 -- The Jerry Koosman Fan Club of Appleton, Minn., suffered another rude jolt tonight. The pitching hero of the soybean farms was knocked out of the box inside three innings as the Pittsburgh Pirates demolished the New York Mets, 11-3.

TOKYO, April 16 -- Foreign Minister Kiichi Aichi is understood to have conveyed to the American charge d'affaires today Japanese concern lest the United States embark on some retaliatory action for the loss of the EC-121 reconnaissance plane yesterday, shot down by the North Koreans.

Despite public puzzlement, close friends of Robert F. Wagner agreed yesterday that he had taken the course they had hoped he would take in not asking the Liberal party to consider him for the mayoral nomination.
There are very few former Girl Scouts at the benefit dance held annually for the organization. But according to Mrs. Clyde Newhouse, it doesn't really matter.

SEOUL, South Korea, April 16 -- The mood of this city following the downing of a United States reconnaissance aircraft off North Korea yesterday is a curious mixture of tension, belligerence and a kind of "we've been through all this before" attitude.

SHOWER curtains are beginning to sprout the same designs that last year seemed so bold when they appeared on note papers. But compared to the diminutive, neoart-nouveau graphics on stationery, the new versions on Kleinert's shower curtains seem gargantuan.
The Newspaper Guild of New York conferred its annual Page One Award yesterday on The New York Times for the "Best Example of a Crusading Newspaper."

GENEVA, April 16 -- The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake said today that the visit Pope Paul is to make to the headquarters of the World Council of Churches would emphasize the "growing fellowship among Christians."

New York City's bid for a share in the Federal food stamp plan for needy people could confront the Nixon Administration with a new annual cost exceeding $100-million, according to available calculations yesterday.
PARIS, April 16 -- Independent stores of all kinds as well as cafes and restaurants were closed throughout France today to protest the Government's tax and economic policies.
The Federal Government questioned yesterday whether major sections of the state's amended welfare law reducing relief payments conformed with the requirements for Federal aid.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 16 (UPI) -- Jimmie Johnson, all-America quarterback for the Carlisle Indians in 1903, and seven other star players who performed at the turn of century will be inducted into the National Football Hail of Fame May 27, officials of the hall announced today.

LONDON, April 16 -- One trouble with the world today is that there is not enough international misunderstanding. For twenty or thirty years now, high-minded persons have been promoting the specious theory that happiness will prevail only when people understand each other, and look at the results.
The Royal Dorset Yacht Club of England has withdrawn its challenge for the 1970 America's Cup yacht races, the New York Yacht Club announced yesterday.
The Penn Central Company is about to borrow $375-million.
CLAYTON LAKE, Me., April 8 -- By 4 A.M., only a small pocket of flickering coals remained in our wood-burning stove, and the bunkhouse was cold.

FRANCIS POULENC'S little tour de force, his one-act opera "La Voix Humaine," was presented last night by the Juilliard Opera Theater at the Juilliard Concert Hall. Along with it was the American premiere of Arthur Honegger's "Antigone," another one-act opera.
NEW DELHI, April 16 (AP) -- The Indian Government disclosed today that it had urged the prosecution of one of the country's highest Hindu holy men for having advocated untouchability.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Talks will begin shortly to prepare for the resumption of diplomatic relations between the United States and Cambodia, which were broken nearly four years ago.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -The chairman of the House Subcommittee on Fisheries and Wildlife Conservation has asked the Interior Department to review permission for the Hudson River Expressway granted by the former Secretary of the Interior, Stewart L. Udall.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 16 (Reuters) -- President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that South Vietnam was ready to continue fighting by itself and any allies wishing to withdraw their forces could do so.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Two large additional demands on the Federal National Mortgage Association to buy mortgages -- one actual and one a proposal -- were disclosed today.
ALBANY, April 16 -- After receiving a special message from Governor Rockefeller, the Assembly today passed his legislation establishing a minimum wage of $1.40 an hour for the state's farm workers.

ATLANTA, April 16 -- The growth rate of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company speeded up during this year's first three months, H.I. Romnes, chairman and chief executive officer, told 1,925 persons at the company's 84th annual meeting here today.
TWO men, both long on hair, hope and talent, have set up shop in a seventh-floor suite at the Plaza. (A humble beginning it ain't.)

HOUSTON, April 16 (UPI) -- Clark Graebner, the top-seeded player, breezed into the quarter-finals of the River Oaks tennis tournament today, but Stan Smith, seeded No. 2, was the upset victim of Zan Guerry, a Rice University sophomore.
LONDON, April 16 -Charles Chaplin indicated today that he would not appear on the movie screen again.
Major additions to the Readders Digest's central headquarters building in Chappaqua, N. Y. have been approved unanimously by the Town of New Castle Planning Board after a public hearing.

RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 16 -- Roberto de Vicenzo of Argentina, who lost a chance to tie with Bob Goalby for the 1968 Masters golf title because he failed to detect an error on his scorecard, was critical today of Lee Trevino, the United States Open champion.

John Glenn Paton is a singer who has a lot going for him. He has looks, personality, a masterly command of the German language which, in the all-lieder program he sang last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, gave all his work the sort of authority that comes only from knowing and being sensitive to poetry in a familiar tongue.

The limitations of military power are once again being brought home to the American people in the humiliation and tragic loss that attends the shooting down of a Navy reconnaissance plane by North Korean jets over the Sea of Japan.

ANYONE who appreciates good acting is recommended to study and enjoy Jack Warden's performance in Robert Shaw's "The Man in the Glass Booth" at the Royale Theater. It was in this play that Donald Pleasence was giving one of those virtuoso, look-ma-I'm-acting performances that have been such a feature of the present rather dismal Broadway season.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that Bertram M. Ostrau had been barred from employment in the securities business and that the brokerage firm that he formerly headed, Tessell, Paturick Ostrau Co., Inc., had been suspended from doing most over-the-counter business for 10 days.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The American Jewish Committee has published two books aimed to give American Jews a greater understanding both of themselves and of their role within the larger American community.

MOSCOW, April 16 -- The second of the 24-game world championship chess match between the titleholder, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, and his compatriot, Boris Spassky, played tonight at Moscow's Variety Theater, was adjourned after the 40th move.
LONDON, April 16 -- The Government disclosed today the substance of the strike-curbing plan that had aroused furious opposition before its unveiling.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers told the annual meeting of the American Society of Newspaper Editors here today that the United States was seeking to resolve its oil dispute with Peru in an amicable and fair manner.

Suddenly confronted with the possible unavailability of Walt Frazier, the New York Knickerbockers depart for Boston today where they will face another sudden-death situation in their National Basketball Association Eastern playoff series with the Celtics.
The birthday of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on Jan. 15 will be observed as a holiday in the city schools, the Board of Education decided last night.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- Frank J. Kulak, charged with killing two policemen in a six-hour gun battle on Chicago's Far South Side Monday, has admitted placing six bombs in that area within the last 20 months, the police said today.

The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that strikes last year have had lingering effects on operations. First-quarter profit fell to $11,056,000, or 61 cents a share, from $12,706,000, or 70 cents a share, in the 1968 period.
TEL AVIV, April 16 -- Damp-eyed Israelis last night acclaimed a new immigrant, Nehama Lifshitz, the Soviet Yiddish folk singer.

FORT DIX, N. J., April 16 -- The Army opened the Fort Dix stockade for inspection today in an effort to demonstrate that the 628 soldier-prisoners confined here were being detained under acceptable conditions.

King Hussein of Jordan warned here yesterday that the time was shorter than was generally believed for finding a peace settlement in the Middle East or seeking a longer and bloodier struggle burst out there.
LONGBINH, South Vietnam, April 16 -- A 23-year-old American civilian was sentenced to nine years at hard labor today in a court-martial here.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 16 -- I. W. Abel, the president of the United Steelworkers of America, stood under the front portico of the Greenbrier Hotel this afternoon, waiting for a car to take him to the airport.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Federal Reserve Board, by a vote of 5-2, approved today the proposed acquisition of the Tinker National Bank of East Setauket, L.I., by Marine Midland Banks, Inc.
Liberal party convention delegates voted overwhelmingly last night to designate Mayor Lindsay as their candidate for Mayor and to prevent any Democrats from entering the Liberal primary election.

A local draft board may not punish a registrant by ordering him to report for immediate induction simply because he has violated the Selective Service System's "delinquency regulations," a Federal judge ruled yesterday.
One penguin chick has made a public appearance at the Coney Island Aquarium, and another is getting ready to leave its rocky hutch.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -Well over a hundred million Americans, even those who may be due the refund of part of their withheld taxes, are thinner in the bank balance today because of their final Federal income-tax accounting yesterday.
The pins some of the members of Columbia University's radical Students for a Democratic Society wear say in bold red letters: "Shut It Down."

Chancellor Albert H. Bowker of the City University declared yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's executive budget allocations do "not guarantee sufficient funds to allow the university to admit a freshman class" next fall.
ALBANY, April 16 -- The Court of Appeals rejected today an appeal of three Black Muslims sentenced to life in prison for the murder of Malcolm X, leader of the Organization of Afro-American Unity.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 -- A conservative block won a clean sweep today in a nationwide election of directors of the Sierra Club, a leading conservation organization.
A boycott by Negro and Puerto Rican parents kept virtually all pupils out of Public School 39 yesterday as the Board of Education took over direct supervision of the troubled East Harlem school.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -The National Student Association filed a suit today challenging the constitutionality of legislation that would cut off Federal aid to students who engage in "disruptive" campus protests.
From the terrace of a Brooklyn Heights brownstone, Norman Mailer gazes at the sootcloaked sweep of lower Manhattan and listens to the cars and gulls below.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- President Nixon said tonight that peace, inflation and crime were the three highest priority problems of his three-month-old Administration. He promised action on all of them within the next year.
The Federal Trade Commission acted wisely to preserve competition in American industry when it required large corporations to notify it sixty days prior to making major acquisitions through mergers.

ALBANY, April 16 -- The Assembly Rules Committee voted to the floor today a bill that would legalize pari-mutuel betting on quarter-horse racing and at the some time provide an estimated $40-million in construction and improvement funds for the state's harness-racing tracks.

Eight men and the fiancee of one of them were arraigned in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday on charges growing out of a grand jury investigation of bank swindles and thefts amounting to more than $1-million.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 16 -- "Humanities 5" is a general education course at Harvard that begins with Plato's "Phaedo" and ends with Samuel Beckett's "End Game," with way stops at St. Augustine's "Confessions," Shakespeare's "King Lear" and John Stuart Mill's "On Liberty," among others.

SOL SANDERS has been an observer of the Far East for two decades, a newspaperman who has evidently thought continually about the nations and people of those lands and a man with wide and sometimes deep contacts in the area. At the conclusion of his book, a critique of our presence in Asia, he writes that we must stay there and help solve its problems.
With inflation on the rise, incomes moving up, ever-broadening corporate benefits and larger life insurance coverage, Americans are more prosperous than ever -- on paper.

CARSON CITY, Nev., April 16 (UPI) -- The Parvin-Dohrmann Corporation announced today that it had informed the Securities and Exchange Commission that a Switzerland-based company would sell its 81,000 shares of Parvin-Dohrmann, as ordered by the Nevada Gaming Control Board yesterday.

The quiet evacuation by black students early yesterday from a Columbia University admissions office as a result of a confrontation with a court order raised the hopes of some college administrators, the eyebrows of a few lawyers and the apprehension of some students.

PRAGUE, April 16 -- The Executive Committee of the ruling Czechoslovak Communist party's Presidium sought today to rehabilitate in the eyes of the people a group of pro-Soviet conservatives.

Plagued by incoming air cargo delays at Kennedy International Airport, the American Importers Association published yesterday a report that found the Atlantic had been converted "from a six-hour ocean into a six-day ocean." The report offered some quick remedies.

ROME, April 16 -- Pope Paul VI announced today that he would go to Geneva early in June to address the 50th-anniversary meeting of the International Labor Organization.

Pianistic color seems to be the specialty of Francis Brancaleone, last night's recitalist in Town Hall. The Detroit pianist, who made his debut here two years ago, devoted the second half of his program to eight Debussy pieces, and to these he brought an interplay of sonorities and timbres that made the music glow and shimmer.
Stock prices declined along a broad front yesterday as possible tension in North Korea elbowed possible peace in Vietnam out of Wall Street's center stage.
National Educational Television won two of 1968's seven George Foster Peabody Awards yesterday for excellence in television programing.

The status of the Reserve Officers Training Corps has moved into the central spot in much of the current ferment on college campuses. A key decision on that issue confronts the faculty of strike-beset Harvard at its meeting today.
