Benjamin Bartel, a lawyer who became chairman of Alexander's, Inc., when the New York-based retail chain became a publicly held company last December, resigned unexpectedly yesterday.

Volkswagen of America, Inc., announced yesterday that its dealers were recalling 4,000 late-model "beetle" sedans and Karmann Ghia coupes to modify their carburetors and prevent their engines from stalling at idle.
LOS ANGELES, April 16 -- The jury continued its deliberations today in the murder trial of Sirhan B. Sirhan, who has admitted that he killed Senator Robert F. Kennedy.
WESTPORT, Conn., April 16 -- The Planning and Zoning Commission has recommended that a referendum be held to determine whether the town should purchase Cockenoe Island.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Shareholders of the B.F. Goodrich Company who tendered their shares in exchange for those of Northwest Industries, Inc., will be permitted to withdraw that tender offer, if they wish, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.
JERUSALEM, April 16 -- Premier Golda Melt, who will be 71 years old next month, visited armored units in the Sinai Desert today.

The Nixon Administration turned in a lackluster performance in its revision of the budget, but the conservatives on Capitol Hill can usually be depended upon to make a bad job worse. In this tradition, Representative Wilbur Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, wants to cut the budget by another $5 billion beyond the $4-billion reduction proposed by the President.

Auguste Rodin's sculpture, "The Age of Bronze," was auctioned last night for $85,000 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. Slightly over 71 inches high and a bronze, the sculpture is of a young male nude. It created a scandal when it was first exhibited in plaster in Brussels, Belgium, in 1877.

PIKESVILLE, Md., April 16 -- Miss Carol May Kaufman, an alumna of the University of Maryland School of Nursing, plans to be married on June 7 in Baltimore to Alan James Segal, who expects to be graduated from Maryland's School of Medicine in June.

DACCA, Pakistan, April 16 -- After weeks of anarchy the people of this troubled region are searching silently for bodies in the rubble to which whole sections of Dacca and Comilla and less densely populated places in East Pakistan have been reduced -- not by rioting, but by a fearsome tornado that struck Monday.

ROME, April 16 -- Italy's shaky governing alliance of Christian Democrats and Socialists showed signs of coming apart tonight at the end of a two-day debate over bloody disorders in a depressed southern community and riots in eight Italian prisons.
The Brooklyn Museum will have an Italian motif for its annual Museum Ball, which opens an exhibition of paintings by Pietro Annigoni on the evening of April 26.

PARIS, April 16 -- Biafra's provisional capital of Umuahia [has been evacuated and faces] imminent assault from advancing Nigerian armored columns, according to reliable reports reaching the European headquarters of relief agencies operating in Biafra.

SOME of the most irritating and difficult hands in the game are those on which the combined hands have the point-count for game but no good game contract is available. This is liable to happen when the only good fit is in a minor suit and one of the major suits is very weak for no-trump purposes.

The Federal Government came to the aid of five states hit by floods yesterday in the Middle West as the Upper Mississippi River and smaller prairie streams sent record or near-record crests battering protective dikes and soggy lowland communities.
MEMPHIS, April 16 (AP) -- Judge Arthur C. Faquin Jr. today set May 26 to hear a motion by James Earl Ray for a new trial in the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
VIENNA April 16 -- United States and Soviet scientists agreed today that the widespread use of nuclear explosions for the benefit of nonnuclear countries was still five years off.
Clems Fairy Gold showed the doubters in the rainy-day crowd of 26,585 fans at Aqueduct yesterday that an odds-on favorite could win.
The Merce Cunningham Dance Company performed with music last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. On Tuesday it had performed without it for the opening bill because of a labor dispute.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Robert H. Finch said today, following a meeting with President Nixon yesterday, that the Administration had no changes in mind for the school desegregation guidelines that white Southerners have attacked so steadily.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- House Democrats called today for prompt repeal of the 7 per cent tax credit on business investment, terming it inflationary.

Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay presented basic plans yesterday for the $1.1-billion Battery Park City development in lower Manhattan, but their allocation to low-income families of less than 7 per cent of the project's housing threatened to throw the proposal into new controversy.

LITTLE FERRY, N.J. -- If Jerry Komarek's seasonal role as a turtle-thumper seems a bit odd in this community, he is only pursuing a pursuit that is older than the discovery of America. The town of Little Ferry was, in fact, once called Quocksoc, an American Indian name meaning "place of the turtle," and turtles, which once abounded here before civilization's encroachments, are said to have formed a substantial part of the Indian diet.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 16 -- Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey said tonight in a panel discussion at Massachusetts Institute of Technology that he had not spoken out against the war in Vietnam while he was Vice President because he had known that President Johnson was trying to get talks started in Paris and he did not want to jeopardize them.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Following is a statement issued today by the Defense Department on the American reconnaissance plane lost yesterday off North Korea. All times mentioned are Eastern standard time.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The House passed legislation today establishing tighter Federal controls over pollution of coastal waters and rivers, particularly by tankers and offshore oil wells.

All Long Island Rail Road service to and from Pennsylvania Station was seriously curtailed at the height of the evening rush hour yesterday when a body was discovered near the tracks in one of the four tunnels leading from the station to Long Island.

The pattern for prize money for the 1969 baseball season was announced yesterday, and the complicated formulas guarantee a minimum of $15,000 a man to the team that wins the World Series and $10,000 a man to the team that loses it.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Industrial production and personal income both rose robustly in March, Government reports disclosed today.

A union of 30,000 retail workers here withdrew yesterday from its parent union and from the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations, charging that both organizations had failed to provide "aggressive and progressive leadership" in organizing millions of low-paid Negro and Puerto Rican workers.
SALEM, Ore., April 16 -- The Oregon Supreme Court unanimously reversed today a lower-court decision and said that Lee Johnson, a Republican, was entitled to be Oregon's attorney General.

Now that Merce Cunningham has won the artistic battles that have occupied him for the better part of his performing career, he appears to have inherited a flock of procedural difficulties that would do credit to an Establishment figure. In short, a young generation of choreographers has taken wing following his artistic direction but Cunningham himself has become involved in a jurisdictional dispute between two unions that threatens his entire musical repertory.
A city official urged the State Public Service Commission yesterday to set stricter operating standards for the Penn Central Company's Hudson and Harlem division commuter service.
Negro students issued a call yesterday for a one-day strike today at Columbia University, then canceled the plans shortly before midnight.

Robert Moore, who staged the Off Broadway hit "The Boys in the Band," has turned down the chance to direct the film version of the play in order to make his film debut as a star ih "Tell Me That You Love Me, Junie Moon."
ASK any Wall Streeter for the prefect defense against a corporate takeover, and he'll tell you in an instant: A high price-earnings ratio.
Prices retreated on a broad front yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as the list broke out of the narrow trading pattern that had characterized the week.

MEXICO CITY, April 16 -- One hundred of Mexico's leading industrialists and financiers and three ministers have just completed one of their strongest campaigns to improve their country's trade with the United States.

A member of the State Board of Regents charged yesterday that state and local education officials were involved in a "conspiracy of silence" against 670 students who were removed from the Franklin K. Lane High School in Brooklyn last Jan. 27.
Fifteen lounging black students talked casually around Columbia University's sundial late yesterday, paying little or no attention to the taking over of the Philosophy Hall by 200 white students.

The Caterpillar Tractor Company achieved its largest profit gain in recent years for the first quarter, establishing a record in earnings and sales, according to the report issued yesterday from Chicago headquarters.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The White House now believes that there is probably no constitutional impediment to the appointment of Representative Donald Rumsfeld to the nation's top antipoverty post.

The New York International Sport and Camping Show is ashamed of itself. Admitted-so. In a rare mood of confession last week, show officials stopped patting themselves on the back over how much money they made last month at the Coliseum and started kicking themselves for trying to put one over on the public.

DETROIT, April 17 (AP) -- Automobile production picked up speed again this week following at least a temporary settlement of a dispute that closed down Chrysler's big stamping plant in Sterling Heights, Mich.
PRAGUE, April 17 -- Alexander Dubcek, who led Czechoslovakia's efforts for liberalization under communism, fell from power tonight.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

NEAL WEAVER'S "War Games," which opened at the Fortune Theater last night, is about hostility. And for much of it I was feeling pretty hostile myself. I could, in fact, have been doing a lot of interesting things -- such as going to Martha Graham, reading a book, eating an apple or even finishing off my outstanding expense statements for The New York Times.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today a rule change on trading by corporate insiders before and after they hold office.
JERUSALEM, April 17 -- Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said tonight that Israel had suffered 1,600 dead and wounded in the nearly two years or border fighting since the six-day war in June, 1967.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- a widespread new study of the Job Corps shows that it has substantially increased wages and reduced unemployment among youths who complete their training, Congress was told today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A major study of the Federal Head Start program for pre-school children, which concluded that poor children who took part were not appreciably better off than disadvantaged youngsters who did not, has been attacked within and outside the Government as "full of holes" technically and as a potential disaster politically.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -Formation of a national citizens committee to oppose President Nixon's plan for deployment of a modified antiballistic missile system was announced today by two prominent Democrats.

Earlybirds interested in reaching Islip, L. I., from Newark before 7 A.M. are getting an assist from the Civil Aeronautics Board. The same holds for anyone who wants to leave Islip for La Guardia Airport after 7 P.M.
ALBANY, April 17 -- The Senate passed a bill today that would supersede New York City's law requiring that pre-packaged meat be sold in containers that are transparent on all sides.
Following is the text of a statement on campus disorder released yesterday by the American Council on Education:

MASSAPEQUA, L. I., April 17 -- The Nassau County police were searching today for vandals who severely damaged the interior of the 125-year-old Grace Episcopal Church here. The extent of the damage was estimated at $30,000.
LONDON, April 17 -- The hereditary peers of Britain, whose legislative power has for so long eluded reformers, escaped today from the latest threat.

Benjamin Bartel, who resigned Wednesday as chairman of Alexander's, Inc., has agreed to serve until a new chairman is named, Alexander Farkas, president and chief executive officer, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- King Hussein of Jordan has assured the Nixon Administration that he could control the Palestinian guerrilla organizations once a reasonable Middle East settlement had been devised.

PASADENA, April 17 -- The Garden Club of America at its 56th annual convention tonight awarded Garden Club of America Medals to 11 distinguished citizens for their efforts in behalf of conservation, civic beautification and horticulture.
Prices turned mixed in moderate trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., April 17 -- Fighting between Negro and white students forced the closing of Plainfield High School today for the second consecutive day.

DETROIT, April 17 -- The General Motors Corporation said today it was asking that 4,000 school buses across the nation be taken off the road because an effort to repair a brake defect had created another brake defect.
A group of 150 militant students at Queens College made a strategic retreat yesterday in their battle against alleged "political suppression."

WASHINGTON, April 17 -Following, as made public by the Pentagon today, is the text of a statement made by Maj. Gen. James B. Knapp of the Air Force at the 290th meeting of the Military Armistice Commission at Panmunjom, Korea:

The apparently unconsidered risk in the reconnaissance operations the United States conducts along the North Korean coast is the impact of incidents like this week's destruction of a spy plane on Japanese-American relations.
A further sharp fall on the London stock market yesterday dropped prices close to their lowest levels of the year.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- President Nixon announced today he would nominate Shelby Cullom Davis, an investment banker from New York, to be Ambassador to Switzerland.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Secretary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin said today that the Federal Government had "budgetary problems" in bringing New York City into the Federal food stamp program for needy persons.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 17 (Reuters) -- Twentyone-year-old Miss Bernadette Devlin defeated her Unionist opponent in a by-election today and became one of the youngest members ever to enter the British House of Commons.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 17 (Reuters) -- The Rhodesian Government contended today that it succeeded in breaking economic sanctions in 1968 and forecast an even healthier economic outlook for 1969.

STRATFORD, Conn., April 17 -- A pair of giant Sikorsky S-64E "Skycrane" helicopters started today on a journey to Alaska, where they will be used to support oil exploration and drilling operations on the North Slope.

LIMA, Peru, April 17 -- A meeting of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America opened here this week with expressions of support for Peru's military Government by Cuba, the Soviet Union and six other Communist nations.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, in a major policy action, voted yesterday not to list new debt securities recently issued by the General Host Corporation and the N.V.F. Company.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 17 -- Reacting to Soviet policy in Eastern Europe and to the discovery of pro-Soviet officers high in the Yugoslav Army, the Communist Government of President Tito is leaning more and more toward the West.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) -- Negotiators for Pan American World Airways and the Transport Workers Union reached agreement on a new contract tonight about 35 minutes before a midnight deadline that could have produced a strike.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 17 -- A group of biochemists from the University of Wisconsin have, apparently for the first time, tracked the way Vitamin D works in the body's complex chemical factory.
PRAGUE, April 17 -- Following is the text of a communique issued tonight by the Central Committee of the Czechoslovak Communist party as provided by the official news agency C.T.K.:

PARIS, April 17 -- North Vietnam and the National Liberation Front of South Vietnam, or Vietcong, rejected today allied proposals for mutual troop withdrawals at the 13th plenary session of the peace talks here.

THE New York Knickerbockers will take their high-wire, death-defying balancing act out of the circus setting in Madison Square Garden tonight for a road performance in the Boston Garden. If they go kerplunk, someone will have to scrape up the pieces, because there is no net below to protect them this time.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The nation's economy continued to roar ahead at nearly full throttle in the first quarter of this year under pressure of higher taxes, tight money and high interest rates.

The chief executive officer of a leading conglomerate company currently involved in a major antitrust case about a large merger proposed yesterday that the Federal Government levy a 2 per cent "merger tax" on corporate consolidations.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The campaign to abolish the Electoral College and choose the President by popular vote moved forward significantly in Congress today.

ALBERT and David Maysles's "Salesman," which opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, is a documentary feature about four door - to - door Bible salesmen who move horizontally through the capitalistic dream.
John V. Lindsay and Robert F. Wagner met last night for the first time since they became rivals for the mayoralty, a job familiar to them both.

LOS ANGELES, April 17 -- Howard Hughes's Nevada organization presented a new series of queries to the Atomic Energy Commission today inferentially questioning safety aspects of atomic bomb test detonations in Nevada.
Rows of deserted stores stretch along the once-bustling streets of downtown Newburgh, N. Y. The wind blows down from gentle hills across the Hudson River, nudging bits of trash along the gutter.

BONN, April 17 -- West Germany's central bank raised its discount rate today by one percentage point, to 4 per cent, despite awareness that this might increase foreign pressure for a revaluation of the strong German mark. The increase will take effect tomorrow.
Interest rates on tax-exempt bonds this week showed their sharpest decline in almost nine months, figures released by The Bond Buyer disclosed yesterday.

Your editorial of April 4 entitled "The Big Four Meet" calls for comment. There is no doubt by now that Israel started the war in June 1967. The battle was fought on Arab territories, which are still occupied by Israeli forces.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17 -- Secretary General Thant said today that he had begun to "pin very great hopes" on the talks of the Big Four powers on a Middle East settlement.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 17 -- In a confused and hectic meeting, the Faculty of Arts and Sciences at Harvard University declared overwhelmingly today that the university should sever all official connections with the Reserve Officers Training Corps program.

Nearby platinum and nearby copper futures went far in opposite directions yesterday. July platinum dropped the $10 an ounce daily limit and set a new life-of-contract low of $184 The three nearby copper-future months made new life-of-contract highs.

Georg Semkow, the Polish conductor who led the New York Philharmonic last night made a definitely good, though limited impression in the second and last program of his first guest engagement. His rhythmic instincts and ability to float a melodic line never deserted him, at least, in such varied works as Rossini's Sonata in C for Two Violins, Cellos and Double Bass, Stravinsky's "Jeu de Cartes" and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 5.

Coach Red Holzman of the New York Knickerbockers said yesterday he was counting on injured Walt Frazier to play tonight when the Knicks oppose the Boston Celtics in the sixth game of the National Basketball Association Eastern Division final series at the Boston Garden.

Surveys of several thousand newborn infants have indicated that the XYY chromosomal defect in men, which has been linked to criminal and antisocial behavior, may be more common than previously believed.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 (AP) -- Bill Stoneman, who had pitched only one complete game in his professional baseball career, hurled a no-hitter tonight. In doing so, he wrote baseball history for the expansionist Montreal Expos with a 7-0 classic against the Philadelphia Phillies.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 17 -- The South Vietnamese Government announced today the arrest of 26 intellectuals and professional people in Saigon on charges of having maintained private contacts with Vietcong political agents.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Friday, April 18 -- The United States charged North Korea today with having committed "a calculated act of aggression" in shooting down an unarmed Navy reconnaissance plane with 31 men aboard.

MOSCOW, April 17 -- Experienced observers here, analyzing the fall from power of Mr. Dubcek, attached particular significance to the role in recent developments in Prague that was played by the Soviet military, backed or instigated by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 17 -- Al Nida, a Communist organ, said today that the Iraqi Government had imposed tight controls on the activities of Palestinian commando groups within its territory.

Senate investigators have become accustomed to finding hunger in rural America, in its economic eddies and forgotten places where progress, like everything else, seems to have taken the by-pass. This week they also found hunger in the shadows of the Capitol's dome, where wrong-way agricultural policies have perennially been brought to bitter bloom. The new Nixon budget projects no basic change in these policies.

TOKYO, April 17 -- Premier Eisaku Sato today denounced North Korea's downing of an American reconnaissance plane and defended the United States' right to conduct reconnaissance flights over international waters.
" A strong and soundly based black studies program" was pledged yesterday for Columbia by Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, acting president of the university.
NEW HAVEN, April 17 -- Kingman Brewster Jr., the president of Yale University, described in detail today the steps his administration would take in the event of student disruptions on campus.

ST. LOUIS, April 17 (UPI) -Bill Hands and Phil Regan combined to pitch a four-hitter tonight as the Chicago Cubs blanked the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-0. It was the second straight shutout suffered by the Cards and the victory was the Cubs' ninth in 10 games.
The "bank credit proxy," which the Federal Reserve published yesterday on a current basis for the first time, is probably the most important single measure in the determination of credit policy.
Nearly five acres on the Palisades in Fort Lee, N. J., have been purchased by Hyman R. Shapiro, Manhattan apartment-house builder, from the Investors Funding Corporation of New York.
Harlem Hospital prepared yesterday to resume full-scale operations today. The medical board decided to admit patients beginning at 5 P.M. and to open all clinics Monday morning.
Thousands of Columbia University students stood in tense and eerie silence yesterday afternoon while radicals marched into Philosophy Hall amid punches, curses and shouts.
Every so often at Yankee Stadium yesterday, the 6,883 customers were exhorted on the message board to "Vote for Greatest Yankees Ever. See Page 25 of Your Program."

The Ornette Coleman Quintet, which is usually the far-out entry on any music program, last night had the novel experience of being the conservative element in the season's final concert in the "New Image of Sound" series at the Hunter College Playhouse.
New York's determination to cut welfare spending and rely more heavily on Federal food programs adds urgency to the need for Congressional action on hunger.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee cautioned today that the United States, by its very military presence in Spain, had assumed a "quasi commitment" to defend the Franco regime, possibly even in a civil war.
Justice was on trial with Sirhan B. Sirhan. Now that the jury has returned its verdict of murder in the first degree, after a long and careful trial, it can be said that justice has been served.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) -- Representatives of the mutual fund industry urged the Senate Banking Committee today to reject legislation intended to restrict mutual fund sales and management commissions.

EVEN the most dedicated tournament enthusiasts prefer to play at a vacation spot when opportunity offers, so it was not surprising that the South-Eastern Regional Championships in Miami Beach last week attracted a substantial number of players from the New York metropolitan area.

What the management of the Horn Hardart Company expected to be a routine annual meeting yesterday escalated into a stormy session that lasted more than three hours. The meeting started at 10:30 A.M. and finally ended 2:15 P.M., with no breaks for lunch or even coffee.

Robert F. Wagner did not ask for the Liberal party nomination for Mayor because he became convinced after a conversation last Monday night with Alex Rose, chief Liberal party tactician, that he had no chance to get it.
LOS ANGELES, April 17 -- The chief prosecutor stands in the courtroom the same way he must have stood in the line of the victorious, mighty Bruins.
CHICAGO, April 17 -- National Dairy Products Corporation announced record first-quarter earnings and an increased dividend at the annual stockholders meeting here today.

In what was virtually a two-horse race all the way, C. V. Whitney's Chompion -- the 1968 Travers winner -- made a successful season's debut at Aqueduct yesterday by beating the Hobeau Farm's Conceited. Jean Cruguet steered the 4-year-old to a one-length triumph in the mile-and-an-eighth test for older horses while a crowd of 27,293 looked on.

When you're 45 years old, have $2.4-billion in sales and people really don't know who you are, you've got a problem -- right? The National Dairy Products Corporation felt that way and so did its stockholders so they voted in Chicago yesterday to change the name to the Kraftco Corporation.

SOFIA, April 17 (AP) -- The Bulgarian press agency said the new 11-member Presidium of the Czechoslovak party was made up of Gustav Husak, Oldrich Cernik, Alexander Dubcek, Evzen Erban, Stefan Sadovsky, Ludvik Svoboda, Lubomir Strougal, Karel Polacek, Vasil Bilak, Jan Piller and Peter Colotka.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Nixon Administration has warned the Soviet Union that any violent repression by Soviet troops in Czechoslovakia will once again interrupt progress toward strategic arms talks, diplomatic sources said today.
Time Inc. had a net operating loss of $300,000 in the first quarter of this year, the company said at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday.
Special grants for programs to help meet the changing needs of Negro college students was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.

BOSTON, April 17 -- Just when it seemed the Montreal Canadiens would bounce back as they did in the first two games of the East Division final series, the Bruins held on and staged an offensive of their own to trounce the Frenchmen, 5-0, tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Senator Clifford P. Case, New Jersey Republican, said today that Robert H. Finch's pledge not to weaken school desegregation guidelines reinforced assurances that Mr. Finch gave to a group of liberal Republicans earlier this month.
Without not a slide rule in sight, a troupe of 80 or so people from Massachusetts Institute of Technology took over the stage of Carnegie Hall last night and presented an evening of music.

The Metropolitan New York chapter of the Construction Specifications Institute has elected James A. Strosnider as president and Eugene Jaffe, C. Corey Mills and Alvin D. Skolnik as vice presidents. Members of the institute are architects, engineers and other specialists who determine standards of construction specifications for workmanship and materials.

MOSCOW, April 17 (UPI) -- Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, the Soviet war hero who suffered demotion and disgrace under Stalin, describes the late Soviet dictator as a wise diplomat and competent Commander in Chief in his memoirs published here today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- President Nixon may ask Congress to make a broad study of whether the Constitution should be amended to soften the effects of Supreme Court rulings that have enlarged the rights of defendants.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 17 (AP) -- Bert Yancey's first-round tie at 66 today with Richard Martinez in the $35,000 Tallahassee open golf tournament was shattered by a 4-stroke penalty.

CLAYTON LAKE, Me., April 9 -- Early in the afternoon, Raymond Armandi and I found Gene Letourneau at the intersection of Ninemile Road and the Thibodeau Road, stretched out on his snowmobile, his weathered face to the bright sun -- a man at peace with the world.

About 200 radical students occupied Philosophy Hall at Columbia University yesterday afternoon but, after a flurry of violence in connection with the serving of a restraining order last night, left the building voluntarily shortly after 11 P.M.

HOUSTON, April 17 -- The American Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church, reacting to growing pressures within the church to permit priests to marry, reiterated today their allegiance to mandatory priestly celibacy.
A fire ignited by a molotov cocktail caused extensive damage early yesterday to the basement auditorium of the Gould Memorial Library on the Bronx campus of New York University.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -Ralph Nader staked out a new consumer crusade today with the food industry as his target.

THE situation established at the outset of Hortense Calisher's fourth novel, "The New Yorkers," is most arresting. Simon Mannix -- fiftyish, barely 5 feet tall, a judge on New York's appellate court, a wealthy "lace-curtain Jew and a lapsed one" -- leaves a banquet in his honor at "one of the best of those midtown men's clubs" and arrives at his home in an Upper East Side brownstone.

HONG KONG -- There is probably a direct relationship between Mao Tse-tung's attempt to rebuild the chaotic Chinese Communist party in his own image at the present ninth congress and the ever-worsening quarrel with Soviet Russia. Peking has just aimed a one-two punch at the Kremlin's chin.
The nation's college and university leadership issued yesterday a firm warning that "the academic community has the responsibility to deal promptly and directly with disruptions."

McCall's Magazine, which calls itself the world's largest women's magazine, has named its first woman editor in 48 years: Shana Alexander of Santa Monica, Calif. The last woman editor, Bessie Beaton, retired in 1921.

As one who has much reason to be grateful to the American Civil Liberties Union, I nevertheless believe the A.C.L.U. wrong in its position on student demonstrations, and The Times wrong in endorsing the A.C.L.U. position. [Editorial April 9.]

ALBANY, April 17 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the statute of limitations could not be used to block a damage suit charging medical malpractice in which foreign objects have been left in the body of a patient.

ALBERTA, Ala. -- The black women had ambled out to the cornfield as they do every afternoon at 4 o'clock. Their store-bought dresses were as green as ripe limes or in lemon yellow, cornflower blue, but pink, red and violet, creating a crazy quilt of color against the walls of their soon-to-be-completed sewing center.
MOSCOW, April 17 -- The pretty blonde gatekeeper in police uniform smiled winningly as she opened the little door in the high wooden fence in the western Moscow suburb of PetrovoDalneye.

OTTAWA, April 17 (Reuters) -- The luxurious but ill-starred turbotrain, the most modern form of rail transport in North America, is back in the workshop as more than 100 technicians from its United States makers try to repair it.

United Press International will demonstrate for publishers here next week a computerized system designed to deliver error-free news copy to various types of newspaper production systems, Mims Thomason, president of the news agency, announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, April 17 -- The New York Mets lost the sixth game in their last seven tonight when the Pittsburgh Pirates overpowered them, 4-0, on the three-hit pitching of Jim Bunning and Ron Kline.

DUBLIN, April 17 (UPI) -- George Keck, president of United Airlines, called today for an additional $12.5-billion to avert "catastrophic congestion" in United States air travel over the next 10 years.

Four unusual little trees that began their existences in a laboratory dish at The Institute of Paper Chemistry in Appleton, Wis., may help to provide a fast new route to superior forests in the future.

PITTSBURGH, April 17 -- In a talk before shareholders at the annual meeting of the Aluminum Company of America today, John D. Harper, president and chief executive officer, called continuing inflation this country's greatest single economic problem.
LONDON, April 17 -- Brian Gossman, a 27-year-old printer, read the gloomy headlines about the budget. He did not read on.

LONDON, April 17 -- London has seen more ambitious musicals than the New Theater version of "Anne of Green Gables," but few that applied showbusiness skills more single-mindedly to adapting a children's classic with sincerity and affection.

MOSCOW, April 17 -- The second of the 24-game world championship match series between the title holder, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, and his fellow countryman, the challenger, Boris Spassky, which was adjourned last night, was completed today.

The week-old feud involving Gerome Ragni and James Rado, authors and leading performers in "Hair," and Michael Butler, producer of the musical hit, was settled yesterday. This was confirmed last night by Mr. Ragni and Mr. Rado in their dressing room at the Biltmore Theater and by Mr. Butler, who was there, too.

A co-defendant in the Roy M. Cohn bribery conspiracy case moved yesterday in Federal Court to shift the September trial from Foley Square to Hartford because he said his case had been prejudiced by publicity given the lawyer-financier.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Members of the House Banking Committee raised questions today about some of the language in the Nixon Administration's bill to regulate one-bank holding companies, but there was clear support for the basic principles of the bill -- to make sure banking is kept separate from commerce and industry.
LOS ANGELES, April 17 -- Sirhan Bishara Sirhan was convicted today of murder in the first degree for the slaying of Senator Robert F. Kennedy last June 5.

When President Nixon speaks out for the first time at a news conference today on North Korea's shooting down of an American intelligence plane, he will be under no serious public pressure to alter his policy of prudent restraint. The Liberal party's decision to endorse Mayor Lindsay for re-election keeps alive the fusion image any reformer needs if he is to have any hope of victory in this overwhelmingly Democratic city.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 17 -- High-ranking United States military men here who have been arguing with Nixon Administration officials against a cutback in offensive operations believe that their views have prevailed.
The stock market moved on an even keel yesterday as tension abated somewhat over North Korea's shooting down of a United States reconnaissance plane earlier this week.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Effects of the current budget squeeze on one important national health program were brought into sharp focus today at a Senate subcommittee hearing.

SEOUL, South Korea, April 17 -- High official South Korean sources said today that the North Korean Government had ordered the same kind of "emergency measures" it took after its seizure of the United States intelligence ship Pueblo last year.

The Chase Manhattan was doing its best to be friendly again last night. It celebrated the 10th anniversary of its art acquisitions program with a party for perhaps 125 artists -- the contemporary sculptors and painters whose works are included in the bank's $1.4-million collection.

J., and the Monmouth County community's Zoning Board of Adjustment was concluded, temporarily at least, with the board's decision Wednesday night that the office she has operated for the last four years is a violation of the borough's zoning regulations.

" Do you realize that film is our only native art form?" said Lillian Gish. "There's jazz, of course, but that came from Africa. Film is the most powerful medium of communication in the world today."

LONDON, April 17 -- Industrial stocks and Government bonds tumbled sharply today as doubts spread among businessmen and economists concerning the reinforced tax squeeze applied by the new British budget last Tuesday.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 17 -- It is the belief of Billy Haughton, who often trains and drives Carlisle, that the secret of success for the trotter lies in the shoes worn by the 6-year-old.

Despite massive churning in the money markets caused by problems in cash management at the Treasury, the Federal Reserve System maintained its sharply restrictive credit policy during the last two weeks.

Only two pupils attended Public School 39 in East Harlem yesterday, the second day of the boycott in the dispute between the central Board of Education and the Intermediate School 201 demonstration district, from which the school was removed this week.

GENEVA, April 17 -- High officials of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade showed little enthusiasm today for the Nixon Administration's plans to extend the protection provided the United States textile industry against low-cost imports.
The B. F. Goodrich Company advised its shareholders yesterday against "any hasty decision" in accepting an exchange offer from Northwest Industries, Inc., for their Goodrich stock.

RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 17 -- Some thought the rough was "tough." Others described it as almost "unfair," but Dick Lotz had nothing to complain about after leading the opening round of the Tournament of Champions today with a five-under-par 67.
" CALL ME LEON." Thus, Leon Hess of Hess Oil insisted on informality in greeting a reporter who visited the hallowed board room of Amerada, where Mr. Hess hopes to hold forth regularly after mid-May.

Temple Israel at 112 East 75th Street will rock to the sounds of a Sabbath eve service next week when Gary William Friedman's "Prayers for Friday Night" is given its premiere. Mr. Friedman calls the work a rock oratorio and has scored it for a rhythm section (piano, string bass, two guitars and drums), a string quartet, a singer and chorus.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Clerical and lay leaders of the Roman Catholic Church in this country have demonstrated greater sympathy for Israel's position in recent events than American Protestant denominational officials, the American Jewish Committee has concluded.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- President Nixon predicted to members of the League of Woman Voters today that a woman would be elected President within 50 years.
W. J. Jakimiuk, President of Sud Aviation Corporation, writes that the supersonic Concorde will be quieter than present-day airplanes "in certain important respects."

BRUSSELS, April 18 -- The Executive Commission of the Common Market reported today accelerated expansion at the end of 1968 and in the first months of this year. In its first quarterly survey for 1969, the Commission forecast a rise of about 6 per cent in the gross product and of about 9 per cent in industrial production this year.

COOKSTOWN, Northern Ireland, April 18 -- Six months ago Bernadette Devlin was just another 21-year-old psychology student at Queen's University in Belfast, anonymous and apathetic along with 5,000 other students. At 4:15 A.M. today she was declared elected to a seat in the House of Commons in London.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 18 -- A band of largely shoeless or sockless members of Students for a Democratic Society started a "spring offensive" against the university's administration in front of Nassau Hall this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Conducting a news conference is like "going to the country," President Nixon observed today. But preparing for one is more like going to court in behalf of some old and valued Wall Street client.
Following is a transcript of President Nixon's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 19 (AP) -- The publisher of a newspaper that was closed early this year was sentenced yesterday to a five-year prison term on charges of "rebellion.
A rematch of a sort, with the Claiborne Farm's Dike opposing Ogden Phipps's Reviewer at even weights, will be presented at Aqueduct today with the 45th running of the Wood Memorial.
Harvard will survive the recent crisis. If history is any guide, we know that Harvard has the strength and the wisdom to adapt to changing times and even to develop strength through turmoil.
HELSINKI, Finland, April 18 Aarne Saarinen, leader of Finland's recently liberalized Communist party, repeated his party's support of the Czechoslovak Communist reform program in an interview today.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The Communications Satellite Corporation reported today net income of $1,525,000, or 15 cents a share, for the first three months of 1969.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) -- Three Representatives attended a screening today of the Smothers Brothers show that was banned by the Columbia Broadcasting System and promised Tom Smothers that they would help him get back on the air.
Leaders of the Liberal party yesterday endorsed Mayor Lindsay's running mates, Sanford D. Garelik, a Democrat, for City Council President and Fioravante G. Perrotta, a Republican, for Controller.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange tumbled to a 19-month low in the reporting period ended April 15, the Big Board announced yesterday.

ON demand, Red Holzman will share his three rules of life: "First, never worry about something you can't control. Second, never argue about money before you go to bed. Third, never make a point with your finger when the waiter is coming with the check. Hey, wait a minute. Those last two make me sound cheap. So, I only have one rule of life."

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., April 18 (UPI) -- Two wingless experimental spacecraft, which could be used to ferry men from space stations to earth, were launched high over the Mojave Desert yesterday for a test flight.

Seven leading portfolio managers from Wall Street have quit their jobs to found a new investment management concern that will adopt a department-store approach to investing by putting clients' cash into art and real estate, as well as into the stock market.

Traffic and site studies for a proposed highway bridge across the lower Delaware River between Kent County in Delaware and Cumberland County in New Jersey have been ordered for next month by the bistate Delaware River and Bay Authority.

BARBARA TEPPER of Livingstone, N. J., one of the top-ranked women players in the metropolitan area, achieved the rare feat of winning three events in one tournament at the New Jersey Bridge League's Spring Championships last weekend.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 19 (AP) -- United States tanks and armored troop carriers ran into a hidden North Vietnamese base camp northwest of Saigon yesterday and killed at least 82 enemy soldiers in a running battle.
BERKELEY, Calif., April 18 -- The Regents of the University of California ordered today that all permanent faculty appointments be submitted to them before being made final.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Pentagon officials are increasingly concerned that the mounting intensity of campus attacks on the Reserve Officer Training Corps will affect the quality and prestige of the program.
SHE can be addicted to hip boots, chains and plastic, but on her wedding day a girl wants to look dreamy, romantic and traditional.

Steve Adams, a 16-year-old junior from St. Joseph's, Montvale, N. J., turned in the only meet record performance yesterday as the 15th annual Queens-Iona reray carnival opened a two-day stand at Randalls Island with an all-scholastic program.

The city's lawyers were put on notice yesterday that unless they refrained from the widespread practice of detailing their professional functions on their office windows and doors they would face disciplinary action.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 18 -- Harness horses and those who are devoted to them have known and enjoyed better nights than the one that bobbed up this evening at Roosevelt Raceway. A heavy rain, dense fog, strong wind and a sloppy oval marred the $15,000 Open Handicap one-mile trot, which went to the favored Carlisle in 2:05 1-5.

Germany's Stuttgart Ballet will make its United States debut at the Metropolitan Opera House on June 10. Between then and June 29, the 85-member company under the direction of John Cranko will give 11 American premieres, including four full-length ballets.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The head of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith said today that a "new frankness and realism" had been developing in recent months between Negroes and Jews through a series of "off-the-record informal conferences" throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- William McChesney Martin, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, urged Congress today not to permit disagreements over details to prevent prompt enactment of legislation to restrict the kinds of businesses that can be owned by banks, through the use of the one-bank holding company device.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The following are the main points of President Nixon's news conference today:

ALBANY, April 18 -- The Senate gave final approval today to a bill that prohibits appointed school boards and the State Education Commissioner from ordering the busing of students to correct racial imbalance in schools.
GLEN COVE, L. I., April 18 -- After three days of racial unrest, Glen Cove High School was closed at noon today. Shortly afterward, two white youths were beaten, allegedly by a gang of Negroes.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 18 -- Following is the text of a statement issued today by the president and fellows of Harvard College, who constitute the corporation:

A man who refused to tell a grand jury whether he tried to bribe a former confidential assistant to Surrogate S. Samuel DiFalco to obtain a suspended sentence for a convicted extortionist was found guilty yesterday of criminal contempt.

Gulf Western Industries and Famous Players Canadian Corporation, Ltd., which is 51 per cent owned by the American conglomerate will seek a new "solution" to meeting Canadian Government regulations on foreign ownership, following rejection of a reorganization plan for Famous Players.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The tax reform proposals that President Nixon will send to Congress early next week will include a plan to remove from the tax rolls all those officially defined by the Government as "poor."

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) -- A new vaccine against rubella, commonly referred to as German measles, will be recommended for boys and girls, Dr. William H. Stewart, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, said today.

Despite the heavy evening rainstorm and the drawing power of the New York Knickerbockers on television from Boston, 2,076 fight fans showed up at Felt Forum last night to watch the four eight-round bouts.
Three Black Panthers were charged yesterday with ambushing and shooting down two policemen who answered a false call for help last summer in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas, V. I., April 18 -- Bearded and looking fit, except for a slight pallor, the four veterans of man's longest experiment in underwater living let the world in today on some of their experiences.

McGraw-Hill, Inc., whose books, magazines and information services are largely devoted to business subjects, and the American Heritage Publishing Company, which specializes in historical and cultural publications, have agreed to merge.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 18 (UPI) -- John (Sonny) Franzese, a reputed Mafia leader, was acquitted in Nassau County Court today of charges of robbery, grand larceny, assault and conspiracy in connection with a $3,000 holdup in 1965.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 18 -- The major Western powers have warned Secretary General Thant that if they are to go on paying the United Nations' bills, there must be economies in its operation.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) -- Senator John Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, proposed today legislation to combat lumber price rises by increasing the yield of the national forests.

Joe Venuti, who is generally considered to have been the first jazz violinist, also claims to have taken part in the first jazz concert. It was held, he says, in the men's room of a hotel in Atlantic City.

Art Blakey, a jazz drummer whose sound is so heavy that he seems to be using redwood legs for drumsticks, brought his quintet, the Jazz Messengers, to Carnegie Recital Hall last night as part of the series "Jazz: The Personal Dimension.''

JERUSALEM, April 18 -- The Israeli Premier, Mrs. Golda Meir, indicated today that she would reject any proposed independent Palestinian state in the occupied area on the west bank of the Jordan River.

At noon yesterday, blares of bullhorns from three separate political rallies clashed in a confusion of sounds that underscored the divergence of goals, tactics and ideologies that has surfaced on the Columbia University campus.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) -- Paul Blair, a .211 hitter last season, belted two home runs and Frank Robinson and Elrod Hendricks hit one apiece tonight as the Baltimore Orioles trounced the Washington Senators, 6-0, behind the four-hit pitching of Tom Phoebus.

Confronted by 100 helmeted policemen and the threat of mass arrests, about 50 students filed quietly out of the administration-library building at Queensborough Community College last night, ending an eight-hour sit-in to protest the planned dismissal of a faculty member.
New York University reopened the Gould Memorial Library on its Bronx campus yesterday after ascertaining that an incident of arson in the basement auditorium had caused no structural damage.
Oil and steel issues showed the best group gains yesterday as the stock market moved modestly higher.
Harry J. O'Donnell, who recently resigned as press secretary to Mayor Lindsay, has been appointed deputy commissioner for the Division of Economic Development of the State Commerce Department.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Nixon promised today to support a shift to direct popular election of the President, but only after Congress has approved the necessary constitutional amendment on its own.

BOSTON, Mas., April 18 -- A watercolor on the office wall showed Charles XII and Euclid dead-heating for first in the 1839 Doncaster Great Leger, but the man in the white turtleneck sports jersey was unmistakably Bill Veeck.

About 10 men dressed in animal skins along with an indeterminate number of chickens and goats are to set out in a Norse longship about May 1 from Norway to try to retrace the Vikings' 11th century discovery route to Newfoundland.

Senator Albert Gore (letter, March 20) calls upon President Nixon to "act decisively . . . to accept a compromise political settlement" on Vietnam. Senator Fulbright publicly warns Secretary Laird that "Johnson's war" is fast becoming "Nixon's war." These Senators clearly place the burden of courage, decision and action upon Mr. Nixon.

Reports from Nigeria's war zone are depressingly familiar: Biafran refugees clog the roads west from Umuahia; relief agencies hastily move their stations to escape shelling; civilian patients in one of the few major hospitals are moved in a hurry to make room for military casualties.

ALBANY, Calif., April 18 (AP) -- The richest horse race to be held in northern California and the last major test for 3-year-olds before the Kentucky Derby takes place tomorrow with the 54th running of the California Derby at Golden Gate Fields.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Sharpening both his rationale and his rhetoric, President Nixon defended today the Safeguard antiballistic missile system as vital to national security and promised to press vigorously for its approval.

PRAGUE, April 18 -- Gustav Husak, the new Communist party chief, told Czechoslovaks last night that the party would not tolerate any resistance to its decisions and warned against "counterrevolutionary" elements.

St. LOUIS, April 18 -- The New York Mets and the St. Louis Cardinals were rained out tonight, but the first ax of the season fell on the Mets when Manager Gil Hodges revamped the team's line-up for tomorrow night's game against the Cards.
Copper futures rose sharply in price yesterday, setting new life-of-contract highs for each delivery. Volume was moderate.

BAYVILLE, N. J., April 18 (AP) -- James E. Johnson, gubernatorial candidate of the conservative New Jersey Independent party, was arrested here today by agents of the Internal Revenue Service, who contended that he had tried to prevent them from seizing property wanted in a tax lien.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 18 (UPI) -- Jose Napoles, a refugee from Cuba, won the welterweight championship of the world tonight as he scored a knockout over Curtis Cokes of Dallas. Cokes was unable to answer the bell at the start of the 14th round.

MONTE CARLO, April 18 (AP) -- Tom Okker of the Netherlands and John Newcombe of Australia turned back amateur rivals today and set up an all-pro men's singles final in the Monte Carlo open tennis tournament.

WALL TOWNSHIP, N. J., April 18 (AP) -- "Entrez, Rusty," said the sign on the door of the French class at Wall High School. Russell Louis Schweickart, the astronaut, entered and was immediately kissed by two girls.
ITHACA, N. Y., April 18 -- A cross was burned on the doorsteps of a Negro women's cooperative house at Cornell University early this morning and 11 false alarms were set off in campus buildings.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Many universities torn by student disorder "have brought much of it on themselves," Robert H. Finch, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today.

NEW ORLEANS, April 18 -- The private American merchant marine can do a better job of transporting the nation's military cargoes than the Federal Government, a leading ship operator asserted here today.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino accused Mayor Lindsay yesterday of evading his responsibility in urging that a health and hospitals corporation be set up to operate the municipal hospitals.
THAT celebrated list compiled by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith continues to fascinate investors.

BOSTON, April 18 -- "That's right, there's no tomorrow," Dave DeBusschere said in the New York Knick dressing room after tonight's 106-105 loss to the Boston Celtics. "But there's next year. We're in the process of building a dynasty. At least we hope so."

Mrs. William G. Bardel stepped out onto a tiny balcony overlooking the East River, took a deep breath and said to no one in particular, "I wonder if the people on that barge realiz they're passing the most fashionable party in New York right now?"

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Nixon went out of his way at his news conference today to condemn the Soviet Union over the forced ouster of Alexander Dubcek, the liberal Czechoslovak Communist leader, and to warn Moscow that future actions of the same kind could affect relations with Washington.

The approaches heretofore employed to provide disadvantaged children with an opportunity for the good life have been unsuccessful. The youngsters' six-hour daily exposure to the educational system has not sufficed.
A 20-year-old remedial reading teacher in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville Education Center was held in $100,000 bail yesterday in Federal Court in the fatal shooting of a Detroit policeman last March 29.
A tiny band of demonstrators, 134 as counted by one bored policeman, marched past massive police guards at City Hall yesterday in a rally that the sponsors had said might draw 100,000.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Army released from imprisonment today one of the "Fort Jackson eight," a group of antiwar soldiers charged by the military authorities with staging on the base a "disrespectful" and "insubordinate" demonstration against the war in Vietnam.

ALBANY, April 18 -- The leaders of the Democratic minorities in the legislature today pledged a "last-ditch fight" to restore "the most onerous" of the recent Republican-sponsored cuts in the state's welfare, Medicaid and school aid programs.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, April 17 -- Vladimir Nabokov, creator of the celebrated nymphet Lolita, is certain that the heroine of his new novel will become just as renowned -- and for many of the same reasons. The heroine is Ada (pronounced Ahdah), a delicious girl from whom the novel takes its one-word title. It will be published May 5 by McGraw-Hill in New York.

HOUSTON, April 18 -- The two astronauts who are expected to be the first men on the moon this summer conducted a dress rehearsal today of the two hours and 40 minutes they should spend walking and working on the lunar surface.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Investment Bankers Association of America testified against permitting banks to enter the mutual funds business today before the Senate Banking Committee.

MOSCOW, April 18 -- The third of the 24-game world chess championship match series, played tonight between world titleholder, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union and his compatriot, the challenger, Boris Spassky, at Moscow's Variety Theater, was adjourned in a reasonably even position. Petrosian, as black, sealed his 44th move.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Nixon today ordered the resumption of reconnaissance flights off the North Korean coast and vowed to provide protection for the unarmed planes.

Nobody should be surprised at the recent outbreaks of fighting on the Russo-Chinese frontier. Tension, punctured by incidents, has been the rule along much of the 4,000-mile frontier for some time now. We are not yet at the end of the business, and we shall make a grave mistake if we belittle or discount the part which China must play in any settlement in Southeast Asia.
Bob Dylan has released his first album in over a year, "Nashville Skyline," a simple blend of country music and gentle thoughts.
ROME, April 18 -- The Italian Communist party today denounced yesterday's ouster of Alexander Dubcek as party leader in Czechoslovakia.
Canon Dillard Robinson this week became the first Negro dean of a cathedral of the Episcopal Church in this country.
RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 18 -- George Archer, the Masters champion, and Lee Trevino, the United States Open titleholder, shared the 36-hole lead in the Tournament of Champions today.

MONROVIA, Liberia, April 18 -- An agreement for peace talks on the Nigerian civil war eluded a committee of the Organization of African Unity here today as it opened a series of meetings on the situation. But Biafran leaders, under the pressure of Nigeria's new military offensive, indicated that they might be ready to drop their insistence on a cease-fire before any negotiations.

By an anomaly of law, holding companies that control only one bank are exempt from Federal regulation. Thus, by the simple expedient of forming holding companies, the nation's largest banks have been able to acquire manufacturing establishments, insurance companies, mortgage brokerage houses and other businesses from which they have long been debarred.

Moscow's iron fist is being used to extinguish the last vestiges of liberalization in Czechoslovakia. The application of extreme Soviet political and military pressure has now produced a coup d'etat ending the Dubcek era -- the key objective Moscow sought but missed when it invaded Czechoslovakia last August.
HOUSTON, April 18 (UPI) -- Clark Graebner posted a straight-set victory today and advanced to the final of the 35th annual River Oaks tennis tournament against Zeljko Franulovic.

BONN, West Germany, April 18 (Reuters) -- Mike Burton, a double gold medal winner in the Olympic Games at Mexico City, broke the 16-minute barrier in the 1,500-meter free-style today to give the United States its first title on the opening day of the West German international swimming championships.

SAIGON, April 18 -- Though ground fighting was light and scattered throughout most of South Vietnam in the last 24 hours, United States fighter-bombers and helicopters put in an active day, attacking enemy troops on the ground.
For possibly the first time in medical history, an electrocardiogram has been taken of the heart of a swimming whale.

The possibility of a fight for control of the Federal Pacific Electric Company and cancellations and delays in other proposed corporate consolidations highlighted the acquisition and merger scene yesterday.
KANO, Nigeria, April 6 -- This is the other Nigeria -- arid, medieval, sluggish -- as different from sultry, cosmopolitan, staccato Lagos as Miami from Minneapolis.

Current fashions inspired by Lorenzo di Medici's era of 500 years ago were shown last evening at the Botticelli Ball, which brought 350 guests to the Plaza's Grand Ballroom. The evening was a benefit for Orphans of Italy.
MOSCOW, April 18 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, General Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, warmly congratulated Gustav Husak today on his election as First Secretary of the Czechoslovak party.

The Mississippi River, gathering volume and power from tributaries, spilled out of its banks as far south as Hannibal, Mo., yesterday testing the flood prevention measures of big industrial cities in Wisconsin, Iowa and Illinois.

TOKYO, April 18 -- Analysts of Communist affairs here believe that North Korea shot down an unarmed reconnaissance plane over international waters as part of a long-range campaign to undermine South Korea and make it ripe for the dissension and domestic unrest that must precede any Communist take-over.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 18 -- Four persons died and 26 were injured here tonight as a fire swept two floors of a 12-story apartment house.

Consolidated Edison will buy 142 acres of property in Verplanck, N. Y., on the east shore of the Hudson River, for construction of its fourth nuclear power unit, Charles F. Luce, board chairman of the company, announced yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 18 -- Five thousand Harvard University students voted this afternoon to suspend for seven days the strike that has crippled their campus.

IOWA CITY, April 18 (AP) -- Sixteen black players, including four defensive starters from last year, boycotted spring football practice at the University of Iowa today and Coach Ray Nagel said they had "dismissed themselves" from the squad.

The United States Steel Corporation, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the Inland Steel Company followed yesterday the price increase for steel bar products initiated Tuesday by the Republic Steel Corporation.

BOSTON, April 18 -- The Boston Celtics, the amazing king-pins of professional basketball, continued their reign over the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association tonight, turning back a game challenge by the New York Knickerbockers, 106-105, before a capacity crowd of 14,933 that filled Boston Garden with tumult.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Nixon, in a somewhat unusual procedure, has asked the American Bar Association to conduct a study of the work and the effectiveness of the Federal Trade Commission.

Frantic backroom activity in Albany indicates almost universal recognition that action must be taken at this session of the Legislature to clear the way for decentralization of New York City's public schools. The danger, however, is that forces opposed to any effective voice for parents in the reorganized system will succeed in pushing through a bill that has the trappings of reform without the substance -- one that would frustrate effective decentralization.

IF a new, strong-faced young actor named William Smith sheds his mannerisms he may go places on the screen, places that a junky little exercise such as "Run, Angel, Run?" can't take him. The actor's intensity is the one interesting aspect of the picture that opened yesterday at the Cinerama and Loew's Orpheum Theaters.
The American Can Company reported yesterday a decline in first-quarter earnings on a slight increase in sales.
Observations from a rocket have shown that 5 per cent of the X-ray emissions from the Crab Nebula are pulsing in pace with a recently discovered pulsar there.
Postal, police and welfare officials reported yesterday that their efforts had sharply reduced assaults on letter carriers and the theft of welfare checks in recent months.

NAPLES, Italy, April 18 (AP) -- The commander of forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Southern Europe said today that an increase in Soviet naval strength in the Mediterranean in the last week, including the addition of more submarines, has created "a real problem."
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) -- The White House reported today that William J. Driver, director of the Veteran's Administration since 1964, had resigned.

Axel Springer, West German publisher, said here last night that the key to the Middle East situation was the readiness of the West to remain in the struggle with the Communist bloc with a determination to win.

SEOUL, South Korea, April 18 -- Official South Korean sources here said today that the American walkout from the meeting of the Military Armistice Commission in Panmumjom this morning had been carefully calculated tactical device for dealing with the North Koreans rather than a spontaneous action.

In a day of tense confusion at Columbia University, the Students for a Democratic Society was split yesterday when 32 members occupied a campus building for six hours over the objections of the radical group's leaders.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- John M. McGee, a Navy employe, won a raise and a transfer today instead of the disciplinary measures he said were taken against him because he reported massive thefts of petroleum from United States military stocks in Thailand.

Parents kept their children out of Public School 39 in East Harlem for the third consecutive day yesterday, and 60 pickets booed seven teachers and a counselor who entered the school under police escort shortly after 8 A.M.

About 600 militant students at Stanford University ended a nine-day sit-in at an electronics research laboratory yesterday after the Stanford judicial council voted to give the university president power to suspend the occupiers.
BALTIMORE, April 18 -- Thomas S. Nichols's Jean-Pierre will head a field of 14 grass specialists tomorrow in the $30,400 Riggs Handicap at a 11-16 miles at Pimlico.
ST. LOUIS, April 18 -- John D. Rockefeller 3d said last night that neglect of art was one of the symptoms, if not one of the causes, of a sickness that seems to pervade American society today.
CHICAGO, April 18 -- The resignation of Sir William Haley as editor in chief of the Encyclopaedia Britannica was announced today by William Benton, publisher and chairman.

FOR anyone with a special interest in contemporary sculpture, the exhibition scene in New York is a particularly rich and varied one just now. There is the David Smith retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum, the Julio Gonzales show at the Saidenberg Gallery, Louise Nevelson at Pace, Frederick Kiesler at Wise and Herbert Ferber at Emmerich. There is even, alas, the Jules Olitski show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
The Waterfront Commission said it had received 3,320 applications for longshoremen's jobs yesterday. There has been a shortage of registered dockers in the bistate Port of New York for many months.

The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest manufacturing enterprise, disclosed yesterday in its proxy statement that it paid its top officer and directors a total of $17,739,500 in salaries, bonuses and stock credits in 1968.

As I read your April 7 editorial on the cancellation by C.B.S. of the Smothers Brothers show, I did not get the impression that the show was dropped because of Washington pressure, as Robert D. Wood stated in his letter published April 12.

The Police arrested 254 persons charged with crimes committed in Times Square area in the week from April 7 through last Sunday, a spokesmen for Inspector Edmund A. Donnelly reported yesterday. The arrests were part of a drive on street crimes in the area bounded by West 38th and 45th Streets and the Americas and Ninth Avenue.
LONDON, April 18 (Reuters) -- Americans won the men's and women's individual titles at the world professional ice dance championships tonight.

ALBANY, April 18 -- The chief sponsor of the abortion-reform bill that was defeated yesterday briefly considered amending the bill and reviving it today, but he dropped the idea when key legislators told him it would be rejected again.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The governing body of the nation's largest biological science group has passed a resolution deploring President Nixon's decision against the appointment of Dr. Franklin A. Long to direct the National Science Foundation.

LISBON, April 18 -- Premier Marcello Caetano today proposed greater financial and administrative autonomy for Portugal's overseas possessions in a speech before the Mozambique Legislative Council in Lourenco Marques.

AU SABLE FORKS, N. Y., April 18 -- Rockwell Kent, the 86-year-old artist, and his wife fled into a downpour of rain early today as a fire started by lightning destroyed the home he had designed and helped to build on his farm here.
LONDON, April 18 (Reuters) -- Americans won the men's and women's individual titles at the world professional ice dance championships tonight.

ALBANY, April 18 -- The chief sponsor of the abortion-reform bill that was defeated yesterday briefly considered amending the bill and reviving it today, but he dropped the idea when key legislators told him it would be rejected again.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The governing body of the nation's largest biological science group has passed a resolution deploring President Nixon's decision against the appointment of Dr. Franklin A. Long to direct the National Science Foundation.

AU SABLE FORKS, N. Y., April 18 -- Rockwell Kent, the 86-year-old artist, and his wife fled into a downpour of rain early today as a fire started by lightning destroyed the home he had designed and helped to build on his farm here.

Fourteen American and British authors (including Norman Mailer, Truman Capote and Anthony Burgess) recount rather warmly the pains suffered in writing their novels and getting them published. Mr. Capote, in fact, confesses that he is "not a keen rereader of my own books: what's done is done" and says that he is "always afraid of finding that my harsher detractors are correct."

President Nixon has given a reasonable and responsible answer to the shameful North Korean attack on a United States reconnaissance plane. Galling as it is to all Americans to accept the loss of the plane and its 31-man crew, the President showed good sense in eschewing futile saber-rattling.

A student riot in the cafeteria of Eastern District High School in Brooklyn, resulted in the closing of the school yesterday and brought in further disturbances in the street. Five students were arrested and a policeman was injured.

"FOREIGNERS IN ANCIENT CHINESE ART," an exhibition of small ceramic figures at the China Institute, gives the casual visitor insight into the principles of Chinese art while providing the informed collector with the opportunity to see significant rarities.

BAD GODESBERG, West Germany, April 18 -- West Germany's Social Democratic party offered the country's voters today a program that the party hoped would carry the Socialists to their first postwar federal election victory Sept. 28.
PARIS, April 17 -- The French franc was slightly weaker and the West German mark slightly stronger on foreign exchange markets today.
About $6-million will be budgeted by the Department of Hospitals next year for the addition of 1,200 employes to the staff of Harlem Hospital.

BUFFALO, April 18 (AP) -- Two firebombs were thrown early today onto the campus construction site of a controversial Navy-sponsored research project. The bombs caused minor damage, according to Martin Meyerson, president of the State University at Buffalo.

The violin-playing of Henryk Szeryng shows what dignity and unimpeachable taste can do for musical performance. They can make it wear very well, not only through an evening, but in repeated hearings over the years. They can also rob it of the excitement that less fastidious playing sometimes provides.

The open-market prices of new issues appeared firmer and the tempo of offerings quickened last week, according to a survey of specialists in this field. Some said the new-issue price tone was the best in more than a month.

VALLEY STREAM, L. I. -- The menu listed onion soup, crepes aux champignons, petits pois a la Francaise, salade a l'Alsacienne and cream puffs with chocolate sauce. The 40-cent price also included bread and butter and a beverage, but everyone reading the mimeographed list knew that.
WHEN Design Quorum says it offers a one-stop decorating service, it is not speaking lightly.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- A Californian's proposal of an urban gravity-vacuum transit system, in which a train would be pushed through a tunnel as a change carrier is shot through a pneumatic tube, has attracted the at tention of Federal transportation officials and regional planners.

The Twentieth Century Fund announced last night that it was setting up studies of the Constitution, major philanthropic foundations and art museums in an effort to determine their relevance in meeting the current needs of the nation.

MILAN, Italy, April 18 -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans proclaimed tonight as objectives of the Nixon Administration the worldwide reinforcement of "the four economic freedoms" -- freedom to travel, to trade, to invest and to exchange technology.

The Inter-American Development Bank lent more cash, got more money back and earned more last year than it had in any preceding year, the international lending institution disclosed in its ninth annual report made public today.

LOS MOCHIS, Mexico -- The Tarahumaras, a short-statured, brown people, are still one of the most primitive groups of Indians on the North American continent. TEHERAN, Iran, April 18 -- This is a land of lovely, high, windblown steppes on which the opium poppy grows so well. Perhaps two million people in Iran once liked their opium pipe so well that they felt they would die without it.
BOSTON, April 19 -- Two hours before Suffolk Downs opened its 60-day meeting today. Bill Veeck noticed 150 horseplayers waiting in the rain outside a locked admission gate.

Napoles thoroughly whipped Curtis Cokes for the world 147-pound title last night. "Butter Knife" would be a more appropriate nickname.

AIR travel to the Caribbean and Pacific is heading for a boom season this summer, with a record number of departures, many new routes and service at additional gateways. EVERY spring thousands of visitors flock to Branch Brook Park near Newark, N.J., to see its display of oriental cherries. AN automatic watering system for house plants, named Plantender, supplies water to plants as they require it. A special sensor device maintains correct soil moisture as the plant responds to sun, temperature, humidity and growth.

Regents Bill -- Would replace the present 13-member, unsalaried, lay Board of Education in New York City with a five-member professional paid board to be appointed by the Mayor. WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) -- Hubert H. Humphrey, former Vice President and Democratic Presidential candidate, gave President Nixon mixed marks today for his three months in office.

Reviewer, a leading Kentucky Derby candidate, broke a bone while finishing third in the $110,900 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct Saturday and will be sidelined for at least six months, Eddie Neloy, the colt's trainer, said yesterday.

Eugene Thompson made a promising debut at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon in a benefit concert for the Tremont United Methodist Church. LONDON, April 20 -- The British Government's decision to assign its troops to guard public utilities in Northern Ireland could mark another fateful turn in the long and troubled history of relations between Britain and Ireland.
