MOSCOW, April 21 -- The fourth game of the 24-game world championship match series between Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, the title-holder, and his compatriot, Boris Spassky, was adjourned tonight in an easy winning position for Spassky.

ROME, April 21 -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans said today he had found Italian leaders receptive to proposals, advanced by the United States, for reduction or elimination of nontariff barriers to international trade.
The identity of the West German group, if any, interested in buying into the Alan Wood Steel Company continued to be a mystery yesterday.

In the past, the West Coast composer Pauline Oliveros has provided moments of entertainment in her witty beamish mixed-media events. There was one moment last season at the Electric Circus, for instance, in which a musician kept being a magician.

The annual Mike Berger Awards of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism have been won by Robert Mayer of Newsday and Sy Safransky and Archie Waters of The Long Island Press. Each will divide a prize of $1,000.

A lively three-hour annual stockholders meeting of Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., covered subjects ranging from directors' stock ownership, accounting fees, stock options and charitable contributions to last winter's flu epidemic.
GLEN COVE, L. I., April 21 -Glen Cove High School was closed today in an effort to ease the racial tensions that disrupted classes last week.

LONDON, April 21 -- The Netherlands Dance Theater, Europe's most enterprisingly creative ballet company, is back in London for a season that both celebrates the company's 10th anniversary and gives a good start to a new policy for the Sadler's Wells Theater.
LONDON, April 21 (Reuters) -- A six-man team from the International Monetary Fund started today a two-week study of British economic strategy.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -The chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers said today that "if history is any guide" the slowing of the United States economy as a result of the Government's policy of restraint would not show up until the third quarter of this year

Francisco Aybar, who stepped up for his first Carnegie Hall piano recital last night, has the old-worldly habit of taking bows with his hands clasped behind his back. It was easy to think at times during the night that he could play such a recital with one of his hands tied there.

BONN, April 21 -- A West German Government spokesman disclosed today that a senior agent of the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence agency, had defected to the West and disclosed the names of a number of agents, some of whom have been arrested in West Germany.

PINK and blue and yellow and all those pastels that are so right for a bonechina blonde are going to be very much in evidence at White House parties this summer. Mrs. Richard M. Nixon and her daughter Tricia went wardrobe shopping yesterday -- without setting foot out of the Pierre Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused hearings today to two of the 10 Texas Gulf Sulphur Company officers, directors and employes found to have violated the disclosure provisions of the securities laws.
A legal battle of the sexes in the maritime industry came before the State Division of Human Rights here yesterday.
The Xerox Corporation realized a 24.8 per cent rise in its first-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 19.5 per cent, both records for the period, the company reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Supreme Court rejected today, 7 to 2, a challenge to the Government's authority to regulate mail packages from Communist countries.
President Nixon's proposal to repeal the 7 per cent investment tax credit touched off a broad decline in stock prices yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 21 -- After three days of relative quiet, the enemy launched heavy mortar and rocket attacks against allied bases and civilian communities last night, according to military reports.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 21 -- Police officials of Northern Ireland today blamed members of the illegal Irish Republican Army for bomb attacks on a main reservoir and 10 post offices in Belfast over the weekend.
The city of Ithaca has no local gun - control ordinance that would put teeth into the ban on firearms announced yesterday by Cornell University.
NEWARK April 21 (AP) -- Lay teachers posted pickets at 10 Roman Catholic schools and the chancery office of the Newark Archdiocese today in a wage dispute.
The credit markets, viewing President Nixon's new tax proposals as potent anti-inflationary medicine, rallied yesterday afternoon, pushing interest rates downward.
New York City welfare officials hailed the Supreme Court's decision against welfare residency laws yesterday but said it had come a decade too late to have a great effect on the city's relief roll.

If you measure news value by an event's rarity, the big baseball news last night was that the Los Angeles Dodgers knocked Juan Marichal of San Francisco out of the box in the sixth inning of a 7-5 victory.
TRENTON, April 21 -- A new conflict - of - interest code for state officials and legislators was unanimously approved by the State Senate today.

The academic world was aghast early in the 1930's when pictures of academic convocations in German universities featured jackbooted students with daggers and sidearms. Some observers, to be sure, explained the whole development away as a temporary aberration -- the unfortunate but excusable reaction of concerned youths to social injustice in a country ground down by an oppressive peace treaty.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Supreme Court upheld today a Federal law that makes it a crime to threaten the life of the President or Vice President.
WASHINGTON -- When the ladies of the San Blas Islands stopped painting their clothes on their bodies, they started making molas, according to one theory.
The New York State Senate yesterday confirmed Governor Rockefeller's appointment of Bernard J. Lasker as a commissioner of the Port of New York Authority.

BALTIMORE, April 21 (AP) -- The adult adviser of a Youth for Decency Rally said today that the fighting, stealing and stabbing at its conclusion yesterday was caused by "1,000 peaceniks and hoodlums" out of an audience of 40,000.

BOSTON, April 21 -- Tiny Japanese flags, discreetly concealed today on the final afternoon of Patriots Day weekend, suddenly sprouted along the route of the Boston Marathon as well-wishers urged on a tight-striding Hiroshima school-teacher to victory in record time.
Stocks retreated yesterday on the American Stock Exchange after investors got wind of President Nixon's tax request to Congress.

PRAGUE, April 21 -- The Czechoslovak Communist party celebrated the 99th anniversary of the birth of Lenin today, and the occasion left little doubt that "normalization" in relations with the Soviet Union was well on its way.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -The earth is beaming extremely powerful bursts of radio energy into space, much like the puzzling low-frequency bursts emitted from several spots on Jupiter.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey, in his strongest criticism to date of the Nixon Administration questioned today its "basic commitment" to civil rights and the eradication of poverty.

King Hussein's promise "to do everything for all religions" including the Jewish (news report April 15) if East Jerusalem is returned to his jurisdiction has a hollow sound to anyone who has seen that city since the June war.

HOUSTON, April 22 -- George Foreman, the 1968 Olympic heavyweight champion, disclosed today that he would turn pro "soon, but not too soon" under the guidance of Dick Saddler, a long-time California boxing trainer.

JERUSALEM, April 22 -- Israeli forces repulsed two new Egyptian raids across the Suez Canal early today. For the first time in this week's series of commando landing attempts, Israelis were reported killed.

MOSCOW, April 22 -- The Soviet Communist party's leadership expressed its satisfaction today with the present situation in Czechoslovakia, while Dr. Gustav Husak, new leader of the Czechoslovak party, applauded.

Art by American, European and Israeli artists will be displayed at the New York Chapter of Hadassah's third annual art exhibition, Sunday through Wednesday at American Friends of the Hebrew University, 11 East 69th Street.

SEOUL, South Korea -- It appears less and less likely that the United States will be able to avoid an ultimate showdown with cock-a-hoop little North Korea, which President Nixon once referred to as a "fourth-rate power."

ALBANY, April 22 -- New York City Democrats, after more than 24 hours of intensive negotiations, are on the verge of producing a compromise school decentralization bill acceptable to the teachers' union and most Democratic members of the Legislature.

Texaco, Inc., told its stockholders at the annual meeting in Denver yesterday that consolidated net income in the first quarter dropped to $200,011,000, from $212,520,000 a year earlier. Per-share earnings in the 1969 period were $1.47, compared with $1.57 in the 1968 quarter.
THE woman who complains she can't find any wearable, ladylike clothes is just carping. However, if she's looking for fashion excitement, she's in for a letdown.
PRAGUE, April 22 -- The Czechoslovak Communist party moved today to head off any possible new demonstrations and embarrassment at the celebration of May Day next week.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Supreme Court cracked down today on "dragnet" arrests by ruling that the state cannot use fingerprints obtained by rounding up suspects for purposes of investigation.

David Merrick, the Broadway producer who is not always pleased with the reviews of his productions in The New York Times, sparred lightly with the newspaper's publisher about its advertising rates at the annual meeting of the New York Times Company in Town Hall here yesterday.

Walter C. Fisher was elected a director of the Zenith Radio Corporation at the company's annual meeting in Chicago yesterday. He became vice president of marketing of the corporation in December, and is also president of the Zenith Sales Company, the corporation's marketing division.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Senator Robert C. Byrd introduced legislation today that would make it a Federal crime to disrupt a school receiving Government aid.

Strife and shutouts constituted the mainstream of major league baseball activity yesterday. Three managers were banished from their games by umpires; a free-for-all fight enlivened the game in Kansas City between the American League's two new clubs, the Royals and the Seattle Pilots; and five more teams were held scoreless, keeping the rate of shutouts at 20 per cent, almost exactly what it was last season when the dominance of pitchers was so widely recognized.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Republican Congressional leaders predicted today that the Nixon Administration would seek more money, more men and some government reorganization for the battle against organized crime.
UNDER no circumstances will I consent to being traded from the Red Sox. All my interests are in Boston and that's where I want to stay."
Representative Hugh L. Carey has agreed to run for President of the City Council on a ticket headed by former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, according to high Democratic sources.
At about 1 A.M. yesterday, the doorbell rang at Mrs. Julia Chepa's ninth-floor apartment at 79 East 79th Street.
A modified plan for reorganization of the city's health services under a public-benefit corporation has been agreed upon by Mayor Lindsay and the City Council.
The Military Sea Transportation Service has announced a new procurement program for dry-cargo ships that may provide United States shipyards with more than $300-million in new orders.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -The Senate Armed Services Committee exposed itself today to a public debate on the missile defense issue, and the apparent result was to deepen the division within the committee over the Administration's proposed Safeguard System.
BOSTON, April 22 -- Kenny who?

ITHACA, N. Y., April 22 -- "The university is a place of reason, order and freedom," Clinton Rossiter was saying, looking out from his book-lined office over the Arts Quadrangle of Cornell University.

A varied assortment of works for flute and piano were played in Carnegie Recital Hall last night by Paige Brook, assistant first flutist of the New York Philharmonic, and Elizabeth Wright, a pianist who has made several appearances in this area.
The stock market snapped back with a late rally yesterday after moving lower in continued response to the Administration's proposal to repeal the 7 per cent investment tax credit.

Until the Vietnam war, research and development on chemical and biological weapons was a dark corner of the Defense Department's many-sided enterprise. But the use of tear gas and chemical defoliants in Vietnam in recent years has alerted the nation to the dreadful potential of these weapons. Now, because of the courageous initiative of Representative Richard D. McCarthy of upstate New York, more light is shining into this dark corner.

HOUSTON, April 22 -- Doctors at Methodist Hospital today performed the world's first total human eye transplant, the hospital said. It will be about three weeks before doctors can determine if the surgery was successful, a spokesman said.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Paul Haney disclosed today that he had been relieved of his job as the "Voice of Apollo" and the space agency announced that Brian Duff, 40 years old, would succeed him.

CHARLESTON, S. C., April 22 -- With toothbrush, toothpaste and a 30-year-old Bible in hand, the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy led a noisy, exuberant march of more than 700 striking hospital workers and their supporters through the back streets of this historic city today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 22 -- Light and widely scattered action from the demilitarized zone to the Mekong River delta was reported in the last 24 hours.
Three suits have been filed in Federal Court in Brooklyn, over ownership of two paintings believed to have been painted in 1499 by Albrecht Durer and now valued at $1-million.

ROME, April 22 (AP) -- Playing despite an upset stomach, Charlie Pasarell of Puerto Rico was beaten by Vladimir Korotkov of the Soviet Union in the first round of the Italian open tennis tournament today. The scores were 13-11, 2-6, 6-4.
A Manhattan lawyer returning from a European business trip arrived at Kennedy International Airport recently and waited for his bags to appear so he could clear customs and go home.

TWENTY years on -- and everyone is 20 years older except the Royal Ballet itself, which, with that disconcerting facility of dance companies, remains as young as ever. True, the dancers have changed here and there -- and the technical standard is, for that matter, far higher -but the spirit hasn't.

For seventy years the Bronx Zoo, one of the greatest collections of wildlife anywhere in the world, has been a source of unending pleasure to New Yorkers, young and old. For all that time admission has been free four days a week and a small entrance charge made Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays.
DALLAS, April 22 -- Billy Casper said today he would have to withdraw from tournaments on the professional golf tour when the course was sprayed with certain chemicals.

THE folk idiom could hardly have been spoken with more charm and authenticity than it was last night by the Afro-American Folkloric Troupe, which opened the City Center's week-long Black Expo festival of Negro talent.

HOUSTON, April 22 -- Floored at about the 40-second mark, Dave Zyglewicz didn't last much longer than it takes to say his name as Joe Frazier registered a knockout tonight after 96 seconds of the first round in a dynamic defense of his share of the world heavyweight championship.

LOS ANGELES, April 22 (AP) -- Odds-makers in Las Vegas, where betting is legal, have established the Los Angeles Lakers 11-5 favorites to beat Boston in the National Basketball Association finals, which open tomorrow night.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 22 (AP) -- Specialist 5 Paul D. Savanuck, 23 years old, of Baltimore, a Pacific Stars and Stripes correspondent on the job only two weeks, was killed in action when North Vietnamese troops penetrated an American position, the Army announced yesterday.
Gimbel Brothers, Inc., achieved a 5.9 per cent gain in sales in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, Bruce A. Gimbel, president, reported yesterday.

WINSTON-SALEM, N. C. -- To some, it might have appeared to be a dinner arranged mainly to admire some huge pop sculpture, or to see a stage set for a Broadway show, with mini-skirted chorus girls, wrenches and oil cans in hand, waiting in the wings.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 22 (AP) -- Barbara McIntire, the medalist, and Mrs. Paul Dye, the titleholder, led the favorites through the first round of the North and South amateur golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Nixon Administration has decided to give welfare reforms a high priority in its domestic programs and is at work on alternative plans to submit to Congress, probably within the next month or so.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -The United States urgently appealed to Israel and the United Arab Republic today to take effective measures to restore the cease-fire along the Suez Canal and reduce tensions in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A Republican proposal to postpone electoral reform until after President Nixon's re-election campaign in 1972 appeared today to have lost its Democratic support in the House.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee raised today the possibility of significant tax changes affecting stock traders and banks.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 22 -- Cornell's non-radical white student's expressed today both their fear and an attempt to comprehend the black militancy that has thrown this hilly 730-acre campus into turmoil.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A Republican official defended the Nixon Administration's 90-day record in civil rights today and pledged that the Government would fight racial discrimination with "the full force of law."
LONDON, April 22 -- A 21-year-old Irish girl held the House of Commons spellbound today with a maiden speech of quiet eloquence and powerful emotion.

IN a lecture that he delivered four years ago at Princeton University, James Alfred Perkins commented that a university "is both the engine of change and is transformed by it."

MANY writers of bridge books include quizzes designed to test the bridge ability of the reader, but very few have compiled a book consisting entirely of questions and answers. While hoofs whacked the sloppy track with a staccato "ker-plock, ker-plock," novice handicappers at Aqueduct yesterday concentrated dutifully on mud ratings.

LONDON, April 22 -- The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies, the worldwide oil enterprise, predicted today further increases in profits for this year but at a reduced rate from 1968's striking 18 per cent gain.
TONY COLECCHIO, the theology student-turned actor-turned-dress designer, showed a bright and sunny collection at Franklin Simon yesterday to an audience clad in dripping raincoats.

MONTREAL, April 22 -- Over-eager after their wild charges brought them inches away from scoring, the Boston Bruins missed virtually every opportunity to pop in the puck tonight and dropped a 4-2 decision to the Canadiens, who did what they had to do.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith today elected Samuel Dalsimer, advertising executive of New York City, as its national chairman. Mr. Dalsimer, vice chairman of the board of Grey Advertising, succeeds Dore Schary, playwright and producer.

Galt MacDermot, composer of the rock music for the Broadway hit "Hair," is collaborating with Joseph Papp, founder and producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, on a rock opera derived from Shakespeare's "Troilus and Cressida."

TEHERAN, Iran, April 22 (Reuter) -- An Iranian freighter sailed down the disputed Shatt al Arab river border between Iran and Iraq today, escorted by heavily armed Iranian Navy craft and jet fighters.
FALMOUTH, England, April 22 -- Robin Knox-Johnston came home today from what he called "a jolly good holiday" -- the first solo voyage around the world accomplished without touching land.

Copper prices continued their upward spiral yesterday, which took one contract -- nearby May -- to a new life-of-contract high. The rising prices reflect a currently tight supply situation, especially in scrap copper.

ITHACA, N. Y., April 22 -- A threatened seizure of campus buildings by militant students of Cornell University and faculty sympathizers of Negro student demands turned into a peaceful sit-in tonight on a basketball court.

An "evacuation" of the Columbia University campus called by black students cut attendance somewhat in the undergraduate colleges yesterday but had little effect elsewhere in the 17,000-student institution.
Top executives of several major companies were named to new positions yesterday.
Ken Harrelson will be doing his thing again, baby, when he plays baseball in a Cleveland Indians uniform tonight.

Meanwhile back at the State Theater, the New York City Ballet got off to a splendid start in its 48th season. Appropriately enough, as the home team, it offered something of an all-American program that began with "Serenade," the first Balanchine ballet choreographed in the United States, and wound up with "Slaughter on 10th Avenue," not necessarily everybody's favorite ballet but one that played a historic role in American musical comedy.

Earnings of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., in the first quarter showed little change from the year-ago level. The report issued yesterday attributed the results to the rise in taxes and to higher labor costs.

MONTREAL, April 22 (UPI) -- Avery Brundage, head of the International Olympic Committee, was reported today to have demanded the return of all Alpine skiing medals won during last year's Winter Olympics at Grenoble, France.

Queensborough Community College pressed further legal action yesterday -- but still stopped short of calling the police -- as students continued to occupy the college's library-administration building in defiance of a restraining order issued on Monday.

The Union Carbide Corporation outlined yesterday progress towurd solving some of the problems that marred its earnings last year.

The president and chairman of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., admitted to his shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday that he, too, was "deeply concerned" about the continuing cost-price squeeze in which his company and industry found themselves.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Analysis of earthquakes throughout the world has disclosed patterns of horizontal slippage consistent with theories of slow drift by huge plates of the earth's crust.

Dr. Kenneth B. Clark said last night that the armed occupation of a Cornell University building by Negro students prompted the same feelings of revulsion and sadness that were evoked when policemen in Alabama used cattle prods on civil rights demonstrators a few years ago.

ALBANY, April 22 -- The State Senate gave final approval today to a bill that creates four more three-day weekends for residents of New York State by shifting to Monday four legal holidays that sometimes fall in mid-week.

ALBANY, April 22 -- More than 100 legislators, appalled by news photographs of rifle-carrying student protesters at Cornell University, affixed their names today as co-sponsors of bills that would outlaw firearms on college campuses.

GENEVA, April 22 -- Sweden aligned herself with the Soviet Union at the 17-nation disarmament talks today by rejecting the United States view that a complete demilitarization of the seabed would be "simply unworkable and probably harmful."
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Food and Drug Administration set interim limits today on the amount of DDT in fish shipped as food in interstate commerce.
Oliver Henry, a Negro senior at Columbia, went to his American Foreign Policy class yesterday despite a pouring rain and an "evacuation" of the campus called by the Student AfroAmerican Society.

EVAN CONNELL'S fourth novel and seventh book, "Mr. Bridge," is a guided tour through the interior of an upper-middle-class Kansas City lawyer. We get to know the man, Walter Bridge -- and we get quite fond of him -- through a series of fictional vignettes, each of which has a title that illuminates its contents with gentle irony or deadpan humor.
Paul Miller, president of the Gannett Newspapers, was re-elected yesterday as president of The Associated Press, a post he has held since 1962.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 22 -- Businessmen must take a more active part in government and make the weight of their opinion felt in the selection of Congressmen, Meshulan Riklis, chairman of the McCrory Corporation, told a discounters' convention here tonight.

The 25-member National Science Board, the N.S.F.'s chief policy-making body, undoubtedly spoke for the bulk of the scientific and educational community in denouncing this break with "established tradition and essential practice."
ROME, April 22 -- A high ranking official of the Jesuits announced today he had requested permission to leave the order to carry on work with youth with lay associates.

Mayor Lindsay, wearing a floppy felt hat trudged through pouring rain yesterday into a newly rehabilitated apartment house in East Harlem, the first of 25 buildings to be renovated or constructed by a local nonprofit group.

DETROIT, April 22 -- The new car-selling rate of mid-April was 7 per cent ahead of the pace last year, the nation's automobile makers reported today, but even with that gain the sales are cool for spring.

HELSINKI, Finland, April 20 -- The Finnish Communist party's leadership appears to have fought itself free of Soviet domination for the first time in the 50 years of its existence under the dynamic reform policies of its chairman, Aarne Saarinen.

CAIRO, April 22 -- A military spokesman reported today that Egyptian commandos crossed the Suez Canal last night for the third night in a row and reconnoitered camps and defensive positions inland from the canal, killing five Israelis.

The value of the securities tied up in Wall Street's back-office problem has dipped to less than $2.5-billion for the first time in at least a year, pointing to a sharp reduction in the paperwork difficulties of brokerage houses.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 22 -- The Faculty of Arts and Sciences at Harvard University voted today to give Negro students a voting voice in the appointment of professors for a proposed new program in Negro studies.

PARIS, April 22 -- With French voters ready to decide Sunday whether President de Gaulle stays in office, Gaullist campaign managers are running scared and, for the first time, the opposition is beginning to smell the scent of possible victory.
A $900-million damage suit was filed yesterday against the International Business Machines Corporation, marking the fourth legal attack on the computer giant in the last four months.

Retail advertisers might not have been at the annual membership meeting of the Bureau of Advertising yesterday morning in the Waldorf-Astoria, but they were mentioned. Not once. Many times.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- An informed source said today that Pan American World Airways pilots had begun a work slowdown in protest against what they call excessive hours that jeopardize safety.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22 -- Secretary General Thant reported to the Security Council today that "a virtual state of active war" existed between Israel and the United Arab Republic along the Suez Canal.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 22 -- Northern Ireland's Prime Minister, Capt. Terence O'Neill, told the Unionist Parliamentary party today that he would resign unless it accepted a reform proposal for local elections.

City College was ordered closed for today by its president, Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, after more than 150 Negro and Puerto Rican students locked themselves inside the gates to the south campus yesterday, blocking access to eight of the school's 22 buildings.
BEIRUT, April 22 -- The dispute between Iran and Iraq over navigation rights in the Shatt al Arab reflects tension between the two countries over the wider issues of the future of the Persian Gulf.
LOS ANGELES, April 22 (AP) -- Don Drysdale, starting pitcher for 13 years, said tonight he might be through hurling for the Los Angeles Dodgers. There is a deep injury under his shoulder, he said.

EDWIN O. REISCHAUER, the Harvard professor who was Ambassador to Japan, will give a kind of Foreign Service officer's appraisal of that country -- psychologically deep but readily understandable -- on the Columbia Broadcasting System network (Channel 2 here) tonight from 10 to 11 P.M.

JERUSALEM, April 22 -Pablo Casals is to conduct in the Holy Land late this summer two performances of his Biblical oratorio "El Pessebre" ("The Manger") as part of this 10th annual Festival of Israel.

Congratulations to Dr. Gerald M. Edelman for deciphering the structure of gamma globulin. But shame on him for saying in an interview that "poetry is beautiful and useless." The condescension of the scientist. [News story April 15.]

The final accounting of the 1968-69 New York Times Neediest Cases Fund's receipts was made yesterday by the Fund's board chairman, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times Company.

The credit markets handled a heavy volume of new issues with considerable dispatch yesterday as investors continued to construe the Nixon Administration's tax proposals as long-range reasons for lower interest rates.
The annual Feather Ball for Just One Break, Inc., will be held Tuesday at the Pierre. Mrs. Samuel Pryor Reed is chairman of the evening, for which the 500 guests will pay $100 a ticket.

YONKERS, April 22 -- Teninecy Rainbow was sold for $50,000 and Bart Hanover brought $41,000 today as the two-day spring session of the Old Glory Horse Sale was concluded at Yonkers Raceway.

A Pan American World Airways executive yesterday endorsed the recommendation of the American Importers Association that "punitive" charges be imposed on customers who add to air cargo congestion at Kennedy International Airport by delay in picking up their shipments.
The Nixon Administration's decision to abandon the 7 per cent investment tax credit appears to be a response to the ancient maxim, "If it's inevitable, relax and enjoy it."

The First National City Bank, in an expansion move, has signed a lease for 62,356 square feet of floor space in 100 Wall Street, diagonally across the street from an 870,000-square-foot structure the bank has leased in its entirety.
The London stock market reversed its recent slide yesterday with a fairly broad recovery of share prices.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- New orders for durable goods showed a big drop of $1.3-billion in March, but much of the decline was in the volatile flow of defense orders, particularly in the aerospace industry.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Soviet Union has complained to the United States over the build-up of a special task force of 24 warships in the Sea of Japan to protect American reconnaissance missions off the coast of North Korea.
GENEVA, April 22 -- A special committee of the International Labor Organization called on the Spanish Government today to decree a 'generous amnesty or pardon' for imprisoned trade unionists.

In 1946, Sol Hurok decided that he would not call his autobiography "To Hell With Ballet," and the result was the United States debut of the Royal Ballet three years later -- that historic chapter in dance, with its impact on London and New York.
The president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association called on the Nixon Administration and Congress yesterday to set up controls over Federal regulatory agencies.
ABOARD THE QUEEN ELIZABETH 2, in the Atlantic, April 22 -- The Queen Elizabeth 2 started her first commercial voyage today -- a 3,156-mile cruise to the Canary Islands.

The Cultural League of New York, a nonprofit advisory body that promotes the city's artistic events, will hold a symposium on May 5 at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street.

Transience -- in life, love, friendship and simple social justice -- has been the source of many of Alvin Ailey's finest dances. Last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performed a beautiful revival of one such ballet: Mr. Ailey's "Knoxville: Summer of 1915."
LOS ANGELES, April 22 -- The jury deciding whether Sirhan Bishara Sirhan live or dies in a state penitentiary continued its deliberations today as anxiety grew in the courtroom.
The city could sue merchants who deceive their customers, then pay any damages to the victims, under legislation proposed yesterday by the Lindsay administration.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Nixon Administration received a friendly response from the top-ranking members of the House Ways and Means Committee today when it unveiled the details of its interim tax reform plan.

A bill in the State Legislature to raise the permitted interest rate on Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority bonds would, in effect, eliminate an important city option to assume control of a billion dollars worth of T.B.T.A. facilities within a few years.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -Student leaders from many of the nation's leading universities and colleges vowed today they would go to jail rather than serve in the military "as long as the war in Vietnam continues."

LA BRANCHE SWAMP, La., April 17 -- "Rrrrrrummp, rrrrrrummp," said Frank A. Reno, game warden, as he paddled his small boat through the murky water here last night amid a cacophony of aquatic sounds that suggested a barbershop quartet with hiccups and headcolds.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Daniel Jackson Oliver Wendel Holmes Morgan, one of America's foremost jailhouse lawyers, had his day in the Supreme Court today -- as a client.

Consolidated Freightways, Inc., one of the nation's largest trucking companies, announced yesterday that it had acquired a 51 per cent interest in Pacific Far East Line, Inc., from the Natomas Company for about $25-million in cash.
The 38th annual Carnation Ball, a benefit for the Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital in Denver, will take place next Wednesday in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom.

BONN, April 22 -- The West German Cabinet has agreed to push legislation to abolish the statute of limitations for the prosecution of Nazi war criminals and other murderers, according to a top Government source.
In the last paragraph of your editorial of April 13 entitled "Thinking Man's Army," the following assertion is made:
DIANA SANDS, the actress, shifted a platter of fried chicken, part of an elaborate buffet, and smiled.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 23 -- A band of 75 members of Students for a Democratic Society at Princeton University blockaded the entrance to the headquarters here of the Institute for Defense Analyses early this morning with partial success.

TRENTON, April 23 (AP) -- The State Board of Institutions sharply rebuked the administration at Greystone Park State Hospital today and removed the state's Director of Mental Health in the continuing inquiry into charges of sex abuses at the Morris County institution.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI) -- A cigarette manufacturer said today that the tobacco industry would fight in court any attempt to ban cigarette commercials or make them include a stiff health warning.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., April 23 -- Three Negro high school students were arrested here today and jailed overnight after carrying two air rifles -- which their friends later called "symbolic" -- into a morning meeting with their principal.

LONDON, April 23 -- The vast wealth and influence of Viscount Cowdray, one of Britain's richest men, is being detailed for the first time. The occasion is his decision to offer the public a minority interest in his family's huge private holding company, S. Pearson Son.

BALTIMORE, April 23 (AP) -- Conestoga Flash, under top weight of 114 pounds, became the first three-time winner of the Pimlico spring meeting today by capturing the featured seventh race under Eldon Nelson.

Mr. Stinson noted that demand for steel was inflated by inventory building in the early part of 1968. He said the earnings comparison had also been affected by provision for the 10 per cent surtax in the 1969 quarter.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Justice Department disclosed today that it would appeal to the Supreme Court the recent ruling by a Federal judge in Boston that a nonreligious person could qualify as a conscientious objector.

City College was ordered closed again today by its president, Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, following an agreement to discuss the "non-negotiable" demands of Negro and Puerto Rican students who are blockading the south campus.

ALBANY, April 23 -- The Legislature, struggling to adjourn by this weekend, will be called back into special session after the Nov. 4 elections by Governor Rockefeller to redraw the state's 41 Congressional districts, legislative sources disclosed today.

BROOKLYN COLLEGE is expected to register its 27th consecutive dual-meet tennis victory when it faces Adelphi today. The Kingsmen have been dominant in Eastern small-college competition since shortly after Charles Tobey became the coach in 1967.
KARLSRUHE, West Germany, April 23 (Reuters) -- Karl Blessing, West German Federal Bank president, today forecast that Governments would opt for greater currency discipline.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 23 -- Prof. Henry Rosovsky, chairman of the faculty committee that urged Harvard University to develop a program in Afro-American studies, resigned today from a new committee that is forming the program.
CHERRY HILL, N. J., April 23 (AP) -- Elberon Farm's Process Shot, under a highweight of 124 pounds, easily won the $28,225 Betsy Ross Stakes today as Garden State Park opened its 28th racing season.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Nixon Administration went on record today in favor of giving Arab refugees the choice between repatriation or compensation as part of a Middle East settlement.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI) -- John W. Gardner said today the Government should immediately pour billions of dollars into a broad antipoverty program.
FORT DIX, N. J., April 23 -- One soldier was convicted today and another was acquitted of charges of distributing antiwar material here.

The Marine Midland Bank of Southeastern New York, Poughkeepsie, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Saugerties (N. Y.) National Bank. Under terms of the deal, three shares of Marine Midland Banks, Inc. (parent company of the Poughkeepsie bank) would be exchanged for each share of the Saugerties National.

At an organizational meeting of the Association of Primary Dealers in United States Government Securities held Tuesday, William E. Simon of Salomon Brothers Hutzler was elected president, it was announced yesterday.
Three floors in the Gulf and Western Building now rising at Columbus Circle have been leased by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants, for an aggregate rent of about $8-million.
LOS ANGELES, April 23 -- Sirhan Bishara Sirhan was condemned to death in the gas chamber today for the murder of Senator Robert F. Kennedy last year.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers scotched mounting suspicions in the State Department and diplomatic community today that he would shortly leave his job to go to the Supreme Court.

With more than $50 million of new commercial and residential construction sparked by Lincoln Center completed around Lincoln Square since 1963 and $60 million more in the construction and drawing stage, it has become apparent to the city's planners that some kind of order -- both functional and esthetic -- must be imposed on the area. The attitude of the developers as crisis is compounded is strictly business as usual.
PEKING, April 23 (Agence France-Press) -- The ninth party congress is likely to mark the start of a period of relative moderation in Chinese internal politics, observers here said today.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The nation's factories continued to operate at only 84 per cent of capacity on the average in the first quarter, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
A recital devoted to groups of songs by Dowland, Vaughan Williams, Richard Strauss, Poulenc and Falla is a welcome event, and William Mount is to be praised for having provided it.
The Police Department yesterday ordered four Bronx precincts to establish the controversial fourth platoon next Monday.
Victor Muscat, the embattled financier, has staved off an insurgent bid to win control of Defiance Industries, the apex of his corporate empire.

PARIS, April 23 -- The Nixon Administration faces a long and difficult period of negotiations with foreign nations if its proclaimed objective of further trade liberalization is to be achieved. Secretary of Com merce Maurice H. Stans, making the Administration's first working contacts with Europe ans in trade matters, has found at first hand that the going will be rough.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 23 -- Upsala College, a normally calm institution affiliated with the Lutheran Church, was the scene last night and this morning of a minor student demonstration that appeared more symbolic than militant.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Senator John Stennis, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, showed signs today of groping around for a compromise on the missile defense issue.
CAIRO, April 23 -- The Egyptian Government's chief spokesman said today that Cairo considered the 1967 cease-fire agreement with Israel to be void,
LISBON, April 23 -- Students of the University of Coimbra proclaimed "academic mourning'' today to protest the suspension of student association leaders.

GEORGES MILLS, N. H., April 18 -- Dipping live smelt out of a well m his dock, John (Babe) Sargent, fisherman, artist and Lake Sunapee marina operator, fed several of the squirming silvery fish to a fat gray cat who was rubbing against his leg.
LONDON, April 23 -- Hungarian industry has turned to the West for capital funds for the first time since World War II.
CHICAGO, April 23 -- The Inland Steel Company plans to pursue a program of diversification through acquisition, Philip D. Block Jr., chairman, told shareholders today at the annual meeting.

ITHACA, April 23 -- The Cornell faculty, facing the threat of building seizures by militant students and by some of its own members, reversed itself today and nullified disciplinary action against five Negro students.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., April 23 -- Five hundred stockholders of the General Electric Company, the world's fourth largest industrial corporation in sales, gathered in the Beverly Hilton Hotel's ballroom today for a placid two-hour colloquy with company executives.

LONDON, April 23 -- European currency markets had another erratic session today amid political and economic uncertainties. The pressures were less than yesterday, but foreign exchange traders expect nervous dealings to continue until the weekend.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Robert Henry McCride, the United States Ambassador to the Congo (Kinshasa) since 1967, was named today by President Nixon as Ambassador to Mexico.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 23 -- An American military spokesman tonight announced the loss of five helicopters.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The House handed the Nixon Administration a solid victory today, scaling down extension of Federal aid to schools from five to two years and consolidating some grant programs.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren, who has had his political differences with President Nixon, and Mrs. Warren were honored tonight at a flower - bedecked White House dinner.

FORT JACKSON, S.C., April 23 -- The Army reversed today the pattern it has been following here in dropping charges against individual suspects during the pretrial proceedings of a group of outspokenly antiwar soldiers known as the Fort Jackson Eight.

It is a pleasure to report that Melissa Hayden, who has been afflicted with more physical torments than Job this year, is alive and well at the State Theater. She danced "Tchaikovsky Suite" for the first time last night with New York City Ballet and showed clearly how much of a star vehicle this a la russe melange of steps is.

PRAGUE, April 23 -- At the Czechoslovak Communist party's urging, a group of conservative journalists are reported to be forming an organization to serve as a counterweight to the reform-minded Czech Union of Journalists.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 23 -- Roosevelt Raceway's policy of presenting its Friday and Saturday features as the eighth event on the program will be changed for Saturday night's 21st edition of the United States Harness Writers' Trot.
LAGOS, Nigeria, April 23 -- The Government said today that federal forces had captured Umuahia, administrative headquarters of Biafra and the last major center held by the secessionist regime.

Trading volume expanded yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as prices turned mixed.
In the largest tax-exempt revenue bond sale so far this year, the Delaware River Port Authority raised $140-million yesterday to finance construction of two bridges near Philadelphia.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Thursday, April 24 -- Capt. Terence O'Neill, the Ulster Prime Minister, won narrow approval from his Unionist (Conservative) parliamentary colleagues yesterday for legislation to grant equal voting rights to all in Northern Ireland.

The attention drawn to thoroughbred racing with the emergence of women jockeys will be shared soon by harness racing, which announced yesterday a series of international races in which the drivers will be women.

Most neighborhood anti-poverty agencies were reported closed yesterday as hundreds of people demonstrated outside City Hall against a sharp cut planned in the city's anti-poverty budget.

GUATEMALA, April 23 -- The Peruvian representative at the 10th annual meeting of the Board of Governors of the Inter-American Development Bank, the major source of loans for Latin America, today attacked United States predominance in money-lending in the hemisphere.

HOUSTON, April 23 -- With tickets at $100 a ringside seat for the first time for a single indoor heavyweight title bout, Joe Frazier will defend his share of the world championship against Jerry Quarry on June 23, a Monday night, at Madison Square Garden.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 23 -- Israel called on Secretary General Thant and the Security Council today to insist that the United Arab Republic abide by the cease-fire agreement.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Members of the House Ways and Means Committee of both parties continued their criticism of the Nixon Administration today for failing to go far enough with its tax reform proposals.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company achieved a 12.2 per cent increase in first-quarter earnings on sales gain of 11 per cent. Both sales and earnings set records for the period, the report from Akron, Ohio disclosed yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, April 23 (AP) -- Fifty-eight defectors from American military service have left Sweden thus far to return to the United States or to American military camps elsewhere, the United States Embassy in Stockholm disclosed today.

TORONTO, April 23 -- Harry S. Wingate, chairman of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., forecast today that world production of nickel would expand by 5 per cent this year and by as much -- or a bit less -- in 1970. He anticipated that Inco would retain its 60 per cent share of the non-Communist market.
LONDON, April 23 -- The British Leyland Motor Corporation will unveil tomorrow its long-delayed Austin Maxi 1500, the first new all-British car in four years.

MOVING up in the scheme of things can mean moving down in fact. Witness Olga Oshrin, who started selling hand-knit designs about two years ago in a tiny, second-floor shop at 128 West 72d Street. Mrs. Oshrin and Linda, her daughter and partner, recently moved down to street level in new digs at 211 West 72d Street.

The State Legislature seems about to cap its sorry 1969 record with a $40-million giveaway to the politically influential operators of harness racing tracks. This openhandedness to an industry built on betting comes amid reports of backdoor trafficking by shadowy forces in Albany. Even without such reports, the proposed handout would be a disgrace after the ruthlessness the legislators exhibited in balancing the state budget at the expense of the poor and afflicted.

PARIS, April 23 -- Former Premier Georges Pompidou, in a televised appeal to the nation tonight, urged a "yes" vote in the referendum Sunday in the the name of "common sense" and "fidelity to General de Gaulle."
BONN, April 23 -- The West German Cabinet moved today to modify its decision to seek abolition of the statute of limitations for prosecution of Nazi war criminals and other murderers.

The Lindsay administration lost the opening round yesterday in its attempt to reverse a ruling by one of its own agencies -- a ruling that granted a special zoning variance to a private developer to build a luxury apartment house opposite Lincoln Center.

Robert H. Stier Jr., has been appointed vice president-manufacturing of the Gillette Toiletries Company, Boston. Formerly vice president of manufacturing operations of the Paper Mate Manufacturing Company, he replaces R. W. Britton, who has been named vice presidentoperations services of Gillette.
SYRACUSE, April 23 -- Three separate groups demonstrated at Syracuse University today with varying success.
A 43-year-old writer has encamped at Columbia University and over the last four days has disbursed about $3,000 in $100 and $50 handouts to students and others who Strike his fancy.

MONTREAL, April 23 -Except for Coach Claude Ruel, the Canadiens have been bemused by the strange turns their Stanley Cup series has taken against the Boston Bruins. Today, they still were discussing the 26 shots the Bostonians took in the second period last night.

Mayor Lindsay's proposal for setting up a management corporation to run the city's hospital system, freeing it from webs of bureaucratic red tape, has been modified by the City Council in minor but important ways. The modifications improve the proposal, and the full Council should approve it today. That will clear the way for an immediate go-ahead from the State Legislature.

The board of governors of the American Stock Exchange has adopted amendments to the exchange's constitution which make allied members of the exchange eligible for the office of chairman of the board.

NEW CITY, N. Y., April 23 -- Edwin W. Kirk, former Rockland County Commissioner of Social Services, and his assistant, Gerald Steinberg, pleaded not guilty here today before County Judge John Gallucci to sealed indictments that followed a three-month grand jury investigation.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The first attempt from space at in-depth measurements of temperature and humidity within the atmosphere is a dramatic success.
DETROIT, April 23 -- The Ford Motor Company today reported an 18 per cent drop in first- quarter profits to $167.7-million, or $1.54 a share, from $203.3-million, or $1.86 a share, a year ago.

ALBANY, April 23 -- An upstate Republican Senator urged fellow legislators today not to vote themselves expense-allowance increases this year, because of the extensive cuts the Legislature made in the recently passed state budget for welfare, education and health programs.

A copy of the first English translation of Jacques Cartier's "shorte and briefe narration" of his voyages and discoveries in Canada was auctioned yesterday for $21,000 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The rise in consumer prices accelerated in March and was the largest for any month since the peak of Korean War inflation in early 1951, the Labor Department reported today.

THE last hours of a marriage -- wild, bleak, bloody and harrowing -- provide ostensibly the complete subject matter for Lanford Wilson's "The Gingham Dog," which opened at the John Golden Theater last night.

The Penn Central Company, on a parent railroad company basis, and including the operations of the New Haven Railroad, reported yesterday a net loss in the quarter ended March 31 of $12,764,000, in contrast to a net profit of $1,026,000, or four cents a share, for the comparable period last year.
PASADENA, Calif., April 23 (AP) -- A $34 - million school bond issue to finance a high school complex designed to provide racial balance for 7,500 students has been turned down by voters.

NEW ORLEANS, April 23 (UPI) -- A $4-million damage suit was filed in the United States District Court here yesterday in connection with a fiery accident April 6, involving a freighter and an oil barge on the Mississippi, that left 25 persons dead.

Fears of currency devaluations caused a slump in British Government bonds yesterday on the London stock market. Share prices again advanced, partly on currency hedge buying. Trading was slow.

ALBANY, April 23 -- A New York City school decentralization bill pieced together in three weeks of negotiations received tentative approval today from a majority of Democrats in the Legislature, the Republican leadership and the teachers' union.

ALBANY, April 23 -- Former State Supreme Court Justice Louis Friedman, who was removed from his Brooklyn bench six years ago for official misconduct, was thwarted today in his effort to collect the salary that was cut off by his ouster.

ROME, April 23 (AP) -- Manuel Santana of Spain and Martin Riessen of Evanston, Ill., were upset and favored Arthur Ashe and Tom Okker had to struggle to win in the second round of the Italian open tennis tournament today.

Col. Frank Borman, commander of the Apollo 8 flight around the moon, said yesterday that the most important reason for pressing space exploration was to "challenge American technology and American industry" as has never happened, "except under the stress of war."
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 23 -- The Brazilian Government has decided to place a tax of 13 cents a pound on instant coffee exports to the United States, it was announced tonight.

MOSCOW, April 23 -- Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, challenger for the world Chess championship, defeated Tigran Petrosian his compatriot who holds the title, at Moscow's Variety Theater tonight in the fifth game of their 24-game match.

Prof. John K. Fairbank and his distinguished colleagues (letter, April 10) assert that the leadership of China in its international dealings has shown neither irrationality nor a disposition to launch unprovoked aggression in any of its more traditional forms, least of all to initiate a nuclear war with the United States.

The New York Mets heaved a collective sigh of relief last night when Jerry Koosman -- one of the late bloomers of a cold spring -- pitched nine innings and defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates on five hits, 2-0.

He said he anticipated a delayed impact of any repeal, and added, "I have some question whether this is well conceived. What condition the economy will be in when it begins to show up, we're not yet in a position to make a judgment."
LIMA, Peru, April 23 -- A conference of 43 nations exploring potential new approaches to the development of Latin America ended today after a series of vaguely worded resolutions had been approved.
Yeshiva University yesterday canceled all undergraduate classes as more than 1,200 placard-bearing, chanting and singing students occupied a university building.

THE Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's Broadway image, strengthened through its appearances at the Billy Rose Theater two months ago, lost some of its luster last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music -- and this was all to the good.

PITTSBURGH, April 23 -- Morris B. Abram, president of Brandeis University, said today that the nation would never again "have the same sorry set of national standards nor will we ever again look on war with the same attitude" because of the generation of students now in American colleges.
ITHACA, N. Y., April 23 -- "They brought us here for their benefit -- to integrate the place. This is Cornell, the great liberal campus in the East. And you can't be liberal without Negroes."
Ever sign on the dotted line and then wish you could back out of the deal?

The American system of justice, which was shown at its best in the long and careful trial of Sirhan B. Sirhan, has been exposed at its worst in the jury's decision yesterday to sentence Sirhan to death.
ITHACA, N. Y., April 23 -- The wild cheer that echoed through Barton Hall's cavernous basketball court and drill deck from 9,000 white students this afternoon was made up of both triumph and relief.

BRUSSELS, April 23 -- Recent diplomatic exchanges have disclosed that members of the Warsaw Pact are interested in exploring the North Atlantic alliance's cautious approach toward negotiations leading to a detente, qualified sources said today.
TOKYO, April 23 -- North Korea said in effect today that it would continue to shoot down American reconnaissance planes if they violated its airspace.
JERUSALEM, April 23 -- An Israeli Government official said tonight that Egypt's assertion that the cease-fire agreement was void represented no more than a rewording of earlier declarations.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 23 (AP) -- Jane Blalock, in her first North and South amateur golf tournament, upset a two-time winner, Mrs. Nancy Roth Syms, 1 up, today to join Barbara McIntire, Phyllis (Tish) Pruess and Connie Day in the semi-finals.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Nixon proposed today a $61-million attack on organized crime, focused largely on the illegal gambling operations of the Mafia.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., (UPI) -- Jerry West scored a playoff career high of 53 points tonight, including a pair of free throws with four seconds left as the Los Angeles Lakers defeated the Boston Celtics, 120-118, in the opening game of the National Basketball Association championship series.

MUNCIE, Ind., April 23 -- Whether Muncie residents gather at Frosty Miller's Tavern or out at the Flamingo Supper Club, they engage in a common conversation: just where and when is inflation going to stop.
Developments at troubled colleges and high schools yesterday included the following:

Reports of Mayor John Lindsay's political death have been greatly exaggerated. Mourners from the provinces are finding him alive and -- if not well -- kicking hard in the hydra-headed monstrosity that New York's mayoralty campaign has become.

DALLAS, April 23 -- Mickey Mantle said today that he would rather play baseball than golf for a living. "Professional golf has got to be the most competitive sport," he remarked after participating in the pro-amateur preliminary to the $100,000 Byron Nelson Classic.
One hundred and sixty actors appearing on Broadway have signed a petition asking Actor's Equity to limit nudity at auditions and performances off Broadway.

A hundred students seized the Hall of Languages at the University Heights campus of New York University at dawn yesterday after a breakdown in talks with the heads of the English department on the dismissal of an instructor championed by the students.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 23 -- The enemy is sending South Vietnamese teen-agers to North Vietnam for political indoctrination, allied intelligence officials said today.

ST. MARY, Mont., April 18 -- The brown hands grasped the rubber mallet and tapped it softly against the sharpened chisel. The blade dug firmly into the slab of clean white pine, dislodging a tiny chip. The process was repeated several times, and gradually the curved leg of a horse began to emerge.

ATSUGI, Japan, April 23 -- The families of the 31 crewmen of the United States reconnaissance plane shot down by North Korea last week, joined by fellow Navy pilots, gathered today for memorial and prayer services.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 23 -- Lebanon declared a state of emergency tonight after at least seven persons had been killed and scores injured in clashes between security forces and demonstrators protesting restrictions on Palestinian guerrillas, who have been using Lebanon as a base for attacks on Israel. Beirut was placed under a strict curfew.
IN the quarter-final stage of the New York Double Knockout Championship six teams survive in the once-defeated category.
Stocks continued to be narrowly mixed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
TOPEKA, Kan., April 24 -- A new criminal code for Kansas, containing a liberalized section on abortions, was signed today by Gov. Robert Docking.
The American Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that it would open an investigation into trading in the shares of the Parvin-Dohrmann Company, which owns three Las Vegas gambling casinos.

The nation's banking system was under exceptionally heavy strain during the last week in adjusting to the increased requirements for reserves against deposits that were effective on April 17, monetary data reported yesterday showed.

LOS ANGELES, April 24 -- Eleven jurors looked across the long brown table at the one man who still believed, after almost two days of deliberation, that Sirhan should spend the rest of his life in prison for the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.
The Procter Gamble Company attained the highest sales and earnings in its history in the threee and nine months ended March 31, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today that new international trans-Pacific routes awarded by President Nixon to four airlines would become effective May 28.
ROME, April 24 (AP) -- Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia eliminated third-seeded Arthur Ashe today and set off another wave of upsets in the Italian open tennis championships.

Tom Wicker's April 17 column on the distorted sense of values reflected in the Nixon budget and your editorial of the same date on the "neglected lessons" that we must learn of substituting diplomacy for military responses, are actually sermons on the same subject.
The former executive direcor of the Overseas Press Club was arrested yesterday on a harge of stealing more than 1,500 from the club.
HONG KONG, Friday, April 25 -- The ninth congress of the Chinese Communist party concluded its meeting in Peking yesterday with the naming of a Central Committee of 170 members and 109 alternates.

IT has been several years since I last heard Gina Bachauer play a solo recital, and it has been many years longer than that since I last ran across Liszt's "Spanish Rhapsody" in concert. So off to Carnegie Hall last night, where the great lady was playing Beethoven's "Waldstein" Sonata, Chopin's B minor Sonata and Schumann's "Kinderscenen," in addition to the Liszt.

BOSTON, Friday, April 25 -- It took Jean Beliveau 16 years -- and perhaps his final one in the National Hockey League -- but the big man scored an overtime goal today that gave the Montreal Canadiens a 2-1 double overtime victory and the East Division final series with the Boston Bruins.

BONN, Friday, April 25 -- The West German Cabinet agreed last night finally and without reservation to press for the abolition of the statute of limitations on prosecution of Nazi war criminals and other murderers.
" Che!," the off Off Broadway play, is scheduled to reopen tonight at the Free Store Theater.
OTTAWA, April 24 (AP) -- Transport Minister Paul Hellyer announced today his resignation from the Cabinet.

Leaders of both the Democratic and Republican parties have been preparing legislation to end the state's year-old system of open primary elections for statewide offices, including Governor and United States Senator.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 24 (AP) -- Iranian military forces strengthened their fortifications along the Shatt al Arab river frontier with Iraq today and another Iranian freighter prepared for a voyage up the disputed river.

PITTSBURGH, April 24 -- After three days of discussions, members of the Academy of Religion and Mental Health generally agreed today that rebellious students were staying in college too long, were not being given enough responsibility for their own affairs and were not being listened to by the older generation that is teaching them.

THE sale of the New York Jets appears imminent and the price tag will be in the neighborhood of $15 to $20-million. For those on the receiving end that's a lovely neighborhood to be in. For the buyer, though, the cost appears ridiculously high. Yet no one is placing a gun to his head and putting the snatch on his wallet.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI) -- Robert H. Finch, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, criticized a report today that had been used by Republicans to justify the transfer of Head Start from the Office of Economic Opportunity to the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

PARIS, April 24 -- Federal Reserve authorities have carried out a series of discreet consultations with the leading American borrowers in the Eurodollar market to see what can be done about restricting this activity, it was disclosed here today.

Dissident Fordham students ended a 24-hour sit-in at the university administration building at midday yesterday and marched to the Campus Center building chanting "U. S. out of Vietnam. Rotsy (R.O.T.C.) out of Fordham."

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The most exciting thing in Washington these lovely spring days is Washington itself. It is inexpressibly, almost recklessly beautiful: a remarkable combination of male and female -- strong, orderly and heroic, yet veiled by the young green leaves of the trees, like an impressionistic painting of a monument.
Five men have been named as co-conspirators in connection with possible sweetheart contracts involving Local 11 of the Restaurant Workers Union and restaurant owners in the metropolitan area.

Earnings of the New York Telephone Company continued the downward trend that started in the second quarter of 1968, reflecting the rise in operating expenses and taxes, plus higher labor rates since the signing of a new labor contract in mid-1968.

A WHILE back, when they were showing warm weather clothes, it looked like designers, with their see-throughs and cut-outs, were bent on returning to the fig leaf and putting themselves out of business.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) -- The Justice Department filed its first suit against "blockbusting" today, charging a Baltimore realty firm with racial discrimination in the sale of housing.
Alerino Caceres, hawk-nosed and pushing 40, smiled a gold-toothed smile at Aqueduct yesterday when John Cotter told him the truth about Kimberly Girl.

David Amram's opera "Twelfth Night," based on the Shakespeare play, was given its premiere by the Lake George Opera Company last August. The Presidential Realty Corporation of White Plains has contracted to buy the Government-financed Tysens Parl middle-income apartment development nearing completion a Tysens Lane and Mill Road in New Dorp, S.I.

The almost straight upward line on copper futures price charts came to an end yesterday, at least temporarily. Prices, and hence the chart line, moved down -- perhaps as a technical reaction to the long, strong rise since the year's start.

PARIS, April 24 -- The principal speakers for the Gaullist regime and for the opposition today reflected expectations of a close outcome in Sunday's referendum by focusing their campaign on the possible consequences of a Government defeat.

The proposal to repeal the 7 per cent tax credit for investment in new plant and equipment was not designed primarily as an anti-inflation move, and in any event will probably have very little impact on the over-all economy, a member of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers said here yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, April 24 -- When a basketball player scores 53 points against the Boston Celtics, what more could he possibly ask for? The answer, if he is Jerry West, is 63 points.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., April 24 (AP) -- An anticipated proxy fight for control of the Western Air Lines board of directors evaporated before the start of an annual stockholders' meeting today, when Terrell C. Drinkwater, president, and Kirk Kerkorian, a Las Vegas financier, jointly proposed a compromise.

Consumer prices in the New York City area jumped 1 per cent from February to March, the Labor Department reported yesterday. That means that it cost 6.1 per cent more to live here last month than it did a year earlier.
CHICAGO, April 24 -- Stockholders of United Airlines took the first step at their annual meeting today toward diversification, as they approved creation of a holding company.

ALBANY, April 24 -- A controversial bill legalizing pari-mutuel betting on quarter-horse racing, which narrowly passed the Assembly Tuesday, was pronounced dead in its present form in the Senate today.

For the third time in seven days, the New York Mets lost one to the weatherman yesterday. Their Shea Stadium game with the Pittsburgh Pirates was postponed because of low temperatures and soggy grass.

SAIGON, April 24 -- Allied officials said today that enemy troops had pulled back from most population centers throughout South Vietnam and were arrayed much as they were before the spring offensive that began two months ago.

The country's paper industry is running at capacity, with demand exceeding last year's by 8 per cent, despite record output, William R. Adams, president of the St. Regis Paper Company, told the annual meeting yesterday.
HOUSTON, April 24 -- A human heart and lungs, kept alive in a special organ preservation machine, were flown from San Antonio to Houston early this morning in the first intercity trial of the device.

DETROIT, April 24 -- Earnings of the General Motors Corporation climbed 25 per cent in the first quarter to $522.7-million, or $1.82 a common share, from the year-earlier $418.8-million, or $1.46 a share.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Rates on nine-month and one-year Treasury bills declined at today's $1.5-billion auction from last month's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

The world's major shipping companies have asked Governor Rockefeller to veto two bills that would give 145 Sandy Hook pilots a 50 per cent rise in their incomes, to more than $30,000 annually, and a similar percentage increase to their Hudson River colleagues.

It is a mistake not to punish North Korea for killing 31 U.S. airmen shot down in their unarmed plane over the Sea of Japan. Surely we were taught by the Pueblo disaster that total military forbearance is not respected and creates further tragedy.

UNLESS you are a vegetarian, you will be happy to know that you can buy a good fiberglass boat today for the same price a pound as a good steak. And when you think how a zippy 17- footer or a palatial 47-foot cruiser can bring happiness for years while a steak is enjoyed today and gone tomorrow, it can be made into a fairly startling fact.

The National Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress will hold a luncheon Tuesday in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom at which awards will be presented to Representative Shirley A. Chisholm of Brooklyn, Mrs. James Fuld, campaign chairman of the New York Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, Dr. Sophia L. Halpern, a physician, and Myrna Loy, the actress.
The development of the first 80 acres of the College Point Industrial Park in Queens was voted last night by the Board of Estimate.

HOF, West Germany, April 24 -- The murder trial of Alois Doerr, the wartime SS (Elite Guard) commandant of a Nazi concentration camp at Helmbrechts, near here, heard testimony this week from eight of Doerr's former prisoners, four of whom came from Israel for the trial.

The Casablanca Complex, defined by Humphrey Bogart a generation ago in a movie and thriving today in a hit Broadway play by Woody Allen, permeated major league baseball activity yesterday. The syndrome is summed up in the lyric, "the fundamental things apply as time goes by," which Bogie kept imploring Sam to play again.
Thirty-six of the city's 192 free public libraries will be closed if proposed cuts are made in the executive budgets, according to the heads of the three library systems here.
PARIS, April 24 -- South Vietnam's chief negotiator at the peace talks here denied today that his Government was seeking the destruction or surrender of the forces fighting it.

Howard J. Samuels, former head of the Small Business Administration, accused the Nixon Administration last night of allowing the Federal program of aid to minority-owned businesses to "slip backwards."

BONN, April 24 -- Dr. Herbert Weichmann, the Mayor of Hamburg and the highest government official in West Germany who is Jewish, turned down a chance last year to become federal President because he felt that a Jew should not be the country's head of state.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 25 -- Daylong raids by high-altitude bombers rained almost 3,000 tons of bombs on the Cambodian border area northwest of Saigon yesterday -- by far the heaviest bombing concentration of the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The American Society of International Law heard arguments today that North Korea and other small countries might be justified in taking drastic action to protect themselves from electronic reconnaissance by the great powers.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 24 -- Record first-quarter sales and earnings, a new corporate name and efforts to move into the electronics field were announced here today by the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation.

A LOT of long-established fashion rules are falling by the wayside these days. Take watches, for instance. A real watch (one from a serious watchmaker with a price tag in three figures or better) has usually been a small, discreet affair a woman would wear for years.
The estranged wife of a Manhattan clothing manufacturer was released in $15,000 bail yesterday on charges of attempting to hire an undercover detective for $10,000 to kill her husband.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Nixon asked Congress today for a series of postage rate increases, including a penny an ounce more for first-class mail, to provide $638-million in Government revenue.
CLEVELAND, April 24 -- Even the debut of Ken Harrelson, the darling of the mod set, was of no help to the sagging fortunes of the Cleveland Indians tonight against the New York Yankees.
Leo M. Weins, president of the H. W. Wilson Company, has been elected a trustee of the Dollar Savings Bank of New York.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 24 -- The Harvard faculty has learned a great deal from its students -- and from its own members -- in the last two weeks of unrest.

ONEONTA, N. Y., April 24 (AP) -- Officials at the State University campus here have turned down a demand by Negro students for a $35 weekly spending allowance, it was announced today.

A jagged red line inked on a map of the West Side provided the key last night to approval of a special zoning district for the area around Lincoln Center.

Leonard Bernstein started down the homestretch of his directorship of the New York Philharmonic last night as he returned for a final four-week session. He is conducting works that his audiences have expressed a desire to hear him do.

RICHMOND, England (AP) -- Magistrate Charles Moody applied the judgement of Solomon to a bicycle dispute but neither party gave an inch. So Gary Carrig got the seat, bell, pump, chain and handlebar grips. Stephen Thomas, his playmate from next door, got the frame, wheels and handlebars.

The poem, "My Thing," by Horace Mungin, deals with a major theme of the black revolution that is frequently expressed in cries for "liberation," for "self-determination" and for a "positive identity."

ALBANY, April 24 -- A tentative agreement on a compromise school decentralization bill for New York City, endorsed by all but a handful of the figures involved in the issue, was blown apart at day-break today after the State Board of Regents declined to endorse the proposal.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The United States and West Germany are reported to have agreed in principle on a "burden-sharing" formula to cover the annual balance-of-payments costs to the United States for maintaining 200,000 troops in West Germany.

A national committee for assistance to victims of the Biafran-Nigerian war is being organized with the support of former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey, Mrs. Martin Luther King and a number of prominent church leaders and private citizens.
DALLAS, April 24 -- Bert Greene, a 25-year-old Fort Lauderdale, Fla., professional, solved the tempo of the fast greens so well today he led with a 66 in the Byron Nelson Golf Classic.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Nixon administration was accused today of attempting to "muzzle" the director of a Federal study on hunger and malnutrition in America.
DETROIT, April 24 -- A Common Pleas Court judge today awarded $361.04 to a woman whose suitcase was lost on a bus trip from Fort Smith, Ark., to Detroit.

FORT JACKSON, S. C., April 24 -- The Army put on the witness stand today for the first time its G.I. informer on the so-called Fort Jackson Eight, an interracial group of antiwar soldiers that faces a court-martial here on charges of "demonstrating" and "making political speeches" against the war in Vietnam.

BATON ROUGE, La., April 24 (AP) -- A Federal judge dismissed today the Justice Department's first discrimination suit under the fair housing section of the 1968 Civil Rights Act. Judge E. Gordon West of United States District Court ruled that the alleged acts of discrimination by six real estate firms and five of their top officers were not subject to provisions of the law.

RAMAT SHALOM, Israeli Occupied Syria, April 23 -- Private enterprise, an unusual concept in Israeli land settlement, was established today in a corner of the occupied Golan Heights by a group of American and British immigrants who intend to operate a ski resort.
MOSCOW, April 24 (Reuters) -- The traditional Red Square military parade will not take place on May Day this year and will be replaced by a "workers' meeting," it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Robert H. Finch, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today he continued to stand by the candidacy of Dr. John H. Knowles for the important post of Assistant Secretary for Health and Scientific Affairs.

The Baltimore architectural and planning firm of Taliaferro, Kostritsky, Lamb has announced the addition of three partners and the incorporation of its practice. The corporation will be known as RTKL, Inc.

The stock market forged ahead with quiet strength yesterday, paced by computer, electronic, glamour and savings-and-loan issues.

Prime Minister Wilson's decision to push anti-strike legislation has provoked the greatest convulsion in Britain's Labor party since it returned to power in 1964. Union and left-wing opposition to the proposals has strained party viability to the point where Mr. Wilson has threatened Labor rebels with his ultimate sanction: dissolution of Parliament and new elections.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
