PARAMUS, N. J., April 24 -- The Garden State Women's Golf Association opened its 16th season today with a get acquainted tournament over the East and West nines of the Ridgewood Country Club course.
ALBANY, April 24 -- The controversial plan to build a $140-million bridge across Long Island Sound between Rye and Oyster Bay received a go-ahead today from the state's highest court.
A Federal judge granted welfare clients an order yesterday restraining the state from reducing welfare payments until the constitutionality and validity of the cuts could be tested in the courts.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The United States has agreed to a $30-million arms deal with Jordan, including sale of a second squadron of 18 F-104 jet interceptors, reliable sources reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Some Republican Senators opposed to the Safeguard system, but reluctant to break with the White House, are advancing a strategic arms moratorium as a way out of the political impasse confronting the Administration on the missile defense issue.

Britain will continue to encourage the merger trend among companies in that country, the new British Ambassador to the United States, John Freeman, declared in an address here yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 24 -- In his first public appearance after two weeks of crisis at Harvard, the university President, Nathan M. Pusey, today declared "categorically and as emphatically as I can say it that disruption and coercion have absolutely no place" in achieving change on college campuses.

NEW DELHI, April 24 -- Chester Bowles, who ended his tenure as Ambassador to India Monday after nearly six years, left behind some outspoken last reflections on such matters as the "obsession" of Indian leaders with ideological slogans and the widespread evasion of tax and land-reform laws.

The three winners of this year's Bancroft Prizes for the best books in American history and international relations were announced last night at Columbia University.
ALBANY, April 24 -- Governor Rockefeller late today urged the Legislature to approve a bill that would make possession of firearms on campus a crime punishable by up to seven years in prison.
MOSCOW, April 24 -- The Soviet Union made public today a proposed new charter for its collective farms, replacing outdated statutes adopted in 1935.
ARTFUL use of the powers of color television brought George Washington to life -- well, almost -- in a Donald B. Hyatt production last night at 7:30 on the National Broadcasting Company network.

THE second of these two books on conservation, "Wildlife in Danger," spotlights the problem. An illustrated encyclopedia based on the files of the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources, the volume lists and describes the "mammals, birds, and other animals and plants that are threatened with extinction."
WASHINGTON, April 25 -Senators Edmund S. Muskie and Eugene J. McCarthy proposed today that the Democratic party hold a mid-term national convention to discuss issues and adopt a party platform.
Forty-seven of the 50 states will go on daylight saving time tomorrow as clocks are moved ahead one hour at 2 A.M.

The Board of Education conceded yesterday that it had erred in excluding 678 students from Franklin K. Lane High School last January as a means of ending overcrowding and restoring discipline after student attacks on teachers.

ALBANY, April 25 -- The Republican legislative leadership began today to work with Negro and Puerto Rican members of the New York City legislative group to draft a new compromise school decentralization bill. By nightfall, sources close to the Republican leaders said that they "appeared to be within three or four hours of a bill" and that plans were to take up the measure tomorrow.

MOSCOW, April 25 -- The sixth game of the 24-game match series for the world chess championship between Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, the titleholder, and his fellow countryman, Boris Spassky, the challenger, was played tonight at Moscow's Variety Theater and was adjourned.

Most major landlords and managers of the city's uncontrolled apartments are not expected to reduce rents as mandated by the City Council until June 1, according to sources close to the leadership of the real estate industry.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., April 25 -- About 600 employes continued their sit-in and work stoppage today at three hospitals and a nursing home in Nassau and Suffolk Counties in support of 24 practical nurses seeking recognition of their union.
BOSTON, April 25 (AP) -- Joe Cronin, president of the American League, warned today that the rule barring pitchers from deliberately throwing at batters would be strictly enforced.

LONDON, April 25 -- The Beatles have made a $5.1-million counter offer to stockholders of their song company, Northern Songs, Ltd., to win control and defeat a take-over attempt by the Associated Television Corporation.

PARIS, April 25 -- President de Gaulle, in a last appeal to the voters, asked the French nation tonight for a "show of confidence" that would enable him to serve out his term and finish his "30-year chapter" in French history.
CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -Suicide is the second greatest cause of death among college students and the third greatest among youths of high school age, a Harvard psychiatrist reported today.

The nation's chain stores and catalogue houses registered a sales gain of 11.4 per cent in March over the same month last year, and had a volume increase of 13.1 per cent for the first quarter of the year.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 28 -- Bart Hanover, a 3-year-old pacer who originally cost $105,000, suffered various injuries and ailments while earning $502, then was sold for $41,000, was among eight horses who went to the post in a one-mile qualifying dash at Roosevelt Raceway this morning.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The effect of gun control legislation that bared the importation of cheap, concealable hand guns is being offset by domestic manufacture of the guns or by the importation of foreign parts for assembly here.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy has sold a portion of his stock in the bank he headed before entering the Government, the Treasury Department disclosed today.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the world's largest brokerage concern, will acquire Lionel D. Edie Co., a leading investment management and consulting firm, according to a joint announcement yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 29 -- It's going to get a lot noisier before it gets quieter.
JO COPELAND owns a baby grand piano, but she can't play a note. "It lends a certain validity to the home," she says.

President Nixon's message to Congress on the government of the District of Columbia is a constructive statement. He endorses the principle of local self-government for the people of Washington, who are now ruled in an absent-minded, often arbitrary, manner by various committees of Congress, and he proposes a commission to study the form that self-government should take.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Nixon, asserting that there can be "no compromise with lawlessness," urged university officials today to display some "backbone" against campus revolutionaries.
A spokesman for Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the state had reneged on a promise of dollar-for-dollar matching aid for financially beset City

TEL AVIV, April 29 -- Defense Minister Moshe Dayan asserted tonight that the present Lebanese Cabinet crisis had vindicated the widely condemned Israeli reprisal raid last December against the Beirut airport.
" Who's that up there on the platform with June Wayne?" an artist asked a friend one day at a lecture. "The Ford Foundation," replied the friend.

LOS ANGELES, April 29 -- Barry Goldwater Jr., the elder son of the 1964 Republican Presidential candidate was elected to Congress tonight in a special election for the 27th Congressional District. The contest was to fill the seat vacated when Ed Reinecke, a Republican, replaced Robert H. Finch as California's Lieutenant Governor.
Until last Saturday, Hirsch Jacobs hadn't made up his mind about the Big Four in this year's Kentucky Derby. He liked them all.

MONTREAL, April 29 -- Yvan Cournoyer, who ran away and hid from the Boston Bruins, was not so afraid of the sponge-rubber St. Louis Blues tonight. Guided by his return to form, the Montreal Canadiens scored an easy 3-1 victory over the Blues.
Government bond prices declined slightly yesterday as credit markets readied themselves for the Treasury's announcement later today of its plans to refund $4.3-billion of notes coming due May 15.

LONDON, April 29 -- From among the many new works brought to London by the Netherlands Dance Theater for its season at Sadler's Wells, one of the most impressive is "Nouvelles Aventures," the first ballet to be seen here with choreography by the company's leading male dancer, Jaap Flier.

PARIS, April 29 -- Former Premier Georges Pompidou today announced his candidacy for the succession to General de Gaulle and immediately received the endorsement of the Union for the Defense of the Republic, the Gaullist party.
Anyone who wants a piece of Chagall, poster size, can now buy it at the Metropolitan Opera for $30 a copy.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (Reuters) -- The United States Government today accused the Soviet Union of harassing American correspondents in Moscow and said it would make a formal protest to the Soviet Government in the next few days.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 29 -- The criminal trespass trial of 172 Harvard University students began today with an all-day session in a hot redbrick courthouse in East Cambridge.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Accusing the Nixon Administration of giving "only the barest nod to the hungry," Senator George S. McGovern called today for a $1.5-billion annual increase in food stamps for the needy.

DALLAS, April 29 -- Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., will not lose money on its investment in the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, regardless of who wins the Government's antitrust suit, James J. Ling, chairman, told the annual meeting of stockholders here today.

The number of candidates running in the Democratic primary for Mayor in 1969 is a good omen for both the City of New York and the Democratic party. I believe that the city must have a change of Mayor next November, and the best way for the people to express themselves is by hearing those candidates who want to run.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The National Academy of Sciences, holding its 106th annual meeting here, announced the election today of 50 new American members and 10 foreign associates in recognition of their achievements in research.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has until tomorrow to "put up or shut up" on its frequent boast that it can supply enough volunteers to man a fourth police platoon in the high-crime hours between 6 P.M. and 2 A.M.
The widow of a 29-year-old civilian test pilot who was killed when his F-111B attack plane crashed during a test flight filed a $3-million negligence suit against the manufacturers yesterday.
Several American theologians and physicians have stated that it is not immoral to allow terminally ill patients to die by withdrawing the medical means that keep them alive.

Nytronics, Inc., an electronics company that has been expanding rapidly through acquisitions, has agreed to purchase 20.7 per cent of the outstanding stock of Gulton Industries, Inc., and plans to make an offer for the remaining stock.

While owners of the 26 pro football teams in the National and American Leagues debated 1970 realignment for hours yesterday in the sumptuous suites of the St. Regis Sheraton Hotel, the Super Bowl prophet, Joe Namath, solved the situation within seconds in the dim light of his Bachelors III restaurant.
FLEMINGTON, N.J. April 29 -- William S. Vaughn chairman of the Eastman Kodak Company, told the annual meeting here today that the concern was "optimistic about 1969 but not in an exorbitant way."

The resignation of President de Gaulle continued to loom over the commodity market yesterday as an influence on commodity futures prices. Fear remained that with General de Gaulle out of office foreign currencies might be revalued.

Recently, the New York State Assembly, perhaps swayed by a highly emotional speech of one of its members, narrowly defeated a bill for abortion reform. One of the bill's provisions would have permitted abortion where there was medical evidence that a child would be born with severe physical or mental defect.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 29 -- A group of students conduct ed an eight-hour sit-in today in a basement of the administration building at Hofstra University here in support of demands to abolish the Reserve Officers Training Corps as an academic subject and physical education as a required course.

Special to The New York Times WESTBURY, L. I., April 30 -- Lucien Fontaine, who is to drive Shadow Rocket in a Class B-2 one-mile event at Roosevelt Raceway Friday night, could not wait for the outcome of that race before recommending to the owners that the colt be named for the Messenger Stakes.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30--The Nixon Administration has put off indefinitely plans for a comprehensive attack on hunger in America, turning to a series of short-range and considerably cheaper measures instead.

The Columbian Carbon Company, a subsidiary of the Cities Service Company, announced plans yesterday to build a second polyethylene plant at Lake Charles, La., that will nearly triple the company's capacity in this product. The unit will cost about $20-million and will have a capacity of 140 million pounds a year.

Radical students seized two buildings at Columbia University yesterday, and hours later an order requiring the demonstrators to appear in court today was read to the students holding out behind barricades.

Special to The New York Times PARIS, April 30 -- The chief negotiator for the National Liberation Front, or Vietcong, said at the peace talks today that "on the basis of its position," the Front was ready for "discussions with the other parties to make the conference move forward."
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The Pentagon announced today the arrival of one squadron of F-4 fighters to strengthen United States air strength in South Korea.

Special to The New York Times UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. April 30 -- The United Arab Republic accused Israel in a note to the Security Council today of a "grave act of aggression against civilian installations hundreds of miles from the military front."
KRAIJEVICA, Yugoslavia, April 30 (AP) -- President Tito told the Soviet Union today to "leave us alone," and he challenged the Russians to sit down for talks to settle their differences.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -- On the damp, dark morning of May 8, 1919, three "flying boats" lumbered off the beach at Rockaway, Queens, toward a seemingly impossible destination: Europe. Twenty-two days later, after both its sister airplanes had crashed in the Azores, the NC-4 descended on Lisbon, Portugal -- the first plane in history to cross the Atlantic.

CAMBRIDGE, April 30 -- The old Campaign Nixon has surfaced again for the first time since his inaugural. Speaking to the U. S. Chamber of Commerce in Washington, the President roundly proclaimed that "when we find situations" on the campus where students terrorize others and "engage in violence" in the name of dissent and change:
The nation's "No. 1 problem, crime," is causing hundreds of millions of dollars in price rises and increased security costs in business and industry, an executive said here yesterday.

ALVIN ROTH and Tobias Stone, one of the world's most famous partnerships, will be back in action, after a four-year bridge divorce, when the Summer National Championships are played in Los Angeles next August.

Special to The New York Times ALBANY, April 30 -- The Legislature, after 10 chaotic days of continuous negotiations and several false starts, finally broke its impasse and passed a school decentralization plan for New York City tonight.

Net income from financing by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation in the initial quarter of this year reached $11,829,000, compard with $11,003,000 in the 1968 period, John O. Zimmerman, president, announced yesterday.

Special to The New York Times CAIRO, Ill., April 30 -- With small units of the National Guard patrolling its streets, this sleepy river town was quiet tonight after a weekend of wild shooting between Negroes and white vigilantes.

"Trumpets of the Lord," the gospel singing show, which opened Tuesday night at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, will close after seven performances on Saturday night Starting tonight, all tickets will be reduced to $3. The top price at night was $6.95 and for the matinees, $5.50.
A Federal judge held yesterday that the Board of Education had violated the constitutional rights of 678 students it had excluded from Franklin K. Lane High School last January.
Special to The New York Times BERLIN, April 30 -- Highly placed East European sources say that opposition has developed in the Soviet Communist party to the leadership of Leonid I. Brezhnev.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -The White House announced today the appointment of John Davis Lodge as Ambassador to Argentina, thus concluding a bizarre example of diplomatic musical chairs.
CINCINNATI, April 30 (AP) -Jim Maloney of the Cincinnati Reds pitched the second nohitter of his career tonight, overpowering the Houston Astros, 10-0, with a 13-strike-out performance.

William A. Coolidge, a business executive of Topsfield, Mass., has been elected president of the Episcopal Church Foundation. He succeeds Bromwell Ault of New York, who was elected vice chairman of the board. The Right Rev. John E. Hines, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, was elected chairman of the foundation.

ROME, April 30 (UPI) -- The police broke up sit-ins in social security offices in Rome and other cities today in the government's biggest show of force since it ousted rebellious students from the University of Rome two months ago.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- When the leaders of our various campus uprisings have time to reflect, they will surely be amused at the ease with which their acts have made a mockery of their rhetoric.
Each of the two young men ran away to Sweden with the thought of breaking his Army enlistment. Each came back to take his punishment, as have 51 other soldiers who went to Sweden.
CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -Joe Lopez, 26-year-old jockey from Charlotte, Tex., was in critical condition with a crushed chest and possible skull fracture after a spill at Sportsman's Park today.

The annual spring luncheon and fashion show of the Variety Club Women of New York, Tent 35, will be held May 8 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom. Proceeds will go toward the club's goal of $1.5-million for a mental retardation center and dormitory for children at the new campus of New York Medical College at Grasslands in Valhalla, N. Y.

The owners of the 26 pro football teams, meeting in the St. Regis Sheraton Hotel, were coming closer yesterday to resolving their differences over the realignment of the National and American Leagues for the 1970 season and thereafter.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 30 (AP) -- The United States Auto Club postponed today a 200mile championship auto race tentatively scheduled for Saturday at the Trenton International Raceway. The race will be run July 20.

Special to The New York Times JAKARTA, April 30 -- President Suharto has postponed his planned May tour of Europe, Minister of Information Budiardjo announced today. The Minister cited "events in Paris" -- an allusion to President de Gaulle's resignation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 30 (UPI) -- United States marines attacked a force of North Vietnamese regulars on the banks of the Vugia River near Danang today and reported having killed 55 in fighting that raged into the night. American jets dropped napalm on the enemy ranks.

During the long course of his choreographic career, Jose Limon has often reflected on betrayal and oppression in his dance works. Last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, his company presented a program of four pieces all of which touched on these twin thorns of the human condition.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) -- Physicists petitioned the White House and Congress today in opposition to President Nixon's proposed antiballistic missile system, or ABM. They called it wasteful and futile.
NEWMARKET, England, April 30 (AP) -- Right Tack won the 2,000 Guineas Classic today in a horse race that left fans wondering whether Ribofilio, the American-owned favorite, had been drugged.
LONDON, April 30 -- The police were called in toay to help extricate five members of Parliament from a roomful of demonstrating students at the London School of Economics.
Irving Wiggs, vice president and general manager of the Gimbels New York division of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., for the last six years, has submitted his resignation for "personal reasons."

Special to The New York Times PARIS, April 30 -- The last presidential bodyguard left Colombey-les-Deux-Eglises today, the special helicopter with its first-aid equipment returned to its base and the Elysee Palace physician went home.
TODAY marks the 30th anniversary of an event that was to alter, in the most permanent sense, the restaurant scene in Manhattan.
Special to The New York Times LOUISVILLE, April 30 -- At breakfast in the Kentucky Hotel, a tourist from Indiana tells his friend it's too early for a mint julep.
Special to The New York Times JERUSALEM, April 30 -Egyptian and Israeli artillery and tank units fought across the Suez Canal today following an Israeli raid deep inside Egyptian territory.

Arthur Krock, former correspondent and Washington columnist of The New York Times, yesterday received the annual book award of the Colonial Dames of America for his recent memoirs, "Sixty Years on the Firing Line."
The Mobil Oil Corporation announced yesterday its most important executive changes in more than a decade.

WHEN Le Treteau de Paris prepared to stage Fernando Arrabal's "Guernica" in Paris last May, the performance was postponed a month when its actors joined students and workers in the massive strike against President de Gaulle.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- A House Interior subcommittee approved today a $25-million authorization for water desalinization after trimming $2-million from the Senatepassed bill. The full Interior Committee plans to vote next week on the authorization for the year beginning July 1. The money is still subject to appropriation by separate legislation.
Special to The New York Times LOS ANGELES, April 30 -John K. Van de Kamp, the Democratic candidate for Congress in California's 27th District, said last week of his opponent:

LYNNWOOD, Wash., April 30 (AP) -- Edward Nixon, 38-yearold brother of the President, has announced he will make his first venture into politics next month in seeking election as Snohomish County Republican State Committeeman.

The McCall Printing Company will print the Ladies' Home Journal starting with the August issue, John Mack Carter, president of Downe Publishing, publisher of the Journal, announced yesterday. The contract amounts to an estimated $20-million for the first year, Mr. Carter said, for both printing and paper. The Curtis Publishing Company, which sold the magazine to Downe last year, is handling the printing now.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 30 (Reuters) -- Iraq has decided to extend full recognition to East Germany, the Baghdad radio reported tonight in a broadcast monitored here.

Spencer D. Moseley, president of the Railway Express Agency, announced yesterday plans for asking the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to raise tariffs on commodities making up over 80 per cent of its dollar volume.
The withdrawal of Task Force 71 from the Sea of Japan and the deployment of a much smaller force southwest of Korea reflects prudent second thoughts in Washington.

Special to The New York Times ROME, April 30 -- The first non-Italian Vatican Secretary of State in 55 years is a French peasant's son who not only lists his telephone in the Rome directory but often answers it himself.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 30 (AP) -- Bill Shoemaker, the jockey, was thrown in an accident in the saddling paddock at Hollywood Park today and was taken to a hospital, where it was reported he had suffered a fractured pelvis and internal injuries.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON April 30 -American officials tonight declined direct comment on Prince Sihanouk's statement but acknowledged that talks on resumption of diplomatic relations had not moved as rapidly as some officials had expected.
Special to The New York Times ROME, April 30 -- Pope Paul VI announced today the appointment of 30 churchmen from 18 nations to the commission to evaluate new trends in theological speculation.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The State Department said today it had accepted temporarily Brazil's offer to impose a 13-cents-a-pound tax on instant coffee exported to the United States.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -Trading in the stock of the Westec Corporation, which has been banned since August, 1966, will be allowed to resume on Monday under actions taken today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the American Stock Exchange and the Texas Securities Commission.

Theodore W. Kheel was designated yesterday as mediator in a dispute between the city and three unions that represent 6,000 lieutenants, sergeants and detectives in the Police Department. The main issue in the dispute is the question of the police officers' parity with corresponding officers in the Fire Department.
The Savings Banks Association of New York State, in its drive to create housing for lowincome families, is turning increasingly to major industrial and utility corporations to sponsor its projects.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) -- S. L. A. Marshall, in an assessment made at the request of the United States military command in Saigon, said today that 40 per cent of American casualties in the Vietnam war were "due to our own mistakes."
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) -- The Defense Department today listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in the war in Vietnam:

1969 The Globe and Mall, Toronto PEKING, April 30 -- Le Duc Tho, the political leader of North Vietnam's delegation at the Paris peace talks, left Peking today for Moscow and Paris. In the past, Mr. Tho's movements have sometimes coincided with turning points in the negotiations.
Open admission--college for anyone who wants it--has long seemed to many educators the natural extension of the American ideal of equal opportunity for all.
QUEBEC, April 30 (CP) -Premier Jean-Jacques Bertrand believes that Quebeckers are grateful for the interest General de Gaulle took in their province while President of France.
A spokesman for the Humble Oil Company said yesterday he was "not in a position to discuss" the award of a contract for construction of the 800-mile Alaskan oil pipeline.

Bear, Stearns Co., a member of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the admission of eight general partners. They are Raphael Bernstein, Robert B. Brown, Frank X. Cummings, Jerome R. Goldstein, Michael J. Heaney Jr., David Mulgrum, Michael E. Tennenbaum and John G. Ward.

Executives and city, education and labor leaders are joining with 1,500 volunteers to start the first campaign of the United Fund of Greater New York at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria today. The fund is an amalgamation of the money - raising activities of the Greater New York Fund and the American Red Cross in Greater New York into a single appeal within the business community.

Special to The New York Times LINDEN, N. J., April 30 -This industrial city of 45,000 people was calm today after a series of scattered disorders involving white and Negro youths over the last several days.
Special to The New York Times LONDON April 30 -- All British national newspapers were shut tonight by a political strike and were forced to cancel tomorrow's issues.

The idea that progressively stronger dissonances meant progressively modern music was a logical outcome of post Wagnerian Romanticism, and not many musicians would defend the notion today. The emptiness of a harmonica blowing in the wind, or even gasps of silence, as in the post-Webern idiom, suggest contemporary esthetics more vividly.
KANSAS CITY, April 30 (UPI) -- Vernon Vanoy of the University of Kansas, the No. 3 draft choice of the New York Giants, has signed with the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League.

Andrew A. Lynn will join Yardley of London, Inc., as president and chief executive officer next Monday. He most recently has been president and chief executive officer of Jacqueline Cochran, Inc., and vice president of Shulton, Inc.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday it had bought a polyvinyl chloride plant that is being built at Plaquemine, La., from the Dow Chemical Company. The purchase price was more than $4million.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 30 (AP) -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's chief of state, reversed himself today and rejected a new United States initiative aimed at restoring relations severed nearly four years ago.

The opening of Tennessee Williams's "In the Bar of a Tokyo Hotel" has been postponed. The premiere has been switched from Sunday night to May 11 at the Eastside Playhouse. It is the second postponement for the production, which had been scheduled to open tonight.

The Oil Shale Corporation announced yesterday that the Atlantic Richfield Company had exercised an option to purchase a 30 per cent interest in a longterm mining lease involving 8,560 acres of oil shale reserves in eastern Utah. Atlantic Richfield paid $8-million to each of the three other participants in the venture.

The phrase "mellow with age" has rarely seemed more apt than it did last night at the final Music in Our Time Concert of the season at the Kaufmann Auditorium of the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 30 (UPI) -- The scene shifts to the West tomorrow night for the fifth game between the Boston Celtics and the Los Angeles Lakers for the National Basketball Association playoff title.
The textile industry as a whole might be satisfied with an import quota system based on the 1968 level, Buford Brandis, economist for the American Textile Manufacturers Institute, said yesterday.
Five Americans and two Sherpa guides have been killed in a mountain-climbing accident in western Nepal, a spokesman for the American Alpine Club, the sponsor of the expedition, said early today.

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -Man-like teeth and jaws have been found in southern Ethiopia that would nearly double the history of man's ancestors in East Africa from two million to four million years, according to the University of Chicago's anthropology department.

Special to The New York Times LEXINGTON, Ky., April 30 -- Vice President Agnew said today that Congress could properly provide for withdrawal of Federal aid to educational institutions and to students when the action of either went beyond "the limits of permissibility."

In his comments on campus unrest, President Nixon has reaffirmed his previous pledge to uphold the right to lawful dissent and to help preserve the independence of the universities from Federal interference. At the same time--and with increasingly urgent reason--he emphasized the need for university administrators and faculties to stand up to the disruptive and violent tactics of a small minority of student extremists.

PARIS, April 30 -- What is wrong with the French economy? Why has the franc become the sick currency of Europe? Attention has focused on the resignation of President de Gaulle, which has led to a temporary power vacuum and may result in a weaker political will to defend the currency.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (Reuters) -- The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to rule that the General Host Corporation's acquisition of Armour Co. was illegal because it was in violation of the terms of the 1920 consent decree holding that Armour could not merge with companies in similar food fields.
Special to The New York Times PARIS, April 30 -- Fresh speculation buffeted Europe's key currencies today as market talk of inevitable parity changes intensified.

Peter Serkin has been around as a performing artist so long that it is hard to realize that he only came of age last July. But at 21 he is asserting his will with a vengeance. Last night he played a recital in the "Great Performers at Philharmonic Hall" series, which has a relatively conservative subscription audience, and brought a program that is usually the fare of small coteries in small auditoriums.
Volume rose sharply yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as prices continued to advance.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, April 30 (UPI) -- An Air Force bomber crew today identified as a weather balloon an "unidentified flying object" reported at 35,000 feet over San Juan and Ponce. The B-52 was sent up to investigate the object after two Puerto Rican National Guard F-104 jet fighters had been unable to identify it.
Initial steps toward creating the first large-scale cluster zoning development here were taken yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 30 (AP) -- The Manhasset Bay International One-Design team took a one-race lead in the Cow Bay Bowl yachting series today by defeating the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club, 14 3/4-21.
More than 2,000 people, many from the city's diplomatic community, are expected to attend a showing next Tuesday night of works by young artists from about 60 countries.

An incorrigible baseball fan, who still feels the pain of the $750 he lost when that third strike got past Mickey Owen in the 1941 World Series at Ebbets Field, made a most thought-provoking accusation after reviewing last night's baseball activity.
Alvin J. Smith has been admitted as a general partner of Katzenberg, Sour Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday.

CARSON CITY, Nev., April 30 (UPI) -- Reversing an earlier shutdown order, the Nevada Gaming Commission ruled last night that the $12-million Circus Casino on the Las Vegas Strip could remain open at least until May 31. The casino, with its carnival-type of atmosphere, had been slated to close its gambling at midnight tonight when its state license expired.

Special to The New York Times CAIRO, April 30 -- The Egyption Government today denied reports by Israel that helicopterborne commandos had caused extensive damage to bridges, power lines and other strategic installations along the Nile in Upper Egypt, the southern part of the country.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 30 (UPI) -- Chuck Bednarik, an all-America center at the University of Pennsylvania in 1947 and 1948 who later starred with the Philadelphia Eagles, was selected today to the National Football Foundation's Hall of Fame along with seven other former collegiate stars.

Special to The New York Times ROME, April 30 -- Pope Paul VI today named Jean Cardinal Villot, a 63-year-old Frenchman, as Secretary of State, virtually Premier of the Vatican. The Cardinal will be the first non-Italian in 55 years to hold the most important job in the administration of the Roman Catholic Church below the papacy.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (UPI) -- Dr. Fernando G. Bloedorn, professor of radiology at Tufts-New England Center, was elected president of the American Radium Society today at the close of the group's annual three-day meeting.

Special to The New York Times GENEVA, April 30 -- The people of Geneva, birthplace of Jean-Jacques Rousseau and site of the founding of the Red Cross, turned out in force today to commemorate another great event in the history of the city--the decision, 50 years ago yesterday, to establish the League of Nations here.
Westchester County's tallest rental office building, completed a year ago, has now been filled with the signing of two leases for space totaling 28,300 square feet.

NEW ORLEANS, April 30 (UPI) -- Long-hitting Jack Nicklaus and the United States open champion, Lee Trevino, were in the favored roles for the opening round of the $100,000 Greater New Orleans Golf tournament starting tomorrow on the 7,090-yard, par-72 Lakewood Country Club course.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 30 -- Latin-American diplomats disagreed today with President Nixon's assessment that student participation in governing their universities has produced "one of the most inferior" systems of higher education in the world.
Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -The White House, which has tried to avoid involvement in the New York City mayoral race, had the campaign brought to it today.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) -- The Treasury warned Americans today to stay out of a European mutual fund that says it had been formed to buy gold bullion. The Midas Gold Fund is reported to plan its first offering on May 1.

Between 150 and 200 Brooklyn College students, including many who were Negro and Puerto Rican, broke into the prresident's office yesterday, vandalized it and created general disorder there for three hours.
The odds flashed 99-1 on the tote boards at Aqueduct yesterday, but progress in the boycott by horsemen that has halted racing since last Saturday was the same as the payoffs: Zero.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -An academic consultant to the Nixon Administration today proposed a sizable territorial trade between Israel and the United Arab Republic as part of a settlement in the Middle East. Under his proposal, Israel would give up the port of Elath on the Gulf of Aqaba in return for Port Fuad on the northern end of the Suez Canal.
Shoppers could claim immediate cash discounts as an alternative to taking trading stamps under a bill approved by the City Council Finance Committee yesterday.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -A demonstration that the Maverick, the Ford Motor Company's new subcompact automobile, is easy to dismantle for maintenance and repairs, took place on Capitol Hill today before an informal meeting of the Senate Antitrust and Monopoly Subcommittee.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 30 (AP) -- Lanny Wadkins and Joe Inman, both of Wake Forest University, led the charge through two rounds into the quarter-finals of the North and South amateur golf tournament today.
Special to The New York Times DETROIT, April 30 -- The Ford Motor Company will resume its hiring program in the slums here Friday.

IT could read, in a manner of speaking, like Genesis, chapter and verse. In the beginning Henri Soule begat Le Pavillon and La Cote Basque. Le Pavillon begat La Caravelle and Le Poulailler. La Caravelle brought forth Le Mistral and the new Le Cygne. Le Pavillon, La Cote Basque and Le Mistral begat the new Le Madrigal. And Le Pavillon and La Cote Basque and Le Poulailler more or less begat the new La Seine.
Textile and other import quotas were opposed by a major farm group yesterday with the warning that such restrictions would lead to a further decline of farm exports.

El Tiempo, a Spanish - language daily which has endorsed Mayor Lindsay for re-election, yesterday editorially endorsed Borough President Herman Badillo of the Bronx for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 30 (UPI) -- Gary Bradds continued his red-hot playoff shooting tonight, as he scored 40 points in leading Oakland to a 123-114 victory over the Indiana Pacers. The triumph gave the Oaks a 1-0 lead in the four-of-seven American Basketball Association finals.
Pitney-Bowes, Inc., said yesterday it had named Fred T. Allen president. At their annual meeting in Stamford, Conn., shareholders approved a 2-for-1 stock split.
The Chelsea dock district will lose its last major shipping tenant next week when the United States Lines abandons cargo operations at four piers in the area.
Special to The New York Times LONDON, April 30 -- British shipping is enjoying what gives every appearance of being an exciting revival.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 30 (AP) -- John Newcombe powered his way into the quarter-finals of the British clay-court open tennis championship today in his bid to land two titles in a row. Meanwhile, United States stars continued to have troubles.

Entries for the $200,000 United States Open closed yesterday with a record total of 3,400. The previous high of 3,007 was filed last year. The Open will be contested over the Champions Golf Club course in Houston June 12 through 15.

Special to The New York Times SAIGON, South Vietnam April 30 -- The Government is quietly redrawing the political map of South Vietnam to show, on paper at least, a loyal administration in every village-and possibly every hamlet--by the end of the year.
SAN FRANCISCO, (UPI) April 30 -- A Federal Grand jury began an investigation into activities of the Black Panthers today, with seven black men, six of them Panthers, on hand under subpoena.

Special to The New York Times ALBANY, April 30 -- "Art and politics are like oil and water--they don't really mix," Governor Rockefeller has said. But, taking time off today from a stormy session of the State Legislature, he proved that for him, at least, they do. In an informal press conference at the Executive Mansion in Albany, continuously interrupted by frantic calls from politicians, he sat down to discuss himself as an art collector.

The money market got so tight yesterday that banks paid 9 1/2 per cent on overnight loans they make to each other--a record rate for the postwar period that approached the peak for day-today money set in early 1929.
Special to The New York Times MONTREAL, April 30 -- Tom Seaver pitched the New York Mets to a 2-1 victory over the Montreal Expos this evening in Canada's first night game in major league baseball.
Ak-Sar-Ben, as any racing fan knows, is Nebraska spelled backward. The Omaha track opens for business tomorrow, and Clarence P. Haver is looking forward to it.
Share prices slipuped to new low levels for the year on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. In Paris, further strong demand for domestic companies' shares pushed the index to a new 1969 high.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 30 -- A baby who survives a bout with hyaline membrane disease, the respiratory disorder that took the life of Patrick Bouvier Kennedy, has a surprisingly good chance of developing normally, according to the findings of an eight-year follow-up study described here today.
"IS it true," asked a gentleman of my acquaintance several days ago, "that you couldn't catch a finnan haddie in a seafood restaurant?"

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -The Senate Education and Labor Committee approved on a party-line 10-6 vote today a resolution asking the Nixon Administration to hold up its decision to shut down 59 Job Corps centers.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday appointed Dr. J. Herbert Fill to the $35,000 a year post of Commissioner of Mental Health Service. The 44-year-old psychiatrist became Acting Commissioner in November, 1967, following the resignation of Dr. Marvin E. Perkins. Dr. Fill, who was born in Italy, has lived in the United States since 1957.

Special to The New York Times MOSCOW, April 30 -- The seventh game of the world chess championship match series between Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, the titleholder, and Boris Spassky, the challenger and his compatriot, was drawn today after 27 moves at the Moscow Variety Theater. The score is 4 to 3 in favor of the challenger.

The stock market, ignited by new peace glimmers in Vietnam and a dramatic turnabout in investor psychology, scored its best advance in more than a year yesterday as the DowJones industrial average soared 16.08 to 950.18.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (Reuters) -- The Penn Central Company has filed an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission to form itself into a holding company to cover its railroad and other activities, including large real estate holdings and its pipeline company.

WITH something of the pomp and splendor due royalty, Dame Margot Fonteyn, accompanied of course by Rudolf Nureyev, made her return to New York last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. She was dancing in the Royal Ballet's "Swan Lake," and, fairly enough, endowed it with the special quality of grandeur that belongs to her very particular authority.

A complicated intrigue laced with chicanery, greed, threats, double-crosses and orders from a reputed Mafia figure was spun out yesterday in Federal Court here by Herbert Itkin, a Federal Bureau of Investigation informer.

Special to The New York Times SOUTHAMPTON, England, April 30 -- The Queen Elizabeth 2, Cunard's new liner, returned here today after an eight-day cruise to the Canary Islands and it seemed that all her troubles were over.
Special to The New York Times BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 30 -An armed clash between the Lebanese Army and Palestinian commandos broke out in southern Lebanon last night.

Net income of General Dynamics Corporation in the March quarter fell to $7,482,000, or 71 cents a share, from $12,450,000, or $1.19 a share, in the 1968 period. Roger Lewis, president, yesterday told the annual meeting in San Diego, Calif.
Trouble continued yesterday on campuses of the City University, including the following:
Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -President Nixon announced today preliminary efforts to enlist citizen volunteers in the attack on social and economic ills.
Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -President Nixon is confronted by a choice between two alternative plans for revising the nation's welfare system.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 30 -- Republican Governors, whose past conferences have brought them gifts, such as deer meat sausage and Palm Beach jackets, had a new experience tonight: they were given a $70,000 race horse.

Joseph E. Seagram Sons has moved out of Wells, Rich, Green all of the assignments it had from the BrowneVintners Company, recently redesignated as a division of the General Wine and Spirits Company. In their place the agency has been assigned a new, unnamed product from Calvert Distillers, whose Passport Scotch W.R.G. already has.
A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn indicted nine men and one woman yesterday in what agents said was a multimillion-dollar pornography ring.
William J. Pearce, general manager of Channel 21, Long Island's noncommercial television station, has resigned to become president and general manager of Rochester's educational television station.

After struggling to a three-hit, 3-0 shutout over the New York Yankees here last night, Sam McDowell of the Cleveland Indians hopped off the mound and shook hands with his teammates, as if he'd been doing it all season. But he could have been excused if he'd forgotten.

Many presidents of colleges and universities are finding out the hard way what their philosophy is for dealing with student unrest. Others knew all along--and are discovering how inadequate their best plans were.
Special to The New York Times PRINCETON, N. J., April 30 -- After three months in office, President Nixon has won approval from 61 per cent of Americans, the Gallup Poll reported today.
THE third game of the current 24-game title match between the world champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, and his challenger and compatriot, Boris Spassky, was drawn after 43 moves.
Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -The Treasury announced today an inquiry into possible "dumping" of ceramic wall tile from Britain.
For the first time in the 59year history of the Greater New York, Long Island and Westchester Automobile Dealers Association, a son has followed his father to the presidency of the organization.
Higher zinc prices announced on Tuesday by the American Zinc Company spread through the industry yesterday.
ADA. Or Ardor: A Family Chronicle. By Vladimir Nabokov. 589 pages. McGraw-Hill. $8.95.
MILWAUKEE, April 30 (UPI) -- The Milwaukee Bucks signed Bob Greacen, a 6-foot-7-inch Rutgers star, to a National Basketball Association contract today.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -President Nixon took his first tentative step toward "block grants" today, asking Congress for authority to merge and otherwise consolidate many of the Government's 500 separate programs of assistance to the states and cities.

W. A. Boyle, who fills a small part of the shoes once occupied by John L. Lewis as president of the United Mine Workers, has been stumping the coal fields denouncing the "enemies" of his union. By an odd coincidence the list is made up almost entirely of those who have been criticizing the U.M.W. for its laxity in the fields of mine health and safety.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The first half of a comprehensive review of the nation's security policies, setting forth options for sweeping modifications in United States global strategy, is scheduled to go to the National Security Council tomorrow.

BEN SCHWARTZWALDER has had a loyal and good football staff at Syracuse for many years. His assistants have done a fine job, producing outstanding teams and individual players for the Orange. Now Schwartzwalder is losing two of his key assistants --Bill Bell and Jim Ridlon.

A sharp decline yesterday in the price of copper, a key defense metal, was attributed by brokers to a conciliatory Vietcong statement at the Paris talks. For the May delivery, a measure of current market prices, the close was 60.6061.10 cents a pound, down from 63 cents on Tuesday.
Marvin Lefkowitz, an art director and designer at Young Rubicam, walked off yesterday with three of the 17 medals at the 48th annual Gold Medal Awards Luncheon of the Art Directors Club.

SCARBOROUGH, N. Y., April 30 -- Children's Village, a training and research center for the prevention and treatment of emotional problems of young boys and their families, will benefit from a luncheon and bridge party at the Sleepy Hollow Club tomorrow afternoon.

Business executives are not singing the blues about profits so far this year despite the income-tax surcharge and the high cost of money. But there are doubts about how long the sweet music will linger before inflationary pressures set in.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (Reuters) -- Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today the Department of Justice had filed an antitrust suit charging the Continental Oil Company, the American Petrofina Company of Texas and Spencer Co. with conspiring to fix prices for asphalt sold in New Mexico. The suit charges that the three companies used the Spencer Company as their exclusive marketing agent, which resulted in the elimination of price competition between Continental and Petrofina.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The Senate Education and Labor Committee approved unanimously today President Nixon's nomination of Dr. James E. Allen Jr. of New York to be Commissioner of Education.

The financially troubled overseas Press Club has been told to pay $65,000 in back rent and taxes or vacate its building at 54 West 40th Street. The club disclosed at its annual membership meeting last night.

Special to The New York Times HONG KONG, April 30 -- In the opinion of recent Asian visitors to Peking, Communist China's relations with the Soviet Union may grow worse but will not improve in the foreseeable future, whereas relations with the United States may take a turn for the better.

Special to The New York Times DETROIT, April 30 -- Layoffs at General Motors Corporation plants around the country rose today as the manufacturer reduced parts production because of strikes at seven assembly plants.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -The State Department imposed travel restrictions today on two Soviet journalists stationed in the United States "in response" to travel restrictions recently imposed on two American correspondents in Moscow.

The two-week-old boycott of Public School 39 in East Harlem ended yesterday when 289 pupils and 36 teachers went to school. But the conflict and bitterness between the local school board and the United Federation of Teachers persisted.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- President Carlos Lleras Restrepo of Colombia has accepted an invitation from President Nixon to make a state visit to Washington June 12 and 13, the White House announced today. Mr. Lleras also will visit New York City.

Rene Barrientos Ortuno was an unusual kind of South American military strongman. He helped overthrow constitutional government in Bolivia in 1964, then restored it in 1966, won a reasonably democratic election and carried forward the revolution begun by his predecessor, Victor Paz Estenssoro.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -Prosecutors in New York State are using court-approved wiretapping far more than all the other law enforcement officials in the country combined, the Federal Government reported today.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird pledged today that the Pentagon would not repeat mistakes made in contracting for the C-5A cargo plane, the cost of which has nearly doubled from the original price set four years ago.

HANOI, North Vietnam, April 30 (Agence France-Presse)--North Vietnam's main official newspaper forecast failure today for the United States' attempt to turn much of the war effort over to South Vietnamese forces.

Special to The New York Times CHARLESTON, S. C., April 30 -- Mrs. Martin Luther King Jr. led 2,000 exuberant Negroes through the streets of this troubled city today, taking what she said would have been her husband's place at the side of striking hospital workers.

MADRID, April 30 (Reuters) -- Roman Catholic bishops in several parts of Spain today published May Day pastoral letters calling for more social justice, better conditions for workers and independent labor unions.
A jazz program based on a variety of African source material was presented by Clifford Thornton's New Art Ensemble last night at the Countee Cullen Branch Library, 104 West 136th Street.

Special to The New York Times MAHWAH, N. J., April 30 -The Ford Motor Company reported today that it was able to resume normal assembly operations on its night shift after additional Negro workers had returned to their jobs.

The Eastern Life Insurance Company of New York yesterday reported that it wrote $33,919,020 in new business in the March quarter, compared with $33,198,388 written during the comparable period last year. Insurance in force climbed 12 per cent to $813-million from $722,200,000 a year ago.

Special to The New York Times ALBANY, April 30 -- The Senate unanimously gave final approval today to a bill that bans guns on college property and to a measure requiring all colleges chartered by the state to submit rules and regulations for the enforcement of order on campus or face a cut-off of state financial aid.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -The Treasury Department's general counsel refused today to appear before the House Banking and Currency Committee on Saturday to answer questions about the financial affairs of Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy.

HEWLETT, L. I., April 30 -- The Five Towns Music and Art Foundation will celebrate its 20th anniversary on Tuesday with a luncheon honoring Walter Kerr, the author and Sunday drama critic of The New York Times. The event will take place at the Seawane Country Club here.

Special to The New York Times PRAGUE, April 30 -- Dr. Gustav Husak, the new Czechoslovak Communist party chief, today held out the prospect of a new party congress "in the first half of next year" to be followed by elections to the Federal Assembly.
A Brooklyn intermediate school came under a rock and brick attack yesterday from 200 Negroes and Puerto Ricans of high school age who massed on the street and aimed volleys at the windows.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today award of a $586,885 contract to McDonnell Douglas Corporation, Santa Monica, Calif., for testing of a life support system to keep four astronauts alive in space for 90 days.
Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The jolt of an "earthquake" may account for the sudden and brief change in pulse rate of a pulsar a few weeks ago, it was suggested here today.

New York City's job gains have been accelerating over the last three years, with private employment rising an average of 31,000 jobs a year, against an average annual loss of 3,000 in the first five years of the nineteen-sixties.

Special to The New York Times MOSCOW, April 30 -- Marshal Matvei V. Zakharov, chief of the Soviet General Staff, affirmed today that Soviet missiles could not only carry "colossal" payloads but could also penetrate an enemy's antimissile defense.

Special to The New York Times MINNEAPOLIS, April 30 -The Democratic - Farmer Labor party's candidate for Mayor of Minneapolis was eliminated in the primary election yesterday as a 41-year-old police detective, Charles Stenvig, finished first after campaigning as an independent.
"I think they are desperate and issueless. Ugliness and meanness is all they have left."
The Long Island Lighting Company reported yesterday new highs in revenues and net earnings for the first quarter.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -The Treasury offered holders of $5.9-billion of maturing securities today a choice of a 15-month note bearing 6.42 per cent interest and a seven-year bond at 6 1/2 per cent.
Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -For several years Dr. Luis Alvarez, Nobel laureate in physics, has been trying to outguess a pharaoh who lived some 4,600 years ago.

Louis Sheaffer, author of "O'Neill, Son and Playwright" and drama critic of the Brooklyn Eagle until its suspension in 1955, was named yesterday the winner of the first George Freedley Memorial Award for the book.

Special to The New York Times CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 30 -- Judge M. Edward Viola denied today defense motions to acquit 172 persons, most of them Harvard students, who were charged with criminal trespass after the student occupation of an administration building here April 9.
The city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Bess Myerson Grant, sold a newspaper at noon yesterday to officially open business at a new-style aluminum and glass newsstand at Broadway and 43d St.

Special to The New York Times LOUISVILLE, April 30 -- Ack Ack is out, eight others are still in. That's the latest on the lineup for the Kentucky Derby, to be run for the 95th time at Churchill Downs on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) -- Senator J. W. Fulbright said today that President Nixon should resubmit a 44-year-old treaty banning gas and germ warfare because the United States was the only major nation that had not ratified it.
A Bronx teamsters' union official was arrested yesterday and charged with victimizing men who were desperate for work.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -Senator Everett McKinley Dirkson moved a step closer to his goal of a national constitutional convention tonight, when the Iowa Legislature became the 33d state Legislature to petition Congress to convene a second constitutional convention.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, April 30 -Influential Democrats in the Senate indicated today they were eager to restore to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting the full $20-million budget President Johnson proposed for next year. President Nixon has asked for only $10-million.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 30 -- Faculty members at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have greeted with approval the institute's decision to refuse temporarily new classified research contracts at two laboratroies it runs for the Government.

Special to The New York Times BONN, April 30 -- The West German Interior Ministry today banned a small neo-Nazi group that a ministry spokesman said had ties to the American Nazi party through an American stationed here with the United States military.

KAY THOMPSON skibbled into town this week accompanied by her irrepressible brainchild, Eloise, the fictitious moppet who lived at the Plaza Hotel where, naturally, she and Miss Thompson have taken up residence.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that rents for welfare families in Federal and city-aided public housing projects would be raised by an average of nearly 47 per cent on June 1.
ARE today's young mothers doing the job they should?

Arbed, a Luxembourg-based steel company, and the Continental Ore Corporation, a subsidiary of the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation, announced plans yesterday to build a multimilliondollar ferro-alloy plant near the city of Luxembourg to serve the European steel industry.
Special to The New York Times PARIS, April 30 -- Former Premier Georges Pompidou's campaign for the presidency picked up speed today.
ST. LOUIS, April 30 (AP) -When their organist, Norm Kramer, swings into action, the St. Louis Blues usually pick up the momentum and turn the game into a Missouri waltz.

Israel's retaliatory commando strike deep inside Egyptian territory points up the vulnerability of Egypt's long Nile River lifeline and the futility of Cairo's recent belligerence. The Egyptians can hardly expect sympathy from the international community after their open repudiation of the Suez Canal ceasefire line.

Special to The New York Times ALBANY, April 30 -- Following is a summary of the major provisions of the compromise New York City school decentralization bill hammered out by the leaders of the Republican-controlled Legislature.

The Ashland Oil and Refining Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Midhurst Oil Corporation and Whitehall Canadian Oil, Ltd., for more than $50-million in a new Ashland preferred stock. Ashland also reported a decline in earnings for the quarter and six months ended March 31.
IT HAPPENS fairly frequently. An investor calls his broker and says, "Buy me 100 shares of Stock X at the market [price]."

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Aril 30 -Under Secretary of State Elliot L. Richardson told a television audience tonight that the talks in Paris had not achieved any real progress on major issues of substance.

TOKYO, April 30 (Reuters) -A contract to build a 372,400ton tanker, the largest in the world, was signed today between Ishikawajima - Harima Heavy Industries, Ltd. and the Tokyo Tanker Company, a Japanese concern affiliated with Caltex Oil. The ship will cost about $27.5 - million, and is scheduled to be completed by November, 1971.
SYDNEY, Australia, May 1 -- Students opposed to the Vietnam war pelted Sir Roden Cutler, the Governor of New South Wales, with tomatoes, apples and oranges when he visited Sydney University today.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Dr. Lee A. Du Bridge, President Nixon's science adviser, told the Senate Government Operations subcommittee today that the number of secret Government research contracts held by universities is now 4 per cent of the total and is going down.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -Representative Mario Biaggi, a freshman Democrat from the Bronx and a decorated former policeman, today assailed President Nixon's recent proposals to attack organized crime as "insulting" to Italian-Americans.
SANA, Yemen, May 1 (Reuters) -- President Abdul Rahman al-Iryani asserted today that the six-year-old civil war between Yemeni royalist and republican forces was over.

GENEVA, May 1 -- A jewelry auction at Christie's here produced total sales of $2.9-million tonight. A Christie spokesman jubilantly said this was more than double the previous world's record, set at a Parkevernet jewelry auction in New York a year and a half ago.

Cornell University President James A. Perkins was directed yesterday by the university board of trustees to implement a 10-point declaration affirming that disruption and "tactics of terror" on the campus would be met by "firm and appropriate response."
BERLIN, May 1 -- Communists and Socialists of all shades marked May Day in this divided city today with four parades, including a military show of power in East Berlin.

A recent editorial in The Times [April 13] criticizing the manner in which the armed forces are handling soldier dissidents and similar articles in other media questioning the ability and integrity of senior members of the services are reason for real concern at this time.

The chaos that marks the end of every legislative session in Albany was highlighted by the decentralization battle. But as the Legislature completes its business today, it can be safely predicted that in the closing rush many legislators will be passing upon additional bills without the slightest knowledge of what they are voting for. And it is reasonably sure that they will hope that the public doesn't learn about some bills until too late.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration ordered the Upjohn Company and Merck Co., Inc., today to tone down sharply claims for the antibiotic novobiocin and to put a stiff warning on the label about serious side effects.

PALO ALTO, Calif., May 1 -- Student demonstrators peacefully surrendered an administration building at Stanford University early today after the police were brought onto the campus for the first time in the school's history.
ROME, May 1 -- Pope Paul VI exhorted 33 new cardinals and Christians in general today to exalt the dignity of labor and to work for human development and the elimination of social injustice.
Bands of student vandals roamed through the Queens College campus yesterday afternoon, overturning bookcases, emptying card catalogs and smashing display cases in the main library.
The country's three largest department-store and catalogue-sales chains reported yesterday record sales gains in April of more than 10 per cent over the year-earlier month.
The Singer Company achieved record sales and earnings in the first quarter this year, Donald P. Kircher, president, reported yesterday.

NEWMARKET, England, May 1 (AP) -- Ron Hutchinson, an Australian jockey, pushed Full Dress to a 1 1/2-length victory over Hecuba in the 1,000 Guineas Classic for 3-year-old fillies today. The victory was worth $50,515.

GENEVA, May 1 -- Secretary General Thant of the United Nations said tonight that the world's information media were giving inadequate or only partial coverage to "important and exciting developments."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 1 -The Lebanese Army yesterday relieved a police post in southern Lebanon that had been besieged by Palestinian commandos. Several men were wounded in the clash, according to a Government source.
Your editorial "Justice Without Mercy" [April 24], concerning the death penalty imposed upon Senator Robert F. Kennedy's assassin, restates the best arguments being made against capital punishment.

The meeting of pro football club owners at the St. Regis Sheraton Hotel became stalled yesterday because the National Football League failed to find three members willing to move over to the American League for the 1970 season.

Current arguments concerning the deployment of an ABM system seem to center, at least in part, on whether or not the money would be better spent for social purposes. No one would deny that funds spent to bring about legitimate social change constitute a greater benefit to society than do huge piles of military hardware.

OTTAWA, May 1 -- A woman traveling from Ottawa to Vancouver this week took a train and three airplanes via Toronto, Chicago and Seattle. A man going from Toronto to Edmonton, normally a three-hour nonstop jet ride, took a plane to Chicago, another to Denver and a third to his destination.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 1 -In tense proceedings, Judge M. Edward Viola found guilty today all but four of 173 persons charged with criminal trespass in the occupation of a Harvard University administration building April 9. He meted out to each of them the maximum penalty for the misdemeanor, a $20 fine.

ALBANY, May 1 -- The Assembly narrowly passed a series of bills tonight strength-Waterfront Commission to deal with organized crime on the docks over the heated objections of both Democrats and Republicans.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Forty-six Congressmen proposed legislation in the House today to eliminate oil import quotas by 1980.
Most commodity futures were in the doldrums yesterday, registering only modest price changes and slow volume.

WHEN the 65,863-ton Queen Elizabeth 2 looms over the horizon Wednesday on the last leg of her westbound maiden voyage, there will be the usual scurry among small - craft operators eager to greet the new luxury liner.

Students of the New England Conservatory occupied Carnegie Recital Hall last night, but no protest was involved. It was their turn to be heard in the conservatory's four-concert New York Festival, which will end tomorrow night. Last night's program was the second.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday after a dull session.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
JERUSALEM, May 1 -- What Israel terms the token nature of her commando raid into Egyptian territory is under review here in terms of the value of such further operations.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (UPI) -- Leonard Tose, a trucking executive, completed his purchase of the Philadelphia Eagles last night five minutes before the midnight deadline and immediately announced the dismissal of Joe Kuharich as coach and general manager.
Four Correction Department officials were indicted yesterday on charges they tried to conceal their failure to follow proper procedures at the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men.
PARIS, May 1 -- Continental monetary sources said today no emergency meetings had been scheduled this weekend to consider action on currency parities.

ARCTIC BAY, Northwest Territories -- Four times a day, often in stiff winds and temperatures 40 below zero, Bob Giroux or Iain Hoey reads the weather instruments at the top of the hill and radios the data to the Government weather station at Resolute.

In the last 10 years, the difference in the cost of office rental space in Manhattan and the suburbs has resulted in a considerable gap, according to Harry C. Huberth Jr., president of Huberth Hubert, Inc., real estate brokers.

The Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn is a short distance from the Academy of Music and on Wednesday night, the area's residents went over to the academy to watch their own most talented neighbors take part in tryouts. The best performers will appear next Wednesday in Bedford-Stuyvesant's first community concert.

TRENTON, May 1 -- After nearly 20 years of successive defeats, advocates of a New Jersey lottery finally came up with the winning number today when a November referendum on the issue won final legislative approval in the State Senate.

WHEN Electronic Data Systems made its bid for Collins Radio a while back, it was immediately obvious that the tiny computer-services company wasn't seeking the half-billion-dollar Collins for the cash in the till. Collins was even more cash-poor than usual, with just $2.3-million in the kitty.

Two of the nation's most influential Episcopal bishops were confronted yesterday by a representative of the National Black Economic Development Conference who demanded $500-million as reparations due Negro Americans who have been persecuted, exploited and killed.
ROME, May 1 -- The 33 prelates inducted by Pope Paul VI this week into the Sacred College of Cardinals are now members of the oldest, most exclusive "club" in the world.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

ST. LOUIS, May 1 (UPI) -- Roigatien Vachon gained his first shutout in Stanley Cup competition tonight, and goals by Serge Savard and Jacques Lemaire and two by Dick Duff gave the Montreal Canadiens a 4-0 victory and a 3-0 lead over the St. Louis Blues in the Cup finals.
Truck hijackings in the New York area have shown a marked decline in the last two months, it was disclosed yesterday by security officers of New York trucking companies.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 -The Kentucky Derby on Saturday will have eight colts starting, and Braulio Baeza will be on one of them. The cool Panamanian was selected today by Elliott Burch, the colt's trainer, to ride Arts and Letters in the classic for 3-year-olds.

Ian MacGregor, the new chairman of American Metal Climax, Inc., used the company's annual meeting yesterday to plead for higher depletion allowances for some hard-rock minerals and for the retention of the 7 per cent investment tax credit.
PARIS, May 1 -- Post-de Gaulle France passed a test today as May Day, a potentially dangerous time, came off without major violence anywhere in the country.

Professor George Wald of Harvard has suggested in an article that appeared recently on this page that a significant source of unrest among young people is the failure of adults "to cope with situations we freely concede to be altogether wrong, and that threaten their and our lives."

A counter sit-in staged in Columbia University's Fayerweather Hall by eight professors and a graduate student determined to demonstrate "that this building does not belong to Students for a Democratic Society" ended formally yesterday about two hours after the radical student left the building.
Prices continued to advance in active trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

William S. Renchard, chairman of the Chemical Bank, was re-elected yesterday as president of the New York Chamber of Commerce. The organization of businessmen also re-elected G. Wallace Bates, vice president and general counsel of the New York Telephone Company, as chairman of the group's executive committee.

A new technique for brain and spinal surgery that puts the surgeon behind a microscope and places highly precise instruments in his hands is now being demonstrated to a group of 80 surgeons from around the country at Mount Sinai Hospital.
LIMA, Peru, April 25 -- At conferences and in private meetings throughout Latin America, Peru is trying to organize a coalition against the United States.

Seaboard World Airlines, the Kennedy-based all-cargo trans-Atlantic carrier, said yesterday that it planned to start flying from Middle Western and Pacific-Coast cities to the 11 countries it serves in Europe on or soon after June 28.

BERLIN, May 1 -- An East German train engineer and a woman conductor used the May Day celebration to escape to the West today. They drove an empty train of the city's elevated railway to a West Berlin stop, got out and asked for political asylum. The railway is operated by the East Germans although it tuna in both parts of the city.

NEW ORLEANS, May 1 (UPI) -- Lee Elder, using a borrowed club, took only one putt on 12 holes today to shoot a six-under-par 66 and tie Kermit Zarley for the first-round lead in the $100,000 Greater New Orleans open golf tournament.
THE white suckers' annual spawning run up Eastern streams is beginning, and some fishermen find them worthy of pursuit.
MOSCOW, May 1 -- The Soviet Union celebrated May Day today without brandishing its missiles and tanks and with a reaffirmation of its declared readiness to settle outstanding disputes by negotiation.

William R. (Tim) Crandol, 26 years old, who wears a white shirt and dark tie and drives a Manhattan Transit Company bus between the New Jersey suburbs and the Port Authority terminal on Eighth Avenue, does not look as though he has been through a revolution.
The Nixon Administration's otherwise laudable efforts to promote peace in the Middle East are ill-served by the decision disclosed last week to sell more jet fighter planes to Jordan.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, May 2 (AP) -- South Vietnam is waiting for "acts instead of words" to prove that the Vietcong is prepared to begin bilateral talks, a governments spokesman said today.

Treasury bond prices, reacting to the Government's plans for refinancing $5.9-billion of maturing securities, declined yesterday to bring interest rates more into line with the 6.50 per cent yield that is being offered.

Black Chamber Dance Concert presented the first of two programs last night at Barnard College's Minor Latham Playhouse. Sponsored by the Harm Cultural Council, the Urban Center of Columbia University and Barnard College, the series designed to provide a showcase for talented black choreographers and dancers.

The Police Department's fourth platoon went into operation for the first time last night in one of the most dangerous areas of the city as the Patrolman's Benevolent Association lost the first round of a legal battle to block the new setup.
"New York City is in a lot of trouble," a 35-member board of top leaders said yesterday as the first United Fund of Greater New York campaign began.

DETROIT, May 1 (AP) -- The General Motors Corporation reported today that its production of automobiles and trucks in April was off 5.3 per cent from April 1, 1968; indicating that the company had been setting a strong pace for the month until hit by strikes in six states.

Neither a one-hitter by Don Sutton of the Los Angeles Dodgers, nor a three-hitter by Detroit's Denny McLain, was good enough for top billing in yesterday's baseball program, because of Don Wilson's no-hitter for Houston at Cincinnati.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 1 -- A scrubby $70 mule named Hope was presented to the nation's Republican Governors today by a delegation of poor people to remind them that Kentucky life is not all bluegrass, bourbon and thoroughbreds.
MOSCOW, May 1 -- Soviet theorists who once took an enthusiastic view of student unrest in the United States appear less than enchanted these days with America's youthful rebels.
Earl H. Richert, a 54-year-old newspaperman who began his career as a copyboy on The Oklahoma (City) News, was appointed yesterday as editor in chief of Scripps-Howard Newspapers.
Stockholders at three oil-industry annual meetings were treated to good news yesterday.

The city's real estate industry said yesterday that it would challenge the constitutionality of the newly passed measure to limit rents in uncontrolled apartments by violating it in selected instances to develop a test case.

TOKYO -- Japan has done everything right to make sure it inherits the future. First of all it lost the war. It was not only squashed in 1945 but yielded 46 per cent of its territory (not including Manchuria) and all its overseas empire. It was bombed to rubble and occupied by a conquering army.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 1 (UPI) -Wilt Chamberlain dominated Bill Russell for the first time in the series and Jerry West poured in 39 points tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers defeated the Boston Celtics, 117-104, to move to within one victory of their first National Basketball Association championship.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 1 -- A leading human geneticist predicted here today that vaccinations of synthetic viruses would soon be used to correct certain inherited defects.

The Lila Motley Cancer Foundation will hold its 14th annual Peacock Ball tomorrow night in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom. Proceeds will help the New York University Medical Center at 550 First Avenue, where the foundation has its offices. In addition, a check for $200,000 will be presented during the ball to Dr. Ivan L. Bennett Jr., the center's director, toward a chair in cancer research that the foundation has pledged to endow.
