WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A high-ranking task force in the Nixon Administration is focusing on the second phase of a two-part study that could result in a reduction either of worldwide American commitments or of the forces deployed to meet those commitments.

THREE conductors were supposed to share last night's New York Philharmonic concert. Leonard Bernstein was scheduled to lead the two big numbers of the Stravinsky concert, while two of the assistant conductors were to take care of more minor items.

HARTFORD, April 30 -- The 27th season of the opera department of the Hartt College of Music ended tonight with a double bill that contained the world premiere of a one-act opera by Edward Miller. The other work on the program was Manuel de Falla's "La Vida Breve." Because it was sung in English, it was presented as "The Short Life."

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 1 -- Maj. james D. Chichester-Clark, a moderate in the Protestant-dominated Unionist party, was chosen today to become Northern Ireland's fifth Prime Minister. He won, 17 to 16, in a vote by the Unionist members of Northern Ireland's House of Commons.

As an alumnus of City College I am concerned lest the granting of unreasonable demands by disruptive students cause a serious deterioration in standards and performance, resulting in an inferior college that will eventually present a problem similar to that of the slum school.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Carter Brown, 34 years was named today director The National Gallery of Art. succeeds John Walker, 62, has been with the gallery 31 years and director for last 13. Mr. Walker will July 1.
The parents of two Columbia University students had sharply different reactions yesterday to the naming of their sons in a court order stemming from the latest occupation of campus buildings.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May -Secretary General Thant has no intention of withdrawing United Nations observers along the Suez Canal, despite identical letters to Israel and the United Arab Republic expressing concern for their safety, a secretariat source said today.

ATHENS, May 1 -- A Greek labor unions' attempt to test the military regime's assurances that Greek workers now have the right to strike was defeated today because the regime proclaimed May Day a public holiday.
Albert H. Bowker, chancellor of the City University, said last night that "wholly segregated or separatist" education was a "fraud" that "exploits the student."

The Royal Ballet presented its long-awaited new production of "The Sleeping Beauty" last night at the Metropolitan Opera. Any new look, such as this one under the direction of Peter Wright, that surrounds the highly formal Petipa choreography with a romantically medieval setting is not only daring but asking for trouble.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 1 -- The Saratoga Horse Show, first of the important outdoor events on the Eastern circuit, is scheduled for the Saratoga race track tomorrow through Sunday with a record entry of more than 335 horses.
PRAGUE, May 1 -- Czechoslovaks marked May Day with a mixture of restraint, holiday spirit, solemnity and silent protest.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -The Senate today ended its hearings on the immediate financial needs of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. There was scant mention and no resolution of the question of long-term funding.

LONDON, May 1 (AP) -- World War II's favorite pinup girl, Betty Grable, the movie actress, made a smash comeback on the London stage last night dodging bullwhips and gunfights and emerging intact from a burning saloon. But she didn't get a single review from British drama critics.

LOUISVILLE, May 1 -- Johnny Longden, a wizened little guy in a ridiculous looking orange helmet and black leather jacket, stood in the doorway of the empty end stall and blinked in the early morning sunshine. The trainer of Majestic Prince, the huge and beautiful favorite for Saturday's Kentucky Derby, shifted nervously from foot to foot, much too keyed up to exchange conversation with rubberneckers crowded on the outside of the barn.
LONDON, May 1 (Reuters) -- About 200,000 labor unionists across the country today launched a series of May Day strikes to protest the Government's proposed antistrike legislation.

ALBANY, May 1 -- Despite cries of "unconstitutional," the Assembly gtave final passage late today to a bill that would permit religious colleges to participate in a $15-million program that provides state aid to private institutions of higher learning.

IF a game of word association were played in Manhattan today, the term "professional model" would probably evoke the following responses: Young . . tall . . . skinny . . . flat-chested . . . cool . . . aloof . . . self-centered.
The Yankees continued their program of kindness toward the young, the aged and the needy yesterday at their welfare house in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- In his first confrontation over domestic programs with the Nixon Administration, Senator Jacob K. Javits urged the White House today to reconsider its reported decision to put off plans for a major program against hunger in the nation.
Two men identified by the police as members of the Black Panther party were arrested yesterday on charges of felonious assault in the beating of two Transit Authority patrolmen.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 1 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan said today that he would like to see the Republican Governors Conference endorse President Nixon's Safeguard anti missile system and indicated that he might seek such an endorsement tomorrow.

A group of 35 horsemen, critical of the way the executives of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association have handled the Aqueduct boycott, called yesterday for a showdown over the stoppage at a meeting at the track.
Money was tight as a drum last week, banking data released yesterday showed.

BEALLSVILLE, Ohio, April 30 -The Beallsville City Council decided this week to erect a flagpole and a granite plaque in the town's tiny cemetery, where four of Beallsville's dead from the Vietnam war are buried.

HONG KONG, May 1 -- Mao Tse-tung, the Chinese Communist leader, and his chosen heir, Lin Piao, made a May Day appearance at Peking's Tien An Men (Gate of Heavenly Peace), the press agency Hsinhua reported today.

The Bowery Savings Bank, the nation's largest mutual savings bank, has decided to withdraw from membership in the Federal Home Loan Bank System, a quasi-Governmental organization that provides reserve credit to the thrift industry.

Queens shoppers surged in by the hundreds yesterday to shake Robert F. Wagner's hand, wish him well or get his autograph as the former three-term Mayor took his first walking tour in eight years seeking voter support.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Despite a conservative voting record on Federal spending and antipoverty legislation, Representative Donald Rumsfeld, the young Republican picked by President Nixon to be director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, sees himself emerging as an Administration's chief spokesman for the poor.
LOUISVILLE, May 1 -- In the stable area at Churchill Downs today, men with tape recorders kept shoving microphones at trainers and asking, "Is he ready?"

NEW HAVEN, May 1 -- Kingman Brewster Jr., president of Yale University, told a mass meeting of 4,000 students, faculty members and trustees tonight that the university "will not break its legally enforceable promises" to the Reserve Officers Training Corps.
Two show-cause orders were served yesterday upon Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, in an effort to force him to reopen the school, which he closed last week after a student look-in.

SUSAN SONTAG'S second collection of critical essays (and her fourth book) is in many ways better than her first and in some ways a disaster. The first, "Against Interpretation," was bumpy and erratic, by turns brilliant and dull. In contrast, three-fourths of "Styles of Radical Will" is consistent and well-integrated, and displays an enlightened, energetic intellect exploring the margins of contemporary consciousness.

GENEVA, May 1 -- Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, Secretary General Thant's special representative for the Middle East, returned to Moscow today after discussions here with Mr. Thant. The Secretary General said that Dr. Jarring, who is Sweden's Ambassador to the Soviet Union, would not resume his United Nations mediation efforts for the time being.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 1 -- United States battle deaths dropped in the week ending last Saturday to the lowest point since the first week in January, while enemy casualties rose slightly, according to United States Army reports.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 1 -Because only 13 colts were named this morning to start in the 14th annual Messenger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway the night of May 10, the one-mile pace for 3-year-olds will offer a gross purse of $203,476.75, making it the richest event in harness-racing history. The purse for last year's Messenger -- $189,018.54 -- set the record.

THAT the antiheroes should usurp familiar imperial crowns and assume now-dusty laurels was inevitable. There have been signs of Nicol Williamson's portrayal of Hamlet for some years -- in other performances, sometimes in other plays.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 1 (UPI) -- Gov. Robert E. McNair declared a state of emergency today and imposed a curfew on this coastal city, where National Guard troops were already on duty as a result of a strike by Negro hospital workers.
About 100 radical Columbia University students fled yesterday from the two buildings they had occupied overnight within minutes after warrants for their arrest had been signed in State Supreme Court.

This year's earlier Easter, which brought substantial seasonal business to stores in March rather than the customary April upswing, was reflected in last month's sales results among New York's leading department stores. Average April sales here rose only moderately over last year.

ALBANY, May 1 -- The Legislature, having finally passed a school decentralization plan for New York City last night, began today to speed toward adjournment. It prepared to pass a supplemental budget and pay increases for top state employes, as well as increases for court personnel.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 1 (AP) -- Julie Heldman, a New York amateur, advanced today in the British hard-court tennis championship with a 6-8, 6-3, 6-0, victory over Mrs. Joyce Williams of England.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The New York Stock Exchange asserted today that the Securities and Exchange Commission has no power to abolish minimum fixed-commission rates for securities transactions.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -The Navy awarded Litton Industries a $112.5-million contract today to build the first of a series of nine amphibious assault ships, each capable of putting a Marine battalion ashore by helicopter as well as landing craft.

KATMANDU, Nepal, May 1 -Stormy weather in a narrow Himalayan gorge made it impossible today for a Royal Nepalese army aircraft to pick up survivors of an American expedition that was attempting to scale Mount Dhaulagiri.

The Mill Factors Corporation, the insolvent finance company that uncovered huge, unsuspected losses in its commercial loan portfolio late last year, announced yesterday that it sustained a loss of $37.49-million in its operations in 1968.
LOS ANGELES, May 1 -- A rocket-engine vehicle fueled by liquefied natural gas will attempt to break the world land speed record, the American Gas Association announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel flew to Micronesia today in hopes of tying the Pacific Trust Territory closer to the United States.

Frugality and efficiency are good Republican watch-words. President Nixon has often stressed them. MONTREAL, May 1 -- The New York Mets ended their Canadian caper today by losing to the Montreal Expos, 3-2, in the last half of the ninthinning.
PLAYERS who refuse to have post-mortems miss a great deal of the fun in bridge. For the keen analyst, the post-mortem may be much more exciting than the actual play.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 1 -- In September, 1963, barely six months after Capt. Terence O'Neill became Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, there were rumors that his Unionist party colleague, Brian Faulkner, was intriguing to oust him.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission and the Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service drew the last strong attacks today as the House Commerce Committee ended hearings on the cigarette controversy.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, April 27 -- In 1958, two years before this little West African country won independence, 15,000 Frenchmen lived here. Today the total is 35,000 in a population of more than four million.

P. Ballantine Sons, the big Newark brewer whose fortunes have been lagging in recent years, is slated to be sold to the Investors Funding Corporation of New York, a holding company with extensive interests in real estate and financial services.

Three mothers of pupils at Public School 39 in East Harlem yesterday put an end to the transfer of pupils into the classes of seven teachers loyal to the United Federation of Teachers. The presence of the teachers has become a community issue.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company may soon bring legal action against certain construction companies that were indicted last year by a New York County Grand Jury on charges of rigging bids on utilities contracts.

The stock market remained on an even keel yesterday while consolidating its spectacular gains of Wednesday. Advances outpaced declines by 716 to 642.
CAIRO, May 1 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser warned tonight that Egyptian planes might retaliate against Israeli civilian targets if Israel attempted further raids against Egypt.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 1 (UPI) -- Bill Shoemaker, who suffered a fractured pelvis and internal injuries in a race track accident yesterday, was reported resting comfortably today after having undergone a one-hour operation last night.
Dr. Robert D. Cross, the president of Hunter College for the last 18 months, is expected to be named next week as president of Swarthmore College, the small liberal-arts school in Swarthmore, Pa.

CINCINNATI, May 1 (UPI) -Twenty-four-year-old Don Wilson pitched the second no-hitter of his brief major league career last night as the Houston Astros scored a 4-0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds. Jim Maloney of the Reds held the Astros hitless last night at Crosley Field in a 10-0 victory.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 1 -- Robert S. McNamara, addressing a predominantly Roman Catholic audience, appealed today for a "humane but massive" reduction in the world rate of population growth.
WASHINGTON May 1 -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen temporarily blocked today the confirmation of President Nixon's choice for chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

Charles M. Spofford, a member of the law firm of Davis, Polk Wardell, will receive the first Cultural League of New York award for "outstanding contribution as a private citizen in advancing the cultural life of New York City."

WARSAW, May 1 -- More than 200,000 people marched and strolled for three and a half hours today in the May Day parade.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Some American officials privately acknowledged today that a statement by Tran Buu Kiem, the chief Vietcong negotiator in Paris, showed more flexibility and could signal some willingness to move into secret talks.

The City Center is making an effort to attract the Spanish-speaking theater audience with "Fiesta in Madrid," an expanded version of a famous Spanish zarzuela. It will open May 28 for a three-week run.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia refused today to stay a lower court's injunction ordering the Government to drop limits on the size of crowds demonstrating in front of the White House.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 1 -- At a diplomatic reception here recently, two European diplomats were talking about their post here.

HONOLULU, May 2 (UPI) -- Vice President Agnew warned today that there was a danger that vigilante groups would take "the law into their own hands" unless college officials stood up to illegal campus protests.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The New York Stock Exchange disclosed today that an indirect form of commission-splitting between its members and non-members was still under way, and said it may pose a serious threat to the integrity of the securities industry.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Nixon said today that "American homes are being bombarded with the largest volume of sex-oriented mail in history," and he asked Congress for three new laws to stop it.
Stock prices moved steadily upward yesterday as the Dow-Jones industrial average reached a new high for 1969, gaining an impressive 7.95 points to close at 957.17.
LONDON, May 2 -- The pound sank to its effective floor rate of $2.3825 today in jittery preweekend selling, brought on by uncertainties over whether the West German mark would be revalued upward.
DETROIT, May 2 -- A substantial price reduction on the low-priced Valiant compact car line was announced today by the Chrysler Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Senate critics believe they have pinpointed a weakness in the proposed Safeguard defense system that could provide a technical excuse for political compromise in the missile defense controversy.
CHICAGO, May 2 -- Fresh from their recent success in Canada, the New York Mets ran into trouble on the home front today when they dropped a 6-4 decision to the Chicago Cubs.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The United States and West Germany reached "substantial" agreement today on a long-term financial formula under which Bonn would "offset" most of the annual dollar cost caused by the stationing of 200,000 United States troops on West German soil.

THE excitement stirred by the recent auction sale of a fine 18th-century English cabinet by William Vile is a sign of improving taste in the English furniture field.
A spokesman for Sears, Roebuck Co. yesterday denied statements by the leader of a citizens' anticrime committee about the company's losses from theft.

Six members of the Black Panther party awaiting trial on charges of plotting a terror campaign against the city yesterday were granted a hearing Monday at which they will argue that their bail is too high.

RIVIERA BEACH, Fla., May 2 -- The forward hatch was shut tight above the men in the Ben Franklin. Sea water began pouring into the ballast tanks, the electric motors sent a low hum through the humid interior and the clickety-click of the fathometer assured the captain that his submarine was sinking slowly to the bottom.

ANOTHER Pierre Cardin collection is taking shape, this one in workrooms a few doors off Seventh Avenue instead of on the Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honore in Paris. The clothes, for next fall, have the plastic appliques, the plethora of pleats and the crisp, contrasting border designs that marked the couture collection Cardin showed in Paris earlier this year.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 3 (AP) -- United States armor overran a network of enemy bunkers yesterday during a four-hour battle on the southern edges of the Boiloi woods, 35 miles northwest of Saigon.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has notified Antioch College that it may operate its all-Negro black studies institute as long as non-blacks are not excluded solely because of race, color or national origin.

HAVANA, May 2 (AP) -- The latest issue of Verde Olivo, Cuba's armed forces magazine, says 11 United States fliers are living a quiet country life in a North Vietnamese prison village. The article quotes Lieut. Col. Robinson Risner as having said the men were well treated.
OAKLAND, Calif., May 2 -- The president of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation today held out 30 cents a pound -- three cents more than the going price -- as a reasonable level for aluminum.

Oil issues led the American Stock Exchange to higher ground yesterday in active trading.

PARIS, May 2 -- Strong central bank intervention was required today to keep Europe's major currencies at their fixed rates. It was a case of the Friday jitters as rumors circulated of possible parity changes this weekend.

QUANTICO, Va., May 2 -- Byron Dyce, who ran his fastest half-mile in defeat last week, made his best mile run a victorious one for New York University's distance medley relay team today in the 13th annual Quantico Relays.

The second (and probably last) annual masked benefit ball at Grasmere, the historic Rhinebeck, N. Y., home of Mrs. Louise Clews Timpson will be held next Saturday.

BONN, May 2 -- Franz von Papen, former German Chancellor who helped to pave the way for Hitler, died today in his villa in the town of Obersasbach in Baden-Wurttemberg. He was 89 years old.
DETROIT, May 2 -- The American Motors Corporation today recalled 54,087 of its 1968 and 1969 cars, and the Chrysler Corporation recalled 18,905 new cars for correction of possible safety defects.

MOSCOW, May 2 -- Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, challenger for the world chess championship, outplayed Tigran Petrosian, the champion and his compatriot, in the eighth of their 24-game match series at Moscow's Variety Theater today.

NEW ORLEANS, May 2 (UPI) -- Frank Beard of Louisville, handling the 7,090-yard, par-72 Lakewood Country Club course like a profitable piece of private property, fired his second straight 67 today to take the lead at the halfway point in the $100,000 Greater New Orleans open golf tournament.

KATMANDU, Nepal, May 2 (Reuters) -- A surviving member of an American expedition said today that a "terrific avalanche" had hurled five Americans and two Sherpa guides to their deaths Monday while they were setting up an advance base camp for the ascent of Mount Dhaulagiri.
ALBANY, May 2 -- The Assembly today killed a controversial bill that would have restored slate voting in New York City only for the June 17 primary.

When Seiferheld Co. put up a "By appointment only" sign after its last show in 1965, the public lost a dependable source of drawing exhibitions. Seiferheld now plans a show a year and is opening the first one today in new quarters at 183 East 64th Street.

To the Editor: The recent announcement by the bistate Delaware River and Bay Authority of traffic and site studies for a proposed bridge across the Delaware River between Cumberland County, N. J. and Kent County, Del. came as a surprise to me, since the New Jersey end would not be directly accessible to present major north-south highways.

BRYAN, Tex., May 2 (UPI) -- A former convict and his wife, armed with pistols and a shotgun, kidnapped a Texas highway patrolman today and led hundreds of lawmen on a six-hour chase that ended when officers killed the gunman from ambush.

ROME, May 2 -- Terence Cardinal Cooke ended five hectic days of ceremonies and social activities in Rome today by assuming formal possession of his titular church and by taking informal leave of the 550 New Yorkers who had come here to see him and 32 other prelates elevated to the purple.

HONG KONG, May 2 -- The decision-making organs of the Chinese Communist party -- the Central Committee, the Politburo and the standing committee of the Politburo -- are back in working order after the disruption to which they were subjected by the party chairman. Mao Tse-tung during the Cultural Revolution.
The general board of the National Council of Churches was presented with a "Black Manifesto" yesterday that demanded $500-million in reparations for black Americans.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 2 -- The only certainty about the Messenger Stakes is that the one-mile classic for 3-year-old pacers will be staged at Roosevelt Raceway on the night of May 10. The final of this 14th addition of the stakes will be preceded by two elimination trials here Tuesday night.
CANBERRA, Australia, May 2 (Reuters) -- The Government today refused to give a passport to an Australian-born reporter who has covered the Vietnam war from the Communist side.

To the Editor: Once again, I see, The Times [editorial April 21] has turned its Olympian gaze on the Government of Greece and with one Delphic sweep of the pen it judges a failure two years of dedicated work. Backed by all the news that fits its preconceptions, it likens Greece to Nazi Germany.

By land, sea, and air, the enemies of man's survival relentlessly press their attack. The most dangerous of all these enemies is man's own undirected technology. The radioactive poisons from nuclear tests, the runoff into rivers of nitrogen fertilizers, the smog from automobiles, the pesticides in the food chain, and the destruction of topsoil by strip mining are examples of the failure to foresee and control the untoward consequences of modern technology.

To the Editor: Abject capitulation to student violence at Cornell climaxes a series of surrenders which may destroy the university in America as a place of free inquiry and respect for morality and law. Unbridled attacks on faculties, destruction of property and wanton breaking into private files would be crimes punishable under law in any other context. [Editorial April 26.]
LOS ANGELES, May 2 -- The Boston Celtics, who traditionally have had more lives than a pack of Kilkenny cats, appeared half-dead on the floor and almost completely defunct in the dressing room.

ACCRA, Ghana, May 2 -- For the first time since President Kwame Nkrumah began to suppress critics of his regime a decade ago, Ghana's politicians are legally free to speak their piece and to solicit the votes of their countrymen.

The Board of Education obtained a restraining order yesterday in State Supreme Court to prevent members of the Intermediate School 201 governing board and others from "interferring" with the operation of Public School 39 in Harlem, where a boycott had cut attendance sharply.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 12 (AP) -- Al Lopez, 60-year-old manager of the Chicago White Sox, resigned tonight because of a stomach illness.

Student disruptions continued yesterday at Brooklyn College as three small fires broke out in campus buildings, several smoke bombs were thrown and members of the Students for a Democratic Society broke down a dean's door.

The annual exhibition of the Artist-Craftsmen of New York will end around noon today after having attracted thousands of visitors. No one kept a tally of viewers, for the gallery -- one of the handsomest in New York -- is the lobby of the First National City Bank on Park Avenue and 53d Street.

The Lots for Little Thrift Shop will receive the proceeds of a luncheon Tuesday in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom. Eight charitable organizations, which also share the shop's profits, will be the eventual gainers.

ALBANY, May 2 -- The 1969 Legislature adjourned tonight after a final spurt in which the Republican - controlled body passed bills to increase pay for top appointed state officials and three New York City District Attorneys.

The hurried motorist who put a rare 19th-century United States gold coin into a parking meter thinking it was a dime can recover it if he gets in touch with Finance Administrator Fiorvante G. Perrotta in the Municipal Building.
Two sisters and their three young daughters died in a fire that swept through a brownstone tenement in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn early yesterday.

City Council President Francis X. Smith said yesterday that the Council "might very well" amend Mayor Lindsay's proposed expense budget for next year to provide more money for the public library system.

PARIS, May 2 -- The French Cabinet, meeting today for the first time under the chairmanship of Interim President Alain Poher, fixed June 1 as the date for the presidential election. If no candidate obtains a majority, a runoff will be held two weeks later.

For the second day in a row, the commodity futures markets generally showed slow activity and few notable price changes yesterday.

YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., May 2 (UPI) -- The famed Wawona Tunnel Tree has toppled, the National Park Service said today.

Former West German Chancellor Ludwig Erhard was identified yesterday as the head of a group of German industrialists interested in buying into the Alan Wood Steel Company. Stockholders of the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation were told yesterday not to expect a "sudden recovery" of the company to its past profitability level.
An evening of dance -- from the classical movements of ballet to the gyrations of rock 'n' roll -- will be held Thursday at the New York State Theater to help the New York City Ballet Fund.

Bates Lowry, director of the Museum of Modern Art for less than a year, has resigned "for personal considerations," David Rockefeller, the museum's board chairman and William S. Paley, president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- There are indications that Hanoi may be preparing to hold some indirect, semi-official discussions on the status of several hundred American prisoners of war held in North Vietnam.

ROME, May 2 -- John Cardinal Wright, Bishop of Pittsburgh, was named today by Pope Paul VI to head the Vatican congregation dealing with the problems of an increasingly turbulent Roman Catholic priesthood.

CHICAGO, May 2 (UPI) -- Ja-neen Welch, who traveled with the entourage of George C. Wallace for a while last year, will plead not guilty when she appears in court here next week on a charge of prostitution.

To the Editor: The proposed antiballistic missile system raises some questions for at least this airline pilot. We who fly on the nation's airlines have waited in vain through the first decade of the jet age for a workable collision-avoidance device.
Prices of most new issues rose this week although the advances were not so large as in the preceding week, according to specialists in the field.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 -- For two minutes tomorrow, give or take a second, the attention of the continent will be held by the Kentucky Derby.

Three seasons ago, Frank Robinson led the American League in batting, homers and runs batted in, thereby winning what is known as the triple crown. This season, the star right-fielder of the Baltimore Orioles has been ahead of his 1956 statistical pace.

ABOARD THE QUEEN ELIZABETH 2 -- The Queen Elizabeth 2 is at last at sea on her maiden voyage to New York. The 963-foot liner turned her beautiful, flared bow seaward from Southampton at 12:45 P.M., 15 minutes behind schedule because of the difficulty of getting several thousand visitors ashore before sailing time.

WESTPORT, Conn., May 3 -- A virus epidemic among horses quartered at the Fairfield County Hunt Club decimated the club's spring junior horse show today, with fewer than half the listed entrants competing.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Supreme Court will rule next term on the constitutionality of state residency requirements that bar millions of citizens from voting in each Presidential election.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -Some Congressional Republicans called today for the resignation of Justice Abe Fortas following the disclosure that he had received -- and later returned -- a $20,000 fee from the family foundation of Louis E. Wolfson, a convicted securities manipulator.

These vignettes of life in a small Sicilian town deal with the period of the early nineteen-fifties. But Leonardo Sciascia, who lived and taught there, has combined past and present, the eternal and the temporary in such a rounded portrait as to make his fictitious town of Regalpetra a classic example of the eroded, meager municipality trying to exist in the modern world, in spite of a burden of feudal, economic and corrupting disabilities.

The suspence was long gone by the time the announcement came at the end of "The Grammy Awards Show" last night that Simon and Garfunkel's "Mrs. Robinson" had won the Record of the Year Award, the top one voted by members of the recording industry.

The Board of Higher Education approved in principle last night a series of proposals for the extensive restructuring of the City University.

Students at Boys High School in Brooklyn rampaged through the school yesterday breaking windows, overturning lockers and allegedly setting two small fires, but a scheduled citywide student strike appeared to have had little impact on the school system.
TRENTON, May 5 -- The New Jersey Senate authorized a further study of a possible jetport site this evening, approving a bill that would establish a State Airport Authority.

Philip A. Kalodner, the Philadelphia lawyer who last month on his own assumed the chief executive officer's responsibilities at the Curtis Publishing Company, and subsequently was elected president, now is locked in a proxy contest for control of the sorely troubled publishing concern.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Nixon Administration was under heavy pressure tonight to take a position on the continuation of the special school milk program.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A new rule that would prohibit anyone who was making a tender offer for stock from buying that same stock outside the tender offer was proposed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The credit markets continued yesterday to display a split personality. Some short-term interest rates climbed and most long-term bond yields moved downward.

ASILOMAR, Calif., May 5 -Carl Marcy, the able staff director of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, recently told a World Affairs Council meeting at this seaside conference ground that the Senate is determined to assert a strong new voice in foreign and defense policy.

Ben Sevran, formerly manager of Gimbels in Valley Stream, L. I., and head of the suburban stores, has been appointed vice president in charge of operations for Gimbels New York and suburban stores. Mr. Sevran, who was also appointed a member of the company's executive board, succeeds Irving Wiggs, who has resigned.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The House Ways and Means Committee is seriously considering a plan that would limit the freedom of foundations to make study grants to individuals.
Pratt Institute announced yesterday that it would arrest and expel students who commit vandalism, deny others access to classes or incite nonstudents to such action.
United States dry-bulk-cargo trade is expected to more than double in the next 30 years, according to a Maritime Administration study issued yesterday.

MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., May 4 -- Dan Smith, a beefy, partly blind black man in a black suit and fedora, peered through thick-lensed glasses at the folklore enthusiasts gathered here today at the first annual Mid-Hudson Folk Festival.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6 -- The chief delegates of the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain talked for three hours today on a Middle East peace settlement.
The first segment of the city's long-delayed computerized system for controlling auto traffic was formally inaugurated yesterday along the 11.2-mile stretch of Northern Boulevard in Queens.

LONDON, May 6 -- The Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe warned the Greek Government today that its internal policies violated the principles of human rights on which the Council was founded.
Mayor Lindsay offered yesterday to send a policeman -uniformed or in plain clothes -- to any church or synagogue in the city whose leaders fear they may be targets of a demonstration.

When Queen Elizabeth 2 steams through the Narrows today on her maiden voyage from Southampton, she will receive the warmest of welcomes from a New York familiar for more than a century with the house flag of Cunard. Since arrival of the first Cunarder in 1847, this harbor and this city have greeted her sisters and descendants as old friends who have strengthened the links between Britain and the New World.

The first two floors of an eight-story Greenwich Village hotel are being converted into six intimate playhouses. The reconstruction is under way at the Broadway Central Hotel, 673 Broadway, between Bleecker and West Third Streets.

Resumption of classes at City College represents another victory for injunctive process over illegal occupation. Coming on top of two similar experiences at Columbia, the decision of 250 black and Puerto Rican students to end their siege provides some small basis for hope that court orders may offer a road to peace on troubled metropolitan campuses without open clashes between the police and undergraduate rebels.

Mrs. Martin Luther King Jr. called on labor, the clergy, political leaders and the civil rights movement last night to rally to the cause of striking hospital workers in Charleston, S. C.

About 300 municipal hospital employes protesting budget cuts massed in front of City Hall yesterday and were pushed behind hastily set up police barriers after 20 members of the group stormed up the portico and banged on the locked glass doors, shouting that they wanted to talk to the Mayor.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., May 6 (AP) -- State troopers, firing a can of chemical Mace to clear a doorway, broke up a sit-in in the Purdue administration building tonight.

W. H. Auden, winner of the highest poetry awards of Britain and the United States, has written for a girls' school in Connecticut the narrative part of an opera based on a medieval French legend. The pupils are composing the music and will perform the work.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Nixon, under intense Congressional and public pressure for an expanded effort to fight hunger, proposed a Government food program today that would eventually cost more than $1-billion a year.

Unless a shortage of jockeys develops, the horsemen's boycott that has kept Aqueduct closed for nine days will come to at least a partial end today. The dispute has cost New York State approximately $3.3-million in lost pari-mutuel tax revenue.

Another big name in the entertainment world has apparently entered the burgeoning fray over control of Northern Songs, Ltd., the British company that holds the copyrights to the songs written by two of the four members of the Beatles, the singing group.

A Long Island automobile owner recently had an engine installed in a 1961 Corvair. The purchase, amounting to $150, went down on his credit card slip as a set of five new tires. Over the next six months, a major oil company -- one of the largest industrial concerns in the nation -will be financing the transaction interest-free.
ENGHIEN - LES - BAINS, France, May 6 -- Tidalium Pelo got a terrible ride and finished sixth today in a not-very-rich but extremely classy trot at this Paris suburb.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 6 -- The New York Yankees ended a seven-game losing streak tonight by winning the first inter-division game they have ever played. They defeated the California Angels, 2-I, on Fritz Peterson's five-hit pitching and Bobby Murcer's two-run single off Rudy May.

TOKYO -- One cannot even dimly understand the psychological forces motivating the gifted and dynamic Japanese people without appreciating the political role intermittently played by Buddhism in this fascinating nation.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Charles A. Meyer, the new Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, urged Latin - American governments today to establish clear rules for foreign investment.

" SHADOW GAME," which the Columbia Broadcasting System is televising tonight at 9:30 as its fourth and final "C.B.S. Playhouse" of the season, reminds one of Marshall McLuhan's observation that television tends to be the mortuary of an earlier era's art --in this case, the office dramas of TV's "golden age" of the 1950's.

MOSCOW, May 7 -- The ninth game of the world chess championship match series, between Tigran Petrosian, the titleholder, and his countryman, Boris Spassky, the challenger, ended in a draw today at Moscow's Variety Theater.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Federal authorities announced here today their first arraignment of a man charged with the "successful" hijacking of an airliner.

U.N. Secretary General Thant's somber warning that time is running out for a Middle East settlement should help to spur laggard Big Four talks in New York and the even more crucial Big Two discussions in Washington. It should also inspire sobering second thoughts in Jerusalem, Cairo and Amman.

BEIRUT, Leganon, May 6 -- President Charles Helou in a television address indirectly gave notice to Palestinian commando groups operating in southern Lebanon that the Government did not intend to be pushed around by its friends any more than by its enemies.
The student disorders on the nation's college campuses have generally received scant attention abroad.
The City Center's American Dance Season resumed last night with Paul Taylor and his dance company after a two-week interval.

City College reopened in its entirety for the first time in two weeks yesterday, but the campus was tense as white radical students staged a series of disruptive hit-and-run forays into classroom buildings in support of black student demands.
The upcoming annual meeting of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, scheduled for Monday, May 19, at 4 Irving Place, is going to be picketed by a group of the utility's supervisors.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 6 (AP) -- Northern Ireland declared an amnesty today for all "political prisoners." One of the first to be freed was the extremist Protestant leader, the Rev. Ian Paisley.

IT was the damnedest concert, and most of the action was outside rather than inside Carnegie Recital Hall last night. The occasion was the last of the Evenings for New Music series, and it was a collaborative event in which LaMonte Young, Terry Riley and Son Hassell participated.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Republican leadership has started a series of changes in the State Department, where President Nixon, during the campaign last year, promised voters a thorough "housecleaning."

The head of Japan's largest chemical company said here yesterday his country must soon provide the same liberal foreign investment rules as prevail among partners of the Atlantic community.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 7 (AP) -- An Army CH-47 Chinook heli-helicopter crashed and burned 75 miles north of Saigon yesterday, killing 34 persons and injuring 35 in what was believed to be the worst helicopter disaster of the Vietnam war.
Ten years ago, the Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, now general secretary of the World Council of Churches, urged the country's churches to begin sharing some of their wealth with the state.

IN the vast literature of bridge over a period of 40 years, there are only about half a dozen books on the play of the cards that rank as classics. An addition to that number is "Winning Declarer Play" by Dorothy Hayden, published today by Harper Row at $6.95.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Britain has "the firm intent and capability of maintaining sterling through this current period unscathed," a United States source reported today following a high-level British- United States financial meeting.

Commodity traders continued to eye the weather of the corn-growing areas of the Middle West yesterday. Buying on news of continued wetness and more rain to come sent corn futures up to new life-of-contract highs.
VIENNA, May 6 -- Czechoslovakia's new leadership moved today to impose tight controls over the country's still out-spoken press, radio and television.
TOKYO, May 6 -- Far Eastern intelligence analysts report that the Soviet Union and Communist China have substantially strengthened their military capability along the 4,500-mile common frontier.

LONDON, May 6 -- Scotland Yard's newly formed art squad, 12 detectives who specialize in investigating major art thefts, yesterday recovered paintings valued at more than 100,000 ($240,000). The paintings were found on the roof of a crematory.

To the Editor: The proposed constituttonal amendment for direct election of President, approved by the House Judiciary Committee, suffers from a serious omission: no deadline is given for ratification by the states.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Labor organizing and collective bargaining for farm workers under a separate Farm Labor Relations Board was proposed today by the Nixon Administration.

The Cleveland Indians have spent almost a decade waiting for Sam McDowell to become a consistent and winning pitcher. Right now his two-game winning streak looks extremely consistent to the downtrodden Indians.

Because he has the hide of a rhinoceros, he just stood there firmly and let everything bounce off.

The city's Board of Standards and Appeals ruled yesterday that a landlord may convert his residential building, apartment-by-apartment, into office space, rather than having to do it floor-by-floor from the ground up, as the zoning law had previously been interpreted.

Mayor Lindsay, capping nearly a year of investigation and negotiation by his administration on the problem of soaring rents, signed into law yesterday a measure designed to limit rent increases in uncontrolled apartments.

Mayor Lindsay paid a ceremonial visit yesterday to John R. Crews and other Brooklyn Republican leaders in a marked departure from his 1965 campaign strategy.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) -- A group of Congressmen attempted recently to get President Nixon to intercede on behalf of the convicted stock manipulator, Louis E. Wolfson, key figure in the Abe Fortas controversy.

PHUQUOC ISLAND, South Vietnam, May 2 -- For two months, American and South Vietnamese authorities have been increasing security around the sprawling camp for prisoners of war on this jungle-covered island.

Norman Mailer took his mayoral campaign to a class of professional policemen yesterday, apologized for having once been a "cop hater" and praised the "good cop" as a work of art.
After years of frustrating effort by scientists to discover why lemming populations multiply at a frantic pace and then collapse in a mass die-out, the answer seems to he within reach.

JERUSALEM, May 5 -- One of the most dramatic restoration projects in the history of cities is forging ahead in the ancient walled area of Jerusalem. The reconstruction of the Jewish quarter of the Old City, lost to the Jews in the 1948 war, is one of the Israeli Government's priority projects.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed moderately lower yesterday. Trading was slow as investors held off commitments pending developments on currency valuations.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (Reuters) -- President Nixon today accepted an invitation from Prime Minister John G. Gorton to visit Australia.
PARIS, May 6 -- A sudden current has developed among middle-of-the-road politicians to draft Alain Poher, the Interim President, as a candidate for the presidency.
Piping Rock, the metropolitan champion, took a substantial lead in the Long Island district of the women's metropolitan interclub team golf yesterday.
The Radio Corporation of America 50th annual meeting yesterday in the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden turned into a nostalgic affair.

CHICAGO, May 6 (UPI) -- Richard Flacks, a founder of Students for a Democratic Society and an assistant professor at the University of Chicago, was reported in "fair but improving condition" today after surgery for wounds suffered when he was severely beaten yesterday in his office.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A senior Navy procurement official charged today there was serious waste and inefficiency in defense spending because of a relationship between the defense industry and military and high-ranking Defense Department officials.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6 -- Since August, a United Nations team of 18 has been helping the Indonesian Government arrange for the people of West Irian to decide their political future by an "act of free choice."

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Spokesmen for big and small one-bank holding companies tried to persuade the House Banking Committee today that the financial combines foster rather than restrict competition.

CORONADO, Calif., May 6 -- Comdr. Lloyd M. Bucher said today that he considered himself completely cleared of wrongdoing by the Navy and looked forward to his next assignment, "whatever it may be."

MOBILE, Ala., May 6 -- Alabama National Guard units were called into action tonight to help the city and state police stand watch against a possible attack by Negroes on the America Junior Miss Pageant.
MOSCOW, May 6 -- A Soviet newspaper complained today that the State Department was barring the sale to the Soviet Union of American films that showed the seamier side of life.
ATHENS, May 6 -- Anna Synodinou, one of the foremost Greek dramatic actresses, appealed to Greeks today for action to help restore freedom in Greece after two years of military rule.

The Mets did not knock out Jim Maloney last night (it took a pulled groin muscle to do that), but they did defeat Gary Nolan for the first time, score some runs for Don Cardwell (who blasted a three-run homer) and preserve their pitching rotation while defeating the Cincinnati Reds, 8-1.
LOS ANGELES, May 6 -Harold E. Gray, chairman of Pan American World Airways, Inc., said here today that "it is clear that selective fare increases are in order."
A 32-year-old New Jersey man with dreams of piloting the smallest plane to London in the "Great Trans-Atlantic Air Race" crash-landed yesterday on a Pennsylvania chicken farm. He was uninjured.
Seventy-two per cent of the crimes committed in the city during the first three months of this year occurred indoors, according to a Police Department survey made public yesterday.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 6 -- Because of what happened in a pair of nonbetting elimination trials at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, Saturday night's Messenger Stake will have a field of eight starters and the gross purse of $182,976.75 will fall short of the world record for a harness race.
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that it had suspended all trading in the shares of the Parvin-Dohrmann Company through May 16.
First-quarter net income of the Cerro Corporation fell to 72 cents a share from $1.19 in the 1968 period, Robert P. Koeing, president, told the annual meeting here yesterday.

The Alan Wood Steel Company said yesterday that officials had neither held nor planned any meeting with former West German Chancellor Ludwig Erhard. The concern repeated earlier assertions that no negotiations were under way to sell any interest in Alan Wood.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Justice Department has quietly begun a grand jury investigation into an action, taken in 1967 by Justice Abe Fortas's former law firm, that delayed the production of documents sought by Federal antiracketeering attorneys from one of the firm's clients.

ITHACA, N. Y., May 7 -- The seizure by armed black militants of the Cornell University student center on April 19 and 20 is being investigated by the Tompkins County grand jury.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- After a 45-minute meeting at the White House today with President Nixon, Prime Minister John G. Gorton of Australia said that he knew of no decision to begin American troop withdrawals from Vietnam.

THE pro football owners are back in town today. A joint meeting of the two leagues is scheduled, a gathering aimed at creating one new league with two 13-team conferences encompassing three divisions each.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 7 (Reuters) -- Five members of the Syrian-backed Saiqah (Thunderbolt) guerrilla organization were killed and 10 wounded in clashes yesterday with the Lebanese Army, reports said here today.

The Council of Europe has warned Greece's junta to restore basic human rights by December or face expulsion from the eighteen-nation body. Greek democrats had hoped that the Council at its twentieth anniversary meeting in London would at least suspend Athens; but the colonels would be wise to take this milder action for the conditional reprieve it was.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- It was a day in the distant future. The Americans were moving out of Vietnam. What a furious commotion there was. What a clatter and confusion as the movers went about their work of loading the big vans.
Berlioz was right: There is almost nothing as impressive as a roomful of staggeringly loud vocal and orchestral sound.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Nixon Administration believes that the long-range solution to hunger and poverty is to put cash into the pockets of the poor, two Cabinet members told Congress today. They said that proposed welfare reforms, emphasizing "cash assistance," would be sent to Congress within a few months.

McLEAN, Va. -- When a woman of taste announces that Abdeslam Jaidi, the press counselor of the Moroccan Embassy in Washington makes the best couscous in North America, it is hard to listen to the claim without a certain hunger. His couscous is, she added, "dreamy, neither dry nor gummy, with grains nice and fluffy and full of caloric succulence.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner was given many promises of votes and good wishes for his political success during a lunch-time campaign tour of the garment district yesterday.
The Regional Plan Association expressed serious doubts yesterday about the advisability of another jetport for the New York region. It urged further study to determine the need.

JUST what was it Hamlet said about a nutshell? Constriction can be an inspiration -- no, that was not what he said! -- but there are times when the artist needs strange chains with which to fulfill himself.
One sensible way for a community to begin a series of entertainments for its members is to focus on local talent.

The disruptive tactics so evident on the college campus these days are not without an element of paradox. To be numbered among the student body at Harvard or Columbia entails passing extremely difficult entrance examinations.
TOKYO, May 7 -- In what may be a landmark decision, Japan's fair - trade commission turned down today a merger bid by this country's two biggest steel companies.
FULTON, Mo., May 7 (AP) -- Reconstruction of an old London church on the campus of Westminster College was praised today as a "modern miracle" by Admiral of the Fleet Earl Mountbatten of Burma.

A bloody pitched battle between club - swinging black youths and white counterprotesters erupted at City College yesterday shortly after the school had been closed for the day because of a previous series of violent incidents.

A Negro-Puerto Rican demand on City College in the negotiations that collapsed last Sunday called for admitting 60 per cent of the freshmen from graduates of 13 Manhattan and Bronx high schools regardless of their grades.

After looking around for a couple of months, the Association of American Railroads has picked McCann-Erickson to replace Geyer, Oswald, its agency since 1961. The current advertising budget is $5-million and that's a lot of track.

LONDON -- He seems all one could imagine as the master of a great ship. "He looks like an old sea dog from Central Casting," one of his passengers remarked during the first commercial voyage of his vessel, the Queen Elizabeth 2, which arrived here yesterday from England. "He can be a bit of a bastard, but we like him," said a steward who has spent most of his working life with the Cunard line.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Comdr. Lloyd M. Bucher, skipper of the intelligence ship Pueblo, was assigned today to a one-year Navy school.

MOSCOW, May 7 -- Pyotr G. Grigorenko, a cashiered former general who is a leading figure in the dissidence movement, was arrested today in Tashkent as he prepared to serve as a nonprofessional defense counsel for a group of 11 Crimean Tatars accused of anti - Soviet activities.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 7 -- The Cuban delegation has been told by United Nations officials that the United States has said there are no present plans to deny re-entry visas to five Cuban diplomats for alledged contacts with black militant leaders.

The nation's railroads are planning various freight service charges that would yield them $60-million a year, Charles Baxter of the Traffic Executives Association of the Eastern Railroads said yesterday.
ESSEN, West Germany, May 7 -- Business sources in Essen said today that a Fried. Krupp Company division was negotiating for an engineering contract on a major new iron mine at Wologisi in Liberia.
LONDON, May 7 -- The chairman of the Parliamentary Labor party, Douglas Houghton, demanded today that Prime Minister Wilson and his Cabinet pull back on their bill on reforms in labor relations.

The construction of a gymnasium under South Field, the broad expanse of turf on the Columbia University campus, is part of the plan for university expansion presented to the trustees by I. M. Pei, the university's planner.
Luis DeJesus is at 18 years of age, a featured performing clown with the Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus.

MIAMI, May 7 (AP) -- Two teen-agers from upstate New York were sentenced today to indeterminate sentences at a Federal correctional institution in connection with an attempt to hijack a National Airlines plane to Havana.

DETROIT, May 7 -- Steam cars, electric cars, hybrid cars and tiny commuter cars -- the General Motors Corporation showed them all to newsmen today to prove it was in the forefront of the technology to curb air pollution.

Representatives of Japanese interests in this country confirmed yesterday that three major Japanese steel companies would provide the steel pipe for the proposed trans-Alaskan oil pipeline. The steel order would total about $100-million.
ONE of the most remarkable -- and rare -- sights in Antarctica is that of a leopard seal shadowing penguins from beneath the ice, then bursting up through the ice to devour one.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) -- Treasury officials said today they would have legislation prepared within a month asking the Congress to review current interest ceilings on long-term United Staates securities.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -The first men to fly around the moon received the Collier Trophy and fresh praise from President Nixon today.
WASHINGTON, May 7--Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, disclosed today some of his ideas for fundamental reform of the tax system.

DURING the recent All Grandmasters' Tournament in Monte Carlo, the American star, the Reverend William Lombardy, was a sharp, unyielding foe. In this 12-man round robin, Lombardy scored three victories, eight draws, and one loss.
The stock market ran into some orderly profit taking yesterday after its recent sharp gains.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., May 7 -- With Howard Lee, 34-yearold son of a Georgia sharecropper, leading the way, Negroes made marked gains at the polls in the municipal elections yesterday across North Carolina.

AT 1:17 P.M. yesterday, 13 minutes before the scheduled start of racing at Aqueduct, a big-bellied groom named Albert Green shouted, "I'd rather be dead than move an inch," and planted his broken black wingtip shoes into the dry dust of the backstretch road. All round him stablehands in threadbare clothes nodded and moved together into a swaying clump. The road they were blocking snaked past the barns and up onto the race track.

RIO de JANEIRO, May 7 -- The world championship for the Bermuda Bowl begins at the Rio Country Club here tomorrow night, with Italy's great Blue Team fighting to defend the title it has won repeatedly in the last 12 years.
Two opponents of Sanford D. Garelik, Mayor Lindsay's running mate for Council President, scored him yesterday for saying that money was "coming from Cuba and China to foment dissent on the campus."

W. Averell Harriman, former Ambassador-at-Large and former Governor of New York, will receive the first Robert F. Kennedy Humanitarian Award, a bronze bust of the late Senator, from the University Settlement at its 83d annual dinner dance tomorrow. The event will be at the Americana.
Riding up the harbor on board the Queen Elizabeth 2 yesterday, Mayor Lindsay proposed that the city's planned consolidated ocean-liner facility be named the Eisenhower Passenger Terminal.

GRAND FORKS, N. D. -The cottonwoods and elms are budding now on the University of North Dakota campus. At noon, the boys lie shirtless on the frame roofs of fraternity houses, dozing in the sun and casually turning as girls walk slowly past on University Avenue.
The election of Ross D. Siragusa Jr. as president and chief operating officer of the Admiral Corporation, the televsion-set manufacturer, was announced yesterday.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., May 7 -- Between 20 and 30 white students occupied an administration office building at Upsala College today, demanding more student involvement in college affairs.

Despite a noisy backstretch blockade by 200 stablehands that delayed the start of the program for two hours, racing resumed yesterday at Aqueduct on a partial basis after a nine-day horsemen's boycott. Forty stablehands were arrested.

Israel's Premier, Mrs. Golda Meir, has reaffirmed in a television interview that she does not expect her country to return strategic areas captured from Arab countries during the six-day war in June, 1967.

HANOVER, N. H., May 7 -- A force of state patrolmen, aided by troopers from neighboring Vermont, cleared the Dartmouth College administration building of youthful demonstrators early this morning, ending a 12-hour sit-in protesting the Reserve Officers Training Corps program.

Second base was as far as the Mets went last night, and it wasn't far enough. They made only three hits and suffered a 3-0 loss to the Cincinnati Reds, who double-teamed them with pitching and stopped the New Yorkers' modest winning string at three games.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (Reuters) -- The Organization of American States rejected today a proposal that the Bolivian Ambassador said could have established the groundwork for eventual Cuban participation.
ROME, May 7 -- Pope Paul VI accused the world press today of "superficial, malignant" reporting of the affairs of the church.
BRUSSELS, May 7 -- The European Common Market faces serious problems if currency values are adjusted by any of its member states.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- President Nixon told a Republican fund-raising dinner here tonight that his Administration had reached "the end of the beginning" and that "the American people will soon begin to see the results of our programs."

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Congressional critics of Justice Abe Fortas appeared to be biding their time today, although they expressed confidence that the controversy would continue unless he came forward soon with a fuller explanation of his receipt of a fee from the family foundation of Louis E. Wolfson.

The Heart Ball in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria last night was an evocation of Portugal -- even down to the menu, a number of the guests and the take-home goody bag. And all because Mrs. William C. Langley wanted a rug.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 7 -- "So when will the stock get a wider distribution so we can get more action out of it, huh?" asked Jean Carroll, the comedienne, in a rough imitation of the querulous Bronx-Brooklyn housewife she portrays on television.

Those who condemn Cornell's "capitulation to coercion" demonstrate the familiar racist tactics used in suppressing blacks over the past decades. Incidents vaguely related or unrelated to the crucial issues are distorted and used to obscure the very problems which initiated the crisis.
LONDON, May 7 -- Britain is considering a break in cultural exchanges and other sanctions if the Soviet Union takes further action against Gerald Brooke, an imprisoned Briton.
Ideally, all newly mined copper should be priced by auction on a commodities exchange, James Boyd, president of the Copper Range Company, told the annual meeting in Boston yesterday.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 7 -- Rutgers won a third consecutive New Jersey College Conference track title today when Princeton was disqualified for a faulty baton pass in the 440-yard relay.

TAYNINH, South Vietnam, May 7 -- Once again, North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops have withdrawn into the sanctuary of the dense jungle and bamboo forest that stretches north and east of here to the Cambodian border.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Howard University, the nation's largest predominantly Negro university, was closed today by the nearly unanimous vote of its faculty in the wake of the overnight seizure of eight buildings by militant students and nonstudents.

A group of students who had been staging a sit-in at Queensborough Community College in Bayside for almost three weeks seized the administrative offices yesterday for nearly three hours, but fled when the police arrived.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) -- The American Medical Association and a large drug manufacturer were sharply criticized in Senate testimony today for the promotion of an "ineffective" drug blamed by one scientist for what he called a $12-million "theft from the public."
One of the two top Democrats in the city government yesterday called for "immediate intervention" by Governor Rockefeller to end the violence and disruption on college campuses.

VALENCIA, Spain, May 7 -- An ambitious project to rechannel the Turia River to make it flow around instead of through Valencia, Spain's third largest city, is expected to be far enough along this fall to end the threat of floods.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP) -- Jerry Williams, who resigned today as coach of the Calgary Stampeders in the Canadian League, will be the new coach of the Philadelphia Eagles, The Associated Press said.
The first comprehensive program of Yugoslav films to be shown in this country will begin in the fall at the Museum of Modern Art and run for two weeks.

CLARY ANDERSON has moved uptown and the citizens of Montclair, N. J., still think he is the greatest football coach around. This man of many skills has given up the coaching job at Montclair High School, where he compiled one of the most successful records in the nation over 25 years, for a similar post at Montclair State College, which is in Upper Montclair.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Army is considering the transportation of a large quantity of obsolete, but still lethal, poison gas across the country in railroad cars to be dumped in the Atlantic Ocean.
COMMACK, L. I., May 7 -- Only one of 21 school budgets was not approved by voters in Suffolk County yesterday, even though most of the budgets called for increases in property taxes.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- New York's two Republican Senators, vowing to actively support the primary campaign of Mayor Lindsay, said today that a Lindsay defeat for re-nomination would be a serious blow to progressive Republicanism in the city and state.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The National Transportation Safety Board warned today that the expanding development of spaces over and under highways runs the risk of "catastrophic accidents."
The 33-year-old mother of two young children was found slain yesterday in the cellar of her husband's air-conditioning repair shop in the Whitestone section of Queens.

THEIR clothes are often called "dumb dresses" or "bread and butter styles" because they skirt the wilder excesses of fashion. At the large-volume houses that make modestly priced, conservative fashions, the waistlines and hemlines change, but not usually to any startling degree. The changes are predictable, like the switch from winter wools to summer cottons.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 7 -- Classes were suspended this afternoon at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to allow students and professors to discuss the military, social and educational problems that are causing wide unrest among scientists.
The National Basketball Association completed its annual college draft yesterday, a month after the first two rounds had been held by telephone.

LONDON, May 7 -- Britain's legislation making abortions available on broad social and medical grounds under the National Health Service is a year old, and the critics and supporters of it are still fiercely debating.

BRUSSELS, May 7 -- Speculation about an increase in the value of the West German mark reached feverish intensity today, amid signs that the Bonn Government's determination to hold the rate might be weakening.
CLYDEBANK, Scotland, May 7 -- The troubled builder of the Queen Elizabeth 2, Upper Clyde Shipbuilders, Ltd., is facing acute financial problems and possible liquidation.
UMUAHIA, Nigeria, May 6 -- A sign on the north edge of town says "Pan-Biafra Insurance Ltd.," but there are no Biafrans to be seen.
Taking their cue from what brokers called "currency jitters," silver futures rose quite sharply yesterday. The trading pace, however, was only a modest 2,349 contracts.

It is still too early to expect to see visible effects of a slowing in the economy resulting from the Government's anti-inflationary fight, the chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers declared here last night.

Your May 2 editorial ("The Legislature Gets a D") describes the school decentralization bill as a "travesty" and a "monstrosity." Perhaps it would be too harsh to use these two nouns to characterize the editorial, but it is certainly inconsistent and illogical.
Eddie Belmonte, one of the top-flight riders who did not call in yesterday with a case of sympathetic sickness, had a robust afternoon at the Aqueduct reopening.

The Leasco Data Processing Equipment Corporation continued its record-breaking revenues and profits since it became publicly owned in June, 1965, reflecting mainly the sharp gains in the computer services field.

In the disturbances that have intermittently convulsed the Columbia campus in the last two years, The Columbia Spectator has been a militant and radical voice for student dissent. NEW HAVEN, May 7 -Public and private beaches along Long Island Sound were threatened today by two large slicks of industrial oil deposited by a leaking barge.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -The United States is reported to have been urging the Soviet Union and other big powers to help reduce tensions in the Middle East, but some officials are disturbed by reports of new arms shipments to the United Arab Republic by Communist countries.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A Congressional backlash against student unrest began to manifest itself today as conservatives, with some support from moderates, demanded that Federal funds be cut off to any university tolerating campus disturbances.

Black, Puerto Rican and white students argued heatedly yesterday morning as they poured from City College's South Campus, forced from the tree-shaded lawns and build-by a line of quiet, but firm, blue-helmeted policemen.
Terence Cardinal Cooke returned to New York from Rome yesterday as a prince of the Roman Catholic Church. But his reaction was more like that of an average New Yorker glad to be back.
John Osborne, one of Britain's angry young men, has signed to write an original 90-minute contemporary drama for the National Broadcasting Company for the 1970-71 season.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The United States Government is maintaining a discreet silence in what is now clearly another major international monetary crisis, but its interests are clear.
CLEVELAND, May 7 (UPI) -- A Federal Grand Jury began today an investigation into the allegations that the former law firm of Mr. Fortas had withheld subpoenaed documents in a price-fixing case.
JERUSALEM, May 7 -- Israeli jets struck today for the second time this week against suspected concentrations of Arab guerrillas in southern Jordan.
ZURICH, Switzerland, May 6 -- For 18 years the International Press Institute has been fighting for freedom of the press by opposing government restrictions on journalists and publishers.

" Flower bonds" is the Wall Street jargon for a form of Government security that more people should know about for a very important reason. They can be used to save on Federal estate taxes, thus increasing the value of an estate.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, was the current best bet for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1972.
Institutional investors joined hands with the ordinary trader yesterday on the American Stock Exchange causing volume to climb close to the high for the year. Prices eased.

GENEVA, May 7 -- A member of the International Committee of the Red Cross reported today that Regis Debray was ing "properly treated" by his Bolivian guards and was now writing a book on Andre Malraux, the French author and politician.
The credit markets muddled along yesterday, registering no pronounced moves in any direction. It was a day when lackluster was king.

Four men were arrested here yesterday on an indictment charging grand larceny and possession of stolen property in the disappearanc eof $193,000 in Treasury bills from the First National City Bank, 55 Wall Street, last June 28. A fifth defendant was still at large.

PARIS, May 7 -- The unsettling effects of swift flights across several time zones are now well-known. But even if a jet-speed journey to Europe did not disorient one's clock, stomach and sleeping habits, landing here at this particular time would seem somewhat unreal.
MONTREAL, May 7 -- The Gazette, giving as its source the West German weekly Der Spiegel, said tonight that "without conducting any test explosion Israel has become the world's sixth nuclear power."

Philip P. Kalodner, who became president of the Curtis Publishing Company two weeks ago, announced yesterday that he would take "immediate action" to insure the continued printing of Holiday and Status magazines at the company's plant in Sharon Hill, Pa.

The superliner Queen Elizabeth 2, the last of her breed, arrived yesterday to a warm and tumultuous welcome from a port that knows the great of the sea. With thousands of watchers lining the foreshore of the city and New Jersey piers, and with flotillas of harbor craft surrounding the 963-foot hull sounding salutes, the 65,863-ton vessel moved up the bay from the Verrazano - Narrows Bridge leading a gala parade.

THE Skye terrier, Ch. Glamoor Good News, made her first public appearance last week since winning best in show at Westminster in February and thereby prompted an inquiry. "Was it so that dogs that gained the top at Madison Square Garden jinxed themselves and their kennelmates for subsequent events?" The question was asked at the fiveday noncompetitive show of the Manhattan Savings Bank.
VIENNA, May 7 -- Rude Pravo, the newspaper of the Czechoslovak Communist party, published today a month-old statement of the Academy of Sciences demanding the end of press censorship.

A. Philip Randolph, the 80-year-old labor and civil rights leader, has urged militant Negro youths to reject confrontationism and violence in their struggle for freedom and justtice.
HOUSTON, May 7 -- Alan B. Shepard Jr., the first American to go into space, was cleared medically yesterday for a return to space flight status at the age of 45.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 -- Vice President Agnew declared today that "a responsible majority in the scientific community'' believed in the workability of Safeguard, the controversial antiballistic missile system approved by President Nixon.
BARNSTABLE, Mass., May 6 -- A newly arrived young man with a spinning rod baited his hook with one orange salmon egg and casually flipped it into the wind-ruffled waters of Hamblin Pond.

A copy of the Declaration of Independence in its first printing, a broadside that was discovered about four months ago tucked away in a scrapbook, was auctioned yesterday for $404,000, the highest price ever paid at auction for a printed or manuscript book or document.

The 400-member faculty of Pratt Institute went on strike yesterday afternoon to protest an administration plan to arrest and expel students found guilty of disruptions on the campus or of inciting such actions.

After long delays New York City has finally put into operation the first section of its computer system for controlling traffic. This electronic traffic regulator may prove well worth its estimated $100-million cost, but it will be at least two years before the system is ready to tackle its toughest job -- the critical congestion that is strangling midtown Manhattan.

The New York State Banking Board approved yesterday the application of Lincoln First Banks, Inc., an upstate bank holding company with 104 offices and $1.2-billion in assets, to acquire the National Bank of Westchester, White Plains.

The third annual Medallion Ball of the New York Junior League will be held next Tuesday at the Waldorf-Astoria. At the event the league's Volunteer of the Year will be chosen from the five league members who will be honored for their volunteer service at medical, community and welfare organizations in New York.
The winners of the 20th annual Albert Lasker Medical Journalism Awards were announced yesterday by Mrs. Albert D. Lasker, president of the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation.
Two high schools closed early yesterday after suspicious fires flared in one of them and a cafeteria disturbance erupted in the other school.
Between puffs, stockholders and officials of the American Tobacco Company voted yesterday to change the name to American Brands, Inc.

BONN, May 7 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger, bowing to conservative pressure, has reversed his stand on a Cabinet decision to abolish the statute of limitations on prosecution of Nazi murders without any qualification.

A piggyback plan for the long-delayed 63d Street tunnel -- one level for a subway and one for the Long Island Rail Road -- will come up for a public hearing on June. 3.

Plans for the acquisition of "21" Brands, Inc., a large liquor importer and distributor, by Foremost-McKesson, Inc., were announced yesterday.

Weeb Ewbank, recently signed to another new contract as coach and general manager of the New York Jets, has been named man-of-the-year in professional football by the New York Chapter of the Professional Football Writers Association of America.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- American B-52 bombers in recent weeks have raided several Vietcong and North Vietnamese supply dumps and base camps in Cambodia for the first time, according to Nixon Administration sources, but Cambodia has not made any protest.
