They gamboled aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2 as though the 65,863-ton liner were gliding through the Atlantic rather than reposing majestically at a red carpeted and bunting-decked Pier 92 at West 52d Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 8 -- The United Nations has leased space in two midtown skyscrapers to accommodate several hundred staff members and to ease overcrowding in its East River headquarters buildings.

DETROIT, May 8 -- The big news at the Ford Motor Company's annual meeting today may have been the pledge by Chairman Henry Ford 2d to use larger type next year in the annual-report footnotes. Otherwise stockholders at the meeting, held at the Ford Auditorium in downtown Detroit, heard the top officers go through information that generally had already been disclosed.
Mayor Lindsay established a special office yesterday to draft a master plan for the redevelopment of midtown Manhattan.

Shareholders of U.S. Plywood-Champion Papers, Inc., were told yesterday that the company expects housing starts in 1969 to match last year's 1.5-million level despite the Government's recent anti-inflationary measures.

AS if real-life college confrontation did not exist in adequate profusion, the Eastern Educational Network staged last night a simulated television version of a university under siege. The intent was to expand video's usefulness in explaining the complexities of the crises on campuses.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Seven members of Congress appeared before a House subcommittee today to express their constituents' growing irritation about the questionnaire prepared for next year's census.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 8 -- Former President Harry S. Truman observed his 85th birthday today at the family home in Independence.

The National Liberation Front's offer of a ten-point peace plan at Paris yesterday represents a potentially significant step toward a Vietnam settlement.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Thomas Bradley brought his campaign for Mayor of Los Angeles 3,000 miles across the country today and won the endorsement of Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts.

The Citizens Committee for Children charged yesterday that the Family Court and protective services for children were being "starved" for funds while "outwardly concerned" city and State officials gave "other things" the money needed to help children.

The Electric Circus was packed to the rafters Wednesday night for the first of a weekly concert series called "The First Generation Blues." The series will feature the blues performers whose work has inspired the current interest in blues by young groups.
Two New York detectives have been indicted by a Bronx grand jury on charges of attempting to bribe an assistant district attorney in the case of a convicted narcotics seller.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) -- The Justice Department is investigating Supreme Court Justice Abe Fortas's relations with the Wolfson family foundation to see whether any criminal laws had been violated.

Senator Ralph W. Yarborough, chairman of the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee, said yesterday that an additional Federal allocation of $2-billion -- the cost of 20 days of war in Vietnam -- could end the hunger problem in this country within a year.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Chairman Wilbur D. Mills of the House Ways and Means Committee has introduced legislation imposing quotas on imports of textiles.

The fight for control of the Piper Aircraft Corporation took a new turn yesterday with an announcement that the Bangor Punta Corporation had agreed to acquire over 500,000 shares of Piper Aircraft stock held by members of the Piper family.

GENEVA, May 8 -- Member nations of the European Free Trade Association agreed today that Charles de Gaulle's withdrawal from the French political scene opened a new phase in the search for European economic integration with out actually clarifying the outlook.
FALMOUTH, Mass., May 8 -- Warm, gentle, intermittent showers fell on Cape Cod this morning, holding promise of improved trout fishing.
Columbia University's new master planner has proposed a major expansion of academic, administrative and athletic facilities that would not involve going beyond the present campus boundaries.

Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of pro football, came closer yesterday to resolving the realignment stalemate among the owners of the 26 teams. These owners, with representation also by some general managers, met for 11 hours in the St. Regis Sheraton Hotel and recessed at 9 P.M. The meeting will continue today.

" He is the most complete basketball player in the National Basketball Association, and maybe of all time." That was the comment of Bill van Breda Kolff, the coach of the Los Angeles Lakers, about Jerry West.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Army promised Congressional investigators today that it would not decide before Tuesday whether or not to ship a large quantity of poison gas across the country in railroad cars to be dumped in the Atlantic Ocean.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 8 -- The Union Pacific Railroad may borrow as much as $100-million this year to finance its acquisition of $222-million worth of giant new diesel-electric locomotives and new freight cars, according to Frank E. Barnett, chief executive officer.

GLASGOW, Scotland, May 8 -- Rootes Motors, Ltd., a subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation, is being plagued with the wildcat strikes that disrupt British industry and raise doubts about the country's economic future.

As Amherst students we believe our college's letter to President Nixon which conveys our sense that unrest on the campus is generated by the problems of American society has been presented out of the context of what happened here last week. After nine days of no racing and two days of subnormal racing, Aqueduct will start becoming the Big A again today.

BACK in February, Representative Wilbur D. Mills, the powerful chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, dropped a bomb on the acquisition-minded business community by introducing a tax bill to sharply curtail mergers.
Leonard Bernstein led the New York Philharmonic in a concert of dignity and eloquence at Philharmonic Hall last night.

NEW YORK -- Odd things are now taking place on the peripheries of China as a consequence of ever-increasing tension between Peking and Moscow. On the one hand, Russia has begun an extraordinary flirtation with Chiang Kai-shek and on the other hand Communist China has started making googoo eyes at Marshal Tito, for long considered by Mao Tse-tung the greatest heretic of them all.
" Backbone" is precisely what our college presidents need; if they had enough, they would shut down their institutions and head for Washington and demonstrate against the war in Vietnam.

A tiny Italian 15th century print proved to be one of the big items at auction this week, bringing $6,100 in the final sale of the celebrated collection of Old Master prints formed by the late Gordon W. Nowell-Usticke.

The Soccer Referees Association of New York unanimously voted late Wednesday not to accept assignments for Sunday's game unless the Southern New York State Soccer Association took proper steps to assure their personal safety.
MINEOLA, L. I., May 8 -- Nassau voters turned down as many school budgets yesterday as they approved. Of the 28 budgets submitted, 14 were defeated and 14 were approved.

YOEL B. GOL is captivated by carved curves. In the first exhibition of his naturalistic furnishings, the 35-year-old former geologist from Israel has explored the sinuous line in as many furniture forms and woodworking techniques as seem possible today. Mushroom-shaped stools, a flowering chess table, a treelike chest with drawers for branches and human feet instead of roots are among the 12 designs now on view at American-Israel Culture House, 4 East 54th Street.
Lawrence T. Schweig, vice president of Vita Food Products, Inc., has been elected first vice president of the National Fisheries Institute.
It is ironic that Congress proposes a 12 per cent cut of the Peace Corps budget at a time when student activists are most intently pursuing societal changes in the university, ghetto and streets.

WASHINGTON, Friday, May 9 -- Students occupying six buildings at Howard University refused to relinquish them last night, thus defying an ultimatum issued earlier by James M. Nabrit Jr., the president of the predominant Negro school.

About 100 maintenance and clerical workers at Yeshiva University walked off their jobs yesterday and conducted a sit-in at the school's downtown graduate center at 55 Fifth Avenue. They demanded university recognition of Local 1199 of the Hospital Workers Union as their official bargaining agent.

An analysis of radio waves transmitted through various levels of the atmosphere of Venus indicates that the planet may be enveloped in concentric clouds of cinnabar, calomel and other brilliantly colored compounds of mercury.

The Black Chamber Dance Concert presented the second of its two programs at Barnard College's Latham Playhouse last night, this time featuring the choreography of Talley Beatty, Donald McKayle and Eleo Pomare.

ALBANY, May 8 -- The State Department of Health charged today that New York City was continually falling behind in its schedule of water pollution abatement, and said that even a new, revised schedule had no promise of municipal funds.

Student leaders at City College are united in their deep concern for the future of the college. But they find themselves deeply divided over the complex issues raised by black and Puerto Rican students, whose seizure of the South Campus on April 22 led to the closing of the college for two weeks.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) -- J. Edgar Hoover, 74 years old, said today he had no intention of retiring as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

ROME -- It happened almost unexpectedly, somewhat like Il Boom, the national economic miracle that shouldn't have occurred but did. For a variety of reasons ranging from the deterioration of the French haute couture to the cessation of hostilities between feuding factions in Rome, Florence and Milan and their transformation into creative industrialists, Italy has captured the fashion leadership of the world.

The executive committee of the Board of Higher Education, after a four-hour meeting with black and Puerto Rican City College students, reached a partial agreement early today on a series of demands that had led to turmoil and violence on campus.

Erich Leinsdorf will return to the Metropolitan Opera in the 1971-72 season to conduct the new production of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" with Birgit Nilsson. Mr. Leinsdorf, who has resigned as music director of the Boston Symphony after seven years, last appeared at the Met as conductor of three complete cycles of Wagner's "Der Ring des Nibelungen" during the 1961-62 season.
ITHACA, N.Y. May 8 -- The Students for a Democratic Society held a strategy meeting on the Cornell campus early this morning and, after a three-hour debate, decided against seizing a building.
KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 8 -- Alarmed by rising disorders on college campuses and eager to make his own views clear, President Nixon has decided to deliver a major statement on the subject.
FOUR years ago, in a movie called "Those Magnificent Men in Their Flying Machines," Hollywood demonstrated how much visual delight could be generated by flights of old-fashioned airplanes.
The Blue Cross disclosed yesterday that it planned to ask permission to make substantial rate increases that would affect 4.8 million subscribers in metropolitan New York.

The Continental Telephone Corporation's first-quarter net income from telephone operations rose 20 per cent over the year-ago level, while earnings of Superior Continental Corporation, the company's manufacturing and supply arm, soared by 75 per cent.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 8 -- The United States and South Vietnam announced tonight that their troops would observe a 24-hour cease-fire late this month to mark the birthday of Buddha.

A Queens man carrying a membership card in the American Nazi party was held in $10,000 bail yesterday on charges that he had plotted to sink the former Israeli liner Shalom.
MOSCOW, May 8 -- A Soviet journal conceded today that a group of Russian Orthodox priests had protested to Patriarch Alexius against the Church's policy of collaboration with the Kremlin.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Within the next six weeks, the signature of Dorothy Andrews Elston will be carried about in the pockets or purses of people with folding money.
Pepsico, Inc., confirmed yesterday its interest in the Miller Brewing Company by announcing an agreement in principle to buy 53 per cent from W. R. Grace Co.
THE HAGUE, May 8 -- A spokesman for the Dutch Government denied today that the Netherlands had any connection with the uprisings in West Irian.

STONY BROOK, L. I., May 8 -- A group of 120 students, led by members of the Students for a Democratic Society, occupied the computer center at the State University campus here for four hours today.
As the Great Trans-Atlantic Air Race of 1969 passed the halfway mark yesterday contestants still were trying to better the fastest over-all time of 6 hours 11 minutes 57 seconds.

After over 10 years with Doyle Dane Bernbach, the Thom McAn Stores division of the Melville Shoe Corporation is moving July 1 to Mitchell-Morrison, Inc. The $3-million to $4-million in shoe billings will just about double the new agency's business.
MOSCOW, May 8 (Reuters) -- The death of another Soviet general -- the sixth in 13 days -- was reported today by the Defense Ministry newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda.
PARIS, May 8 -- The Vietcong presented a 10-point program today for an "over-all solution" of the war in Vietnam.
PARIS, May 8 (Reuters) -- The Bank of France raised its export-credit re-discount rate today by one percentage point, to 4 per cent.

Investor concern over monetary matters caused the American Stock Exchange to close mixed yesterday in active trading.
The American Bible Society announced yesterday the publication of an "extra-large type" edition of the New Testament designed to help persons with handicapped vision.

LAGOS, Nigeria, May 8 (Reuters) -- The federal Nigerian Government today announced a tough wartime budget designed to increase revenue by $110.4-million through higher taxes on imports, exports and on companies.

BONN, Friday, May 9 -- The bitter dispute over how and when to revalue the West German mark intensified here early today as Economics Minister Karl Schiller and Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger stressed their opposing views.

BOSTON, May 8 -- Justice Abe Fortas, whose involvement with a $20,000 fee from the Louis E. Wolfson Family Foundation has caused a stir in Washington, spoke tonight without fee at Northeastern University.

When the superliner France resumes service here Wednesday after a two-month absence she will berth four blocks north of her usual Pier 88 at 48th Street on the Hudson River. She will share Pier 92, at 52d Street, with the Cunard Line's new Queen Elizabeth 2.
OAKLAND, May 8 (AP) -- The Oakland Oaks, new champions of the American Basketball Association, are ready to challenge the Boston Celtics, champions of the National Basketball Association.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

The New York foreign-exchange markets were a reflection yesterday of the new currency crisis in Europe. In some ways, activity here was more intense than on the Continent.

INMAN, S.C. -- Spring came late to the Carolinas. But local residents say it has been worth waiting for, and the blaze of the azaleas still is clinging to the town.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 8 -- Just because he wants to warm up Laverne Hanover himself on Saturday night for the $182,976.75 Messenger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway, Billy Haughton decided today to risk $875.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, May 8 -- Foreign money continued to deluge West Germany today, rocking currency values throughout Western Europe, as the Bonn Government prepared once again to weigh a decision on upvaluing the mark.

There are several factors that make the Thursday night jazz concerts at MUSE, Bedford Avenue at Lincoln Place in Brooklyn, one of the most provocative series in town. This makes the concerts adventurous and often rewarding experiences.

The white, red and blue flags flying high along Fifth Avenue and atop major busi ness buildings signal the beginning of the United Fund of Greater New York's premiere campaign.
WAYNE, N. J. May 8 -- About 30 Negro students, some carrying clubs and chains, occupied a classroom and office building for nearly five hours this cmorning at Paterson State College.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Navy has ruled that winners of its annual Reserve Officers Training Corps scholarships will not be permitted to use the grants at Harvard next fall.
LONDON, May 8 -- The British pound, an innocent bystander in the new currency crisis, bore the brunt again today of a stampede into West German marks.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Competition for the commercial air traffic to Australia and New Zealand approached a final resolution today with the filing of new legal briefs before the Civil Aeronautics Board.

Cowles Communications, Inc., expects operating profits in the first half of 1969 to exceed the 8 cents a share earned in the initial six months of 1968, Gardner Cowles, chairman, reported to stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting. WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University, pleaded with Congress today to give universities time to try to solve on their own the problem of student disruptions.
DENNISON, Ohio, May 7 (UPI) -- At least one person was killed tonight as tornadoes crossed Ohio, injuring at least 40 persons and destroying more than 50 homes.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 8 -- Straightening out Stan Bahnsen is Manager Ralph Houk's No. 1 problem on the New York Yankees right now. In Anaheim, Calif., last night, Bahnsen's won-lost record became 0-6 as he was beaten by the California Angels, 4-2.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., May 8 -- All eight Rockland County school district budgets were approved by voters here yesterday, with the Ramapo Central School District budget of $23,242,767, the 13th largest in the state, passing by a vote of 4,085 to 1,742.

For two decades after its premiere in 1913 it was frequently performed in Italian and American opera houses. Now it is two decades since the Metropolitan last staged it.

LISBON, May 8 -- An antiGovernment leader, held in the million-dollar robbery of the Bank of Portugal two years ago, escaped from prison early today in Oporto, 175 miles north of here.

Javits criticized President Nixon today for following what he termed "the sterile and unsuccessful approach" of the Johnson Administration toward settlement of the Vietnam war. The president of Pratt Institute, Dr. James B. Donovan, has asked the Police Department not to send uniformed or plain-clothes policemen onto the Brooklyn campus.
Ralph A. Graves, currently senior staff editor for all Time Inc. publications, has been appointed managing editor of Life magazine, replacing George P. Hunt.

GENEVA, May 9 -- Member nations of the Euorpean Free Trade Association welcomed the "commitment of the United States Administration to liberal trade policies" in a statement issued today at the close of a two-day ministerial council.

The Weyerhaeuser Company, one of the nation's largest manufacturers of forest products, announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Dierks Forests, Inc., of Hot Springs, Ark., for $325million in cash and convertible preferred stock of Weyerhaeuser.

Northern Ireland is still a long way from Tipperary on the Catholic-Protestant crisis, but Major James Chichester-Clark has succeeded admirably in cooling off the atmosphere in his first days as Prime Minister.
LAGOS, Nigeria, May 9 -- The commanders of two of the three divisions in the federal Nigerian army have been relieved of their posts, informed sources disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Just when Washington was beginning to hoist a placard reading "Tricia Nixon Uses Vanishing Cream," the President's 23-year-old blond daughter has become visible.
The city's top housing official, Jason R. Nathan, criticized President Nixon's proposed tax reforms yesterday as "the most serious kind of threat and danger to the national housing program today."
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Howard University began repairing and tidying up today after United States marshals ended a three-day seizure of six campus buildings with the arrest of 20 students.

LONDON, May 9 -- In the Oscar Wilde play "The Importance of Being Earnest," the governess, Miss Prism, tells her pupils: "The chapter on the fall of the rupee you may omit. It is somewhat too sensational."

MINNEAPOLIS, May 9 -- The Minnesota Legislature ousted two members of the University of Minnesota Board of Regents yesterday, reflecting the displeasure of some legislators over the handling of a disturbance at the university last January.

Three more members of Students for a Democratic Society at Columbia University have agreed to surrender next week to face contempt - of - court charges, Under Sheriff H. William Kehl said yesterday.

The removal of St. Christopher, St. Ursula, and many other saints from the Vatican's universal calendar of saints yesterday was "not really surprising," according to a spokesman for the Archdiocese of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and three other Democratic Senators asked today for an explanation by Otto F. Otepka of his "finances and connections" pending further Senate action on his nomination to the Subversive Activities Control Board.

BRUSSELS, May 9 -Topranking officers of the Atlantic alliance today ended a threeday secret strategy conference at the alliance's military headquarters near Mons, about 30 miles southwest of Brussels.
An Austrian May festival at the Pierre Thursday will benefit the Kips Bay Boys Club.

ALBANY, May 9 -- Public welfare costs in New York State reached a new high of $2.7-billion in 1968, according to the annual report of the State Depatment of Social Service. This was $826,580,000 more than was spent in the preceding year.

Much of the natural beauty of the crest across from New York City has already been impaired by high-rise apartments. CAIRO, May 9 -- A leading Egyptian spokesman, Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, expressed worry today over growing disunity and rivalry among Palestinian commando groups. He pointed to the National Liberation Front of South Vietnam as an example of unification.

About 60 black students ended a one-day sit-in at De Paul University in Chicago yesterday after the university threatened them with court action and agreed to negotiate their demands. The Village Light Opera Group has done itself proud with a beguiling production of "The Gondoliers." It was offered last night at the Fashion Institute Theater, 227 West 27th Street, and will be repeated at afternoon and evening performances today.

JERUSALEM, May 10 -- With the end of the six-day war in 1967, thousands of American students poured into Israel, many to study at Hebrew University. It now appears that the practice of using drugs came with some of them.

WASHINGTON -- A characteristic of the Johnson Administration was a continuing belief that almost any social ill could be cured by government and private actions if sufficient commitments and resources were brought to bear on it.

EASTER ISLAND -- Contrary to public opinion, Easter Island, which is one of the seven wonders of the archeological world and by far the most isolated, is not tropical, does not belong to the French, is not covered with standing stone giants and was not discovered by Thor Heyerdahl, the Kon-Tiki navigator.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 10 -- As far as the people of this area are concerned, the New York Yankees have shed their image of cold efficiency once and for all. After making five errors in one inning during a 3-2 loss to the Oakland Athletics last night, the Yankees made one that set up a grand-slam homer for Rick Monday this afternoon and lost again, 4-3.
CLEVELAND, May 10 (AP) -- Carlos May drove in three runs today as the Chicago White Sox downed the Cleveland Indians, 4-0, behind the pitching of Tommy John and Bob Locker.
Business in the first quarter topped the expectations of the nation's purchasing agents, and they hinted that perhaps it was too good.

A new system of waste disposal that could be fitted to small commercial and pleasure craft will be tested this summer on a tugboat operated by the Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics in Groton, Conn.
BALTIMORE, May 10 -- An underdog Navy lacrosse team defeated Johns Hopkins, the national champion, 9-6 today at Homewood Field before more than 9,000 homecoming fans.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., May 10 -- The establishment of the annual Albert Lasker Award Lectureship to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation of New York was announced here jointly today by Joseph E. Slater, president of the Salk Institute, and Mrs. Albert D. Lasker, president of the foundation.

Some of the people who want to be New York cab drivers are finding themselves in front of a psychiatrist who asks questions in an effort to detect any "aggressive'' tendencies. The aim, the industry insists, is to keep out the "hostile" driver.

NO ONE, offered the chance for a conversation with Igor Stravinsky, passes it up. When I entered the suite at the Pierre, where he stopped recently for a few springtime weeks before moving on to Paris, I found the composer as I had been told he would be found: at his desk, composing.

MIAMI BEACH, May 8 -- "A thought of infidelity a day (without guilt) keeps the psychoanalyst away," said Dr. Judd Marmor, professor of psychiatry at the University of California, Los Angeles, who is head of the psychiatric division at the Cedar-Mount Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland -- If there is anything to be said for 22 hours in a narrow-gauge sleeping car, the Newfoundland Bullet, North America's last long-haul, narrow - gauge passenger train, says it.
Over-all it has been a world gone still. Street after empty street. Brick buildings shut and windows closed. Massive drydocks bone-dry. Long-idled military trucks parked along a fence.

The April 27 letter of Elias Demetracopoulos reflects a position on Greece to which he is entitled. But your readers should know that his opinion is not shared by many others and for substantial cause.

It's become fashionable in American schools to pay lip service to "critical thinking," "individualized instruction" and to a collection of other noble objectives pedagogically associated with intellectual and personal independence.

Louis Beryl, chairman of the board of the Sunshine Mining Company and the Citizens Casualty Company of New York, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 60 years old and lived at 5 Highland Avenue, Great Neck, L.I.

SOME of my best friends are English dance critics, but I do feel that they were, for the most part, a little bit hard on Peter Wright's new production of the Petipa/Tchaikovsky classic "The Sleeping Beauty," just danced by the Royal Ballet during its current season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Seeing the extraordinarily poignant and beautifully executed cover by Romare Bearden ("Soul History," Sunday, April 20) was as pleasurable as it is tremendously encouraging to other black artists who aspire to being given such a prestigious commission.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., May 10 (AP) -- Spring Double, 10 lengths back of the leaders at the quarter pole, moved as if jet propelled and won the $28,475 Valley Forge Handicap by 2 1/2 lengths over the odds-on favorite, Iron Ruler, at Garden State Park today. Abe's Hope finished third in the 1 1/16 mile event.
MADISON, Wis., May 10 -- It was a perfect day for a new riot here today, but the University of Wisconsin students in the Mifflin-Bassett Streets hippie area had a fireman's ball instead.
PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (AP) -- Orlando Cepeda's three-run homer capped a four-run ninth inning tonight and gave the Atlanta Braves a 6-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 10 -- The United States bridge team was struggling here tonight to recover from a disastrous start in which it lost three straight matches in the world championship bridge match.

ALL forms of art are sociable enterprises, but some forms are more sociable than others. Indeed, some forms of art make of their sociability a distinct element of style -- an element as indispensable to their artistic realization as the hermetic metaphors of Mallarme were to his.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 10 -- President Nixon, Vice President Agnew and key Administration officials discussed the problem of campus disorders today. They came up with no decisions. But the White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said the session had not been designed to produce decisions on how to handle student rioting or any other domestic problems that were covered.

JOHN UNITAS quit his off-season job and since January has undergone physical therapy every weekday at Kernan Hospital in Baltimore in an effort to rebuild the strength in his passing arm. The goal of Unitas is a full recovery from the elbow tendonitis that sidelined the game's long-time No. 1 quarter-back through most of the 1968 season.
Even though it has had sex, the corporate annual meeting season so far has been a dull affair.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 10 -- United States marines, coordinating air raids and artillery barrages with infantry assaults, killed 129 North Vietnamese regulars yesterday in the dry rice paddies south of Danang, a military spokesman said.

After a delay of more than three years, the Lindsay administration is about to start seeking Federal money for loans to landlords who want to renew and preserve their old apartment buildings that stand in the paths of spreading slums.

Key Federal proposals for reforming foundations, including the imposition of a tax on investment income and restrictions on such "political activities" as voter registration, have alarmed and dismayed many foundation, civil rights and educational leaders.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 10 -- Indonesia has rejected an appeal for amnesty for political dissidents who oppose Indonesian rule in vast and primitive West Irian, informed sources said today.

HANOI, North Vietnam, May 10 (Agence France-Presse) -- The Communist party daily Nhan Dan said today that American insistence on a mutual withdrawal of troops from South Vietnam was a reactionary policy that would only lead the United States to even greater defeats.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 10 -- A team of economic planners has concluded that South Vietnam can be put back on its feet economically within 10 years after a cease-fire for what it now costs the United States to prosecute the war for a month.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner has indicated that if he were elected to his old job this year he would turn back the clock in at least two ways -- by breaking up some of Mayor Lindsay's new superagencies and by reinstating detailed investigations of all welfare applicants.

Nothing had ever happened to the provincial middle-aged Mr. and Mrs. Kenilworth until they traveled to Mexico. Very little was happening to them there either -- until their car broke down, stranding them in "a terrible town." Paco, their Mexican chauffeur, found them unforgettable accommodations in a castle (a crumbling hacienda), inhabited by an ancient lady (reputedly a queen) guarded by dragons (six Pekingese dogs and one outcast mutt).
PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -- Georgetown's heavyweight crew experienced little difficulty today in triumphing for the second straight year in the varsity division of the 31st annual Dad Vail regatta.

THE biggest run for your money in the way of chess books is the newly published "My 60 Memorable Games" by Bobby Fischer, America's ace grandmaster, former boy prodigy, and the most controversial character in the history of the game.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 10 -- The big money hasn't materialized yet for Stan Hayward, the middleweight who is known as Kitten, but the opportunity for that big money has arrived -- his 12-round bout with Emile Griffith on Monday night at Madison Square Garden.

JACKSONVILLE BEACH, Fla. -- Six miles north of this seaside resort is the Mayport Naval Station, which provides an interesting side trip for vacationists in this area. It has been greatly expanded in recent years, and is one of the largest naval bases on the Atlantic Coast.
LONDON, May 10 (UPI) -England trounced Scotland, 4-1, tonight and retained the British international soccer championship.
The European Zone Davis Cup tennis matches followed form yesterday with six favored countries, including the Soviet Union, advancing to the second round.
A meeting of faculty members from colleges and universities in the city is being planned for this week by a group of educators opposed to campus disorder.
The Seafarers International Union is the second American labor organization to join the ranks of owners of corporate aircraft.

PARIS -- At the ritual press briefings that followed the presentation of the National Liberation Front's ten-point proposals here last week, the North Vietnamese spokesman, Nguyen Thanh Le, was asked to identify the "Vietnamese armed forces in South Vietnam" that had been mentioned by the Front.
The Marriott Corporation, the large restaurant and hotel operator and airline and airport caterer is on an expansion drive.
ORLANDO, Fla. -- Plans outlined here recently for Walt Disney World -- scheduled to be opened in October, 1971 -- illustrate the magnitude of the 27,000-acre vacation project.

Most editors don't care what other publications write about them as long as the name of their magazine is spelled correctly ("The Ramparts Story," April 20). James Ridgeway failed to achieve even this, however, misspelling Scanlan's Monthly with the incorrect and pedestrian form, Scanlon.

New Jersey has reportedly reached a critical point in bus operations, especially within the state, threatening a loss of service that "would strike hardest at the poor, the elderly, the young and the handicapped."

The X-15 rocketship, the world's fastest and highest flying aircraft, whose hypersonic paths through the fringes of space sped the development of planes and satellites, made its final flight yesterday -- into the halls of history.
LONDON -- The disintegration of the Labor Government's morale and ability to govern, which has progressed gradually since devaluation of the pound 18 months ago, reached an alarming state last week.

The significance of the paradox in the United States balance of payments between the "liquidity" definition and the "official settlements" concept (news article by Edwin L. Dale Jr., May 5), is its demonstration of the inordinate importance that has been attached to the concept of a deficit or surplus in our balance of payments as an indicator of our international economic position.

As a voluntarily retired Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of North Carolina I am concerned -- notice that I didn't say shocked and dismayed, although it was a temptation -- at the naive explanation of Abe Fortas of his relationship with the Wolfson "Foundation."
LONDON (AP) -- Britain's decision not to challenge the United States for the America's Cup next year has caused some bitterness in yachting circles.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 10 -- Peter S. Godfrey, with his Shields Class sloop, Egide; Charles J. Seidler Jr., with Sea Jay II in the Ensign Class, and Edward J. Cox, at the helm of the Rhodes-19 sloop, C-Witch, won their second races in two starts on Long Island Sound today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's second preseason regatta for Yacht Racing Association one-design fleets.

John Plank in "We Should Start Talking With Castro," March 30, asserts that there is "one school of thought in the hemisphere that, unhappy with current policy, would turn -- instead of toward accommodation with Castro's regime -- toward increased pressure, military or other, against it.
The businessman, the engineer and the financier will meet at Boston College on May 22 and 23 to discuss the contributions each can make to creating new business in New England.

Mr. Lynne takes the Grand Hotel approach to a rundown London walkup, and reveals a cross section of rum characters. At the bottom of the heap is the mad concierge in her basement flat, a distressed gentlewoman living in a museum of heirlooms and Victorian fantasies.
Two of four former college officials writing on ways to deal with campus disruptions have urged the convening of a "constitutional convention" to reshape the colleges involved.

The rhetoric of the student rebellion and a basic popular distrust of all visible centers of authority have combined to make the university presidency the focus of attack and dissatisfaction on campuses all over the country -- a phenomenon made more graphic by last week's resignations of President Buell G. Gallagher at strife-torn City College and President Ray L. Heffner at more tranquil Brown University.

THE best show in Washington just now (beautifully installed) is the city's greenery in brilliant new leaf. As auxiliary attractions, two museums have opened three spring shows -- at the National Gallery, paintings by John Constable from the collection of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mellon and at the Corcoran a retrospective of the American abstractionist John Storrs and a show of Thomas Eakins's sculpture, which is what we are talking about here.

ROME -- The family motto of Count Romualdo Borletti, a Milanese industrialist whose domain includes the Rinascente department stores, banks and textile mills, is, quite appropriately, "In Labor Honor."

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- In attempting to restore public confidence by disclosing some of their private interests, members of Congress have discovered that they have also reopened the question whether Congress is living by a double standard.
CONCORD, N.H., May 10 (AP) -- The New Hampshire Supreme Court in a rare session today, refused to release 45 young persons jailed for contempt of court in a sit-in at Dartmouth College.

ZAP, N. D., May 10 -- A weekend "Zap-in" ended abruptly today as National Guardsmen and policemen cleared 2,000 to 3,000 young persons, many of them college students, out of this small town following a night of destruction in the business section.
PARIS -- Now the door is open for British entry into the Common Market. Or is it?

Colleges and universities across the country are hurriedly instituting changes and reforms, as administrators attempt to deal with student restiveness and to avoid the kind of demonstrations that have shaken Ivy League and other major universities.

Scientific observations will be transmitted to earth from the surface of another planet for the first time this week, if all goes well. Perhaps as early as Thursday and Friday nights two Soviet spacecraft.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Two spacecraft on their way to Mars have sent back the first direct measurement in deep space of the amount of heat from the sun, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

An international conference of African and Afro-American writers has been called off because some of its American participants objected that a predominantly white organization was co-sponsoring the meeting.
Scattered accidents of looting were reported in Harlem last night after firemen extinguished two fires on 125th Street -- one at fire-alarm blaze in a group of tores
Mr. Sjoman, what caused the trouble with the censors over "I Am Curious (Yellow)"?

BALTIMORE, May 10 -- Czar Alexander, one of the outstanding turf horses in this country, received one of Bill Hartack's great rides today and won the 67th running of the $58,300 Dixie Handicap at Pimlico race course.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 10 -- In the mist on the practice tee, Tom Nieporte peered at his pupil.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sunday, May 11 (Reuters) -- The Malaysian ruling Alliance party lost three Cabinet ministers and one state minister early today as counting reached the halfway mark in the country's third general election in 12 years of independence.

THE attractiveness of many of the medals being produced today to commemorate important events of history -- both past and present -- has induced thousands of collectors to turn their attention to this particular phase of numismatics.

Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo said yesterday that more than $1,479,000,000 of Mayor Lindsay's proposed $6.6-billion expense budget for 1969-70 would be spent for services for which the Federal Government should be paying.
A Long Island girl who thought she had been defeated learned yesterday she was still in the New York-to-London race, thanks to the Royal Air Force.

Entering this novel is like inching one's way into a cold sea. If he persists, the brave reader who can force himself to swim past the chilling currents flowing from the mind of the unnamed narrator may eventually establish his own consonance with an initially forbidding element.

LEWIS, N.Y. -- On a clear day in the Champlain Valley, you can see not only yesterday, but also three centuries of yesterdays -- the ranks of America's history marching and countermarching through this easy corridor of farms, meadows and quiet country roads.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 10 (AP) -- Fred Marti shot a five-under-par 66 today and moved into a five-way tie for the lead with a 137 total after two rounds of the $100,000 Texas open golf tournament.

A Federal report that has, in effect, been suppressed, will be a silent witness this week when the Government moves to head off threatened pollution of Lake Superior, one of the world's largest bodies of fresh water.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 10 -- Arthur F. Burns, the counselor to the President, disclosed today that the Administration was having difficulty in working out tax incentives for private business to help solve slum problems, as repeatedly promised by Mr. Nixon during the election campaign.
CANNONBALL ADDERLEY, bending ponderously to the mike and smiling ineffably, announced to the overflow crowd in the Berkeley campus's Greek Amphitheater, "The name of our next tune is 'Walk Tall.'
MIAMI, May 10 (AP) -- Billy Hardwick set a scoring record last night in winning the 28th annual $65,000 all-star bowling tournament, by a record 1,122 pins.

HILLSDALE, N.J., May 10 -- A $1-million Roman Catholic Church designed to reflect the Judaic heritage of Christianity and constructed in the form of a dove, the symbol of the Holy Spirit, was blessed and dedicated here today by Archbishop Thomas A. Boland of the Newark Archdiocese.

THE office of Artie Brevis, well-known Broadway and Hollywood agent. The walls are covered with pictures of the great and near-great, all bearing fond inscriptions to Artie. There are pictures of such luminaries as Frank Sinatra with Hubert Humphrey, John Wayne with Curtis LeMay, Richard Nixon with Lionel Hampton, Lester Maddox with Miss Roll Weegel Artie is on the phone:

The story of Whittaker Chambers on the stand in the Federal perjury trial of Alger Hiss was on Page One that day and in the entertainment section it was announced that Rudolf Bing would be the new head of the Metropolitan Opera.
IRKUTSK, Soviet Union -- Signs of increasing militarization of the exacerbated dispute between Soviet Russia and Communist China are causing increasing concern in Asian circles.

The acclaim of one's peers is recognition of a special kind, as the winners of this year's Edgars made evident, at the 23d annual Edgar Allan Poe Awards Dinner of the Mystery Writers of America, held in New York on April 25.

WHEN the Cincinnati Symphony appears in Carnegie Hall on Friday night, it will present the New York premiere of Dave Brubeck's oratorio "The Light in the Wilderness." This involves not only the orchestra but Brubeck himself as piano soloist, a jazz trio, a baritone soloist (Robert Hale) and a 100-voice choir from Miami (Ohio) University.

A highly misleading letter to the editor published May 4 must not go uncorrected. The letter was from Samuel Rotrosen, Chairman of the Industry Task Force for DDT, who implies there is no alternative to DDT for controlling malaria.

FORT LAUERDALE, Fla., May 10 -- A new threat to Florida's $4.1-billion agricultural industry has been noted by Jack Peters, director of the Florida Tomato Committee, who warned that Mexico's winter fruit and produce production could seriously hurt Florida growers.
TOKYO, May 10 -- Executives and scholars involved with the mass media of five continents met in Japan this week to lay a foundation for a comprehensive global communications policy.

It is regrettable that Nancy Hicks's April 14 news article ("A Question of Segregation in Reverse at Antioch") contained very little information pertinent to the real concerns and issues involved at Antioch College with the establishment of an all black dormitory (Unity House) and a studies institute for black students only.

Art Modell, the owner of the Cleveland Browns, said last night he was "very happy" with his team's switch to the new American Conference in 1970. He said an earlier report that quoted him as saying the Browns' move would "emasculate" the National Football League was a misquote.

SHAKERTOWN, Ky. -- It is not easy to step into the past, but an overnight visit to this 19th-century Shaker village seems to come close to such a journey back in time. The opportunity to experience even briefly the tranquility of rural life 150 years ago is a rare bonus, and the contrasts between present-day America and the halcyon community that lived here could not be greater.
Prof. Joseph J. Copeland of the City College biology department was named yesterday as acting president of the college.

SALTON CITY, Calif. -- Among the sights puzzling to visitors to this part of California are the long weekend parades of hundreds of Los Angeles motorists towing boats east through San Gorgonio Pass on Interstate 10. Unlike lemmings, these yachtsmen are bound away from the ocean, not toward it. Dropping down through the pass toward Palm Springs and Indio, they appear to be hauling their cabin cruisers, outboards, sloops and skiffs into a waterless desert.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 10 -- The Harvard lightweight crews won all three final races at the Eastern Sprint championships here today on Lake Quinsigamond. This feat was a repeat of last year's results when the Crimson, the most successful rowing college in the United States. also swept all three lightweight races.

MERIDIAN, Miss., May 10 (AP) -- An all-white Federal Court jury acquitted today three of 10 Ku Klux Klansmen in Jones County of civil rights conspiracy charges in the death of Vernon F. Dahmer Sr., a Hattiesburg Negro leader.

WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 10 -- A 4 1/2-year-old red chow chow, Ch. Eastward Liontamer of Elster, owned by Mrs. Jeanette L. Hetherington Jr. and Dr. Samuel Draper of Franklin Lakes, N.J., won his first best-in-show award at the 42d Springfield Kennel Club dog show and obedience trial at the Better Living Center on the Eastern States Exposition grounds. There were 1,263 dogs in the show.
The two men most likely to lead the New York Mets out of the wilderness -- Tom Seaver and Cleon Jones -- combined their talents yesterday to subdue the Houston Astros, 3-1, in Shea Stadium.

There are two approaches to ghost stories. The emotional one is to sit around a campfire at night, or lie abed in the dark, and exchange eerie tales till you're covered with goose pimples. This book takes the second, journalistic, scientific way. It is about as spooky as a Mickey Mouse cartoon.

WASHINGTON -- A new mood is taking hold in official Washington on the whole question of national defense and the resources committed to it. The mood, whether in the executive branch or in Congress, is one of reassessment, of realignment, of impending change.

HONG KONG, May 10 -- A report on Chinese educational reform, prepared by a study team in Shanghai, has proposed a basic nine-year course for China's youth. It also appears to have dismissed the need for university education for most students.

THE stock market's peace rally rolled along at a more leisurely pace last week in the teeth of profit taking and some potentially ominous winds on the domestic and international economic fronts. In the process, however, the market proceeded to new highs for the year.
It's showdown time in Teberan as Iran and the consortium of Western oil companies face each other in a war of nerves over Iran's demand for a sharp increase in oil production.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 10 -- The Harvard varsity crew collected the shirts here today, upsetting the undefeated Pennsylvania crew to win the Eastern Sprint championships once more. The Crimson eight, a loser to Penn by a length and a half in the Adams Cup race last Saturday, beat the Red and Blue today by a length and a quarter.

ON stormier days, doughty weather watchers can observe two "oceans" coming together in a mighty crescendo of spume and spray off the Outer Banks of North Carolina. In addition to bestowing the name "Graveyard of the Atlantic" on the area, the phenomenon has left the Outer Banks with a rich legacy of legends dealing with pirate gold and buried treasure.

Although the general situation at Aqueduct was harmonious yesterday, after the horsemen's boycott, the attendance of 42,175 was the smallest Saturday turnout of the season. The card was featured by the $58,100 Withers Mile, a race that was run for the 94th time.
CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- Ogden Phipp's King of the Castle, charging from far back under Braulio Bacza, won the $79,450 Illinois Derby today before a closing-day crowd of 23,223 at Sportsman's Park.

Judging by his April 29 statement on Latin-American universities, President Nixon should think twice before again venturing into an impromptu speech. The truth is that there was no "revolution similar to ours" in Latin-American universities 100 years ago, nor, for that matter, was there any such revolution in the entire nineteenth century.

A PUBLIC clean-up campaign is being sponsored for Central Park by the Friends of Central Park. Described as New York's newest sport, the clean-up will start today at 2:30 P.M. at the Conservatory Pond, south rim near Fifth Avenue and 73d Street. Helpers are requested to bring shopping bags and old gloves.

A PARTICULARLY lovely place to explore seashore flora is Fire Island, a 30-mile sand bar running along the south shore of Long Island. Remarkable for an abundance of native American holly, the flora is otherwise similar to that of Cape Cod, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket.

OCTOBER 14 at Abilene, Kansas -- his boyhood home and the place where he is buried -- are the date of issue and site for the issuance of a commemorative stamp for former President Dwight D. Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON -- The Society of Wilbur Mills Watchers and Second-Guessers has convened again for what promises to be a long session.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 10 -- Brian McElroy left no doubt today that he is the best school-boy half-miler on the East Coast.

Dan Johnson is a big, heavy-set man with a banker's look. In fact, he is a banker, but at the moment his attention is divided between the fluctuating money market and a desire to put more tennis racquets into the hands of youngsters.
MONTREAL, May 10 (AP) -- Gary Sutherland's two-run single keyed an eighth-inning rally that gave the Montreal Expos a 7-6 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today.

HONG KONG, May 10 -- Forty-four thousand racing fans from this crown colony's four million population crowded to capacity the Royal Hong Kong Jockey Club's optimistically named Happy Valley Track today for the 100th running of the Hong Kong Derby, and they demonstrated that horseplayers in the Orient are very little different from their venturesome brothers in the Occident.
To help ease the discomfort of a hot summer, New York's policemen will abandon their traditional navy blue worsted shirts for a medium-blue, wash-and-wear model, the Police Department said yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., May 10 -- Employment in Virginia expanded by a vigorous 25 per cent between 1960 and 1968, enabling the state to maintain one of the lowest unemployment rates in the nation, and one that since 1965 has averaged less than 3 per cent.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 10 -- Twenty Minnesota companies have enlisted in the vanguard of a new national drive for legislation to allow more United States trade with Iron Curtain countries.

Paraguay's autocratic Government has largely stifled reporting by both local and foreign news organizations of an increasingly serious struggle between the regime on the one hand and liberal university and church leaders on the other, according to reliable information reaching New York.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 10 -- Roosevelt Raceway "beat the gun" on Mother's Day by honoring Mrs. Haughton, wife of Billy Haughton, the owner-driver-trainer, as harness racing's mother of the year in a ceremony at the Nassau County track this morning.

On April 26, 1935, the New Haven Railroad operated its first bicycle train. The destination was Falls Village in the Berkshire Hills in New England. More than 150 cyclists met at Grand Central Terminal to enjoy a new adventure. The fare was $2.50 round trip.

The New York University Alumni Federation announced yesterday that five graduates had won the 1969 Alumni Meritorious Service Medal, the highest honor an alumnus can receive from his fellow graduates.

WASHINGTON -- Soon after the Supreme Court was established, Alexis de Tocqueville observed that the justices' power "is enormous, but it is the power of public opinion." To maintain this power, he felt, "not only must the Federal judges be good citizens, and men of that information and integrity which are indispensable to all magistrates, but they must be statesmen"
BARNSTABLE, Mass., May 8 -- Sitting in the rain at the low dam where the Marstons Mills River runs out of the Mill Pond, Charles Eldridge dipped for alewives with a hand net.
Recruiter Weisel ("Going the Rounds With a Dow Recruiter," April 13) represents a curiously ambivalent position regarding napalm.

I fear very few people who wrote in about the Birgit Nilsson-Herbert von Karajan controversy, and who inveighed so against Karajan, are at all familiar with his art. Those who are can understand what must be his vague feelings of incompatibility, let us say, with Miss Nilsson's bold operatic efforts.

TEXAS tourist officials have created 10 automobile trails in various sections of their state, and the routes have been detailed by the American Automobile Association. An example of the itineraries is the 578-mile-long Hill Country Trail, which passes through the central portion of the state.

Indonesia has recently announced that the self-determination of West Irian vis-a-vis the Suharto regime in Jakarta is to be resolved not by referendum but by the peculiar talkathon process the Javanese call "mushawara." Responsible organs of the U.N. accede to this, despite the fact that mushawara is to take place between some few hundred tribal head-men (one is tempted to say, "basic democrats") and a cadre of Indonesian governing officials.

WASHINGTON -- It has been four weeks since President Nixon laid down the ultimate political argument by claiming that his Safeguard missile defense system was "absolutely essential" for the national security. The remarkable political reaction is that the President did not seem to make even a dent in the Senate opposition.

This is a thundering broadside of a book. It contains 11 accounts of fleet actions and ship-to-ship duels. The first is John Paul Jones's version of how Bon Homme Richard and Serapis grappled to the death. Next is a far more vivid report on Trafalgar by the surgeon of Nelson's Victory.

WHEN a friend suggested that, since I had spent all my adult life in black-power movements and in universities, I might make some comments on the highly topical subject of black power in the American university, it did not at first seem to be a good idea.

WHEN the Pentagle came out onstage at the Fillmore East recently, the light show was off and no wall of amplifiers lined the rear of the stage. Vocalist Jacqui McShee was wearing a subdued red robe, but among the four men in the Pentangle there was no real costuming to speak of.

The Fresh Air Fund, approaching its 92d summer of providing free country vacations to needy New York children, has established a goal of $750,000 this year, and hundreds of this from individuals, program and conditions and command groups have already can be accepted.

CHALAN KANOA, Saipan, May 9 -- Nearly 200 elected legislators and other leaders from Guam and the myriad islands and atolls of Micronesia have been meeting here this week to discuss the common political and economic problems of the widely scattered Pacific dependencies of the United States.

In the crisis that has racked the New York hospital system in recent months the main emphasis has been on lack of money. Last week attention shifted to the problem of hospital organization and thus to the question of how to make best use of what money is available.
VIENNA, May 10 -- Eight nations of the Soviet bloc have agreed on a program of economic coordination, though not integration, and of mutual convertibility of their currencies.
