In an Introductory Note the publisher, having already claimed for it the status of "one of those books which have become classics of our time before finding their way into print, carried by the oral and subterranean tradition of the discerning few," announces his (presumably) "unprecedented" decision to publish the epic in two stages.

The policy-making body of a national organization of psychologists has unanimously challenged a recent contention published in The Harvard Educational Review that Negro-white differences in intelligence quotient scores are based largely on heredity.

PROMONTORY SUMMIT, Utah, May 10 -- The centenary of the driving of the golden spike that tied the Atlantic to the Pacific with steel rails was observed here under a cloudless sky by 20 history-conscious citizen at precisely 2:47 o'clock this afternoon.

MIAMI -- Summer cruises will be resumed on the Great Lakes next year, when the M/S Sunward, a Miami-based liner, starts operations there under the Georgian Bay Line Norwegian - Caribbean Lines flag. The 11,000-ton, 500-passenger vessel, which has been making cruises to the Bahamas and Jamaica from Miami since she was commissioned in 1966, will sail on the lakes from May through October, 1970.
DETROIT -- Ed Davis, a Chrysler - Plymouth dealer here, used to be unique. He was for many years the one and only Negro new car dealer in the United States.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 10 -- The Immorality Act, forbidding interracial sexual relations, has come under new and strong attack from churchmen, politicians and sociologists.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., May 10 -- Four years ago, Howard A. Lee, the son of a Negro sharecropper, bought a house in a white neighborhood in Chapel Hill.
BALTIMORE, May 11 (UPI) -- The two leading candidates for the $150,000 added Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday -- unbeaten Majestic Prince and Top Knight -- both turned in fine workouts today.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 11 -- Laotian leaders struck a conciliatory note today at ceremonies marking the 22d anniversary of the Laotian Constitution.
The New York Greek-Americans, virtually assured of the German - American Soccer League title, tied New York Hota, 1-1, yesterday at Eintracht Oval in Queens before 1,600 fans.

Despite previous denials, the Leo Burnett Company of Chicago and the London Press Exchange Ltd., have signed a letter of intent to bring off one of the biggest mergers, if not the biggest merger in ad agency history.

TOKYO, May 11 (UPI) -- Japan's two largest steelmakers, the Yawata Iron and Steel Company and the Fuji Iron and Steel Company, agreed this weekend to put off their projected merger following the Fair Trade Commission's refusal to approve it.

THERE are many bad bad plays, a few good bad plays, and just one or two positively great bad plays. I suggest that "The Front Page" by Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur, joyously restored on Saturday night to Broadway, albeit for a miserably limited run, is of that number.
The pro football establishment was trumpeting the virtues of the realignment yesterday but many of the National Football League fans who buy the tickets were shocked and unhappy over the moves.
FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, May 11 (UPI) -- Jo Siffert of Belgium and Brian Redman of Britain, driving a three-liter Porsche 908, won the 1,000 Kilometers of Francorchamps auto race today.

Poland created the biggest stir of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis matches yesterday when it announced it would refuse to meet South Africa in the second round because of that country's policy of apartheid.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, May 12 -- North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops shelled Saigon, Hue and more than 30 allied military positions last night and this morning in a considerable increase in the tempo of the war.
DETROIT, May 11 (UPI) -- Jim Price and Al Kaline hit home runs and Dennis McLain, the winning pitcher, added a run-scoring single today as the Detroit Tigers topped the Minnesota Twins, 3-2.
TOKYO, May 11 (UPI) -- Communist China filed a "strong protest" with India today over a piece of linoleum.

TOKYO, May 11, (AP) -- North Korea demanded today that the United States stop "the so-called exercises for getting familiar with the terrain and conditions for combat preparations" near the demilitarized zone in Korea.

William V. Shannon's assertion that "the university is a quiet place deliberately insulated from the conflicts and pressures of the larger society around it" [Editorial page column April 28] is an expression of his own nostalgia, nothing more. It may be that college students once spent four years in political limbo; if so, it is most unfortunate but happily is no longer the case.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Safety recall campaigns are conducted without public announcement by five of the 10 leading importers of foreign cars, a check by The New York Times has disclosed.
Norman Mailer views the plight of New York with the hard idealism of a committed artist who sees the city crumbling, racially torn and gripped with despair.

BONN, May 11 -- Senior aides of Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger report that he has intentionally chosen a "nationalist, conservative policy" on all major domestic and international issues this spring as the guiding principle of his strategy for winning the election of Sept. 28.
PARIS, May 11 -- Black militants interrupted a service at the American Church here this morning to demand "reparations" for past exploitation of American Negroes.
The Great Trans-Atlantic Air Race of 1969 ended yesterday with the winners pointing out what most air travelers already knew:

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- On the Howard University campus, where he led 100 deputy marshals and 22 campus security officers last week in a three-hour operation to remove dissident students from seized buildings, Luke Charles Moore, United States Marshal for the District of Columbia, is still highly regarded.
NORTH SALEM, N. Y., May 11 -- Anthony D'Ambrosio Jr., a teen-ager with a flair for riding, was a double winner at the North Salem Lions Club horse show today.

Raoul H. Fleischmann, who escaped a lifetime of baking bread by backing that improbable and fretful genius, Harold Ross, in the creation of The New Yorker magazine, died yesterday at 4 A.M. in his apartment at 955 Fifth Avenue. He was 83 years old.
The Newfoundland Pulp and Chemical Corporation has leased the entire 34th floor of the 41-story office building at 90 Park Avenue in a $1.5-million, long-term transaction.
GENEVA, May 11 -- The United Nations is about to consider the establishment of machinery to investigate some of the thousands of complaints it receives every year alleging violations of human rights.

Shea Stadium, which has seen some of the most improbable doings in baseball since the Mets moved there in 1964, was the scene of a bevy of wonders yesterday as the New Yorkers split a double-header with the Houston Astros before 19,456 befuddled fans.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 11 -- Fifty Harvard University professors, in a letter to The New York Times, have taken issue with "published news reports" that they say "suggested a number of false inferences" about the faculty's role in the recent disturbances at Harvard.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 11 -- President Tito warned the Soviet Union today that Yugoslavia does not and will never recognize any kind of "limited sovereignty."

PARIS, May 11 -- Pham Dang Lam, South Vietnam's chief negotiator at the peace talks here, declared today that his government was ready for "serious discussions" on both the 10-point program of the Vietcong and the six points of President Nguyen Van Thieu.

CHICAGO, May 11 (UPI) -- Billy Williams hit a two-run homer in the first inning, Randy Hundley drove in three runs with a homer and a single, and Ron Santo batted in two runs with a single today as the Chicago Cubs trimmed the San Francisco Giants, 8-0, behind the nine-hit pitching of Ken Holtzman.
PITTSBURGH, May 11 -- Steel officials are talking about a relatively shallow dip in shipments this summer.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 11 -- The Palestinian commando chief, Yasir Arafat, continued talks with Lebanese leaders for the fourth day today amid signs of growing determination by Beirut not to yield to the commandos' demand for freedom to operate against Israel across the Lebanese border.
Mimeographed notices taped to the front doors of Morningside Heights apartment buildings offer a $150 reward "for information leading to the rental" of an apartment in the Columbia University area.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 11 (AP) -- Rico Petrocelli drove in four runs with his ninth and 10th homers today as the Boston Red Sox downed the California Angels 7-3, extending their winning streak to eight games.
State and municipal borrowing costs, which dipped briefly during April, appear headed upward once again.

CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., May 11 (AP) -- Parnelli Jones was declared the winner today of the Wolverine Trans-American Sedan Race, more than four hours after Mark Donohue had been given the checkered flag to end the tragedy-marred race.

In a letter to the Editor (May 7), Willard Barber states that "The proposed constitutional amendment for direct election of the President, approved by the House Judiciary Committee, suffers from a serious omission: no deadline is given for ratification by the states."

The Baltimore Colts, the Cleveland Browns and the Pittsburgh Steelers of the National Football League will join the present 10 teams of the American Football League to make up the revised 13-club American Conference when pro football starts a new era with its 1970 season.
ZAP, N.D., May 11 (AP) -- Beer can rings and bits of shattered glass littered Zap's unpaved main street today.

ROD McKUEN, the poet, composer and erstwhile lumberjack, had a television special of his own on Saturday evening, a modest half-hour of very substantial attractiveness on the network of the National Broadcasting Company.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 11 -- Thomas J. Watson's Jr.'s Palawan, which sailed at scratch and also finished first, boat for boat, won the first race of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's annual four-race Whitmore Trophy season series for cruising yachts on Long Island Sound today.
An unmanageable pile-up of garbage has led the city to revert to incineration in city-owned apartment projects, although such burning violates municipal regulations against air pollution.

Two of the three Republican mayoral candidates, Mayor Lindsay and State Senator John J. Marchi, yesterday took political swipes at each other, primarily over the unrest on the city's college campuses.

"We take care of your children just as we care for our own," a sign on the door of a United Fund day nursery in Manhattan's lower East Side promises. Each morning several mothers who live in the neighborhood take their babies and young children to the "nursery mothers" and go off to their jobs.

For a school dropout, Stanley Dancer did especially well Saturday. Of course, the 41-year-old harness-racing driver didn't have to utilize any of the skills he learned in school to win races at three tracks and purses totaling $116,088. That was more than any other driver has won.

I don't know exactly where Louis Falco is going choreographically, but I love to watch him getting there. Saturday evening at the Kaufmann Concert Hall, Mr. Falco and his company presented three works, including the premiere of "Time-wright." All had an element of obscurity but shared a surface polish that aroused interested attention.
THE seventh game of the 24-game title match between the world champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, and his challenger, Boris Spassky, was drawn after 27 moves.

City College officials sought yesterday with uncertain success to set the stage for a resumption of talks with black and Puerto Rican students aimed at ending the crisis that has crippled the school for almost three weeks.

HARDLY are you into Leonard Mosley's "On Borrowed Time," when it happens all over again. Only now instead of reading reports of it in the newspapers or hearing about it from your parents, you're right at the scene. It's September 15, 1938. Adolf Hitler and Neville Chamberlain, the Prime Minister of Britain, have just greeted one another on the steps of Hitler's residence at Berchtesgaden.

"How many points do I have to pay to get the loan?" This is the stickler home mortgage men are wrestling with again and again these days, according to a spot survey of major markets conducted by The New York Times.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A panel of scholars who specialize in Soviet affairs sketched today a dark picture of the condition of Soviet Jews.

Eight broadcasters were named yesterday as C.B.S. Foundation News Fellows of 1969-70, by the C.B.S. Foundation Inc., the Columbia Broadcasting System's educational, cultural and philanthropic division.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 11 -- The New York Yankees didn't make any errors today, but they didn't make any runs either and lost to the Oakland Athletics, 2-0. It was their 13th defeat in the last 15 games, and if this sort of thing continues, it could develop into a real slump.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Lulled by friendly winds from the White House and warmed by the soft spring sun, the 91st Congress nodded and dozed through another few days of its four-month-old session last week before going home for Mother's Day.
DUBLIN, May 11 -- Charles de Gaulle and his wife, Yvonne, continued their vacation quietly today at the Heron Cove Hotel in County Kerry. They did not leave the 150-acre grounds of the hotel.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 11 -- Despite small uprisings and demonstrations in the territory of West Irian, all indications point to continued Indonesian rule there after the "act of free choice" scheduled for this summer.

All the music composed by Alban Berg was, as we clearly see today, an elegy on the death of the 19th century. Since it was the dying fall of Romanticism, and not the beginning of anything, no performing style so well suits his works as the all-stops-out, tears-on-the-pillow kind of neo-Romantic approach.

JERUSALEM, May 7 -- In the two years since the six-day war that made this one city again, the Israelis have been consolidating their territorial gains by one of the most permanent of means -- the erection of buildings. The reunification of Jerusalem has been as much a physical as a political process.

Rising prices wiped out the gains in the pay of factory production workers in the New York metropolitan area over the last year, the regional director of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, Herbert Bienstock, reported yesterday.
BASEL, Switzerland, May 11 -- Central bankers from the major countries were hopeful today that they can contain the crisis that has broken out over currency values in Europe.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) -- About 3.5 million jobs will open up each year through the mid-nineteen-seventies despite increasing automation and the gradual disappearance of some "obsolete" occupations, the Labor Department predicted today.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 11 (UPI) -- Deane Beman, getting his chance for a sudden-death playoff when Jack McGowan missed an 18-inch putt on the 18th green, dropped a 20-footer on the first extra hole today to win the $100,000 Texas open. It was his first victory on the Professional Golfers' Association tour.

STUTTGART, West Germany, May 11 -- West Germany's ultrarightist National Democratic party, vowing to forge a new "national consciousness of the Germans," approved an election platform this weekend that leaders predicted would carry the party into the federal Parliament this fall for the first time.
Italy does not intend to lag behind the rest of the world in the development of container shipping services, Giuseppe Lupis, Italy's Minister of Merchant Marine, said here yesterday.

The Military Sea Transportation Service has begun a test program from Great Lakes ports to determine the costs of exporting military goods via the St. Lawrence Seaway, the Great Lakes Commission reported yesterday.

Few singers would care to tackle the imaginative program of offbeat vocal literature offered by Jean Kraft late Saturday afternoon at Town Hall. Miss Kraft, however, obviously enjoys dealing with challenging material.

CURTIS WILLIG paid $1 for a straight razor that he said he "wouldn't dare shave with." William Shubick handed over $2 for a cup and saucer with a swan motif because, he said, "I wanted something grotesque and unique to drink tea out of."

SAN DIEGO, May 11 -- The United States World Cup soccer team was eliminated today from the 16-team finals in Mexico next year when it lost, 1-0, to Haiti in the semi-finals of the North American-Central American-Caribbean series.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 -- The emphasis in arguments for liberalization of abortion laws was substantially shifted here during a weekend meeting of 250 physicians, social scientists and laymen.
I have just read in your newspaper about the outrageous intrusion at Riverside Church on May 4, when a representative of the black militants demanded reparations.

For nearly a decade, Emile Griffith has been the "house" fighter at Madison Square Garden, meaning the boxer who could always be depended upon to attract a sizable crowd and a worthwhile gate. But his future in that role will depend on his 12-round middleweight match tonight with Stanley (Kitten) Hayward.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The admiral responsible for the 41-submarine missile fleet is confident the Russians cannot now and will not in the foreseeable future be able to attack successfully the $13-billion American underwater nuclear deterrent force.
The Theater Guild has bought a New Yorker story by John Updike, called "Bech Takes Pot Luck," which will be adapted for production on Broadway in the fall.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 11 -- Representatives of the consortium of major European and American oil companies that produces most of Iran's oil entered negotiations here today with Iranian oil officials over Iran's demand for a sharp 17 per cent increase in this country's revenue for 1969 from the consortium's oil operations in Iran.

A five-block stretch of Nassau Street in Lower Manhattan that bustles with lunch-hour crowds that jam the narrow road and its shops will be turned into a midday pedestrian mall in a three-month experiment beginning next Monday.

The bright green wagon lurched northward along Madison Avenue, pulled by a dappled horse and laden with shrieking children. It turned east at 82d Street and then turned again at Park Avenue, passing on its way some of the city's more elegant townhouses and expensive apartments.

LANCASTER, Pa., May 11 -- A 5-year-old white miniature poodle, Ch. Round Table Loramar Yeoman, owned by Mrs. Alden Keene of Middletown, Del., defeated 1,401 rivals today to win best-in-show honors at the 24th annual Lancaster Kennel Club event.
Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur always knew they married well, but even they might have been surprised to find their widows with butterflies some 41 years after the show opened.

PARIS -- An unusual boardroom struggle with wide international implications is taking place in one of France's biggest companies, the Schneider Holding Company, which is sometimes known as the Krupp of France.

BALTIMORE, May 11 (UPI) -- Jim Palmer pitched a three-hitter and singled in a fourth-inning run and Frank Robinson slammed a two-run homer today as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Kansas City Royals, 5-0.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The almost daily exchanges of fire along the Suez Canal, coupled with pressure in Israel and the United Arab Republic for tougher military action, have forcefully drawn the attention of high Adminstration officials to the build-ups occurring along the canal.

MOSCOW, May 10 -- Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, the Soviet Union's military commander in World War II, has publicly portrayed Stalin as an alert military strategist who was ready to listen to the other side of an argument.
James Forman, the black militant leader, stood silently during the 20-minute sermon yesterday at Riverside Church, except for occasional whispered words of "peace, peace."

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., May 11 -- A 2 1/2-year-old fawn and white boxer, Ch. Arriba's Prima Donna, owned by Dr. and Mrs. P. J. Pagano and Dr. Theodore S. Fickes of Pelham Manor, N. Y., won her 18th best in show today at the 25th Windham County Kennel Club dog show and obedience trial at Recreation Park. There were 1,452 dogs entered.

OLEAN, N. Y., May 11 -- The president of St. Bonaventure University today banned the Students for a Democratic Society from campus, charging that the radical organization was "anti-democratic, anti-American and anti-Christian."

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The typical dinner menu here these May evenings consists of campus cocktail followed by Vietnam viands and topped off, in cautious servings, by Fortas Flambe. It makes or a high-calorie discussion, but there is hardly a gathering in George town, McLean or Chevy Chase that can resist. Hunger in America intrudes occasionally upon the dinner talk of the ins, outs and hangers-on.

DALLAS, May 11 (AP) -- Carol Mann survived a four-way race down the backstretch with a one-under-par 70 today to win the 14th annual Dallas Civitan open golf tournament by two strokes over a fast-finishing Donna Caponi.
ATHENS, May 11 -- Greece's military-led Government decreed a series of curbs on labor unions today to deter strikes stringently and discourage the employment of career unionists as leaders.

Something disastrous happened to Charles Aznavour this weekend. The small, slim French singer and songwriter appeared at Carnegie Hall Saturday evening and yesterday afternoon, and on Saturday his artistry was all but destroyed by over-amplification.

A Giselle who gets down on her knees and actually appears to weep should, in theory, provide all the pathos the mad scene in "Giselle" could do without. But it was the unalloyed triumph of Svetlana Beriosova's outstanding performance in the ballet, given by the Royal Ballet Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, that she could makes such moments moving rather than merely poignant.
"I DON'T think women should spend hours deciding what they should wear and, frankly, there are more important things to do with their money than putting it all into clothes."

A proposal to include Coney Island's beach, the Jamaica Bay and Floyd Bennett Field areas, Marine Park, the Staten Island beaches and the Navesink Highlands of New Jersey in a vast Federal recreation area here has been made by the Regional Plan Association.

CALGARY, Alberta, May 9 -- Great Canadian Oil Sands, Ltd., of Edmonton, the Sun Oil Company subsidiary that is extracting synthetic crude oil from Alberta's extensive tar sands, reported today that it lost $8,580,000 in the first quarter of 1969.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9 -- If Scott Fitzgerald were alive today and commenting on campus disruptions, he would undoubtedly note that Negroes are different from you and me. And he would be right.

Six police scuba divers searched beneath the choppy Hudson River off 52d Street yesterday in an unsuccessful quest for weapons that might have been used in the fatal shooting Saturday of two men on the Cunard Line pier there. They plan to resume the search today.
Having spent six years together and having started one of the great battles in advertising history, Avis and Doyle Dane Bernbach have called it quits. The billings are estimated at $5-million.

FARMINGTON, Conn., May 11 -- Jared Brinsmade dominated the final day of the Children's Services horse show today by riding both first-year green hunter champions and piloting Michele McEvoy's Act I to victory in the open jumper stake.

ROME, May 11 -- Prosecution lawyers in the trial of 217 Italians accused of turning water, acid, date pits, banana boat sludge and other improbable substances into wine found themselves faced today with a new problem: Who turned the material evidence into water?

The American Civil Liberties Union plans to file a petition today before the United States Supreme Court asking a review of an injunction that prohibits a Connecticut university professor from making any statements that are "untrue, malicious or obscene."
Robert F. Wagner said yesterday that it was the role of the Mayor to lead, but that leadership was impossible without conciliation.
FREDERICKSBURG, Tex., May 11 -- Two of the biggest people ever to hit the Texas hill country came together today with the biggest event around here in at least five years.
Extra police were on patrol yesterday along West 125th Street following a three-alarm fire in a store Saturday evening that touched off a night of scattered looting on Harlem's principal street.

LUSAKA, Zambia, May 11 -- Details of a new taxation plan, which it is believed would give new mining development in Zambia a tremendous stimulus and simultaneously settle the royalty formula issue, are expected to be hammered out in meetings beginning here early next month.

With only one abstention, West Germany's coalition Cabinet decided two weeks ago to support abolition without reservation of the twenty-year statute of limitations for prosecuting Nazi war criminals and other murderers. Now Chancellor Kiesinger has agreed instead to back an effort by his Christian Democratic Union to amend the abolition bill so as to end prosecution of lesser Nazis who killed only under orders.
CHARLESTON, S. C., May 11 -- More than 12,000 persons paraded through the streets of this Old South city tonight on a "Mother's Day march," in support of striking hospital workers.
The heads of three city zoos, who carry the title of Supervisors of Menagerie, have been given the right to be represented by a union in collective bargaining.

Two hospital bills await Governor Rockefeller's signature. One establishes a management corporation to run New York City's twenty municipal hospitals outside the present stifling bureaucracy. It deserves signing. The other establishes Harlem Hospital as an exception to certain provisions governing the operations of the corporation. It deserves a veto.

Philip Morris, Inc., the country's fourth largest cigarette maker, said yesterday that it plans to enter the brewery field with a tender offer for 50 per cent of the common stock of Canadian Breweries, Ltd., Canada's leading brewer.

LAGOS, Nigeria, May 10 -- A few days after the capture of Umuahia, the provisional capital of secessionist Biafra, Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon proudly predicted that "the rebellion will soon be over and Nigeria will return to an era of peace."
PRINCETON, N. J., May 11 -- Dr. T. Cuyler Young, who retires next month as professor and chairman of Princeton University's Oriental Studies Department, will teach Islamic history in Nairobi, Kenya.

The aroma of Southern fried chicken wafted through the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night where 800 persons -- many of them connected with showbusiness and most of dressed as if they were -- paid $100 each to dine on "soul food."
As a member of the Board of Higher Education, I would like to comment on your editorial of May 1st on the City College crisis.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- An antiwar soldier at Fort Bragg, N. C., has issued a new challenge to military authority.
The National Aeronautics and Space Agency apparently plans to relax its precautions against the spread of alien organisms that might be brought back from the moon by the Apollo 11 space flight.

TUMACO, Colombia, May 11 -- An oil pipeline threading out of dank Amazonian jungles up and across bitterly chill Andean summits and down to this clapboard settlement huddled on a sandbar beside the Pacific Ocean was inaugurated here yesterday by Colombia's President Carlos Lleras Restrepo.

Lin Piao's major policy speech to the Chinese Communist Party Congress gives very little comfort to those who have hoped for greater stability within China, and for a more moderate Peking foreign policy. What emerges most vividly from the speech is Mr. Lin's dedication to a sort of permanent cultural revolution within China, and to deep and really ferocious hostility toward both the United States and the Soviet Union.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 11 -- American hopes of winning the 1969 world championship faded virtually to the vanishing point here last night when the United States team lost its fourth straight match in the qualifying stage. With one-third of the qualifying matches completed, the Americans need considerable luck as well as greatly improved performance to reach one of the first two positions and so qualify for the final.
A trustee of the Museum of Modern Art says he believes that intrigue had been a factor in the recent dismissal of Bates Lowry, the museum's director for less than a year.

Barbara Long chose four 20th-century pieces for her Carnegie Recital Hall appearance late Saturday afternoon: sonatas by Hindemith and David Loeb, the Three Madrigals by Martinu, and Manuel de Falla's Suite Popular Espana.

Nicholas Kisburg, an excellent labor researcher, erred in his recent letter [April 28]. He concludes that the white-Negro income differential is increasingly due to "regional growth or stagnation and cultural lags rather than racism and discriminatory patterns." He finds that Southern white families are doing better than Northeastern white families, and sees a "spectacular" rise in the Western black-white income ratio to 84 per cent.
LOS ANGELES, May 11 -- "In the black community," Fred Williams said sharply, "we're not selling Bradley to anybody. There is no opposition."

MANHASSET, L. I., May 11 -- The 6-year-old daughter of a Wall Street executive was abducted from her bedroom last night, but abandoned unharmed in a neighbor's garden when her cries aroused her family.
A heavyweight eight from Columbia University stroked against a blustery headwind with poise yesterday and won the John F. Whalen Cup at the annual Father Knickerbocker Regatta.
PARIS, May 11 -- Editors and the news staff of the conservative daily newspaper Le Figaro shut it down tonight in a strike to preserve their voice in its management.

Paul Mauriat, the French conductor and arranger whose recording of "Love Is Blue" made him a brief and extraordinary star of the pop music world last year, brought his orchestra to Philharmonic Hall last night as part of his first tour of the United States.

The Peoples Gas Company announced over the weekend that earnings in the year through March 31 were virtually unchanged from the comparable period a year earlier, although earnings in the six months through March declined.
MIXERS are whirring, ovens are hot, and many hands are kneading dough and shaping cookies in Brooklyn kitchens today.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) -- The Pentagon's research chief estimated today -- for the first time publicly -- that perhaps only one-tenth of the United States strategic missile force would survive a Soviet nuclear attack in 1975.

Nominating petitions of candidates for city offices must be filed by midnight tomorrow, and none of the declared hopefuls are anticipating any trouble in getting their lists of names certified by the Board of Elections.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 11 -- Governor Rockefeller conferred with President Nixon here this morning and then flew to Mexico City on the first of four fact-finding missions to Latin America. After the conference, the Governor and the President, with their advisers, appeared before newsmen on the lawn in front of Mr. Nixon's bungalow on Biscayne Bay.

Secretary of Labor Shultz has come forward with some interesting new ideas on how to break the long stalemate over extending to farm workers the union rights most other workers have had over thirty years.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 11 -- Malaysia's major political party has suffered its worst electoral setback since it led the nation to independence.
