The sit-down strikes of 1937 evoked all the charges of anarchy and irresponsibility that are being directed against student militants today.

ARMONK, N. Y., May 11 -- Steve Ross of Brooklyn won the 36th Westchester men's tennis championship for the second straight year by defeating John Buchman of Great Neck, L. I., 6-4, 6-4, in the final at the Armonk Club today.
JERUSALEM, May 11 -- The United Nations today moved its Suez Canal control center on the Israeli-held eastern bank from Qantara to a point beyond the range of Egyptian artillery.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 11 (UPI) -- The White House has a new chief usher to supervise the 172-room mansion and keep the 72-man household staff operating in top form, President Nixon's aides said today.
The controversy over Supreme Court Justice Abe Fortas's involvement with a $20,000 foundation fee has begun to engage all three branches of the Government.

LOS ANGELES, May 11 (UPI) -- Ten young black militants were arrested today after they interrupted services at the First Methodist Church of Los Angeles and one took the pulpit to demand that churches and synagogues donate $500-million in "reparations" to Negroes.

Multinational corporations, already shaping a new global economy, are ideally equipped to carry out needed world economic development, according to a report made for the Internatonal Chamber of Commerce.
The Band, which was first known as Bob Dylan's back-up group, spent Friday and Saturday cooly circulating mountain air through the Fillmore East, 105 Second Avenue.

FURIOUSLY storming down an Aqueduct corridor last week, one of the boycotting horsemen muttered, "it's a classic case of the bluebloods against the Italians and Jews." His remark was relayed to a jockey's agent, who dismissed it. "That guy is too sensitive. It's not ethnic, it's a class struggle."
Airlines are aware of the doting affection that pet owners bestow upon their animal companions and they are doing something about it.
George Schick, principal conductor of the Metropolitan Opera, its music consultant and the music director of the Metropolitan Opera Studio, has been named president of the Manhattan School of Music.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Francis Jennings of Quakertown, Pa., sent a letter to President Nixon last March opposing the Safeguard anti-ballistic missile system. The reply distressed Mr. Jennings greatly.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The American Foreign Service Association, professional society of the nation's career diplomats, gave warm endorsement today to the State Department reorganization drive started by Under Secretary Elliot L. Richardson.

ROME, May 12 -- Behind an unobtrusive metal plaque that says "Italian Association for Demographic Education," Italy's only birth-control clinic is beginning to attract attention and patients in the heart of Rome.

TAYNINH, South Vietnam, May 11 -- Since last August, when the enemy fought his way into the heart of this handsome provincial capital, Tayninh has been the focal point of some of the bitterest fighting in Vietnam.

James Meredith, the civil rights activist, was characterized as a slumlord in Bronx Criminal Court yesterday before a judge who issued a summons charging harassment of tenants in a Bronx apartment building he owns.

Joseph Hardy, director of "You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown!" and "Play It Again, Sam," will make his film directorial debut with "The Day They Shook the Plum Tree," Arthur H. Lewis's biography of Hetty Green, the eccentric penny-pinching millionaire.
JERUSALEM, May 12 -- Defense Minister Moshe Dayan warned tonight that Israel might have to take the offensive if the Arabs continued what he called their war of attrition.
Robert H. Finch, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, met with members of the Republican Boosters Club here yesterday to plan a fund-raising campaign for next year's Congressional elections.
The heart, liver and two kidneys of an unidentified donor were transplanted into four recipients at New York Hospital Sunday, the hospital disclosed yesterday.

CHARLESTON, S. C., May 12 -- Gov. Robert E. McNair moved the curfew that has crippled this troubled city's businesses back two hours to 11 P.M. today, as the 8-week-old strike of Negro hospital workers dragged on without any sign of a solution.

About 50 white and Negro seminarians took over Union Theological Seminary yesterday and shut it down in support of a black-militant group led by James Forman. The group demands that white churches and synagogues pay American Negroes $500-million in "reparations" for past injustices.

PRAGUE, May 12 -- Rude Pravo, the organ of the Communist party, criticized Czechoslovak journalists today for not actively endorsing a statement issued by the party Presidium last month upholding a number of prominent conservative politicians.
Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, lashed out last night at Negro militant students.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 12 -- Joseph Jacquesson, who is designated as being colored under South African law, and his English wife, Barbara, were acquitted today of charges of breaking South Africa's Immorality Act, which bars sexual relations across the color line.

Because intercollegiate row ing, at 117 years the oldest of the college sports, has yet to work out a way to establish a national champion, the Harvard and Pennsylvania crews are parties to an unresolved question -- which is better? The Crimson and the Red and Blue beat each other once this spring, Penn winning the Adams Cup and Harvard the Eastern Sprint title. They do not meet again.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -The White House released today an official accounting of President Nixon's assets and liabilities. The report placed his net worth at $596,900.

PARIS, May 12 -- The ten point "peace program" of the National Liberation Front raises in its sharpest form the question whether it is possible both to negotiate a settlement of the war in South Vietnam and to keep in power even a modified version of the present Saigon regime.

The J. C. Penney Company announced yesterday that a new, multipurpose, computerized information system developed by the General Electric Company would be used in some 50 Penney stores in the Los Angeles area.

BALTIMORE, May 12 -- Promise, a 4-year-old from the Locust Hill Farm, proved to be more than a high-class sprinter today when he came off a fast pace and won the $36,700 Jennings Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth at Pimlico.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- It would be nice if all the grown-ups who would like to put a boy in jail right this moment would take time out from writing angry letters to the editor and go to the movies to see "If..."

Jerre Gibson, an English-born violinist who now is a member of the New York City Opera orchestra, gave a recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall with David Garvey as pianist. As could be expected only from a seasoned professional, Miss Gibson's work rarely fell below minimum standards of competence.

WHEN Mrs. Carol Greitzer took her seat in the City Council last January, she became Manhattan's only elected woman official. But she didn't want to make a fuss about her sex. In fact, she even preferred the title "councilman."

JERSEY CITY, May 12 -- Democratic party leaders concluded today that because of the wide field tomorrow's election for Mayor could be so close that it would fail to produce a majority for Mayor Thomas J. Whelan.

Protesters at Queensborough Community College staged a brief sit-in yesterday at the college's library-administration building, where the police had to be called twice last week o remove demonstrators.
The organists in Chicago and St. Louis should have played "Sweet Georgia Brown" yesterday when Ferguson Jenkins and Bob Gibson pitched. It was a good day for Harlem Globetrotters.

The Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, Hartford, and the Connecticut National Bank, Bridgeport, attacked yesterday the action of the Justice Department last Friday in filing an antitrust suit to block their proposed merger.
SHORTLY after 9 A.M. yesterday, Dr. Joseph John Copeland stepped slowly past the glass doors of Room 300 in the administration building of City College.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., May 12 -- A plan to sell six acres of public parkland atop the lower Palisades in Hudson County for private high-rise apartments has aroused a storm of protest from conservationists and civic and planning leaders in the metropolitan New York area.
YONKERS, May 12 -- Dozens of students at Sarah Lawrence College began a sit-in here tonight at the office of the Institute for Community Studies.
SCRANTON, Pa., May 12 -- "He'll double your money" -- the magic words were as common as abandoned coal mines here in the Lackawanna River Valley.

IT IS, according to the Chinese calendar and the New York Shakespeare Festival, the Year of the Rooster. The rooster looked suspiciously like a peacock last night, but it was all in the name of charity -- so far.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 11 -- President Rafael Caldera, the first opposition leader to gain power democratically in Venezuela in 140 years of independence, has achieved an untroubled transition in his first eight weeks in office.

President Nixon was not responsible for the erroneous decision to subsidize the development of a supersonic passenger plane at a time when Government funds were sorely needed for programs of social welfare and private industry was capable of bearing the financial burden. But he now has an opportunity to undo a mistake and strike a blow for the more rational ordering of Federal spending priorities.
Giffen Industries, Inc., which bought 50 per cent of the stock of Keller Industries, Inc., for $50 - million in March, announced yesterday that it was seeking to have the purchase rescinded.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Attorney General John N. Mitchell confirmed today that he went to the Supreme Court last week to give Chief Justice Earl Warren information that the Justice Department has concerning Justice Abe Fortas.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy led a delegation of about 50 poor people through the halls of Congress today in a peaceful campaign for new welfare legislation and termination of the Vietnam war.
BERGDORF GOODMAN has closed its Custom Salon, which was the store's reason for coming into being in 1901.

PALO ALTO, Calif., May 12 -- A boycott of classes at Stanford University, called to support demands for ending war-related research on the 11,000-student Palo Alto campus and at the Stanford Research Institute, was termed "successful" today by boycott leaders.

A Defense Department appeal board has reversed a trial examiner and ruled that a former Communist who admitted party associations from 1933 to 1950 should be denied security clearance for "any level of classified defense information."

HONG KONG, May 12 -- Lin Piao, Communist China's Defense Minister, has been accorded new plaudits in the wake of the ninth congress of the Chinese Communist party, which affirmed that he should succeed Mao Tse-tung.

MOSCOW, May 12 -- The 11th of the 24-game world chess championship match series between the titleholder, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, and his fellow-countryman, Boris Spassky, was adjourned tonight at Moscow's Variety Theater in a position most favorable for the champion.

LUXEMBOURG, May 12 -- The foreign ministers of the Common Market agreed today that there was no use in talking about British entry into Europe Economic Community until after the elections in France and West Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Secretary Romney told Congress today that he saw preliminary signs that mortgage money might be becoming more abundant and less expensive, and therefore the country might move faster toward reducing its critical housing shortage.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Students at Howard University's School of Social Work threatened today to obtain an injunction to force their dean to meet with them.
ATHENS, May 12 -- One of 16 Greeks charged with sedition caused an uproar in the Athens special military court today by charging that prosecution witnesses had tortured him.
A helicopter has been hired to do some spring planting on about 100 acres in the Bronx at daybreak today.
Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz warned labor and management yesterday against collective - bargaining policies based on the assumption that inflation will contniue at its present high rate.

If there was any undercurrent of feuding or dissatisfaction at Aqueduct yesterday, it certainly was of no concern to the race-going public. As far as the New York fans were concerned, they demonstrated a willingness to restore the troubled thorough-bred situation to the way it was before the boycott.
The election of George H. Heyman Jr. as president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York was announced yesterday by the organization's board of trustees.

Bernard J. Lasker, senior partner of E. H. Stern Co., was elected chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday for a one-year term. His nomination for the position had been announced previously.
MOSCOW, May 12 -- In Podarki, a gift store on Gorky Street, about 100 women were waiting patiently the other day for a new shipment of wicker handbags to go on sale.

OTTAWA, May 12 (Canadian Press) -- Abolition of the reserve clause in National Hockey League contracts, by legislation if necessary, was among the recommendations made today in a report of the Federal Government's task force on sports.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -The Treasury disclosed today that it would ask Congress to authorize production of non-silver half-dollars and dollars, thus ending all silver coinage but restoring those almost vanished coins to circulation.
CAIRO, May 12 -- A dispute flared today between Cairo's leading newspapers Al Gomhouria and Al Ahram, over the publication of the memoirs of Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, World War II Soviet commander.

A Columbia University senior who alleges that he was clubbed by policemen while standing in the dormitory lobby during the police raid last May is suing the university trustees and the city for $1.5-million each.
Stock prices moved through a session of orderly profit taking yesterday as volume slowed markedly to 10.55 million shares from Friday's pace of 12.53 million shares.
Theodore T. Boutis has been elected vice president-corporate controller at Revlon, Inc.

In passing a measure that would provide $15 million of direct aid to church-related colleges and universities, the New York Legislature violated the State Constitution and ignored the electorate's recent reaffirmation of the prohibition against subsidizing religious institutions with public funds.
More than 35,000 passengers aboard 50 Long Island Rail Road commuter trains were delayed an average of 45 minutes last evening at the height of the line's homebound rush hour.
MILWAUKEE, May 12 -- Thirteen of the so-called Milwaukee 14 -- a group of men, including seven clergymen, who burned draft records last Sept. 24 -- went on trial in Circuit Court today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 12 -- The Italian Blue Team is strongly favored here to retain its world title, for it is playing much more convincingly than its rivals. Italy held a commanding lead at the half-way stage in the qualifying competition, and the only question seems to be who their opponents will be in the final match.

DAYTON, Ohio, May 12 -- The American intelligence community now has reason to "doubt most seriously" its earlier assumption that the Soviet Union was merely trying to pull even with the United States in land-based strategic missiles, according to the Pentagon's chief scientist.
Suzanne Farrell, the New York City Ballet ballerina, said yesterday that she had resigned from the company.

MIAMI, May 12 -- The Castro Government is rapidly expanding the membership of the Communist party of Cuba. At the same time, the party's base structure, especially in the rural areas, is being overhauled.
A plan for expanding Kennedy International Airport into Jamaica Bay has been reactivated with wider dimensions and has been winning broad quiet backing from airline and government aviation officials.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The first year of the Vietnam negotiations in Paris ended today with the ground war in South Vietnam persisting and the central political issues just being joined.

NEW DELHI, May 12 -- The Home Minister, Y. B. Chavan, began a series of talks with Opposition leaders in Parliament today on a revived proposal to ban a recently formed Communist party, the third in India, and other movements that advocate violence.
The Anaconda Company and Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company joined yesterday the copper price increase of 2 cents a pound initiated last week by competitors.

STONY BROOK, L. I., Tuesday, May 13 -- Eighteen students, many of them freshmen. were arrested at the campus of the State University here on indictments handed up by a Suffolk County grand jury investigating drug use.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Five members of Students for a Democratic Society were arrested today during a scuffle with policemen and firemen who had forcibly entered the organization's national headquarters in response to anonymous false reports of a fire and shooting there.

The 44th annual dinner of the Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in Brooklyn will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria on Sunday. David Minikin is chairman of the event, which will benefit the children's progress program at the center and honor five Kingsbrook supporters.
LONDON, May 12 -- The British pound made a flashy come back in the foreign-exchange markets today, soaring half a cent to close at $2.3876.

ZURICH, May 12 -- Funds flowed out of West Germany today as European currency markets responded to the Bonn Government's decision not to raise the value of the mark and to the weekend action of central bankers from 11 nations to "recycle," or redirect, flows of "hot money" to the countries of origin.

The statement of the case against the Safeguard ABM system, prepared at the request of Senator Edward Kennedy by a group of scientists and scholars, contains some important new technical data, but, above all, it makes available in compact form virtually all the key facts and arguments against immediate ABM deployment. These have been emerging piecemeal in recent months. Put together, they make impressive reading.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 13 -- North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops struck throughout South Vietnam yesterday with the largest number of attacks since the Lunar New Year offensive of February, 1968.
BERLIN, May 12 -- Frank L. Howley, a retired brigadier general, American commandant here during the airlift 20 years ago, told workers this morning that German-American friendship would last forever.
The American Bankers Association called on its members yesterday to help control inflation by tightening their lending policies.

PARIS, May 12 -- Interim President Alain Poher today announced his candidacy in the French presidential election in June, thus transforming it into a contest between him and Georges Pompidou, former Premier and the Gaullist candidate.

" THE thing about Geoffrey is he manages to be commercial and creative at the same time," a rival designer said recently. It was the highest accolade he could give Geoffrey Beene whose high-waisted paper doll silhouette has become his signature and wildly popular.
A bill to give elderly homeowners a 50 per cent reduction in real-estate taxes is expected to be approved by the City Council today after being on the shelf since 1966 as too costly.

MANILA, May 12 -- The Philippine Government disclosed today that it would seek improvements in the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization and resist any effort to dismantle the 15-year-old regional defense alliance.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- Otto F. Otepka denied today any connection with the John Birch Society or the Liberty Lobby and said he realized the dangers of totalitarianism of either the right or the left.
LISBON, May 12 -- Portugal has decided to open Western Angola to diamond exploration and has granted the first concession to an American-backed company.

The trustees of the Cyrus H. K. Curtis estate nominated four additional men yesterday for election to the board of the Curtis Publishing Company. The estate is the holder of more than 32 per cent of the common stock of Curtis and is conducting a proxy contest for control of the company.
DETROIT, May 12 -- G.M. Corvair, the most controversial car of the decade, died today after a long illness, at the age of 10.

HONG KONG, May 12 -- Communist China has accepted a Soviet proposal for a meeting of the joint Commission for Navigation on Boundary Rivers and suggested that it be held in the middle of June in Khabarovsk.
Clashes with the police yesterday on the Brooklyn College campus resulted in the arrests of two students. A policeman and two other students were injured.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Tuesday, May 13 (UPI) -- The countdown was under way today for the three Apollo 10 astronauts. It began on schedule at midnight.

Two Republican mayoral candidates, John J. Marchi and Vito P. Battista, have scheduled a joint news conference for this morning amid indications that they intend to merge on a single ticket in an effort to defeat Mayor Lindsay in the Republican primary June 17.

Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Finch performed a useful service when he dissociated himself from the efforts of other high-ranking Administration officials to discredit the Head Start program. The controversy that had developed out of the extremely dubious conclusions of a preliminary report on Head Start's effectiveness was as destructive of the goals of compensatory education for disadvantaged children as it was unnecessary.

PARIS, May 12 -- The renewal of large-scale enemy attacks in South Vietnam was regarded here today as motivated, at least in part, by a desire to show that the Vietcong's 10-point peace plan was not a sign of military exhaustion.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction, from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
IT was on Feb. 21, 1962, at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, that Dame Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev first danced together. The ballet was "Giselle" and the occasion was dance history.
ALBANY, May 12 -- Governor, Rockefeller has signed legislation mandating full-time service from District Attorneys in all countries with more than 100,000 people.

WERE they, or weren't they? That was the question as Sam Vine, hypnotists, set 21 volunteers to cutting up last night at the Lyceum Theater at a level of exuberance that hasn't been attained since my Uncle Nick's New Year's Eve parties. Or your Cousin Sadie's.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Total business inventories rose $1-billion in March, bringing the first-quarter increase to $2.6-billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

BARNSTABLE, Mass., May 8 -- Taisto Ranta, the soft-spoken Finn who is fish and game and beach officer for the Town of Barnstable on Cape Cod and who had labored long and diligently to restore the annual spring run of alewives in the Marstons Mills River to its former glory, has what appears to be a splendid idea for a home-made smoking device for alewives and other delicacies of the sea.

MEXICO CITY, May 12 -- Governor Rockefeller and his advisers listened today to an impressive array of Cabinet members, bankers, economists and industrialists who argued for preferential treatment for Mexico.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, reported today that he received $300 for delivering a commencement address at the University of Tennessee last Aug. 24.

City Controller Mario A. Procaccino and Borough President Herman Badillo of the Bronx added a little heat to the campaign for the Democratic mayoral nomination yesterday charging each other with irresponsibility and the waging of campaigns designed to appeal to base motives.
ROME, May 12 (AP) -- The Vatican's weekly newspaper says that "the church has not taken halos from any of its saints."
Volume backed down yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as prices weakened.

SEATTLE, May 12 -- Bobby Murcer's two-run homer, followed by a seven-run first inning for the Seattle Pilots, followed by a lively brawl growing out of Marty Pattin's pitch close to Murcer's head were the highlights of Seattle's 8-4 victory over the New York Yankees tonight.

The St. Joseph Lead Company expects that earnings this year will be "satisfactory and above the 1968 level," Lawrason Riggs 3d, president and chief executive officer, told the annual meeting here yesterday.

No dental care for hundreds of thousands of schoolchildren. Libraries closing. Plans to drop free lunches for 165,000 school-children. And this in the richest city in the richest nation in the world. Indeed, the time is out of joint.

CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 12 (UPI) -- Musical Mary, a 2-year-old daughter of Spy Song in her second start, made it two victories in a row at Garden State Park today by winning the $6,000 feature race by a length.
Construction costs across the country in the year ended April 30 spurted 4 per cent above the level of the preceding 12 months in one of the sharpest increases in a decade.
WHEN you own shares in a corporation, your primary concern is how much the company is earning, and, as a fractional owner of the corporation, you want to know the earnings on a per-share basis.

MASON, Mich., May 12 (UPI) -- The prosecution argued today, at a hearing in the first Algiers Motel murder trial, that a former Detroit patrolman's statements should be admitted in evidence against him when the trial proper begins.

BONN, May 12 -- Gunter Diehl, chief spokesman for the West German Government, stressed today the country's "readiness to act in solidarity" with Western Governments that had undergone "difficulties" because of the massive transfer of currency reserves to West Germany.
" DE SADE ILLUSTRATED," a sort of trade show for sexual-gymnast enthusiasts, opened last night at the Bouwerie Lane Theater. It was a two-act play that alternated between spoof and ennui.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -The White House announced today that President Nixon would deliver a televised report to the nation Wednesday night on "the prospects for peace in Vietnam."

YOKOHAMA, Japan, May 12 (Reuters) -- An American housewife set sail today for San Diego, Calif., in a 31-foot Fiberglas boat in an effort to become the first woman to sail alone across the Pacific nonstop.
The Gannett Company, which has doubled its earnings in the last five years, hopes to continue the trend in the next five, Paul Miller, president, told the annual meeting yesterday in Rochester.

Robert Anderson has been elected executive vice president of the North American Rockwell Corporation, the company announced over the weekend. There has been no such company post for some five years and Mr. Anderson's election was widely regarded as the first step in his ascendancy to the presidency.
The annual Military Banquet and Ball, commemorating Armed Forces Day, will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton on Saturday.

CLEVELAND, May 12 -- Fred (Ahmed) Evans, a self-styled black nationalist, was found guilty today of seven counts of first-degree murder arising out of four slayings in the city's Glenville area last July 23.

YOU must hack your way through a thicket of pieties to get at Flannery O'Connor's special grace. A recent critical study of her fiction, published by Vanderbilt University Press, went so far as to suggest that she could only be appreciated by readers with "an orthodox understanding of Christocentric religion."
Trading was light and prices were depressed yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. Brokers observed it was the quietest Monday in weeks.

I have just noticed in the April 6 issue of The Times the senseless accusations of C. L. Sulzberger, who maintains that 36 ships suspected of carrying arms and ammunition touched at Sihanoukville and that fourteen Russian and Chinese ships unloaded 14,367 tons of war material, while the needs of the forces of the Royal Khmer Army do not exceed 400 tons a year.
PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP) -- Bob Brown, an all-pro offensive tackle for the Philadelphia Eagles, was sent to the Los Angeles Rams in a five-player deal today.

The foreign exchange markets calmed here yesterday in the wake of West Germany's decision on Friday not to raise the value of the mark and that of central bankers over the weekend to encourage recycling of speculative money.

The Rev. Milton A. Galamison has asked the Board of Education to order the appointment of 14 locally selected persons to supervisory positions in a state-funded Ocean Hill-Brownsville community education project over the objections of School Superintendent Bernard E. Donovan.
TRENTON, May 12 -- A November referendum on lowering New Jersey's voting age from 21 to 18 years of age was approved tonight by the Assembly's Republican majority caucus.

In discussing the efficacy of ABM's, we have tended to overlook one critical point. It is generally agreed that the proposed Safeguard system would be only marginally effective against a large scale and well-coordinated Soviet missile attack, but might perform quite well against either a future Chinese strike or a weak, scattered, and disorganized Soviet strike.

Four armed men, using a chemical spray to blind their victims momentarily, robbed two armored-car guards in an elevator in the Abraham Straus department store in Brooklyn yesterday and escaped with $350,000 in bills.

Young Rubicam's "Give A Damn" campaign for the New York Urban Coalition continued its winning streak last night at the industry's poshest awards ceremony -- the annual American Television and Radio Commercials Festival.
A book Norman Mailer plans to start in July, dealing with man's first landing on the moon already has drawn close to $1-million in advance royalties, his literary agent reported yesterday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 12 -- A political encounter between Lebanon and the Palestinian commandos ended here today.
Bill Free's year-old agency has landed the $8-million National Airlines account. He doesn't get the business offically until Aug. 1 but by yesterday afternoon he was already flying.

Emile Griffith advanced last night toward a fourth middle-weight title bout with Nino Benvenuti, but Johnny Persol's career possibly ended and Willie Munoz's potential again was clouded in a boxing triple-header at Madison Square Garden.
Mario A. Procaccino has made it "abundantly clear" that "safety in the streets and and security in the home" is the overriding issue facing New York.

LONDON, May 12 -- A British stage hand at the Aldwych Theater, where New York's Negro Ensemble Company is performing during the "World Theater Season," was puzzled why the American national anthem was not being played before the first act.
MEMPHIS, May 12 (AP) -- Justice Abe Fortas, here today for a speech, was asked on his way to the platform whether he could pause a moment to answer a few questions.
The $20-billion Chase Manhattan Bank has started a drive to license its Uni-Card credit card to other banks.
The house and garden tour, a favorite way of raising funds for charity during the spring months, is a prominent feature of the social calendar for the next few weeks.
Structures seemingly identical to oil-bearing salt domes have been discovered thrusting upward through sediments beneath almost three miles of water in the Atlantic Ocean.

TOKYO, May 12 -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans met with members of the Japanese Cabinet today and reportedly indicated that Washington would insist that quotas be imposed on Japanese textile exports to the United States.
Brazil and Yugoslavia advanced in Davis Cup tennis yesterday, ousting Colombia and France, respectively, by identical 3-2 scores.

Silver futures declined yesterday in New York commodity trading, although action by the Treasury to increase the availability of the metal was not announced until after the close of the session. The May delivery, for example, finished at $1.74 6/10 an ounce, down from $1.78 3/10.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- A bill to give the Government a greater role in operating Howard University was introduced in the House today as classes resumed at the predominantly Negro institution for all but liberal arts students fallowing last week's violence on the campus.

FAYETTE, Miss., May 12 -- After a day of campaigning, 17-year-old Calvin Reed sat with friends in the shade of a pecan tree and watched the scores of people across Highway 61 milling about the "Charles Evers for Mayor Campaign Headquarters" in the Medgar Evers Memorial Shopping Center.

More than 120 chiefs of services in the 20 municipal hospitals threatened to resign yesterday unless the $36-million that the city ordered cut from the Hospitals Department's requested budget was restored.
A Highland piper will pipe in guests at the first annual Canadian Universities Ball Saturday at the Plaza.

The Williams Brothers Company, Tulsa-based engineers, builders and operators of pipelines here and abroad, increased first-quarter earnings by $6-million on revenues which were four times greater than those of the corresponding three months last year. The company also announced yesterday a two-for one stock split.

ST. LOUIS, May 12 -- The students and faculty of Washington University have voted by a substantial margin to retain courses in the Reserve Officers Training Corps program in some form at the university. However, most appear to favor dropping it as a credit course.

Hugh Shannon has created a one-man show for the May 22 dinner dance at the Rainbow Room that will benefit the Preventive Medicine Institute-Strang Clinic. The singer-pianist is donating his services for the evening.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- Secretary of Housing George Romney was booed today when he urged 3,000 union delegates to end practices that increased building costs and denied construction jobs to Negroes.
Three million dollars worth of stock certificates have been missing for at least a week from the Chemical Bank, it was disclosed yesterday.
Seventy years ago, quarrymen were clawing away at the Palisades of the Hudson and sending the traprock down to the city in barges to help build bridges, houses, office buildings and sidewalks.
Interest rates -- from short-term Treasury bills to the new intermediate maturity corporate bonds to long-term tax-exempts -- climbed sharply yesterday.
A broken brake line on a 10-car subway train touched off a 75-minute revolt by 1,000 Brooklyn commuters on the BMT'S Canarsie Line during yesterday morning's rush hour.
Joe Healey, the track and field coach at New York University, provoked a round of laughter yesterday at the Metropolitan Track Writers Association luncheon at Mamma Leone's.

JOHANNESBURG, May 12 -The last South African diamond empire, De Beers Consolidated Mines, Ltd., had a record profit of almost $148-million last year. Sales of diamonds through a central selling organization reached a record $600-million dollars.
The board of directors of Armour Co., the meat packer, approved yesterday a previously proposed six-man executive committee of the board at a meeting in Chicago.

Both President Calvin Plimpton of Amherst and Professor George Wald of Harvard bid the nation do essentially the same thing -- "to face effectively, massively and persistently the major social and foreign problems of our society."
The New York Mets, who open a three-game series tonight against the Atlanta Braves at Shea Stadium, received another piece of unpleasant news about their youthful pitching staff yesterday.
John C. Lobb has resigned as executive vice president of Colt Industries, Inc., the company announced yesterday.

DUBLIN, May 12 -- Charles de Gaulle was outmaneuvered on Kerry Beach this evening by newsmen and photographers who caught up with him and shot picture after picture as he walked a half mile back to his car.

University officials are not entirely to blame for letting campus disruptions get out of hand. According to research news reports the city police will not move onto college property without explicit instructions from college administrators.

POCONO MANOR, Pa., May 12 -- The nation's tanker operators face a minimum investment of $1.2-billion for the construction of six million tons of shipping by 1980, Dr. James S. Cross, Sun Oil Company economist, said today.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 12 -- Henry Carr, once the world's fastest human at 200 meters, a former Olympic gold medal winner and now a professional football player, is confident that on Thursday night he will duplicate Jesse Owens's 1948 achievement of outracing a pacer.
LONDON, May 12 -- Prime Minister Wilson today postponed introduction of his Government's controversial legislation to curb wildcat strikes.

WHEN Art Modell first began to suspect that his Cleveland Browns might become caught in the shuffle of three National Football League teams to the American League, his quiescent ulcer began to kick up. So he never did make the marathon meeting over the last weekend but landed instead in Doctors Hospital, keeping in touch with the situation by telephone.

Dr. Joseph J. Copeland, the new acting president of City College, and faculty leaders agreed yesterday to a formula aimed at paving the way for resumption of stalled negotiations with black and Puerto Rican student protesters.
LONE STAR, Tex., May 12 (AP) -- The violence-marked strike of 2,700 employes of the Lone Star Steel Company was at an end today as workers prepared to return to their jobs after nearly seven months.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 12 -- Syria's Chief of Staff, Maj. Gen. Mustafa Tlas, departed by air for Peking at the head of a military delegation.
GUATEMALA, May 13 -- Governor Rockefeller conferred with President Julio Cesar Mendez Montenegro at the National Palace today after arriving from Mexico.

When the New Haven Symphony performed Mahler's First Symphony last year in the five-movement form that included the recently unearthed "Blumine" movement, the question that arose in many minds was whether the grafting operation would succeed.

The failure of Justice Abe Fortas to make a candid and comprehensive statement of his financial dealings with convicted industrialist Louis Wolfson is piling up fresh embarrassments for the judge and the Supreme Court. Now the Nixon Administration has found a way to make this bad situation much worse through an excursion into slander by indirection.
Supreme Court Justice Irwin D. Davidson yesterday enjoined members of the Intermediate School 201 complex Governing Board and others from interfering with operation of Public School 39 in Harlem.
Rajat Neogy, the editor of Transition magazine who was released from prison in Uganda last month, has arrived here to give a series of lectures on African writing and nationalism.

Union Theological Seminary resumed normal operations yesterday after a 24-hour occupation of the administration building by 50 white and Negro students Monday that shut down the interdenominational Protestant institution.

JERSEY CITY, May 13 -- The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company moved a giant step further into the nontobacco field today when its common and preferred shareholders at separate meetings here voted to approve the acquisition of McLean Industries, Inc.

DETROIT, May 13 -- New car sales in early May set a record for the period with 257,490 United States - made deliveries reported today, an increase of 2 per cent from the 252,848 sales reported a year ago.

The Security National Bank, an $850-million institution based in Huntington, L. I., is hoding merger negotiations with the Kings Lafayette Corporation, a one-bank holding company listed on the American Stock Exchange.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 13 -- A committee convened by the Rutgers College dean of students to investigate a racial brawl at the Lamda Chi Alpha fraternity house last month has charged that white students exhibited "pervasive overtones of racism."

Avco Embassy Pictures has added a record producing company, Avco Embassy Records. The new wholly owned subsidiary will be supervised by Hugo Peretti and Luigi Creatore, it was announced yesterday by Joseph E. Levine, who heads Avco Embassy.

Piping Rock and Somerset Hills became district champions as the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches were completed in two districts yesterday. The winner of the Westchester district won't be decided until Thursday.

Borough President Herman Badillo of the Bronx said yesterday that the creation of a qualified, well-balanced interim board of education was endangered because of the failure of Mayor Lindsay and the City Council to determine the pay of members and whether they should serve full or part time.

DULUTH, Minn., May 13 -- Federal officials recommended today that an iron mining company's daily discharge of 60,000 tons of ore waste into Lake Superior be kept "under continuing surveillance" rather than stopped, as some officials and conservationists had urged.
The Bell Jet Ranger helicopter, a large hook dangling from its belly, caught up the bag and, like a giant insect, swept across the field in a trail of dust.
" It's like offering a bull in bear's clothing," a broker said yesterday commenting on the Treasury's silver proposals, which followed the Monday meeting of the Commission on the Coinage.

Attempts to bring black and Puerto Rican students to the bargaining table at City College reached a new impasse yesterday as Dr. Joseph J. Copeland, the college's acting president, rejected a faculty resolution calling for the removal of the police from the troubled campus.
" Embrace Tiger and Return to Mountain," as everyone knows, is the 17th position in a series of 37 exercises of the T'ai Chi, a system of Chinese shadow-boxing developed in the sixth century.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Army officials at Fort Bragg, N. C., said today that a soldier who is a militant organizer of antiwar sentiment would be allowed under strict limitations to distribute literature to troops at the post.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 13 -- About the only thing that was accomplished at the annual meeting of Roosevelt Raceway, Inc., here today was stockholder approval of the company's auditors for the coming year.

The Austro-Hungarian empire before World War I was an unusual melange of burger proprieties and Slavic passion. Arnold Schoenberg reflected it perfectly in his orchestration of Brahms's first piano quartet, and George Balanchine translated that into a masterful ballet modestly entitled "Brahms-Schoenberg Quartet."
CAPETOWN, May 13 (Reuters) -- South Africa today released Robert M. Sobukwe, a former leader of the black underground, after having held him for six years without trial.
Time magazine will be giving away more than $2-million worth of advertising space in an effort to get the creative crowd in agencies to think more about print, print, print.

BOSTON, May 13 (UPI) -- Some 40 students led by Students for a Democratic Society took over a second-floor meeting room today at Northeastern University, the largest privately endowed university in the nation, in support of demands to end the Reserve Officers Training Corps program.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 13 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan today refused to support plans of the Army Corps of Engineers for the Dos Rios Dam on the Eel River.

MASON, Mich., May 13 (AP) -- A circuit judge ruled today that a controversial statement made by a former Detroit policeman in the "Algiers Motel case" will be admitted into evidence before a jury in his trial for the murder of one of three Negroes at a motel during Detroit's riots in 1967.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Senator Joseph D. Tydings, a leader last summer in the effort to win confirmation for Abe Fortas as Chief Justice, called upon him today to resign from the Supreme Court.

BATON ROUGE, La., May 17 (AP) -- Students throwing firebombs, rocks and bottles drew police tear gas and a few shotgun blasts at Southern University today. The police originally said they had been fired upon during the uproar but later said this had not been confirmed.

WHEN a group of professional football owners was having an informal discussion some time ago as to how the teams might be juggled in future restructuring, a point was mentioned by Wellington Mara, president of the New York Giants.

MONTREAL, May 13 (UPI) -- Clarence Campbell, president of the National Hockey League, rejected today a sports task force recommendation that the N.H.L. abandon its player-reserve clause, but agreed to some modifications in the standard players' contract and to breaking ties with amateur hockey.
Najeeb E. Halaby, the president of Pan American World Airways, outlined five steps yesterday that he contended were essential if New York was to cope with the growth of air traffic.
To State Senator John J. Marchi, who seeks the Republican mayoral nomination, the most urgent challenge facing City Hall is "to restore some kind of tranquillity in the life of the people."

The proposed conversion of 50 rental apartment houses here to cooperative ownership has been ordered suspended by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz because he believes the new rent stabilization law does not offer sufficient protection to tenants.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Otto F. Otepka, demoted State Department security officer, easily won today Senate Judiciary Committee approval of his nomination to the Subversive Activities Control Board.

The Board of Education passed a controversial resolution last night directing School Superintendent Bernard E. Donovan to bypass the Board of Examiners and to process as quickly as possible 14 supervisory appointments for the Ocean Hill-Brownsville Community Education Center.

The alliance of John J. Marchi and Vito P. Battista on a right-of-center unity ticket in this year's city elections is seen by many politicians as the official beginning of a new city Republican party -- a party linked with the Conservative party and led by generally conservative legislators and district leaders from outside Manhattan.

The shadow of merger, familiar to the financial world, is beginning to fall across the American symphony orchestra scene. At least four important orchestras are discussing consolidation of playing forces, and others have begun moving toward a regional, rather than city, orientation.

SEATTLE, May 13 -- A major line-up shift, which put Bobby Murcer in right field and Jerry Kenney at third base, could not keep the New York Yankees from losing again tonight, nor Mel Stottlemyre from a disappointing defeat in his first home-area appearance before a record crowd of 19,072. The score was 5-3.
The city has voiced its opposition to Channel 13's having a year-long exclusive option on programs produced by National Educational Television.
Balletomanes will honor Dame Margot Fonteyn at a champagne reception that will give the Royal Academy of Dancing (in America), Inc., a firmer footing in New York.

TOKYO, May 13 -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans said today that he was "disappointed" with his mission to Japan, after the Japanese Government had flatly rejected a proposal to establish voluntary quotas on textile exports to the United States.
Mayor Lindsay visited neighborhoods in Queens again yesterday and conceded that he faces a "difficult struggle" in winning the Republican mayoral nomination on June 17.

I too must raise my voice in protest over the outrageous events at Riverside Church on May 4. However, the outrage was perpetrated not by James Forman, but by the ministers and worshipers of Riverside, who were more concerned with the "dignity" of worship than with hearing and responding to the voice of the poor and oppressed.

IN 1963, as Prince Abdul Rahman completed the delicate task of fusing rival ethnic factions and sprawling territories into the Federation of Malaysia, he described his goal as "a happy Malaysia, at peace with itself."

Our orchestras do not need to worry about where the next generation of musicians is coming from. Last night the National Orchestra and Chorus of an organization called American Youth Performs gave a concert in Carnegie Hall.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 13 (UPI) -- Pfc. Harold C. Vennemann, drafted despite being the father of four children, won a last minute reprieve today from his scheduled departure for Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Army reassured Congress today that it would not go ahead with its plan to ship 27,000 tons of surplus war gas for disposal in the Atlantic Ocean until it was reviewed by the National Academy of Sciences.
FRANKFURT, West Germany, May 13 -- Currency markets acted today as if Europe's monetary crisis was not yet over.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 13 -- Nassau County District Attorney William Cahn asserted today that two reputed organized-crime figures had received preferential treatment over that accorded President Nixon by the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan.
YONKERS, May 13 -- A black student scuffled briefly with a white student at Sarah Lawrence College today during a sit-in demonstration by Negro students at the liberal arts college for girls.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Following is the text of the message on the draft submitted to Congress today by President Nixon:

NEWARK, May 13 -- Rabbi Joachim Prinz, the head of the governing council of the World Jewish Congress and a longtime civil rights advocate, was the intended victim of a $5,000 extortion plot by Black Panthers, the police said today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 14 -- Enemy troops shelled Danang, South Vietnam's second largest city, this morning, keeping the pitch of the war at a high level.

Seventeen Negro and Puerto Rican students at Brooklyn College were arrested at their homes early yesterday on a 23-count indictment charging arson conspiracing to commit arson, and other criminal acts on the college's Flatbush campus.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A high Administration source suggested today that the Federal Reserve Board would probably have to tighten credit somewhat further if there were no signs of slowing in the economy by July.
An executive of the General Electric Company suggested yesterday that employers had better demonstrate a "stiffer backbone" in labor negotiations to combat inflation.

Expanded powers for the city's 62 community planning boards were voted yesterday by a City Council committee. The group's action was designed to combat the sense that the community has no control over the city government.

An author, two magazine writers, two newspapermen and two television producers received yesterday the $500 awards of the Sidney Hillman Foundation, named in honor of the late president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.

Every second Sunday, Aram Kevorkian climbs into his car, drives 10 minutes through light Sunday traffic and catches the 5 P.M. shuttle. The next Tuesday it's just the reverse, only then he catches the 9:45 coming back. The trip is 3,500 miles and takes eight hours.

IF anyone saw an elephant wandering around East 13th Street last night, it was the work of The Great Baltzer. You see, he had to get the elephant off the stage of the Mercury Theater to have room to solve a murder.

BALTIMORE, May 13 (AP) -- Trainer George Mohr withdrew once-beaten Irish Course today from Friday's $30,000-added Black Eyed Susan Stakes when he learned that Process Shot would be entered in the Pimlico race.

NEWTON, Mass., May 13 (UPI) -- Fifty students held the administration building at Newton-Andover Theological Seminary today while the all-white board of trustees planned to meet and consider demands for adding Negroes to the board.

An influential 7,000-member citizens' group that has been working closely with the city's Department of Air Resources in trying to control pollution charged yesterday that "enforcement of air-pollution-control laws in New York City is in a state of collapse."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 13 (AP) -- Editors of the Harvard Lampoon, university humor magazine, have chosen "The Lion in Winter," which won three Oscars, as the "worst movie of the year."

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Representatives of the poor sat down today with President Nixon and his leading advisers for a White House meeting that generated disappointment on one side and bewilderment on the other.
CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 13 (AP) -- Five horses perished today when a fire swept through a stable at Garden State Park.

President Nixon's televised report tonight on "the prospects for peace in Vietnam" bears on the subject that interests the country most. For almost four months, the President's strategy for ending the war in Southeast Asia has been a subject for conjecture, debate and, more recently, sharp criticism -- without a clear statement ever having been made as to what that strategy is.
GEOFFREY BEENE showed a dress Monday with a neckline that was cut below the waist in back. Yesterday Jacques Tiffeau beat him at his own game. He showed one that was cut below the waist in front.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Following is the 52-to-40 rollcall vote by which the Senate rejected today the resolution by Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat o California, calling on President Nixon to delay shutting down 59 Job Corps Centers:
Genesco, Inc., achieved record sales in the third fiscal quarter ended April 30, Franklin M. Jarman, president, reported yesterday. Net income advanced slightly although per-share earnings declined.

LONDON, May 13 -- London's latest permanent troupe -- John Neville's Park Theater Company -- moved into the Fortune Theater this week with a piece by that inveterate punster, Henry Livings, called "Honour and Offer."
Best Turn didn't win the feature at Aqueduct yesterday, but the Calumet Farm colt may have run well enough to earn himself a berth in Saturday's $150,000-added Preakness.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Justice Abe Fortas faced enormous pressure today to decide whether to resign from the Supreme Court or to try, tenaciously and almost alone, to rescue a brilliant legal career.

The New York Philharmonic's fifth season of free concerts in city parks will be given this summer from July 29 through Aug. 22. Three performances each will be offered in Manhattan and Brooklyn and two each in the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island.
Stocks moved ahead in active trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan announced yesterday that he would retire in 1972 as Episcopal Bishop of New York. He called for the immediate election of his successor.
LONDON, May 13 -- Another disheartening deficit in Britain's overseas trade was reported today by the Government.

GENEVA, May 13 -- Taking a stand midway between Soviet and American proposals, Canada said today that there should be a ban on all undersea weapons, military activities, bases or fortifications from which military action could be undertaken.

The initial, but often misleading indicator represented in the filing of petitions saw former Robert F. Wagner's supporters submit 59,320 signatures to the Board of Elections yesterday in his bid for the Democratic nomination for Mayor. Seven other candidates also filed for the June 17 primary.

Musical versions of Lorraine Hansberry's "A Raisin in the Sun," the New York Drama Critics Circle's prize play of 1959, and "Georgy Girl," the British film that starred Lynn Redgrave, are headed for Broadway next season.

BONN, May 13 -- After two decades of effort Bonn won the right today to annex 10 neighboring towns and villages so that the enlarged community will be able to carry out urban planning more effectively.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 -- Trustees of Stanford University decided today to sever ties between the university and its affiliate, the Stanford Research Institute.

Interior Secretary Walter J. Hickel flew here yesterday to announce an immediate start on detailed plans for a bistate "gateway national recreational area" incorporating Jamaica Bay and Breezy Point, Queens, and Sandy Hook, N. J.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The two largest organizations representing the nation's mayors and cities announced today they would consolidate their staffs under one roof, a move expected to strengthen urban interests.

THE people who will like "My Daughter, Your Son" most will, at a guess, be those who confuse television with entertainment. For this play by Phoebe and Henry Ephron is so like a few episodes from a television series that fans of that medium might well receive the cozy impression that they hadn't even left home.
Initial work on the proposed $60-million consolidated passenger terminal along "luxury liner row" on the Hudson is still being held up pending the outcome of litigation brought by opponents.
ALBANY, May 13 (UPI) -- The number of child abuse cases reported to the State Department of Social Services jumped 30 per cent last year.
Nine meet records were set, three by Poly Prep, in the 16th annual Fieldston Relays yesterday at the Fieldston School in the Bronx. Twenty-six schools took part in the meet.

In the dressing room he shared with Johnny Persol at Monday night's triple-header at Madison Square Garden, he heard a voice call "Main event," but before he departed, he hugged the light heavyweight who had arrived there several minutes earlier, his vision blurred.

Gary Gentry got his first look at the Atlanta Braves last night in Shea Stadium, and found out what all the chatter had been about back in grammar school.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Nixon accepted today the resignation of Lee C. White as chairman of the Federal Power Commission. No successor was immediately named.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 5 -- A loose coalition of students, politicians and clergymen is pressing the Government either to release political prisoners who have been in Paraguayan prisons for a decade or more or to bring them to trial.

Pete Rozelle, the commissioner, said yesterday that he was pleased and even surprised by the nationwide reactions to pro-football's realignment that will shift the Baltimore, Cleveland and Pittsburgh teams from National to American League membership in 1970.

HANOVER, N. H., May 13 -- The Dartmouth College disciplinary committee decided today that 39 students arrested last week for seizing the administration building could continue their studies until their individual cases could be heard by the college.

An intricate undercover police operation designed to break up a ring that allegedly kidnapped underworld figures for ransom ended last night in a wild hail of gunfire at a desolate parking lot near the Bronx approach to the Whitestone Bridge.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 13 -- The American team kept alive its faint hopes of winning the 1969 world championship title when it defeated the Italian world champions, 16-4, in a qualifying round match today.
LONDON, May 13 -- Prime Minister Wilson today brusquely dismissed James Callaghan, the Home Secretary, from his inner Cabinet.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 13 -- Medical testimony opened a jury trial here today in which a South Bend man has filed suit against the G. D. Searle Company of Illinois, manufacturers of Enovid, contending that the well-known birth control pill caused his wife's death.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 13 -- A small group of liberal Democrats today helped to solidify the Republican control of the California Legislature.

Despite Britain's disappointing trade performance in April, the spot rate on the pound moved up in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. Traders felt that some commercial buying helped the currency.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The probability increased today that another ceiling would be imposed by Congress upon total Government spending.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Dr. S. I. Hayakawa told Senate investigators today that he believed wealthy white revolutionaries were deliberately recruiting Negroes as "cannon fodder" for campus insurrections.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 13 -- A 17-year-old Negro was convicted in Leon County Circuit Court here last night of the first-degree murder of a white youth in a fire bombing on April 4, 1968, the night the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was slain in Memphis, Tenn.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 13 -- The impending arrest of several students involved in the armed occupation of the student center at Cornell University on April 19 and 20 held the campus in tension today, as the Tompkins County grand jury completed its investigation and handed up 21 sealed indictments.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Stockholders in the Communications Satellite Corporation (Comsat) were told today that there was no immediate prospect of the first cash dividend from the seven-year-old corporation. In every other respect, Comsat's executives gave the annual meeting a glowing picture of the corporation's growth.

CADDIES should get a bigger lift from metropolitan golfers this year toward a college education. Officials in the area are planning more aid for the youthful bag-toter, whose ranks appear to be diminishing with the increased use of the electric cart.

James Meredith, the Negro civil rights activist, denied yesterday that he had "harassed" the white tenants of a Bronx apartment house he owns by shutting off hot water, heat and elevator service last winter.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- The Penn Central Company's "prime objectives" this year are to improve service and to put its railroad in the black "at the earliest possible date," stockholders were told here today at the annual meeting.

Twenty-two hundred high school students -- most of them Negro and Puerto Rican -- who would normally attend schools in northern Brooklyn and in Queens will be shifted next fall to predominantly white and integrated schools in South Brooklyn.

JERSEY CITY, May 13 -- With the leadership of one of the country's most powerful and enduring Democratic political machines at stake, Mayor Thomas J. Whelan was forced today into a runoff election for Mayor next month against former Mayor Thomas J. Gangemi.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A major reorganization of the draft, altering the methods of selection, was proposed today by President Nixon.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- A tax-exempt foundation supported by 10 major religious organizations has contributed substantial sums to "militant and disruptive" groups over the nation, Sgt. Robert Thoms of the Los Angeles police intelligence division said here today.
The question at the New York City Ballet yesterday was: Who will replace Suzanne Farrell as a principal dancer?
CHICAGO, May 13 -- The tender offer for the B. F. Goodrich Company was not on the agenda today at the annual meeting here of Northwest Industries, Inc., but it was on everyone's mind.

In the last few weeks, America has witnessed a series of spectacular controversies. The Fortas case, the Bucher case, the trial of Ray for the murder of Martin Luther King and many of the university conflicts have all raised different questions but have dramatized one of the deepest problems and anxieties of our time.

STOCKHOLM, May 13 -- Ingmar Bergman, the film and theater director, was fined the equivalent of $1,000 today for having hit Bengt Jahnsson, a theater critic, in February this year. Mr. Bergman said it was worth the money and that he did not intend to appeal.

The alliance formed yesterday by State Senator John J. Marchi and Assemblyman Vito P. Battista to run on a common ticket in next month's primary is a serious setback for Mayor Lindsay. It means that all the forces of reaction and political disgruntlement within the Republican party have now made common cause against his brand of progressive government.
The Philadelphia Phillies' losing streak reached five games last night -- six, if you count Richie Allen being punched in the face in the afternoon.
Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, looking fit, sailed for Europe yesterday aboard the liner United States.
LISBON, May 13 --- Portuguese Socialists proposed today the formation of "a broad democratic front" to challenge the regime in this year's National Assembly elections, scheduled for the fall.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- The merger of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific and the Chicago and Northwestern Railroads could become effective as early as July 1, 1970, Curtiss E. Crippen, Milwaukee road president, told the annual meeting today.

HURLINGHAM, England, May 13 (AP) -- Four United States women went into the third round of the London hard-court tennis championships today. The tournament is a tune-up for next month's Wimbledon championships.

George Meany and Walter P. Reuther have parted company in organized labor, but they are standing together in support of striking Negro hospital workers in Charleston, S. C. A similar unity has been established by all the country's major civil rights groups, which rarely agree on tactics these days. They have put aside their differences to help a wretchedly underpaid work force win union recognition and a measure of human dignity.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 13 -- As if the $2 bettor didn't have enough variables to consider, he was given an added worry at Roosevelt Raceway tonight -- hoping his horse wouldn't fall down.

NEW DELHI, May 13 -- V. K. Krishna Menon and S. K. Patil, two former ministers who once represented the extreme left and right of the governing Congress party, were returned to Parliament today in by-elections by landslide margins.
A Manhattan assistant district attorney said yesterday that a "confession" had been obtained from one of the 21 Black Panthers accused of plotting to wage a terror campaign against the city.

JERUSALEM, May 13 -- Menahem Begin, a minister without portfolio, said today that Israel recently rejected a United States proposal that she agree to a contractual peace accord that would mutually obligate the parties involved in the Middle East dispute.

SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, May 14 -- The South Korean Central Intelligence Agency announced today that it had arrested 16 members of a Japan-based North Korean spy ring, including a South Korean legislator from the Government party.

STONY BROOK, L. I., May 13 -- Bands of students burned security police cars, smashed windows and set fires on the campus of the State University here early this morning in a melee protesting a narcotics raid at the school.

BALTIMORE, May 13 (AP) -- Anne Katherine Jenkins, a 22-year-old blonde held captive for three days by a team of kidnappers, was freed today after her father paid a $10,000 ransom.

A week from today, if all goes well, American astronauts will be orbiting the moon and preparing to descend to within nine miles of its surface, the closest man has ever been to another celestial body.

President Nixon's message to Congress yesterday calling for draft reforms came at a time when the draft is in deep political trouble after nearly three decades of almost complete public acceptance.
ALBANY, May 13 -- A bill that would have imposed harsher penalties on criminals who use guns has been vetoed by Governor Rockefeller.
Borrowing costs on tax-exempt notes and bonds moved upward yesterday, causing New York State to cancel the sale today of $88-million of bonds.

MOSCOW, May 13 -- Dr. Gustav Husak, the Czechoslovak party leader, was reliably reported today to have resisted Soviet efforts last month to install a pro-Moscow official, Vasil Bilak, as head of the Slovak party.
The stock market moved briskly higher yesterday as investors awaited President Nixon's address tonight on the prospects for peace in Vietnam.

The year-old New York magazine, which has an operating loss of more than $2-million, has taken the first step to go public -- but not alone. It is one of two subsidiaries of the recently incorporated Delaware corporation named Aeneid Equities, which recently filed a preliminary prospectus with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BONN, May 13 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger's "economic cabinet" outlined five measures today to meet the threat of domestic inflation caused by his refusal to revalue upward the mark last Friday.

ROME, May 31 -- Saints of the Roman Catholic Church who lost their places or whose feast days were demoted from universal to optional in the new edition of the liturgical calendar are still to be venerated as they were before the calendar's updating, a Vatican liturgical expert said today.

HOUSTON, May 13 (UPI) -- John Madden spent three weeks with his eyelids stitched shut, waiting to learn whether an operation would restore his sight.
PARIS, May 13 -- Alain Poher, the Interim President, became the odds-on favorite today in the race for the succession to General de Gaulle in the elections to be held June 1.

A young Westchester husband who three years ago was found by a judge to have abandoned his wife and two sons was granted a divorce yesterday. It is believed to be the first ruling in the state permitting the so-called guilty spouse the legal right to end the marriage.

A total of 229 metropolitan golfers will take the first step toward qualifying for the United States Open when they compete in the local trials on Monday and Tuesday. ITHACA, N. Y., May 14 -- Eighteen black students at Cornell University have been charged by the Tompkins County grand jury with criminal. trespass in the armed occupation of the campus student center April 19 and 20.

WOODBURY, L. I., May 14 -- Three foreign players joined the leaders in the fourth round of the Eastern men's hard-court tennis championships at the Woodbury Country Club today.

PRAGUE, May 16 -- The Czechoslovak Communist party warned its members today against belittling the role of the Soviet Union as an intellectual guide and a source of material aid.
