Mayor Lindsay announced the opening of the city's sixth neighborhood city hall yesterday as well as receipt of an anonymous gift of $75,000 to help keep five public library branches open.

A Federal grand jury indicted Coggeshall Hicks, a brokerage house, and five of its present or former employes yesterday on charges that they used a Swiss bank to circumvent stock-market credit restrictions in the purchase of $20-million in securities.

The New York City Central Labor Council, which says it has 1.2 million members, yesterday endorsed former Mayor Robert F. Wagner for the Democratic mayoral nomination and pledged "to spend whatever money is necessary" to promote his election.

PALO ALTO, Calif., May 16 -- Policemen firing tear gas routed 400 antiwar demonstrators today from the street in front of an annex of the Stanford Research Institute, four blocks from the Stanford University campus.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 16 -- Seventeen-year-old Mary Ann Freed, accused of lying when she testified she acted alone in the 1967 murder of her uncle, will have to stand trial as an adult on perjury charges.

Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter in his letter published April 14 states that proportional representation (P.R.) as a voting system in New York City was abolished only "because enough people were misled into voting for Communist candidates to entitle them to two places out of 23. But no Communists could now be elected in any system."

It is highly regrettable that Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, a man of the highest integrity and an educator of outstanding ability, was forced by intolerable conditions to resign as President of C.C.N.Y. All New Yorkers who love their city and are proud of its good points, and especially those who are interested in educational progress, will be sad at Dr. Gallagher's leaving a post he has filled with exceptional distinction.

Indications from Moscow of uncertainty as to whether Venera 5 sent data from the surface of Venus before its radio transmissions ceased early yesterday call to mind a similar debate on the fate of its Soviet predecessor Venera 4.

THE contemporary Austrian painter Friedrich Hundertwasser, though well known in Europe and Japan, has in the past excited little interest in this country. Even those who cherish the earlier achievements of Viennese modernism -- especially the paintings of Klimt and Schiele -- have shown a remarkable lack of curiosity in the one artist who, at the age of 40, may legitimately be regarded as their successor.

PARIS, May 16 -- Henry Cabot Lodge said today that the North Vietnamese and Vietcong delegations at the peace talks here had given "every indication" they would consider President Nixon's eight-point program as part of the search for a Vietnam settlement.

The Collegiate Chorale, which sang at Carnegie Hall last night, had a new work -- Robert Starer's "On the Nature of Things" -- to introduce in a program that also included Prokofiev's colorful "Alexander Nevsky," Bach's Cantata No. 4 ("Christ lag in Todesbanden") and Mozart's "Regina Coeli."

WITH the opening of Le(igh) Drugstore this week in the Hotel Lexington, the American drugstore has come full circle. The new version includes a men's boutique featuring clothing and cosmetics, a women's boutique bursting with jewelry, scarves and a limited selection of avant-garde fashions, and a host of portable goods ranging from hair-dryers to television sets.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 16 -- A major step toward healing a 108-year-old split within American Presbyterianism was taken here today by the General Assembly of the 3.2-million member United Presbyterian Church.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The head of the Government's supersonic transport program, Maj. Gen. Jewell C. Maxwell, has taken a new assignment to command the Armament Development and Test Center at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida.

FORT WORTH, May 16 (UPI) -- Bert Yancey surged to a two-stroke lead at the halfway point of the $125,000 Colonial National invitation golf tournament today with a course-record tying 32, 33 -- 65 that left him at four-under par 136.

The five Borough Presidents will meet with the City Council in executive session on Monday morning to work out the salaries and working conditions of the interim school board before Tuesday's deadline.

MOSCOW, May 16 -- The principal leaders of Rumania paid a surprise flying visit to the Soviet Union today amid indications that the two countries were in serious disagreement on the coming conference of the world Communist parties.

BALTIMORE, May 16 (AP) -Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, the president of the New York division of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association, was suspended indefinitely by Pimlico stewards today for violations in the claims of three horses.

A group of broadcasting excutives, performers, producers, community leaders and businessmen, including representatives of the Puerto Rican and Negro communities, has notified the Federal Communications Commission that it will try to supplant The Daily News as licensee of television station WPIX-TV on Channel 11.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 16 -- A 35-mile-an-hour wind blew in from the Atlantic today, but Dick Siderowf played golf as if it was calm. With a one-under-par 71, the 31-year-old Metropolitan amateur champion from Westport, Conn., gained a four-strokelead in the William D. Richardson Memorial tournament with a 36-hole aggregate of 145.

GENEVA, May 16 -- Mr. Roosevelt, who was a Democratic Representative from California for 10 years, served from 1965 to 1966 as United States representative at the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 16 -- United States officials said today that the political future of South Vietnam, including possible special elections, was entirely open to negotiation with the National Liberation Front, the Vietcong.

The Admiral directly responsible for the American Polaris submarine fleet has made an assessment of its future effectiveness that is sharply at odds with the gloomy prognosis given to Senators in March by Defense Secretary Laird. This fresh appraisal is bound to heighten suspicions that the Nixon Administration is employing what Senator Fulbright calls "a technique of fear" to win backing for the Safeguard antiballistic missile defense.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz disclosed today that he had ordered reductions in proposed Federal industrial health and safety standards designed to protect six to 8 million workers from noise hazards and lung damage caused by dust.

MOSCOW, May 16 -- The 13th game of the world chess championship match between the titleholder, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union and his Soviet challenger, Boris Spassky, was drawn here today after 25 moves. The score stands at 6-1/2 to 6-1/2 with 11 games to go in the 24-contest match/series.
CINCINNATI, May 16 -- The base hit was back in prominence tonight as the New York Mets outslugged the Cincinnati Reds, 10-9 in a wild, long and raindelayed game before 11,736 at Crosley Field.
WASHINGTON, May 16 --Two more economic indicators added evidence today that the boom in the economy may at last be slowing.

GENEVA, May 16 -- William R. Hewlett, president of the Hewlett-Packard Company of Palo Alto, Calif., officially opened today the concern's new European corporate headquarters in the Geneva suburb of Meyrin.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The financial report of Senator Allen J. Ellender, the only Senator who missed the filing deadline this week, has finally been located.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- At least five of the 24 Republican Senators who endorsed Mayor Lindsay for re-election yesterday were not aware that the Mayor was involved in a Republican primary fight for renomination.

NEW YORK CITY'S most successful human export traditionally has been its annual crop of college-bound basketball players, planted in the ghettos, nurtured in the playgrounds and community centers, harvested in the high schools and packaged for distribution throughout the country: rangy Irish forwards, scrappy Jewish guards and more recently black centers. This decade's prize was Lew Alcindor, shipped from Manhattan to Los Angeles, but the South and the midlands are filled with New Yorkers, too.

The student protest strategy of massive confrontations with the police that once produced bandaged heads and martyrs in almost equal proportions is being replaced by hit-and-run tactics on college campuses here.

THE ballet "Coppelia" is something of a rarity in the Royal Ballet's American repertory. The British company has danced the ballet here before, but not for quite a few years, and last night's performance was the first at the new Metropolitan Opera House.

Harry Mayer, an experienced concert pianist who teaches at the Greenwich House Music School, gave a recital at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. It began with the Bach-Liszt Fantasy and Fugue in G minor, three Scarlatti sonatas and Beethoven's "Appassionata" Sonata.

Dr. Kurt R. Schmeller, president of Queensborough Community College, said yesterday he had offered to arbitrate the summary dismissal of three professors for taking part in sit-ins at the college, but that they had not responded.

With 1,000 guests aboard, the old Hudson River sidewheeler, the Alexander Hamilton, will steam out of Pier 81 at West 41st Street at 8 P.M. on Wednesday. She will cruise around the city harbor and then up the Hudson carrying guests who are paying from $20 to $500 -- the top rate is for patrons -- to dine, dance and relax.

Archbishop Stepinac of White Plains won the Athletic Association of Private Schools team title yesterday as the two-day championships concluded with the field events at Randall's Island. The track events were held Thursday at Mount St. Michael.

The acting president and Faculty Council of Brooklyn College have urged the Board of Higher Education to offer a college education to every high school graduate in the city, particularly needy Negroes and Puerto Ricans.

The Yankees came back to New York from the West last night like Napoleon from Waterloo. They had lost 15 of their previous 18 games, then scrounged only one hit off Rudy May of the California Angels during the first eight innings of their return home.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 16 -- Play was almost level in the first session of the world championship contract bridge final here this afternoon. The Italian world champions met stout opposition from Nationalist China, who upset powerful American and French teams to reach the final.

LONDON, May 16 -- The Beatles' song company Northern Songs, Ltd., successfully resisted a take-over bid by the Associated Television Corporation, whose offer for all the shares expired today with only 47 per cent of the stock committed.
John (Blue Moon) Odom of Oakland became the first pitcher to win seven games this season when he pitched a seven-hitter and beat Cleveland, 3-0, last night.
WOODMERE, L.I., May 16 -- Houses of many architectural periods will be opened for the benefit of the Five Towns Community Chest Tuesday and Wednesday from noon to 5 P.M.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Saturday, May 17 -- Five policemen were injured and three civilians were arrested after a disturbance here today outside a public house on Crumlin Road.

The Otto Otepka case has taken on a new dimension that makes it even more essential for the Senate to reject his nomination to the Subversive Activities Control Board. Right-wing Senators evidently will not be content simply to "rehabilitate" Mr. Otepka by confirming him for a $36,000-a-year job on an inactive and worthless Federal agency.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A group of Democratic Senators led by George S. McGovern of South Dakota is organizing to press for an excess profits tax on Vietnam war contractors as a substitute for the income tax surcharge.
A panel of Negro students rejected yesterday recent criticism of the black student movement by Roy Wilkins and Bayard Rustin, the civil rights leaders.

The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that it had developed a new computerized freight remittance system, which, it said, could cut as much as 75 per cent of the paperwork out of handling railroad and truck freight shipments.

" Police tactics have to change as the tactics of the students change," explained Deputy Inspector Harold Schryver, commander of the special 350-man New York police unit that, in 1969 alone, responded to about 500 demonstrations, parades and political rallies.

The news these days from the KGB headquarters in Moscow's Dzerzinsky Square is not all good. A sense of unease is abroad, recruitment figures are falling off, a general attitude of "why bother?" extends beyond the legitimate needs of constructive self-criticism.
Two issues stood out among this week's first public offerings of common stock and provided examples of the volatility of the new-issue market.

MASON, Mich., May 16 -A prosecution witness in the Algiers Motel murder case testified today that a Negro youth at the motel fired a starter's pistol in fun. The defense believes the incident brought the police to the motel.

GENEVA, May 16 (UPI) -- James Roosevelt, the eldest son of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, was stabbed in the back by his wife late last night at their home in the Geneva suburb of Vesenaz, the police reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Air Force estimates that the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation will lose $285-million on the two major production runs of the giant C-5A jet transport, according to Air Force documents made public yesterday by Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin.
Approximately 700 Eastern Airlines passengers were scanned for large metallic objects on their persons yesterday as they boarded or arrived on planes at Kennedy International Airport.

CAPE MAY, N. J., May 16 -- Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., a leading contender for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, acknowledged today that he had once sold property with deeds containing prohibitions against purchase by Negroes, but he said that the covenants had been inserted without his knowledge.

There is always a serendipitous air about the Spring Dance Concert of the School of Performing Arts. As any halfway serious dance enthusiast will tell you at the drop of a program, the school has graduated hundreds of dancers into all of the major performing companies.

Small fires on the elevated tracks of the West Side IRT subway line yesterday sent dozens of panicked rush-hour passengers scrambling through the broken windows of an eightcar train and delayed thousands of homeward-bound people.

GRISE FIORD, Northwest Territories, May 16 -- To show Canada's Governor General, Roland Michener, an igloo, the Grise Fiord Eskimo Council directed Philapusie, an old hunter, to build one. Philapusie and his helpers set it up far out on the bay ice, sawing the blocks out of wind - packed snow.

A letter in The Times of May 10 by two visiting professors at Cornell who felt compelled to suspend their teaching for the rest of the semester, charges that conditions of free speech and personal safety no longer obtain at Cornell, and that while the situation on the campus is superficially calmer, "academic freedom remains in jeopardy."

THE similarity in training draftees for any army was the chief impression left last night by a television documentary entitled "Comrade Soldier," a study of a Soviet recruit from his induction through a few weeks of training for war. The program was seen on the network of the American Broadcasting Company.

KUALA LUMPUR, May 16 (Reuters) -- A terrorist plot to inflame further racial violence was smashed by Malaysian police and troops today, Prime Minister Abdul Rahman said in a television broadcast to the nation.
The size of salaries paid to officers of the Glen Alden Corporation was attacked yesterday by a number of shareholders at the annual meeting at the Cinerama Theatre here.

COLUMBIA, S. C., May 16 -A biracial group organized here two years ago to promote racial harmony adopted a petition today calling for a factfinding study by the state legislature into the Charleston hospital workers' strike that has been in effect since March 20.
An effort to settle a strike called Wednesday by school-bus drivers of the Varsity Bus Company was unavailing yesterday, and the walkout was expected to continue next week.
A Long Island controller for the Federal Aviation Administration who entered the recent Great Transatlantic Air Race as the "common man" returned home from London yesterday with a $2,400 prize.

Dr. Buell G. Gallagher said yesterday that the state should take over the City University, a move that would mean the end of 122 years of tuition-free higher education here. He called for the establishment of a State University in New York City, with its own governing board.

" The time has come for new initiatives," President Nixon said last week in his address on Vietnam. "Repeating the old formulas and tired old rhetoric is not enough. When Americans are risking their lives in war it is the responsibility of their leaders to take some risks for peace."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 16 -- A United Nations report said today that emergency food was reaching a million Nigerian victims of the civil war, but that early estimates that 4 million to 4.5 million would need help had not materialized so far.

Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein issued a preliminary injunction yesterday that forbids the state to cut welfare benefits on July 1 as mandated by the Legislature, pending a test on whether the cuts violate Federal law.

A champagne reception and buffet supper at Arthur, the discotheque, will follow the preview of "The Tree" Tuesday at the 72d Street Playhouse, where the motion picture will open to the public next month.

A controversial five-year-old program that treats narcotics addiction with methadone is still "in the research stage" and should not be expanded into public-health policy at this time, the State Council on Drug Addiction said in a report made public yesterday.
PARIS, May 16 -- Georges Pompidou opened the presidential campaign on television tonight with a warning that subversive forces were plotting to repeat the violent disorders of a year ago.
BALTIMORE, May 16 -- Heavyweights who respect each other's punching ability seldom try for an early knockout. They probe and spar, waiting for the right moment to apply the pressure.
Agreement was reached last night at City College to resume negotiations on the demands of dissident Negro and Puerto Rican students.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 16 -Three drivers ran laps of better than 170 miles an hour today in the last full day of practice preceding the qualifying trials for the 53d Indianapolis 500.

BONN, May 16 -- In a reprimand clearly aimed at Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger, Foreign Minister Willy Brandt warned today against "those who now believe they can win over the German people with conservative words and appeals to nationalistic instincts as well as slogans from yesterday and the day before yesterday."
Prices on the London stock market closed substantially higher yesterday in a brisk recovery from recent low levels.

The dean of the House of Representatives attacked yesterday the development of the one-bank holding company as a device that could "link together major financial and industrial interests in an alliance beyond the power of effective regulation."

BALTIMORE, May 16 -- Majestic Prince will be the strong favorite, probably odds-on by post-time, to pick up $129,500 for less than two minutes' work in the Preakness at Pimlico tomorrow. Frank McMahon's classically molded colt, who might have served as the model for a sculpture by Praxiteles, will risk his unbeaten record against seven rivals in the mile-and-three-sixteenths race for 3-year-olds.
MILWAUKEE, May 16 -- Twelve protesters against the Vietnam war lost today their plea for dismissal of charges against them in connection with the burning of draft records.

DETROIT, May 16 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers indefinitely suspended their slugging left fielder, Willie Horton, without pay today for failure to accompany the team to Bloomington, Minn., for a series with the Minnesota Twins.

PRINCETON, May 16 -- The student-faculty discipline committee at Princeton University today handed out sentences ranging from expulsion to disciplinary probation to five white students for their alleged parts in a racial clash last Saturday.

MANNING, S. C., May 16 -- Fifteen years after the Supreme Court held public school segregation to be unconstitutional, nationwide controversy rages over how -- and in some areas whether -- the decision should be carried out.
Stocks drifted down yesterday on the American Stock Exchange where trading remained moderately active.
There's little doubt where the speculators in commodity futures are these days. The volume figures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange tell the story.

ALLEN GINSBERG, hirsute, not always kempt, utterer of ecstatic obscenities, lover of men and drugs, is probably the most integrated writer in America. He has no hangups about his work, his audience, his success, his influence or his position among his peers. Unlike others who have tried, he's made it. (He's wealthy enough to have become a foundation.)

I want to thank Lincoln Gordon, President of Johns Hopkins University, for his letter of May 10. I couldn't have asked for a better example of what I was talking about in my Topics column of April 26.

DETROIT, May 16 -- The General Motors Corporation has a $25-million bus project that the company thinks might help solve the nation's rapid transit problems. Now all General Motors has to do is find some customers.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 16 -- Deputy Prime Minister Abdul Razak assumed the task today of suppressing Malaysia's three-day-old communal rioting with what appeared to be unlimited powers.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Federal Communications Commission ruled today that a Chicago television station was guilty of having induced a crime when it staged a marijuana party for the purposes of a documentary.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 16 -- After two months of preparations on the launching pad, the Apollo 10 spaceship was declared ready today for crews to begin the final countdown.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- Secret Government records list Medicare payments of $285,866 in a year and a half to one Miami osteopath.
TWINSBURG, Ohio, May 16 (AP) -- An employe at the Chrysler, Corporation's stamping plant fatally shot two fellow workers and wounded 10 others last night before killing himself.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 16 -- Hundreds of National Guardsmen, augmenting the police, sheriff's deputies and highway patrolmen, kept crowds of demonstrators moving today during an uneasy calm after the "battle of People's Park."

President Nixon has been following a procedure started by President Harry S. Truman, and continued since, under which names of potential appointees for Supreme Court and other Federal judgeships are screened by the American Bar Association.
ALBANY, May 16 -- The state's highest court ruled today that an order establishing five separate bargaining units for 124,000 state employes should be subject to an immediate judicial review.
Dr. Edward O'Rourke is leaving his $35,000-a-year post as city Health Commissioner to become dean of the School of Public Health at the University of Hawaii.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 16 (AP) -- Students trampled and burned an American flag today to protest the visit of Governor Rockefeller, who arrived amid tight security precautions.

COLUMBIA, S. C., May 16 -An officer's recommendation against a court-martial for three antiwar demonstrators at Fort Jackson is not being followed by a higher ranking convening authority, according to a lawyer for the defendants.
The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, Inc., reported yesterday that net earnings for its fiscal year ended February 22 were down 19.1 per cent and sales down 0.4 per cent.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 16 -- Military advisers of six of the eight member states of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization, or SEATO, are meeting here today and tomorrow to discuss their defense plans for the treaty area.
BONN, May 16 -- Siemens, A.G., a major West German electronics and communications concern, plans to buy a 60 per cent interest in the Interatom Reactor Development Company.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday the imposition of penalties on two general partners of Dishy, Easton Co., 40 Exchange Place, for violations of the exchange's constitution and rules.

Anthony (Tony the Shrimp) LaSorsa, the quarry in separate hunts by the police and underworld executioners, gave himself up to the police and was arraigned yesterday in Bronx Criminal Court as the alleged mastermind of a gang in the business of kidnapping Mafia bosses and other racketeers for ransom.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, May 16 -- Shakespeare's late romances are the backbone of the current season here, and Trevor Nunn's production of "The Winter's Tale" follows "Pericles" as part of a continuing pattern.

The Monsanto Company said yesterday it would raise prices of phenolic resins Monday. It will raise the price of liquids and varnishes three-quarters of one cent a solid pound, three-quarters of one cent per pound of flakes and 1 cent per pound of resin compounds.

While I agree with the tenor of James Reston's May 7 column, "The Pueblo: Who Is to Judge the Judges?", I take issue with his suggestion that Comdr. Lloyd Bucher may have been too weak to resist the resentment of his crew and thus violated Navy tradition in surrendering.
CHICAGO, May 16 (AP) -- Union teachers voted 2-to-1 today in favor of staging their first strike against Chicago's public schools May 22.

" SWISS Folk Art," the current exhibition at the Museum of American Folk glimpse of work that has strong parallels on the American scene. The connection between folk art produced by German-speaking communities, whether in Pennsylvania or in Switzerland, is evident.

ATHENS -- The Greek regime's strong man, Premier George Papadopoulos, allowed newsmen to see for themselves today that Alexandros Panaghoulis, the man who tried to kill him last summer, was still alive.

More than 200 armored car guards and drivers walked off their jobs at the United States Trucking Corporation, here yesterday to protest the suspension of two guards victimized in a $350,000 payroll theft at the Abraham Straus department store in Brooklyn last Monday.

Daryl Hine, a Canadian poet and a teacher of writing and comparative literature at the University of Chicago, has been named editor of Poetry Magazine. He will succeed Henry Rago in October. Mr. Rago has been editor since 1955.
A man allegedly intent on robbery attacked a guard with a razor in a Times Square area bank yesterday, but was arrested after a struggle with a city detective.

CARSON CITY, Nev., May 16 -- Charles O. Finley, colorful owner of the Oakland Athletics in the American Baseball League, has purchased 30,000 shares of a company that owns three Las Vegas gambling casinos, it was disclosed today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 16 (UPI) -- Members of Alabama's white and Negro teacher groups voted overwhelmingly today to accept a controversial merger plan rather than face expulsion from the National Education Association.

A luncheon and fashion show have been arranged for Thursday at the Association Residence, a home for women at 891 Amsterdam Avenue. The women, now living at the home are between the ages of 65 and 98.
The struggle between the Bangor Punta Corporation and Chris-Craft Industries, Inc., for control of the Piper Air craft Corporation intensified yesterday.
The board of directors of Union Theological Seminary voted yesterday to raise at least $1-million for projects in Harlem under the direction of blacks associated with the seminary.

NAHA, Okinawa -- A hundred miles northeast of Taiwan and 200 miles east of Communist China, three tiny rock islands and a volcanic atoll dot the East China Sea. Until a few years ago the islets, called Senkaku Retto, the largest of which covers an area of only 1.5 square miles, were known only for their sea-fowl sanctuaries and for the rich fishing grounds that surrounded them.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -With the Abe Fortas controversy fading quickly into the background, President Nixon came under pressure today to "think Republican" when selecting two new members of the Supreme Court.

MOSCOW, May 16 -- Venera 5 completed its four-month 217 million mile unmanned mission today with a 53-minute burst of information about Venus's atmosphere before hitting the surface and depositing a portrait of Lenin and the Soviet coat of arms.

THE idea of a jazz mass has been with us for some years, and there has been a certain amount of flirting with the medium. Last year Dave Brubeck, the well-known jazzman, got into the act with his long and ambitious "The Light in the Wilderness."

RUSS MEYER, a specialist in film sensationalism, has finally brought his latest to town, a slick, lascivious film titled "Russ Meyer's Vixen." It opened yesterday at the Globe, Regency and 72d Street Playhouse.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., May 16 -- From their 32-story-high capsule atop the Saturn 5 rocket, the Apollo 10 astronauts will have three fast escape routes if danger erupts before the launching on Sunday.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy ended his second poor people's campaign here today with a feeling of disappointment in the Nixon Administration's response.

JOSE VARGAS wasn't sure whether the clay he was shaping would turn out to be a cat, a rat or a mouse. But it didn't matter. It was quite beautiful and the 7-year-old boy loved it. And he was going to think up a nice name.

BERLIN, May 16 -- The East Germans said today that they had dismissed a high-ranking agricultural official from his post after he had sought to force a collective farm in Thuringia to start producing potatoes instead of milk.

A gunman who apparently shot from the roof of a public housing project fired one blast last night and wounded three men and a young boy standing in front of a grocery in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 16 -- The textile industry of Nationalist China threatened today to organize international retaliation if the United States imposed quotas on Taiwan's textiles exports.

A three-alarm fire in a building at 103 Second Avenue, between Sixth and Seventh Streets, on the Lower East Side, last night forced the evacuation of 2,700 young people from the Fillmore East next door.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that it had broken up a car theft ring that stole Volkswagens in New Jersey and sold them in New York through newspaper ads.
AVEIRO, Portugal, May 16 -- "This may be the only place in the world today," said one member of the audience, "where old people court students."

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- High Government officials are pessimistic over the continuing deadlock in negotiations between the United States and Peru over seized oil holdings.

The Hardwick Magee Company, carpet manufacturer and retailer, Philadelphia, has elected Archibald Campbell president. Formerly vice president and treasurer of the 132-year-old company, he succeeds Earl W. Glazier, who has been elected chairman.
Joe DiMaggio, Vince Lombardi, Gene Sarazen and Rocky Marciano will be honored at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night in ceremonies and entertainment arranged by Americans of Italian Descent, Inc.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., May 17 -- When Col. Thomas P. Stafford and his two Apollo 10 crew mates wriggle into their capsule tomorrow and scan their instrument panel, the altimeter will read about 420 feet.
PARIS -- "At last we have our Humphreys and our Nixons. We are more like the Americans every day," a Frenchman said, and he did not seem very happy with his thought.

THE Decorative Arts Museum in Lisbon receives orders from museums and private collectors all over the world for reproductions of period furniture made with the methods used in creating the originals. Quality is more important than time. A recent request was from the Palace of Versailles, near Paris, for 6,000 gilded leather book-backs to cover book-shaped wooden blocks and thus give a dwindling library the appearance of well-stocked shelves.

Dr. Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens, clinical professor of orthopedic surgery at New York University-Bellevue Medical Center and a former head coach at New York University and Yale, will be honored at the scholar-athlete dinner of the New York Chapter, National Football Foundation, in the Hotel Biltmore on Thursday.

PEKING -- The once-crowded airlanes and rail lines between here and Moscow carry little traffic these days as a result of the Soviet-Chinese ideological dispute.

The once-stately giant sequaia redwood that towered 234 feet in Yosemite National Park, and stood patiently while millions of tourists rode and drove through a nine-foot-high tunnel in its base, photographing and being photographed as they went, sighed heavily and crashed to the ground under the weight of the past winter's record snowfalls.

NEW HAVEN, May 17 -- Dick Benka set a meet record in the discus throw and captured the shot-put as well today, helping Harvard's track team defeat Yale, 84-70. The victory was the sixth in succession outdoors for the Crimson over the Elis.

MADISON, Wis., May 17 -The Teaching Assistants Association, which represents most of the graduate students teaching at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, was designated today, after two days of elections, as the exclusive bargaining agent for the students.

ATLANTA -- In less than four years, the list of Negroes holding public office in the South has swelled from 72 to more than 400, a proliferation that significantly alters the shape of Southern politics.

The City Commission on Human Rights condemned yesterday a Columbia College alumni magazine for references in an article to the Jewish background of many radical student leaders at Columbia.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Preston Martin, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, announced today that two largely technical steps had been taken toward increasing mortgage lending by savings and loan associations.

ARMY can win a share of the national lacrosse title, which would be a fine going-away present for Jim (Ace) Adams, the cadets' coach. All Army has to do is to beat Navy on May 31, in the annual battle royal, which the cadets haven't been able to do since 1963.
Following are highlights of the remainder of the Apollo 10 flight plan. The schedule is subject to change at any time during the mission. Times are Eastern Daylight.

NEWARK, Tuesday, May 20 -- A patrolman shot and killed a teen-aged boy in the predominantly Negro South Ward here yesterday afternoon and, within hours, large, disorderly crowds were looting stores in the area, the scene of major rioting in 1967.

Dresser Industries, Dallas, Texas-based producers of oil drilling equipment, compressors, refractories, pumps, valves and instruments, reported yesterday higher sales and earnings in the six months ended April 30 than those of 1968.
New York City is fairly well-stocked with training groups for opera singers. Thus a training group for orchestral players specializing in the operatic literature is something of a novelty.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Air Force is being forced to tear down and reassemble 379 F-4 fighter-bombers used in Vietnam because heat and humidity melted a compound in the electrical plugs.
The Union Pacific Railroad announced yesterday the election of Reginald M. Sutton as executive vice president and William S. Cook as vice president-finance.

Goodbody Co., a leading New York Stock Exchange member firm, announced yesterday a realignment of top management, and for the first time in its 78-year history, someone not named Goodbody will become chief executive.
Bond prices declined yesterday, raising interest rates to still higher levels, amid a growing belief that major progress toward peace in Vietnam is not to be expected quickly.
The stock market ran into a squall of profit taking yesterday as the Dow-Jones industrial average fell 8.28 points to 959.02.

The third annual Daisy Ball, the Nassau Council of Girl Scouts' gala fund raising event, will take place on Saturday at the Terrace in the Park in Flushing Meadow, Queens (formerly the Top of the Fair), which overlooks the Unisphere.

HONG KONG, May 19 -- Reports of cures of deaf mutes in Communist China are causing parents of the deaf in Hong Kong to send their children back to the Chinese mainland. According to some sources, more than 10 per cent of the deaf children in Hong Kong have gone back to China this year in search of a cure.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 19 (Reuters) -- Maj. Gen. Salah Jadid, assistant secretary general of Syria's ruling Arab Baath Socialist party, has been placed under house arrest, it was reported today.

Joe DiMaggio, Vince Lombardi, Gene Sarazen and Rocky Marciano, sports stars of Italian descent, were honored last night at the Americans of Italian Descent salute at Madison Square Garden. Vince Promuto, a guard for the Washington Redskins, accepted the award for Lombardi.

THERE must be a machine somewhere underground, a cross between a computer and a garbage disposal, to which publishers feed headlines, surveys, clippings, stereotypes, sentimentalities, racial and/or sexual and/or death fantasies for processing and packaging. The prose product is then sold to "consumers," not readers: a form of freeze-dried fiction, rather like those slabs of rectangulated cutlet that substitute these days for food.
HOUSTON, May 19 -- Following is a partial transcript of radio conversations today between ground controllers here at the Manned Spacecraft Center and the crewmen of Apollo 10.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Treasury bill rates in today's $3-billion sale were higher than last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

The Boy Scouts of America were saluted informally at a ball at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening by a thousand men and women. Proceeds were assigned to the Greater New York Councils of the organization.
HONG KONG, May 19 -- Communist China delivered a strong attack on President Nixon yesterday through the medium of Jenmin Jih Pao, the official party publication.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 19 (UPI) -- Indiana's Attorney General charged today that members of the staff of Mayor Richard G. Hatcher of Gary had helped to "organize and direct" demonstrators who broke dishes and threw food at the Gary National Guard Armory.
